Introduction

Working together the GM and the Players undertake
what amounts to cooperative storytelling. The GM lays
out the scenes, and the PCs determine how they react and
interact with the world.

A few years ago, a company called Open Ended Games
released a game called Against the Darkmaster. This was a
re-imagining of a game that I had loved many years ago. If
you ever get a chance to pick it up, I strongly advise doing so
as it is a fantastic game.
Recently, the creators of Against the Darkmaster (vsD)
have released it under a relatively open license that allows for
the creation of material for the game and even such projects
as the one you are currently reading. This license had another
company, called Imaginary Turtles, create a product for vsD
called the Grievous Grimoire. This is also an excellent product.
I strongly recommend both the game and add-on product. You
can find links to both companies in the credits.
Both of those products serve as the primary inspirations
for this product. It is primarily based on vsD with a number
of elements that come from Grievous Grimoire. And I
sincerely want to thank the folks from both companies for
the excellent products that they have produced!
This is the Fantasy Express, referred to as FX throughout
the rest of this product. This game will not use percentile dice
as vsD does, but instead we will use two ten-sided dice (2d10),
which can produce similar results, but on a smaller scale.
Also, FX will not use the same setting as is found in vsD, but
instead use the Anwyn setting, which is the house setting for our
other role-playing game, Novus 2e. However, even though I am
including the Kindreds from Anwyn and a pocket outline of the
setting, other aspects will remain as generic as I can make them,
so that this product is as widely useable as possible.
And finally, I want to thank everybody who has helped
shape this game, and helped inspire me to write it.

The Role of the Player
As a player, you get to play one of the protagonists of the
story. You get to be one of the brave heroes that help shape
the destiny of the world around them with their deeds and
actions. You decide and control your character’s actions
and are the only person at the table who can tell what your
character feels and/or thinks. However, you have a few
duties as well.
•• Create a character who has reason to be part of the group
and the desire to be there and willing to take action;
•• Pay attention to what is happening in the game, even
if your character is not directly involved;
•• Be familiar with the rules in general, and those
required to handle your character more specifically;
•• If playing in person, make sure to bring snacks or
drinks for the game;
•• Keep in mind that the game is for everybody and
should never be thought of as the PCs versus the GM;
•• Have fun while playing and help make sure that everyone
playing is also having fun and enjoying themselves.

The Role of the GM
The Game Master (GM) is the one who describes the
world to the PCs. You play all of the characters that the
characters interact with as well as any villains and characters.
You also prepare the adventure scenarios and act as the
judge or arbiter in case of rules disputes. Your duties are a
little different from those of the players:
•• Describe a vibrant, living world to your players;
•• Challenge the heroes and spotlight each hero during
the course of the game;
•• Be familiar with the rules of the game and apply
them impartially;
•• Make sure that the PCs are free to forge their own
paths, without arbitrary constrictions;
•• Keep in mind that the game is for everybody, and
should never be considered as the GM versus the PCs;
•• Have fun and make sure that everybody playing is
comfortable and enjoying themselves.

Requirements for Play
All you need to play this game is a copy of these rules,
some pencils and paper, which could even include some
printed out character sheets. You will also need two tensided dice, each of which is often referred to as a d10 and
one or more friends.
One person has to act as the Game Master (GM for short)
and he controls the world and all of the people and creatures
in it. He also is the arbiter of the rules as you play. Everybody
else will control the actions of a single person, referred to as
their Player Character (PC for short). The PCs travel through
the world controlled by the GM and have adventures.

5

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

System Overview

Basic Resolution

Open-Ended Rolls – This is the most common type of roll
you will see. You should presume, unless otherwise
stated, that any roll you will make is open-ended, as
there is always a chance, however slim, of success.
Open-ended rolls occur only on the high side of the
dice roll and are sometimes referred to as Exploding
Dice or an Exploding Roll.
Explosions – On the high side, if your initial roll is a 19
or 20, you roll a second time and add it to the first.
And if that second roll is also a 19 or 20, you roll a
third time and add the result to the first two rolls. This
continues for as long as you continue to roll a 19 or 20
on the subsequent dice rolls.
Critical Failure/Fumble Rolls – When you roll an
unmodified 2 on a dice roll (rolling a 1 on both
dice), this is a Critical Failure. This is when you roll
so badly that something unexpected happens to your
character as a result. This almost always results in a
Fumble, and sometimes requires making a roll on
a Fumble table. You can always fail a roll without
fumbling, but a Critical Failure is always going to be a
Fumble of some sort.

The FX system is what we would call an open-ended rollover system. This means that you will be using a two tensided dice for most if not all of your rolls. It also means that if
you roll high enough on the dice, they explode, allowing you
to roll the dice again and add it to the first roll. Secondary
dice rolls can explode also
Roll-over means that the goal is to roll the dice, and add in
any modifiers, and try to meet or beat a given number. The
following section on Dice Rolls explains more about them.
As you develop your character, you will gain ranks in
various skills. You are always welcome to attempt almost
any skill available.

Dice Rolls

The main type of dice needed for FX is a 2d10, two tensided dice. We do use it in several different ways as we are
about to explain.
Unmodified Rolls – There will be times when you receive
certain results only when a specific number is rolled
on the 2d10. If this occurs, you deal with that result
before adding or adjusting the roll with any modifiers
that might apply to the roll.

6

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

The Darkmaster

Types of Rolls
There are 4 basic types of rolls that you will make while
playing FX. There may be other, uncommon types of rolls that
you may need to make, but if needed, the GM will explain
how they work. The five basic types of rolls are as follows:
Skill Rolls – Whenever you want to perform an action,
you will make a Skill Roll. This is a roll in which you add
any skill bonuses you might have to determine whether
or not you succeed at the action.
Save Rolls – There are three primary types of Save rolls
in FX, and they are used for your character to resist the
effects of spells, poisons, diseases, and other possible
things that might happen to your character.
Casting Rolls – These are used for when your character
attempts to channel mystical energies and weave them into
a spell. We will go into these more in the Magic chapter, as
always, the better you roll the better your result.
Attack Rolls – We will go into these in the Combat chapter,
but in short they are the roll you make when attempting
to attack another person or creature. Every attack roll
will include you subtracting the Defensive Modifier of
the target being attacked. This can result in anything
from a fumble to doing what is called a Critical result.

Being heavily based on Against the Darkmaster, we
would be very remiss if we did not include the Darkmaster
in our re-imagination of the game. You learn more about
creating your own Darkmaster in the relevant chapter.

Glossary

The following is a short list of terms and words that may
be confusing to those who are new to Fantasy Express.
Abort Action – This is one of the types of Actions that may
be declared during a combat round. Normally Abort
Actions are only declared if you cancel a previously
declared action or you are Stunned for the round.
Actions – During every round, a player must declare the
actions that his character will perform. To simplify
things, many of the most common things that a
character might want to do have been classified as
Actions. There are several types of actions that can be
declared: Free, Half, Full, and Abort Actions. Each has
its own entry in this list.
Arcanist – This is a generic term to describe characters
whose focus is on the study magical skills and on
casting spells.
Armor Rating (AR) – Armor has several Armor Ratings,
one for each basic type of damage. The rating for the
given type of damage is subtracted from the total Hit
Point damage dealt by the attack. If there is an Armor
Rating for SL, that number is subtracted from the
amount of Success Levels that the attack earns.
Adept – This is a type of character that is skill based. While
he may have some combat skills, they are not his focus.
Attack Bonus (AB) – This is the character’s total skill bonus
for the weapon that he is using, along with any special
modifiers for that weapon based upon the situation or
the Combat Move being used.
Attack Roll – This is the total of a 2d10 open-ended roll
along with the attacking character’s Attack Bonus.
Boons – Boons are extra twists or effects that can occur. They
are purchased using Success Levels, and are chosen at the
time that they are earned. There are three types of Boons:
Combat, which includes Critical Results, Skill and Spell.
Codex – This is a list of 30 spells within a given School of Magic
that an Arcanist has access to.
Combat Skill – There are 5 different Combat Skills: Blades,
Blunt, Brawl, Polearms, and Ranged. All weapons fall
under one or more of these skills. They represent your
character’s skill in combat.
Culture – This is a description of the society that your
character grew up in. It provides him with some
basic skills. While two Cultures may be similar on the
surface, the details could vary widely.

Passions & Drives

The game also includes what we call Drives and Passions.
Passions are relatively simple; they are short sentences that
describe your character’s Nature, Allegiance and Motivation.
Drive allows the player to help push the story in certain
directions in certain ways. In other games, Drive might
be called luck or fate points. You can earn up to a limited
amount and earn them for many different reasons. Then you
can spend them to help yourself in specific ways, using for
rerolling or altering rolls for yourself or a foe.

The Heroic Path

Every time you spend a Drive point, you get to add the
same number of points to your Heroic Path. For every 10
points you have on your Heroic Path, you earn a Milestone.
You can then use the Milestones to acquire a bonus to better
your character in some small way.

Alternative Dice Notations
In some cases, we may ask for rolls of other dice
types. Use this as a reference.
1d5: roll 1d10 and divide the result by 2, rounding up.
1d4: roll 1d5 and subtract 1 from the result. Any result
of 0 should be treated as a result of 1.
1d3: roll 1d10 and divide the result by 3, rounding up.
Treat any result of “0” or “10” as a 3.
1d2: roll 1d10 and divide the result by 5, rounding up.

7

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Damage Rating (DR) – This is a measure of how much
damage a weapon does. There are several types of
damage that can be done. For example, an Arming
Sword does 10s/8p which means that it does 10 points
of slashing damage or 8 points of pierce damage,
depending on how the character using the sword
decides to attack. Note that circumstances could
dictate the type of attack to be used. Options are good.
Defensive Modifier (DM) – This is a number that is
subtracted from all attacks made against a character.
It is based on their Dexterity and a number of other
factors that apply, such as what armor is worn.
Experience Points (XP) – As characters adventure, they will
gain experience, and this is measured by a number of
points. The total number of points are what determines
what Level the character is.
Fighter – This is a generic term to describe characters whose
focus is on combat skills.
Folio – This is the subset of spells within a School of Magic’s
Codex that a Hybrid character has access to.
Free Action – This is an Action that takes little to almost no
time to complete.
Full Action – This is an Action that takes the majority of the
round to complete.
Game Master (GM) – This is the person who controls the
actions and events of the entire campaign setting. He
is not the enemy of the players.
Gifts – These are special abilities or skills purchased using
Background Option points gained from Kin descriptions.
Half Action – This is an action that takes about half of a
round to complete.
Hit Points (HP) – Also called Hits. This is a measure of how
much damage your character is able to take before
they go unconscious and/or die.
Hybrid – This is a generic term used to describe characters
who mix magical abilities with either skill (Adepts) or
combat (Fighters) abilities.
Kin – This term is used to refer to a group of people who
share similar traits. Sometimes referred to as Kindred.
Level – This is an overall measure of how powerful your
character is. Your level determines the maximum
number of ranks you can have in a given skill, and how
strongly you can resist outside effects to your character.
Mage – This is a generic term used to describe a Arcanist or
Hybrid combination of two Vocational Kits who has
access to only a single School of Magic (i.e. a Druid/
Druid or an Envoy/Champion or a Ranger/Ranger).
Magic Stat – The stat that is specifically associated with a
given School of Magic. It varies based on the School
and it is also the stat used in figuring Mana Points. If a
character has access to more than one School of Magic,
the player must choose one Magic Stat as primary, and
that stat is used in determining Mana Points.

Magus – This is a generic term used to describe a Arcanist
or Hybrid combination of two Vocational Kits who has
access to two Schools of Magic (i.e. a Druid/Sorcerer
or a Magician/Bard or a Ranger/Monk).
Mana Points – This is sometimes referred to as just Mana.
This is a measure of how much magic a character
may manipulate in a given day. The amount of Mana
used in a spell is referred to as the spell’s Tier. Mana is
regained through sleeping.
Martial Move – This is a type of action that can be
performed in combat that can provide results other
than damage to a foe.
Non-Player Character (NPC) – This is a character or
monster that is controlled by the GM.
Player Character (PC) – This is a character that is controlled
by a player. The GM is not your enemy.
Round – This is a unit that measures a specific length of time
during combat. A round is 5 seconds long, so there are
12 rounds in a minute. Characters may perform one
or more of actions in a given round. These actions are
considered to be happening almost simultaneously
over the length of the round.
Save Roll (Save) – This is a roll to resist or avoid being
affected by something (spell, poison, etc.) that is not
covered by any other type of roll. There are three basic
types of Saving Rolls; Toughness, Reflexes and Will.
School of Magic – This is a broad classification that represents
the training that an Arcanist receives. It includes how
they access Mana, and how they shape it into spells, and
the types of spells that they can cast.
Skills – These are how your character accomplishes tasks.
Each represents a close collection related knowledge
and abilities that can be improved over time. The more
ranks you have in a skill the better you are at it.
Stats – These are seven numbers used to describe your
character’s mental and physical attributes. They are
used in various ways to describe your character’s
abilities and potentials.
Stunned – This is a condition that can be acquired through
combat. While Stunned, you may not make attacks,
and are limited to what you can accomplish.
Success Levels – When attempting to accomplish tasks, you
will roll on the Action Table. There are several levels of
success on this table, and those levels can be used to
purchase Boons.
Tier – This is how much Mana is required to cast a spell.
Vocation – This si sometimes referred to as a profession or
class. It is the combination of two Vocational Kits and
basically defines your character’s focus and training.
Vocational Kit – Every character has two separate Vocational
Kits that comprise their Vocation. The combination is
what determines their Development Points and some
of their starting skills.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Introduction to Anwyn

What is Anwyn?

Then there are the stout Dvargr, whom some call Dwarves,
and the Odavi who have also been called Orcs by those who
are less than kind.
There are also the Gnomish race called the Ethori. And
finally, there are the Aeshi, a small race sometimes called
Dwelfs, or Shadow Elves because they look like a combination
of Dwarf and Elf, though they are not technically related to
either Kin.
These Kindred have settled areas of Tir Tuath, Tir Hoige,
and Tir Caledi, and still they only occupy a small portion of
Anwyn overall. The cities of Hyb Ciuin and Mirrhyc serve as
gateways to the mostly unexplored regions of Anwyn.
It is the year 530 CE (Common Era), and adventure waits
just around the corner. And so it begins…

Anwyn is the default setting for Fantasy Express. It is
a setting that is designed specifically for exploration and
adventure. The setting is designed to allow the PCs to
explore the world around them. While the inhabitants have
only been on Anwyn slightly over a century, the land itself
is old and has been populated many times before, only
for those inhabitants to disappear, leaving lots of ruins to
explore and there are a few unusual dangers as well.

Pocket History
Anwyn is small continent that was sundered from its
home world some untold amount of time in the past when it
was struck by a meteor made of magical materials.
It drifted from world to world for eons and was actually
settled over and over by peoples from a many different
worlds. It is unknown what happened to them other than
that they left ruins scattered across the land.
Then Anwyn became Anchored to its own little pocket
dimension. Legends say that this was done by a magically
advanced people called the Anki, who also disappeared just
as this happened. However, Anwyn still maintains many
connections to other worlds in one fashion or another.
A few centuries ago, nine different Kindreds of people
arrived on Anwyn at approximately the same time.
There are two main groups of Humans, the D’Anui and
the Zhuan. This includes several different barbarian tribes
among the D’Anui. In addition, there are the Risi, a very
large type of Human, sometimes called the Asgerdi.
There were originally two main groups of Elves, the Sylvari
or High Elves as they are sometimes called, and the Wood Elves
known as the Verdyri. About 200 years ago, a group comprised
of dissidents from both groups of Elves attempted and failed to
perform a ritual to get themselves home. This altered them into
the Yddari, or Grey Elves as some have called them.

Anwyn Geography

There are 7 major geographical regions in Anwyn and
they are as follows:

Tir Tuath
This is the largest of the inhabited regions. It holds the
kingdoms of Cymbri (populated by the D’Anui – a quasiCeltic-like culture) along the west coast of the region. The
capital city of Hyb Rasil lies at the mouth of the longest
river in Tir Tuath, Rymus Afon, on the shores of the Bay of
Sorrows. Several barbarian tribes of D’Anui migrated to the
northern steppes of Tir Tuath.
The other human nation, Utara, is populated by the Zhuan,
a quasi-oriental culture They control the peninsula along the
southeastern shores of the Bay of Sorrows.
Along the eastern coast of Tir Tuath lies Ælftyr (populated
by the Verdyri (Wood Elves) with a smattering of Sylvari
(High Elves) – the Verdyri have a more Sylvan culture
while the Sylvari have a more urban culture), and along the
southern coast of Tir Tuath lies Chorak (populated by the
Dvargr – these dwarves have a subterranean culture).
9

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

other types of henges. In fact there are so many that the
Esker Highlands are sometimes called the Henge Plains.
There are even rumors that some of the menhir (large
standing stones) dotting the landscape may be alive.
What makes the Esker Highlands so intriguing is that
many, if not all, of the stone circles and other henge structures
are portals to other worlds. These portals open both ways and
open randomly. The same portal opening twice in a row may
not connect to the same world, or even to the same time period
on those worlds. There are many unusual creatures brought
to Anwyn by these portals, from giant reptilian beasts that
some strangers from yet another portal named as dinosaurs to
animated constructs made of metal and other unusual materials.

Additionally, the Ethori (Gnomes) have several
underground city-states scattered across the rugged hills
found in the southern regions of Tir Tuath and the Aeshi
(Dwelfs) have an arboreal semi-tribal culture within the
Dark Woods, Duin Weald, along the southern coast.

Tir Caledi
This region has three main areas; Xondaz, Canga Vytr,
and the Mirr Valley.
Xondaz lies to the north. It is a land of rolling foothills and
small plains and forests, perfect for the semi-nomadic Odavi
(Orcs). They are a relatively peaceful people, though they are
wary of and dislike having outsiders within their lands.
Most of the eastern coast is taken up by the Canga
Vytr, a deep and dark forest more commonly called the
Wraithwood. It is the home of another large contingent
of Aeshi. The Dwelfs of the Wraithwood tend to dislike
outsiders in their lands, just as the Odavi do.
Both of these Kins worked with the Risi (the Asgerdi of the
southern Mirr Valley) to create the trade town of Mirrhyc,
straddling the Mirr River, which divides the Mirr Valley in two.
The Mirr Valley runs north to south. It lies between
the mountains that border its western and northern ends
and the Canga Vytr to the east. Nythm, the Risi collective,
encompasses all of the Mirr Valley south of the Mirr River.
North of the river, the valley is unclaimed territory, except
for a few outposts between Mirrhyc and the entrances to
Xondaz. This is because of the proclivity of unusual creatures
and monsters that filter down from the Esker Highlands
through what has come to be called the Monster Pass.

Ilthach
Also known as the Haunted Steppes, this land is
perpetually overcast, leaving it in endless twilight, which is
good for many of the things that make this place home, but
bad for those seeking to explore this region.
The Steppes and mesas and tabletop hills that dot this
region have an unnatural connection to the lands of the
dead. Places of the dead, especially those containing undead,
often fade into existence for a few weeks before fading away
again. Sometimes, the undead that inhabit these places will
leave them and wander aimlessly.
In the southern portion of the region, there is river in a deep
chasm that empties into the Brackenmire, a massive swampland.
This river is called the Demon’s Run because somewhere near
its headwaters is portal that cycles back and forth between the
home planes of Devils and Demons, and it will sometimes spit
some out into the river, which is comprised of fast moving
rapids for almost its entire length until it hits the swamps. So the
Brackenmire is not only dangerous because of the creatures that
survive in the swamps, but also because of the warring between
the Demons and Devils that have ended up there as well.

Tir Hoige
A few decades after arriving on Anwyn, most of the
Sylvari (High Elves) decide to sail to the west, to settle in Tir
Hoige, also known as the Land of Youth and created their
own nation of Ymwydd. Many Wood Elves (Verdyri) also
sailed west with them.
Not long after settling Ymwydd, a group of elves, both
Sylvari and Verdyri, broke with their brethren and moved
to the northern regions of Tir Hoige and formed their own
nation of Challydd. The elves of Challydd later attempted
a ritual to return them to their home worlds. This failed
spectacularly, and warped the elves and the nearby forest,
giving them all a grey hue. This group of elves have since
taken to calling themselves the Yddari (the Grey Elves).
The mountains on the eastern border of Tir Hoige seem
to have random and sporadic portals to the realms of the
fey, allowing faeries and other fey of various types to filter
through and on down into Tir Hoige.

Tir Pherygl
These low coastal lands would likely be idyllic if it were
not for the creatures that filter down to them from the
highlands, especially the many types of giant lizard-like
creatures that some scholars have named dinosaurs. And
that does not even count the undead that filter north from
Ilthach or the mutated creatures coming through the
mountains from Tuist Rhion.

Tuist Rhion
Also called the Star Crater because this is where the meteor
hit when Anwyn was sundered from its home world. The huge
valley created is littered with many different types of magical
crystals, as well creatures and plants that are highly magical
in nature. The main area of this region also tends to be a zone
of wild magic, where any spells cast can go very wrong very
easily, not to mention how the wild ambient magic tends to
warp creatures, giving them unusual abilities.

Esker Archia
Esker Archia is more commonly called the Esker
Highlands since its average elevation is several hundred feet
higher than the rest of Anwyn. It is covered in multiple ruins
of various ages and materials as well as many megalithic
structures, such as stone circles, dolmens, seemingly natural
stone archways and tri-liths (3 stone pillars bending in and
meeting in the center to form a triple archway), and many
10

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Character Creation Overview

Now that we have covered the basics of the default setting
that we are creating characters for, it is time to make our actual
characters that we are going to play. This chapter will walk
you through the steps needed to make yourself a character.

5. Choose Vocation
You determine your character’s overall Vocation (p.
27) by selecting two Vocational Kits (either the same
or different Kits). Each Kit provides the following:
•• 12 Development Points spread among the nine
skill categories
•• 15 free skill ranks spead across a variety of skills
•• 1 Special Skill (player’s choice from three)
•• Player’s choice of 2 items of equipment from a
small list, to be added to Starting Equipment all
characters receive
You record all of this on your character sheet. Then
spend your Development Points (DPs) on the skills you
want to improve by purchasing ranks in them (p. 46).
When spending Development Points during character
generation, each DP placed in a skill will purchase 1
rank in that skill in the Skill Categories that receive DPs.
This may change at later levels.

Character Creation Checklist
To make it easier to create a character, we provide the
following checklist to allow you to more quickly create your
character and to make sure you do not miss anything.
1. Create Character Concept
You always want to start off by getting a general idea of
what you want your character to be like. It could be just
something you are a fan of, or perhaps the adventuring
party your character will be joining has need of a certain
type so there is a niche to fill. In any case, you want to
make sure that you character is one who will want to be
traveling and adventuring with others.
2. Generate your Stats
The first thing to do in this step is to generate values
for your character’s Stats. You have three options (p.
13) for doing this.
•• Generate values for each Stat using the Random
Stat Roll table and then assign them to your Stats in
whatever order you like.
•• Distribute 14 points between your Stats (minimum
of 0, maximum of 5).
•• Roll 1d10, and assign the numbers of the array given
to your Stats as desired.
3. Choose Your Kin
Choose your character’s Kin (p. 14), and record
the information on your character sheet. Kins give Stat
adjustments, so be sure to adjust your stats accordingly.
If you want to play a Kin like a Half-Elf or Half-Orc, or
a Dwarf with both Dwelf and Gnome ancestry, you would
use Background, Mixed Ancestry (p. 68) to do this.
4. Choose Culture
Choose the Culture (p. 22) that your character
comes from and record the skill ranks gained on your
character sheet. Cultures also adjust the starting money
your character receives.

6. Background
•• Determine your character’s background by spending
your Background Option points to purchase one or
more Background Options (p. 61).
•• You can also give your character one or more
Drawbacks, which can give you up to three extra
Background Option points to spend.
7. Wealth & Equipment
•• Determine how much starting money your character
has and purchase any additional equipment you
want for your character not acquired in earlier steps.
8. Finishing Touches
This is where you finish up anything left undone.
•• Choose and record your character’s Passions (p. 77).
•• Calculate your character’s Move Rate, Defense, Saving
Roll bonuses, etc. (p. 108).
•• Total all Skill, Special Skill, and Combat bonuses (if
applicable)
•• Choose a name for your character
You are now ready to begin adventuring!

11

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Stats

This chapter covers what your base stats are and how to
generate them. FX uses a set of seven basic Stats to start
defining your character.
Each Stat can have a Stat Total that is either positive or
negative. The higher the value the better your character is
in that Stat or that facet of his being. Stat Totals are added
to your skill ranks when making skill rolls and they are also
added to your base Saving Roll values when attempting to
resist the effects of various things.

Wits are also used to modify the amount of Mana that
some characters receive each level. See p. 109 for more
information on Mana Points.
Insight (In)
This is a measure of a character’s empathy and intuition,
as well as their awareness and attention to detail. Characters
with a good Insight are often more perceptive and better
able to resist the effects.
Insight is also used to modify the amount of Mana that
some characters receive each level. See p. 109 for more
information on Mana Points.
Charisma (Ch)
This is a measure of the character’s presence, social
influence, and his strength of personality. Characters with a
good Charisma are better at interacting with and influencing
the actions of others.
Charisma is also used to modify the amount of Mana
that some characters receive each level. See p. 109 for more
information on Mana Points.
Resolve (Re)
This is a measure of the individual’s focus, mental
strength, and determination. Resolve determines how well
a character is able to resist temptation, bribery, seduction,
torture, coercion, interrogation or spells of Influence.
Resolve is also used to modify the amount of Mana that
some characters receive each level. See p. 109 for more
information on Mana Points.

Stat Descriptions
Brawn (Br)
This is a measure of the character might and physical
power. Characters with a good Brawn is often better at
melee combat and tend to be better in physical activities like
climbing, running, or lifting heavy weights.
Dexterity (Dx)
This is a measure of the character’s agility and swiftness,
coordination, balance, and reaction speed. Those with a
high Dexterity can more often evade attacks and do better
with ranged attacks and lighter weapons. They will also have
an advantage at moving silently and jumping over obstacles.
Stamina (St)
This is a measure of the character’s vigor, his constitution
and his ability to resist tiring and draining effect such as fatigue
and pain. This also makes him harder to knock out overall.
Wits (Ws)
This is a measure of the character’s reasoning and memory
as well as his mental agility. Those with a good Wits stat will
tend to do better in academic subjects or anything requiring
memory. They will also do better in tasks requiring quick
thinking or in outsmarting their foes.
12

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Generating Stats

You can use one of the examples given, or split the 12
points however you like, so long as you put no more than 5
points into a given stat.
While this method can lead to more balanced and skilled
characters, it can also lead to some players min-maxing
their characters into what amounts to very one dimensional
characters that many veteran players may be familiar with.
It is recommended that if using this method, that the GM
stress the importance making balanced characters.

We have two ways of generating Stats for your character,
Random Roll and Point Buy. With the Random Roll method,
you can get Stats that are higher than you can get with Point
Buy, but you can also get Stats that are negative as well. With
Point Buy, you get to assign the numbers you want to your
Stats, but with certain limitations.

Random Roll

Random Array

For the Random Roll Method, simply make seven
unmodified 2d10 rolls on the following table and then
assign the results as you like to the stats.
Option: Depending on your GM, he may allow for some
variation by allowing a few extra rolls on the table and
then allow you to choose the best seven out of however
many he allows (i.e. best 7 out of 10). It is strongly
recommended that if extra rolls are allowed, you only
allow two or three extra rolls at most, though a very
generous GM might allow up to fourteen (2 for each
stat) rolls for you to choose from.

Point Buy
For the Point Buy, you get 14 points to split among your
Stats. All the Stats start at zero, and then you split the points
however you want, so long as no Stat receives more than 4
points in total from this pool of 14 points..

Stat Values

The Primary Stats for a normal Human will range from
zero (0) to six (6) usually. The Stat Values table provides you
with a verbal descriptor to give you a general idea of what the
number on the stat actually means. Please keep in mind that
these descriptors are guidelines, not absolutes.
As seen in the Kin section, the Kins provide modifiers
to various Primary Stats. These modifiers also dictate the
normal minimums and maximums possible for a given Stat
for that Kin.
For example, a Grey Elf receives a -1 modifier to his
Brawn. This means that when using the Point Buy option,
a Grey Elf ’s normal minimum is -1 and their normal
maximum for Brawn is 3, after adjusting for their Kindred
modifier from the maximum allowed by the Point Buy.
This also means that the average for a Grey Elf Adult in
his prime is 2, just as the average for a Human Adult in his
prime is 3.
Conversely, a Dwarf receives a +2 modifier to his Stamina.
This means that the normal minimum for his Stamina is 2
and the maximum for his Kin is 6 if using the Point Buy
option, and that the average for an adult in his prime is 4.

Kins

Insight stat.
Charisma: This is the Kin bonus applied to your character’s
Charisma stat.
Resolve: This is the Kin bonus applied to your character’s
Resolve stat.
Base Hit Points: Every member of this Kin begins with this
many Hit Points.

Asgerdi (Risi – Great Men)

Hit Multiplier: This number is multiplied by the character’s
total Body skill bonus and added to the Base Hit Points
to determine their total Hit Points.
Max Hit Points: This is the base Maximum Hit Points that a
character from this Kin has. Add double the character’s
Stamina total to get their actual Maximum Hit Points.
Once a character has this many Hit Points, they can no
longer gain any more.
Kin Mana Points: This is a one time bonus that all characters
from this Kin receive to their Base Mana Points total.
Toughness Saves: This is added as a bonus to the character’s
Toughness Save Rolls.
Reflex Saves: This is added as a bonus to the character’s
Reflex Save Rolls.
Will Saves: This is added as a bonus to the character’s Will
Save Rolls.
Background Points: This is the number of points that a
character of this Kin receives to purchase Background
Options (Gifts and Drawbacks).

Primary Location: Nythm; in Tir Caledi
Common Culture: High Ranges, Hillock, or Rural
Appearance: The Asgerdi peoples stand between 7 and 8 feet
tall and they all have muscular builds. Other than this,
they look much like any other humans found. This
means that they run the full range in skin, hair and eye
colors. The largest difference, other than their size is that
the Asgerdi are a very peaceful people. They also reside
almost solely within the Mirr Valley. It is very uncommon,
but not unheard of to see them in other regions. Most
Asgerdi live up to about 150 years in age.
As mentioned, the Asgerdi are a peaceful people.
They will usually not seek out conflict, but neither
will they shy away from conflict should it find them.
They will also strive to defend others when such
opportunities present themselves.
Size: Large (+5 to Base Move; + 1 to Weapon Damage; -1
Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Colossal)
Kindred Traits:
Imposing: The Asgerdi gain a +2 bonus to all attempts at
intimidation. They also get a -1 to all attempts at Stealth.
Long Reach: The Asgerdi treat all weapons as if they had
a Size one step larger than normal, up to maximum
Size of Longest (i.e. Hand treated as Short, Short
treated as Long, etc.). This increase in Size does not
affect the modifiers for Initiative.
Sure Grip: The Asgerdi are able to use weapons with
the Weapon Quality of Hand and a Half as 1-Handed
weapons with no penalty.
Languages: Asgerdi have 3 ranks each in Spoken and Written
Varni and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the trade tongue).
Background Options: 3 Background Points

Kin Descriptions

We have used the same basic format for all of the races
as follows:
Primary Location: Where this Kin is mostly located in
Anwyn. Most members of this Kin will be from
this region. If not, then this should be part of the
character’s backstory.
Common Culture: What Cultures are common for
members of this Kin. Your character is not limited to
these races, but if he comes from one not common
to the Kin, you should figure out why and make sure
that the story behind that is part of their story.
Appearance: This is a general description of the Kin.
Size: This is the character’s size for when it comes to
unarmed attacks. This also affects his Base Move Rate,
and can affect his Attack Bonuses and/or damage dealt.
Kindred Traits: This is a list of any special traits that
members of this Kin receive.

including the number of ranks in those languages.

Dwarf (Dvargr – Mountain People)

Dwelf (Aeshi – Scathling)

Primary Location: Chorak; in Tir Tuath
Common Culture: Subterranean or Underhill
Appearance: Dwarves stand, on average, about 4’6” with a
few occasionally topping out at 5’ tall. They have stocky,
sturdy builds and male Dwarves almost always have beards
of some sort. Female Dwarves are rarely seen outside of
Dwarven enclaves and contrary to rumors, they do not
have beards. They have lifespans of up to 350 years.
A Dwarf will always have a set of 5 metal beads
with them. The number of beads and the material that
they are made from denotes rank and status within
Dwarven society. They will always have these beads
upon their person, either braided into their beards
or hair, or worn as a bracelet, broach, necklace, or the
beads woven together using metal wire into a single
pendant. Dwarves consider it shameful if their beads
cannot be seen when they are not preparing for or
participating in combat.
Size: Medium (+2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Huge)
Kindred Traits:
Dark Sight: Can see in moon light as if Well Lit, can see
in star light and Dimly Lit areas out to 75’, treating the
first 30’ as Well Lit. Can see up to 10’ in total Darkness.
Can see double distance plus 10’ for artifical light
sources in enclosed spaces as if Well Lit. See Dark Sight
(p. 206) for more information.
Forgekin: Dwarves gain a +6 bonus to Saves and DM
against heat and cold attacks. They also gain this bonus
to all rolls involving metals, stone and gems.
Stoneborn: Dwarves receive a -6 to all attempts at
swimming, but also receive a +4 to Nature and
Wandering rolls when underground.
Languages: Dwarves have 3 ranks each in Spoken and Written
Sprak and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the trade tongue).
Background Options: 4 Background Points

Primary Locations: Vi-Ruma in Tir Tuath; Tai-Ruma in Tir
Caledi
Common Culture: Arboreal, Sylvan, or more rarely,
Subterranean, or Underhill
Appearance: Dwelfs call themselves the Aeshi, but are commonly
called Scathlings due to their affinity for the shadows. They
stand, on average, about 3’6” with a few rarely topping
out at 4’ tall. They have lean wiry builds, and their ears
are pointed. A few Aeshi also sport beards, usually kept
trimmed short. They have lifespans of up to 250 years,
looking young until the last few decades of their life. They
often have ruddy, darker skin tones and hair colors. Their
eye colors include both amber and purple.
Nobody is sure where Dwelfs, who are also called
the Scathlings or even sometimes Shadow Elves, even
though they are not true Elves, came from, but they are
considered a distinct and separate Kin. Dwelfs prefer
locales with lots of shadows, such as heavy forests, or
underground, and they may sometimes share tunnels
with Dwarves, who seem to have no issue with them.
Elves, on the other hand, tend to shun or stay away
from them if possible.
Size: Small (-5 to Base Move; -1 Weapon Damage; +1
Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Large)
Kindred Traits:
Dark Sight: Can see in moon light as if Well Lit, can see
in star light and Dimly Lit areas out to 75’, treating the
first 30’ as Well Lit. Can see up to 10’ in total Darkness.
Can see double distance plus 10’ for artifical light
sources in enclosed spaces as if Well Lit. See Dark Sight
(p. 206) for more information.
Shadowling: Dwelfs gain a +2 to Stealth rolls. This rises
to +4 when in shadowy or heavily wooded locations.
Woodcrafty: Dwelfs gain a +3 to Nature and Wandering
rolls in regards to foraging or navigating in woods,
forests and similar terrains.
Languages: Dwelfs have 3 ranks each in Spoken and Written
Lihasa and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the trade tongue).
Background Options: 4 Background Points

Elf, Grey (Yddari – Dusk Elf)

Elf, Grey (Yddari) Stats

Primary Location: Challydd in Tir Tuath
Common Culture: Subterranean
Appearance: The Grey Elves took their name from their
distinctive grey skin color, a side effect of magics that they
subjected themselves to in an attempt to open the way
to their original home world. Regardless of their original
Elven stock, all Grey Elves now range between 5 and 6 feet
in height. As mentioned, their skin has a greyish cast to it.
Their hair colors range from a greyish-white to black and
their eyes are usually amber, an icy blue or even purple,
with other colors possible but very rare.
It is presumed by the Grey Elves that they will tend
to live to be about 500 years old, but it is unknown if the
magics that altered them also altered their lifespan. They
are considered fully grown by the time that they are 50,
and considered a full adult at around 60 years of age. As
with all Elves, they remain youthful looking until the last
10 or so years of their life, and then age quickly.
Size: Medium (+2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Huge)
Kindred Traits:
Keen Senses: High Elves have superior senses that grant them
a +2 to their Perception skill. Additionally, they have Night
Sight, which allows them to see in natural moonlight or
starlight as if it were day. In dim light, they can see up to
100’, treating the first 50’ as if they were in a well lit area. See
Night Sight (p. 205) for more information.
Light-Footed: As long as Elves are not encumbered and
wearing nothing heavier than Reinforced Leather
Armor, they treat rough terrain as if it were normal for
purposes of movement.
Fair & Wise: Grey Elves must assign one of their two
highest stat values to their Charisma stat. They also
gain a +4 to their Arcana, Influence, and Lore skills.
Magic-Touched: Grey Elves gain a +2 to Saves against
spells of all types. They also receive a -1 modifier to any
spell casting attempts.
Lore of the Ages: Grey Elves have a natural affinity to magic.
They gain 4 free skill ranks that they may split however
they want between two spells of their choice, from any
School(s) of Magic. Treat these as Cultural skill ranks.
Languages: Grey Elves have 3 ranks each in Spoken and
Written Ard Tafodd and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the
trade tongue).
Background Options: 2 Background Points

Elf, High (Sylvari – Silver Elf)

Elf, High (Sylvari) Stats

Primary Location: Ymwydd; in Tir Tuath
Common Culture: Mariner, Urban (Middle), Urban
(Middle/Upper), or Urban (Upper)
Appearance: The High Elves call themselves the Sylvari, but
they are also are often called Silver Elves by the other Kins.
They stand just over 6 feet tall on average. They have slight,
willowy builds and their ears rise to sharp points at the top.
Their skin tones range from very pale to lightly tanned,
and always has a slight silvery hue to it. This silvery hue
is reflective enough that in low light conditions, they may
seem to even have a faint glow. Hair color for Sylvari tends
towards black, platinum blonde, silver, and white. Eye
colors tend towards bright blue, amber, and purple.
Sylvari can live up to 600 years on average. They are
fully grown by the time that they are 60 years of age,
and are considered adult around the time that they
reach 75 years of age. Sylvari also seem to prefer urban
environments in general. They remain youthful looking; only showing their age in the last decade or so of
life. Many Silver Elves also seem to tend towards more
magical skills and training.
Size: Medium (+2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Huge)
Kindred Traits:
Keen Senses: High Elves have superior senses that grant them
a +2 to their Perception skill. Additionally, they have Night
Sight, which allows them to see in natural moonlight or
starlight as if it were day. In dim light, they can see up to
100’, treating the first 50’ as if they were in a well lit area. See
Night Sight (p. 205) for more information.
Light-Footed: As long as Elves are not encumbered and
wearing nothing heavier than Reinforced Leather
Armor, they treat rough terrain as if it were normal for
purposes of movement.
Shipwrights: High Elves are renowned sailors, and gain a
+4 to all rolls involving building, repairing, or piloting
Star-Blessed: High Elves must assign one of their two
highest stat values to their Charisma stat. They also
gain a +4 to their Arcana, Influence, and Lore skills.
Lore of the Ages: High Elves have a natural affinity to
magic. They gain 1 free rank in each of two spells of
their choice from any one School of Magic. Treat these
as Cultural skill ranks.
Languages: High Elves have 3 ranks each in Spoken and
Written Ard Tafodd and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the
trade tongue).
Background Options: 2 Background Points

Elf, Wood (Verdyri – Green Elf)

Gnome (Ethori)

Primary Location: Ælftyr in Tir Tuath
Common Culture: Sylvan or Rural
Appearance: The Wood Elves call themselves the Verdyri,
and sometimes they have also been referred to as
Green Elves due to their love of nature and the slightly
greenish tinge to their normally ruddy skin tones.
Wood Elves stand between 5 feet and 5 foot 6 inches
on average. Their hair color tends to be more earth
tones, like a sandy blonde or auburn or brown. Their
eyes tend towards hazel or a bright green, with the
occasional amber or purple in the mix.
Wood Elves tend to live to be about 500 years old. They
are considered fully grown by the time that they are 50,
and considered a full adult at around 60 years of age. As
with all Elves, they remain youthful looking until the last
10 or so years of their life, and then age quickly.
Size: Medium (+2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Huge)
Kindred Traits:
Keen Senses: Wood Elves have superior senses that grant
them a +2 to their Perception skill. Additionally, they
have Night Sight, which allows them to see in natural
moonlight or starlight as if it were day. In dim light,
they can see up to 100’, treating the first 50’ as if they
were in a well lit area. See Night Sight (p. 205) for
more information.
Light-Footed: As long as Elves are not encumbered and
wearing nothing heavier than Reinforced Leather
Armor, they treat rough terrain as if it were normal for
purposes of movement.
Sure-Shot: Wood Elves gain a +2 bonus to their Ranged skill
with Short Bows, Long Bows, and/or Componsite Bows.
Lithe & Graceful: Wood Elves must assign one of their
3 highest Stat values to Dexterity. They gain a bonus
of +2 to their Acrobatics skill, and +4 to Stealth in any
natural environment.
Languages: Wood Elves have 3 ranks each in Spoken and
Written Teangai and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the
trade tongue).

Primary Locations: City-states of Zhor Isin, Szurbroch, &
Zhubrock in Tir Tuath
Common Culture: Underhill, Rural or Sylvan
Appearance: The Gnomes call themselves the Ethori and
they stand about 4 feet tall on average. They look like
miniature Humans for the most part, but their skin,
which is usually a ruddy or brownish tone, has a slight
grayish cast to it. They have a wide range of hair and eye
colors, and male Gnomes almost all have beards, usually
trimmed into a point, regardless of their length.
While Gnomes have a normal lifespan of about 300
years, they remain young looking for all but the last
century of their lives.
Size: Small (-5 to Base Move; -1 Weapon Damage; +1
Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Large)
Kindred Traits:
Dark Sight: Can see in moon light as if Well Lit, can see
in star light and Dimly Lit areas out to 75’, treating the
first 30’ as Well Lit. Can see up to 10’ in total Darkness.
Can see double distance plus 10’ for artifical light
sources in enclosed spaces as if Well Lit. See Dark Sight
(p. 206) for more information.
Magically Inclined: Gain +2 to all Spellcraft rolls.
Gnomish Magic: All Gnomes have some magical
training. They gain 4 free skill ranks split however
they want between two spells of their choice, from any
School(s) of Magic. Treat these as Cultural skill ranks.
Languages: Gnomes have 3 ranks each in Spoken and Written
Tauro and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the trade tongue).
Background Options: 3 Background Points

Human (D’anui & Zhuan)

Human (D’Anui) Stats

Primary Location: Cymbri for the D’Anui and Utara for
the Zhuan; both in Tir Tuath
Common Culture: Any, excluding Arboreal, Subterranean,
and Underhill
Appearance: Humans are an extremely diverse race. They
have a wide range of builds and colorations. For
Anwyn, we have two very different groups of Humans.
The D’Anui are more diverse physically than the
Zhuan. Each is described below.
D’Anui: The D’Anui are not a homogenous people. Most
Kins have a basic genotype, meaning that they vary,
but within certain parameters, such as build or skin
tone. The D’Anui, on the other hand, vary extremely
widely. On average, D’Anui males range from 5’1”
up to 6’6” tall, with women averaging 2 to 4 inches
shorter, with any size build. Skin, hair and eye color
varies greatly among the D’Anui. Most D’anui can live
up to 100 years if not killed by other means.
The men tend to favor long mustaches with shaved
chins. Women wear elaborate braids, while males crop
their hair short. Skin tones can range from very pale, or
pale and freckled to being very black, almost a bluishblack in some cases.
Zhuan: The Zhuan peoples range from just over 5 feet
in height up to about 6 feet at most, with women
averaging a few inches shorter. It is rare for Zhuan
have a heavy or large frame. The Zhuan have a fair to
light brown skin color. They also thick, straight hair,
which is almost always black in color, or rarely silver.
The Zhuan have a lifespan of up to 110 years.
They have little body hair and little facial hair
growth. Their eyes tend towards hazel, green or brown,
with amber being rare. One very distinguishing feature
of the Zhuan is the epicanthic folds (the small overlap
of skin over the eyes). Zhuan also have whatmay be
described as “flattened” features: small noses, wide,
prominent cheekbones.
Size: Medium (+2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Huge)
Kindred Traits:
Specialization: Gain +2 each to any two skills of your
choice.
Languages: The D’Anui Asgerdi have 3 ranks each in Spoken
and Written Gaelsh and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the
trade tongue). The Zhuan have 3 ranks each in Spoken
& Written Ainu and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the
trade tongue).

Orc (Odavi) Stats

Orc (Odavi)
Primary Location: Xondaz; in Tir Caledi
Common Culture: Barbarian, Hillock, or Nomad
Appearance: Orcs stand about 5 to 6 feet in height and have
very heavy, muscular builds. They have upturned,
flattened noses and their lower jaw juts out slightly,
revealing the small tusk-like teeth that protrude
upwards. This gives them a slightly porcine appearance.
Orcs also have course bristly hair, both on top of
their heads and running in a stripe down their backs.
While brown and orange are the most common colors, other colors can also be found. Their eyes have
the usual range of colors with blue and amber being
extremely rare. Orcs live for up to 90 years, remaining
strong and vital until the last few years of their life.
Size: Medium (+2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Huge)
Kindred Traits:
Bloodhound: Orcs are master trackers and their noses
are incredibly sensitive. They gain a +5 to Hunting
and Tracking rolls. This also gives them a +2 to
Perception skill.
Flame Hardened: Orcs get a +6 to Saves and DM against
flame and heat.
Night Sight: Orcs can see in natural moonlight or starlight
as if it were day. In dim light, they can see up to 100’,
treating the first 50’ as if they were in a well lit area. See
Night Sight (p. 205) for more information.
Languages: Orcs have 3 ranks each in Spoken and Wrtten
Zabon and 3 ranks in Spoken Æglits (the trade tongue).
Background Options: 4 Background Points

Tree Blades: This is a pair of
wooden Daggers that are treated
just like normal steel Daggers.

Cultures

A Culture is basically the society in which your character
grew up. This society determines many of the skills that your
character learned early in life. In this chapter, we present
you with the Cultures that are available to characters.
Every Culture gets a number of ranks in various skills. These
are listed on the Cultural Skill Ranks table on the next page.
Each Culture also gives a little extra Starting Wealth, that is
added to the Wealth gainst in your starting equipment (p. 28).

Arboreals are well known for their ability to blend into
their surroundings. Many carry small pots of pigments that
they spread on their skin and clothing when they are trying
to move unseen through their forests. They also rarely touch
the ground at such times, preferring to attack from above
when needed.
Clothing & Decoration: Everyday wear consists of loose
slacks and a tunic, while the primary type of armor
worn is soft leather. Clothing and armor tend to
have the coloration of their environment, various
shades greens and tans and browns tend to dominate,
sometimes even patterned in such ways to help break
up lines and help them blend in better.

Arboreal

This Culture is only found among forests where the trees
are on average 20 to 30 feet in diameter, if not more. Those
from this Culture build their homes high in the trees, on
platform build on and around the trunks of these massive
trees. They sometimes even have chambers in the trunks
themselves. From the ground, it is hard, if not impossible to
determine that there are buildings above at all.
The members of this Culture tend to have a great respect
for nature and work with it in a strong accord. The villages
found among the branches are usually semi-tribal in nature,
ruled by the village elders and counseled by those who
have a magical connection to nature itself. Those from this
Culture are hunters and gatherers, collecting what they need
from the surrounding forest.

Demeanor: Cautiously watchful is a term that often
describes those from this Culture. Since they rarely
know where danger will come from, they never take
anything for granted. To outsiders, this may make
them seem to be a bit suspicious of outsiders, but
they are that way even with each other, unless they
are in a location that they know to be safe.
Starting Wealth: +1d5 bp
