Barbarian

Clothing & Decoration: Barbarians dress mostly in
various types of leather. They often use soft leather,
known as buckskins, for normal clothing and thicker
or reinforced leather for armor. Such clothing is often
decorated with fringe at the seams, and either have
stone or metal beads on the ends of the fringe, or
beadwork on the leather itself.

Barbarian characters are often seen as primitive and
savage by those from other Cultures. They live deep in
the wilderness, usually as part of small nomadic or seminomadic clans or tribes led by their strongest or their Wise
Ones. Wise Ones are usually spell users of a shamanistic or
druidic nature. Sometimes the two work in concert to lead
a given tribe or clan.
They have a deep respect for the natural environment and
its inhabitants, relying almost exclusively on what they are
able to hunt or forage for survival.
Characters from Barbarian Cultures often have elaborate
tattoos that will seem strange or even unsettling to those
from other Cultures. However these tattoos often carry
great significance to those who wear them. Those from the
same Culture can not only read which tribe that a person is
from, but often such things as their name, social standing
and some major life events.

Demeanor: Because of their tattoos, many Barbarians
often view those from other Cultures with suspicion
since they are “unpainted” and often consider them
as purposely hiding their pasts and motives. Those of
this Culture who deal more regularly with outsiders
do understand that other Cultures do not follow this
custom and so are more trusting, even if they never
lose that suspicion of others completely.
Starting Wealth: +1d5 bp
23

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

High Ranges

It is rare, but not unheard of for Mariners to head inland
for various purposes, and regardless how long that they might
remain landlocked, they always long to return to the sea.
Clothing & Decoration: Those from this Culture tend for
simple clothing, often adding layers as needed to deal
with the elements that they have to fight or handle. In
port, their clothing tends to be similar to that of the
Urban Cultures that they find themselves in.

Living upon the slopes of mountains or in the high
valleys, the people from this Culture are a hearty people who
are survivors. Those from the High Ranges, often referred to
as Highlanders, fortify their towns and villages against the
elements and against natural predators where they live, thus
not only do they look very study, but they also often look
imposing as well.
Highlanders tend to be farmers of those plants that do
better at the higher elevations, as well as shepherds tending
their flocks of sheep, goats, and other animals that do well
at those altitudes.
Clothing & Decoration: Those from this Culture tend to
wear sturdy wool clothing done up in earth tones,
with leather accents, such as boots, belts, and mantles.
They tend to leather for their armors when needed
as well.

Demeanor: When at sea, those from this Culture are all business,
but upon hitting the shore, they tend to be gregarious
and full of life, having survived storm and sea yet again.
Mariners tend to celebrate life whenever possible.
Starting Wealth: +1 sp

Nomad

Nomad Cultures tend to wander across a given territory,
only settling briefly, until they pack up and move on. With such
Cultures, they usually have a reason for this wandering, such
as limited, but renewable resources. For example, Cultures that
raise herds of animals tend to move from location to location,
to find food for themselves and their herds. Another example
might be the Culture following a resource that follows its own
migratory pattern, such as one that follows a certain type of
animal as it migrates across their territory.
It is possible that some of this Culture have set up
temporary villages that they inhabit as their wandering
brings them back around to them, or that they move from
pre-built village to village, or they will carry their homes
with them, in the forms of tents or other temporary shelters.
Those from this Culture usually cannot make everything
that they need, so they will often have specified trade
grounds where they will trade with outsiders or where they
trade with each other for things traded for when trading
with outsiders.
Clothing & Decoration: Those of this Culture tend to
wear soft leather clothing or simple wool clothing, all
depending on the type of herds they work with and
what they can trade for.

Demeanor: Highlanders are protective of their homes and
their families and clans. They often have guesting
laws so that they are quite willing to be friendly
to strangers, so long as those strangers behave
themselves. However, should somebody break those
guesting laws, you can expect that their friendliness
to disappear quicker than you might think.
Starting Wealth: +1d10 bp

Hillock

Those from this Culture live among the foothills of
mountain ranges or among a hilly stretch of countryside.
They may terrace those hills to make farming easier in some,
but not all cases. They do tend to build their homes to blend
into the countryside, and sometimes those homes continue
into the side of those hills as well since that can also provide
extra insulation regardless of the season.
Clothing & Decoration: Those of this Culture tend to
wear simple clothing, often made of a combination
of wool and leather; done up in earth tones and other
simple colors.

Demeanor: Those of this Culture tend to be accepting of
outsiders, unless they prove themselves to be enemies.
They know how hard it is to survive in the wilderness,
so are always helpful to those who need it. Nomads
also tend to find joy where ever they can since they
know life can be so harsh.
Conversely, those from more settled Cultures tend
to view Nomads with suspicion since they do not have
a fixed home, and their constantly moving on often
makes them blamed for anything bad that happens
while they were nearby.
Starting Wealth: +1d5 bp

Demeanor: Peoples of the Hillock Culture tend to be hard
working individuals, but they are rarely suspicious of
outsiders. They tend to be more friendly overall.
Starting Wealth: +1d10 bp

Mariner

The Oceans and Seas are a source of life for many. For
those from this Culture, they often live and work on the
water or on the land just beside the sea. You can often find
Mariners mixing in with other Urban Cultures since the
docklands where they often live and sometimes work, are
usually abutted by Urban Cultures that benefit from the
trade and products brought in by sea.

24

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Rural

Subterranean

Rural folk live in small towns and villages away from the
hustle and bustle of larger towns and cities. Those from this
Culture often are located where some resource is available,
and they work to produce that resource, and trade it to get
other things that they may need, especially if they are unable
to make what they need themselves.
This resource, be it agriculture, or lumber, or some other
item or service that is needed by those far away from the
larger towns. Most Rural folk pay taxes to a local lord of
some sort who grants them protection in exchange for a bit
of their output as taxes.
Most Rural folk only see the local lord a few times a year,
when they visit the lord’s home (and the nearby larger town)
to pay their taxes, or when there is trouble in their area and
the lord has to come deal with it.
Clothing & Decoration: Those of this Culture tend to
wear simple clothing, often made of a combination
of wool and leather; done up in earth tones and other
simple colors.

Carving their homes out of the hearts of the mountains
themselves, whole towns and villages lie deep beneath the
surface. Mining and gem working are common trades
among the peoples of this culture. There is a small portion
of those from this Culture who work the land outside their
homes, as farmers or foresters.
Those of the Subterranean culture also tend to be
extremely good at hiding the entrances to those warrens.
Carved out of solid rock, their tunnels are very wide and tall,
to remove the oppressive feelings that living underground
can often give.
Subterranean people make their homes under the ground;
whole towns and villages that are deep beneath the surface.
The entrances are often quite hidden from those who do not
know they are there.
Clothing & Decoration: Those from this Culture usually
wear sturdy clothing made of heavy cloth and leather,
done in darker forest and earth tones. On festival
days, they tend to wear bright colors. Many from
this Culture also carry a set of five metal beads that
is woven into hair or beard, or sewn to their clothing.
These beads tend to show their status within their
Culture, with the pattern on the beads and in which
the beads are positioned will show their craft and
position within that craft.

Demeanor: Peoples of the Rural Culture tend to be
hard working individuals, but they are sometimes
suspicious of outsiders. They tend not to open up
to strangers unless there is something in it for them,
whether it be a bit of kindness or a bit of coin.
Starting Wealth: +1d5 bp

Demeanor: Those of the Subterranean Culture run the
gamut of personalities, just as any other Kin. They
tend to be more secretive about their deeper city levels
and those who live there, their elders. It is only the
young who leave the cities and travel or go outside.
Starting Wealth: +2d5 bp

Sylvan

Those from the Sylvan Culture live in the deep forests, in
tranquil harmony with nature around them. They tend to
avoid all but the smallest of towns and villages, except their
own which are spread across wide, sparsely settled regions
under the boughs of their forests.
By living in harmony with nature, the Sylvan folk tend to
blend in more with their forest than others, and even their
homes tend to blend in, being hidden from casual notice.
Clothing & Decoration: Those from the Sylvan Culture
tend to wear clothing made of sturdy, yet fine looking
cloth and leather done up in forest tones. Green,
yellow and brown, in muted tones are popular colors
Demeanor: Sylvans tend to avoid larger towns and cities,
sometimes viewing those that live in them with
distrust, since there is usually no harmony with
nature for those that live within them.
Starting Wealth: +1d10 bp

25

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Underhill

Lower Class
The largest social class of those found within an Urban
environment is the lower class. Those from this class are often
referred to as peasants or as serfs. They are at the bottom of
society, working as servants in the manor, or among the most
unsavory jobs to be found within the Urban environment.
Starting Wealth: +1d5 cp

Found solely in hilly country, the Underhill Culture
builds its homes under the hills themselves. The entrances to
these small towns, villages, of even more rarely, small cities
tend to be hidden from casual observation and even from
more serious inspection if found within regions that hold
dangers for the inhabitants of such dwellings. The larger the
community, the more likely that the entrances are disguised
and hidden from outsiders.
The Underhill Culture is usually favored by those who are
smaller than Human, but they build spacious tunnels and
dwellings under the ground to lessen the oppressive effects
of living under the earth can sometimes create.
Another feature of those from this Culture are that they
often build structures above the ground, well away from
their true location, connected to the settlement by tunnels
that can be quickly closed or collapsed to stop invaders.
These outbuildings tend to be where those from this Culture
treat with others.
Clothing & Decoration: Those from this Culture wear
muted earth tones, of brown, green, and even blues
for the majority of their sturdy clothing. However,
those of this Culture also like their bright colors and
often wear at least one item of a bright color, often a
cap or a kerchief scarf, or cloak of some sort.

Lower/Middle Class
This social class is included for those Urban areas that do
not have distinct Lower, Middle, and Upper classes. It also
serves as a more transitory class, for those who right on the
upper edge of Lower or the lower edges of Middle. It could
also be used to represent the more populous class found in
smaller towns when there are not 3 distinct social classes.
Starting Wealth: +2d5 cp

Middle Class
Those of the Middle class which consisted of those who
are not of noble blood, nor of the upper heirachy of a church,
but who were also not peasants. Those from this group were
often those who specialized in specific crafts, merchants,
and the lower clergy members.
Starting Wealth: +1d5 bp

Middle/Upper Class

Demeanor: Those from the Underhill Culture tend to be
friendly and outgoing to those that they consider
friends, but guarded and watchful with strangers, at
least until they get to know them.

This social class is included for those Urban areas that do
not have distinct Lower, Middle, and Upper classes. It also
serves as a more transitory class, for those who right on the
upper edge of Middle or the lower edges of Upper. Those
from this Culture are often considered to be the backbone
and leaders of the city. They are the more wealthy merchants
and upper crust of society. This social class also often
represents the more well-to-do residents of smaller towns
where they do not have 3 distinct social classes.
Starting Wealth: +2d5 bp

Starting Wealth: +1d5 bp

Urban

Urban is another word for city, thus the Urban culture
represents those that live in cities. The Urban culture is the
basic culture of those who live within a city or a large town.
We have kept the sub-cultures within this group as generic
as possible to allow for a GM to customize them.
Clothing & Decoration: Those from the Urban culture
have a wide variety of dress. From the lower classes
wearing drab, plain, dull colors, to the bright colors
and patterns found among the upper classes. A
general rule is that those belonging to higher classes
will wear brighter colors and patterns, though there
are always some exceptions.

Upper Class
Those from the Upper class belong to those of noble or
royal blood, knights, and the upper echelons of the clergy. In
many feudal or feudal-like societies, those within this group
will often squabble over the borders of their domains or the
amount of power that they might control in various courts.
Starting Wealth: +1 sp

Demeanor: The demeanors of those that live within Urban
environments tend to vary widely. Those in the
lower classes tend to look with envy or perhaps even
hatred of those above them, while those of the higher
classes tend to look with disdain upon those lower
than themselves. There are, as always, many different
variations possible within the norm.

26

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Vocations

Each character in Fantasy Express has a Vocation. The
Vocation represents a mixture of innate aptitudes and specific
training that the character has received. The Vocation works
to describe how the character’s apprenticeship and natural
inclinations and aptitudes influence their starting abilities and
also how easy or hard it is for them to develop skills in various
fields of expertise.

Skill Rank Costs
The number of Development Points needed to purchase
a single rank in a given skill will increase based upon the
number of ranks that the character already has in the skill.
This means that the higher the rank, the harder it will be to
further improve the skill.
•• If you have less than 10 ranks in a skill, it will cost
1 DP to purchase each rank.
•• If you have at least 10 ranks, but less than 20 ranks,
it will cost 2 DPs to purchase each rank.
•• If you have 20 or more ranks, it will cost 3 DPs to
purchase each rank.
When purchasing skill ranks, the number that may be
purchased in a given level is equal to twice the character’s
level, providing you have enough DPs to purchase that
many skill ranks. This allows for a more focused and rapid
development of a skill that is not acquired until later levels.
When determining the Development Point cost of a skill
rank, any ranks gained from Culture and Vocational Kits
will count towards the total number of ranks known.

Vocational Kits

In Fantasy Express, we have a flexible system where you
choose two Vocational Kits from those that are available, and
those two Kits are simply added together to create your Vocation
for you. These could be the same Kit twice, or two different Kits.
The Character Sheet, in the skills section has a divided
Vocations column so that you can list the Vocational Kits
side by side.
On the left side of the Character Sheet, you have a space
for Vocation Kit #1 and Vocation Kit #2. As you choose
which Vocational Kits you want, you place their names on
the Kit #1 and Kit #2 lines.
Once you have selected your Vocational Kits, you then fill
in your overall Vocation. You can name this whatever you
want as that is how you present yourself to others.

Shifting Development Points
You may also move DPs from one or more Skill Categories
to another. For every 2 DPs moved, the receiving Skill Category
gets 1 DP. When moving DPs from one Skill Category to
another, once moved, those DPs must be immediately spent.
Example: If the character receives no DPs in the Skill
Category, Knowledge. He can move 2 DPs, 1 DP from
the Skill Category, Combat, and one from the Skill
Category, Adventuring, to get 1 DP in Knowledge.
He can do this for any number of DPs that he has
available to move.

Development Points

Each Vocational Kit provides the character with 12
Development Points, spread amount the different Skill
Categories, so that once a player has chosen his 2 Vocational
Kits; he will receive 24 Development Points (DPs) in total.
He receives these 24 DPs each level. As mentioned, these
points are divided among the various Skill Categories. The
way that the DPs are divided among the Skill Categories
will help determine which Skills are important to the given
Vocation. These DPs are listed next to the name of the Skill
Category in the table.
27

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Special Skills

Saving Development Points
Since the costs for the ranks in different skills increases
over time, you will sometimes end up with not enough DPs
to purchase a given rank. Therefore, you are allowed to save
your Development Points between levels. These DPs must be
saved in the Skill Category in which they are received, since
once you move DPs to another Skill Category, the resulting
DP in that new Category must immediately be spent.

Each Vocational Kit offers players the choice of 3 Special
Skills (refer to page 55 for more information) that are
specifically recommended for that Kit. You are able to
select one of the Special Skills for your character from each
Vocational Kit you take, so that you get two in total.
With GM permission, if the recommended Special Skills
do not fit your character concept, you can exchange one of
the recommended for a different Special Skill.

Vocational Ranks

Starting Equipment

Each Kit also gives a number of free skill ranks to specific
skills. These skill ranks are only gained once, during character
generation. There are also a couple of items that need to be
pointed out in how the skills are listed.
•• Most Vocational Kits list Combat Skills. The ranks listed for
Combat Skills must then be split between the skills: Blades,
Blunt, Brawl, Polearms, and Ranged. No Combat Skill, or
any other skill, may receive more than 4 ranks in total from
the combination of both Vocational Kits.
•• The Vocational Ranks for Spells must be split between
Spells of the player’s choice from their Codices/Folios.
Each Kit contains a note about how many Spell receive
ranks from those listed. No individual Spell may receive
more than 4 ranks in total from the combination of both
Vocational Kits.
•• If a character has more than one School of Magic from
Vocations, the Development Points and Vocational
Ranks are not combined, each School of Magic, and the
spells under it are treated as separate Skill categories.
Example: You select the Magician and Bard
Vocations. The Spellcraft Development Points (DPs)
for Magician may only be spent on Magery spells.
The Spellcraft DPs for Bard may only be spent on the
Wizardry spells available to the Bard.

Every character has some starting equipment that
they begin play with, so that you do not have to purchase
everything for the character. Every character begins play with
the items listed under Standard Equipment, and then they may
also choose one or two items described under their Vocation
description. Be sure to record both on your character sheet.

Standard Equipment
There are three sets of items that every character begins play
with. They are more fully detailed in the equipment chapter, but
you can list these items on your character sheet for now.
•• Standard Pack — Characters begin with a Backpack
(holds 2 cubic feet; 40 lbs max) that contains the
following list of items. If the Player would prefer that his
character has a Framepack (holds 5 cubic feet; 100 lbs
max) instead of a Backpack, he may upgrade by paying
13 copper pieces out of his character’s Starting Money
(the difference in price between the 2 types of pack).
•• 50’ Superior Rope
•• 1 canvas sack
•• 2 weeks of iron rations
•• 1 small steel mirror
•• 1 waterskin full of water
•• 1 flask of oil
•• 1 small lantern
•• 1 Tinderbox
•• 1 Light Bedroll
•• At Belt Items — The character needs something to hang
his weapons on, not to mention belt pouches and a dagger.
•• Equipment Belt
•• 2 belt pouches
•• 1 dagger & scabbard
•• Clothing — Every character starts off with a little clothing.
He begins with 2 outfits, which includes the one he is
wearing, that is based on his background and Culture. For
example, an Upper Class Urban Minstrel will likely have
much finer clothing than a Lower Class Urban Thief.
•• 2 sets of clothing
•• 1 cloak
•• 1 set of soft leather boots
•• 1 weapon (plus scabbard and/or 12 ammunition in
appropriate pouch or quiver if a Ranged weapon)
•• Starting Wealth: 5 +1d10 bp

Mana Points from Vocational Kits
Each Kit that a character chooses will provide that character
with a specific amount of Mana Points. The Mana from both
Kits are added together with the character’s Kin Mana Points
to give them their Base Mana Points, which are then added to
the Mana gained from the Mana skill.
•• Arcane Vocational Kits: Each Arcane Vocational Kit gives
the character 5 Base Mana Points.
•• Hybrid Vocational Kits: Each Hybrid Vocational Kit gives
the character 3 Base Mana Points.

Mage & Magus
Mage – This is a generic term used to describe an Arcanist
or Hybrid combination of two Vocational Kits who has
access to only a single School of Magic (i.e. a Druid/Druid
or an Envoy/Champion or a Ranger/Ranger).
Magus – This is a generic term used to describe an Arcanist
or Hybrid combination of two Vocational Kits who has
access to two Schools of Magic (i.e. a Druid/Sorcerer or a
Magician/Bard or a Ranger/Monk).
28

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Vocational Kits

Berserker

There are 4 basic types of Kits. We have the Fighter Kits,
which focus primarily on combat of some sort, and the
Adept Kits, who focus on various combinations of skills.
There are also the Arcane Kits, which focus on being spell
casters, and finally we have the Hybrid Kits which combine
a lesser casting ability with other skills.

Fighter Kits are those who are masters of arms and combat.
They possess unparalleled skills in fighting with all kinds
of weapons, both melee and ranged, as well as in unarmed
combat. Fighters can have other interests, but their focus is
usually on their combat abilities.

A Berserker is a type of fighter who works himself up into
a frenzied state, which enhances their combat capabilities.
Berserkers rarely wear anything heavier than Chain and
they rarely carry shields as they usually forget to use it once
they have become frenzied.
Berserkers also tend to favor larger weapons as this allows
them to maximize the damage that they can do to their foes.

A Sicarius is one who focuses in infiltration and deadly
skills. In some cultures, they are known by other names, such
as Ninja. They are usually loners who are hired to eliminate
specific enemies. Sicari (plural of Sicarius) usually do not
wear armor unless they are posing as a fighter or other type
of adventurer.
Special Skills (Choose one Special Skill each time this

Thieves are specialists in liberating and acquiring items
that do not belong to them. This often includes lifting small
objects from pockets or pouches without their owners
realizing it. This has led to them sometimes being called
Pickpockets or Cutpurses.

traps guarding some things.

Arcane Kits

Envoy (Cleric)

Arcane Kits are purely focused on casting spells.
Characters with these kits are often called Arcanists. Each of
the Vocational Kits listed in this section focuses on a single
School of Magic and also lists the Stat considered to be the
Kit’s Magic Stat, and thus which is used in figuring Mana
Points and used as the bonus for all Spells learned and for
the Arcana skill.
If a character gains Arcane Kits and/or Hybrid Kits from
more than a single School, the player must select which is
their primary School and use the Stat for that in determining
Mana and their Arcana skill. The stats for each School are
always used for Spells from that School.

Envoys are priestly magic users, sometimes called
Clerics, who are devoted to one or more deities whose
goals are benign to the mortal realms. As such deities often
stand against creatures from the Infernal Realms, their
Envoys often travel the world, adventuring and looking for
such blights to wipe out.
Many clerical orders of benign deities prefer using
bludgeoning weapons over edged weapons due to the
symbolism involved with sacrifices (i.e. the shedding of
blood), and the fact that bludgeoning weapons are often more
effective against a number of the lesser forms of undead.
Special Skills (Choose one Special Skill each time this
Vocational Kit is acquired):

* = Rank to be assigned to one of the Combat skills.
** = Ranks to be split between 3-5 of the Druid’s spells, with
no spell gaining more than 2 ranks.
† = Only Spells from the Universal Folio & Druidism Codex
belong to this Vocation’s Spellcraft skill category. All other
spells are treated as belonging to another Skill Category.

•• Arcane Scholar

Druids are practitioners of Druidism. They are often
considered protectors of nature. This does not mean
that they are non-violent. They often believe in survival
of the fittest. However, they are strongly against wanton
destruction of nature, especially for profit.
Special Skills (Choose one Special Skill each time this
Vocational Kit is acquired):
•• Arcane Scholar

Folios & Codices
A Codex is a list of 30 Spells belonging to a
single School of Magic. This means that every
School of Magic has its own Codex.
A Folio is a subset of spells within a Codex.
The spells from a School’s Folio are the only
ones a Hybrid caster may learn.
The list of 10 Universal Spells are also
considered to be their own Folio. They are
available to all characters.

Magicians are practitioners from the the School of
Magery. They tend to be obvious and flamboyant in both
their dress and mannerisms. They like to perform for
others, but this gregarious attitude often disguises their
true intentions and goals.
Magi often cast spells that are focused on conjuration,
illusion, or the elements. They are sometimes called Mages,
Conjurers or Illusionists.
Special Skills (Choose one Special Skill each time this
Vocational Kit is acquired):

The Mystic is often looking inwards; focusing magic
through his mind to create spells that focus primarily on
himself. Mystics believe that the mind, body, and soul are all
connected and their spells reflect the merging of these.

Sorcerers believe and treat magic as if it were just another
type of science. Magic to them is just another application of
explainable forces. Many Sorcerers also dabble into one or more
various semi- or quasi- scientific fields of study (i.e. Lores).
Special Skills (Choose one Special Skill each time this
Vocational Kit is acquired):

Shamans are often tribal spell users who communicate
and traffic with the Spirit World (p. 188). Shamans
tend to believe in a strong balance between the natural
and supernatural worlds, and they often work towards
maintaining that balance.

Hybrid Kits

Blackguard

Hybrid Kits are ones that specialize in a mix of skills and
magic. While not as powerful as the Arcane Kits, these Kits are
more versatile in that they often have other skills to fall back on.
Each Kit lists its School of Magic and the Magic Stat for them as
well. As with the Arcane Kits, the Magic Stat is used for all Spells
and the Arcana skill.
If a character gains Arcane Kits and/or Hybrid Kits from
more than a single School, the player must select which is
their primary School and use the Stat for that in determining
Mana and their Arcana skill. The stats for each School are
always used for Spells from that School.

Champions are mystical fighters, trained both in the
way of the sword and the magical arts. They are Hybrids
from the School of Divinism. A Champion could come
from a secluded mountain monastery, or be an enforcer
of some religious military order, or a knight sworn to an
ancient discipline. Champions have sometimes been called
Paladins, while others have been referred to as Warrior
Monks or Warrior Priests. Champions are proficient in both
combat and spell casting, though their spells are mainly
geared towards helping and complementing their skills.

Dabblers are some of the most versatile and eclectic,
merging mundane skills of exploration and stealth with
magical arts. They are from the School of Sorcery since
they also see magic as just another tool in their arsenals.
The useful combination of so many different talents allows
the Dabbler to be a real jack-of-all-trades, capable of
winning the day using the right skill at the right time, or
with a lucky trick.

Monks are Hybrid spell casters from the School of
Mysticism. They are essentially someplace between Mystics
and the non-magical Sohei. They use their magical training
to manipulate what they refer to as their Chi energy. This is
part of their rigorous training to enhance their mind, body
and spirit. Many orders of Monks also serve as priests in
some cultures (as opposed to Envoys/Clerics) due in part to
their focus on spiritual training and on philosophy.

wilderness. Their affinity for nature allows them to survive
and explore areas that others might not survive in.

* = Ranks in Combat Skills must be divided among the 5 individual skills. No individual Combat Skill, nor any other skill, may receive more than 2 ranks (4 ranks total for
both Vocations that a character may aquire).
** = Ranks may be divided between Universal spells and spells belong to the character’s School of Magic. No spell may receive more than 2 ranks (4 ranks total for both
Vocations that a character may acquire).
† = The Development Points (DPs) gained by this Vocation are for a Skill Category that is comprised of the spells available to the Vocation’s School of Magic and the Universal spells.
For Hybrids, any spells from their School of Magic that are not marked as available to them would be treated as if it were a different School of Magic for learning. If a character
has more than one School of Magic (i.e. Druidism and Sorcery) from their chosen Vocations, they would have two Spellcraft Skill Categories, and the DPs from each Vocation
would apply only to the Spellcraft Skill Category for that Vocation (i.e. The Druid’s Spellcraft DPs would apply only to the Skill Category for the Druid’s Spells and Universal
Spells while the Sorcer’s Spellcraft DPs would apply only for Sorcery spells and Universal spells).

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Skills

A few skills may have more than one Stat that could apply,
depending on how the skill is used. They are indicated as such.

In Fantasy Express, a character’s skills represent
specialized capabilities that they have developed over time
with experience and training, just how their Stats represent
their innate abilities and aptitudes.
Skills are divided into a number of specific Skill Categories,
which group together skills of a similar theme or purposed.
For example, the Skill Category, Combat, contains skills that
are generally only used during combat situations.
We use the Skill Categories make it easier to reference
them quickly, and for the purpose of determining which
skills are easier to purchase as the character advances.

Skill Ranks

There are three main sources of Skill Ranks that your
character can acquire. Each has its own column on the
character sheet.
There are a number of things, such as Special Skills,
that rely on how many Ranks a character has in a given
skill. Purchased, Cultural, and Vocational Ranks all count
together in these situations. Each Rank in a skill also
provides a +1 bonus to that skill.

Skill Bonuses

Purchased Ranks

Your character’s proficiency with any given skill is measured
by their total skill bonus, which is added to any rolls made
when they attempt to perform a task involving that skill. Refer
to Resolving Actions (p. 114) for more information.
Characters with a higher skill bonus are more likely to
succeed, even when attempting difficult tasks, while those
with lower bonuses will fail more frequently.
To determine your total skill bonus for your skill, you will
add together several different numbers. These include your
Stat for the task being attempted, your number of ranks in
the skill, any Vocational Bonus for the skill, any Culture or
Kin bonuses for the skill, plus any modifiers coming from
items, spells or other sources.

The costs for each rank will increase as you gain more
ranks in the skill. This reflects how hard is it to improve as
you grow more and more competent in a given skill.
Purchased Ranks in a skill may never exceed double the
character’s level, so that a Third level character may never
have more than 6 Purchased Ranks in a skill.
When you purchase ranks in a skill, they are listed under
the Ranks column of the Skill section of the character sheet.

Cultural Ranks
These are a one time award of skill ranks that your
character receives based on their chosen Culture. They are
recorded in the Culture column of the Skills section of your
character sheet.

Stats

Vocational Ranks

Each skill is normally associated with a single Stat, which
aids in determining your character’s natural affinity for certain
types of tasks. For example, characters with a higher Dexterity
stat will generally be better at skills requiring nimbleness and
coordination, like Acrobatics or using missile weapons.

These are a one time award of skill ranks that your character
receives based on their chosen Vocations. They are recorded
in the Vocation column of the Skills section of your character
sheet. Since you gain 2 Vocational Kits, this column is divided
in half, one side of the pipe (|) for each kit.
46

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Kin Bonuses

Your character’s Kin may provide bonuses to one
or more skills due to their Kindred Traits. If those
bonuses are for all uses of the skill, record them under
the Special column in the Skills section of the character
sheet. If the bonuses apply at certain times or in
certain circumstances, then record them in either the
Background/Abilities section or in the Additional Notes
section of your character sheet.

Special Bonuses

Some Background options will grant free ranks or bonuses
in one or more skills. These should be recorded under the
Special column in the Skills section of the character sheet
along with any other permanent modifiers that you have
received to the skill. All modifiers of this type are cumulative.
Should you have modifiers that are only applied in
certain situations or under specific conditions, then record
that information in either the Background/Abilities section
or in the Additional Notes section of your character sheet.

Item Modifiers

Special Equipment or magical items can also provide
bonuses to skills, or if the item is poorly made or cursed
impose a penalty on using the skill. For example, a set of
masterwork lock picks could grant a +2 to the Locks &
Traps skill, while an old rusty sword might impose a -1
to your Blades skill while it is being used.
You may only ever have one bonus from an item or
equipment. Should you have multiple items that provide
a bonus, use only the one with the highest bonus.

Every Vocation has a specific number of Development
Points (DP or DPs) under each Skill Category. You are
allowed to spend those points to purchase ranks in the
skills under those categories. The cost of purchasing a rank will
depend upon how many ranks that they already have in the skill.
•• Skill rank costs for each individual rank in a given
skill are determined by the total of the Purchased,
Cultural, and Vocational ranks in that given skill.
•• If you have less than 10 ranks, it will cost 1 DP to
purchase each additional rank.
•• If you have at least 10 ranks, but less than 20 ranks,
it will cost 2 DPs to purchase each additional rank.
•• If you have 20 or more ranks, it will cost 3 DP to
purchase each additional rank.
•• You may purchase any number of ranks in a given
skill, limited only by available DP, so long as the total
number of purchased ranks does not exceed double
the character’s level.
Example: Fred has 10 ranks in his character’s Blades
skill. To purchase an 11th rank, Fred will have to spend
2 DPs. However, since his Ranged and Brawl skills only
have 3 ranks in each, he could spend those 2 DP to gain
1 rank in each or 2 ranks in either one of them.

Using Skills Untrained

There will be times when a character will want to
try to use a skill when they have no ranks in the skill.
This is allowed to be attempted, but there is a penalty in
attempting this. Physical skills would receive a -4 modifier,
and mental skills would receive a -10. However, both types
of skills would receive their Stat to the roll as well.

Armor, Body & Mana Skills
These 3 skills are unlike any other skills. No rolls
are ever made using these three skills, so no negative
modifiers apply. In fact, the Stats should apply even if
there are no skill ranks to the skills. For example, even
with no ranks, every character would have a just a
little bit of inherent mana.

47

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

~Armor~

Shifting DPs

Players may move DPs from one or more Skill Categories
to other Skill Categories on a 2 for 1 basis. The DPs moved
do not need to be from the same skill category. However,
they must both be moved at the same time, so that the
new Skill Category gets a full DP after the move. Once DPs
have been moved to another Skill Category, they must be
immediately spent.
Example: Fred decides that his character needs to learn
a rank in Influence, a Knowledge skill. Since Fred’s
character is a Warrior, he gains no DPs in that Skill
Category. Fred decides to move 1 DP from Combat,
and 1 DP from Adventuring and put them into
Knowledge. This gives him 1 DP total in Knowledge
to spend to get that rank of Influence that he wanted.

Armor

Stats: Brawn
Description: This skill represents the character’s ability to
move efficiently while encumbered or wearing armor.
When wearing Armor, the character receives several
different penalties to various physical skills and actions:
Move Penalty, Dexterity Modifier, and Attack Bonus Penalty
are the ones that can be affected by this skill.
The total bonus of this skill is used to reduce those
penalties to zero. The Move Penalty is reduced first. Once
this has been reduced to zero, then the Dexterity Modifier
(which applies only to the Defensive Modifier), and then
finally, the Attack Bonus Penalty.
More information on the types of Armor available can
be found in the section on Armor & Shields (p. 88).

Saving DPs

Instead of spending all of their DPs each level, a player
may elect to save them until a later level. Saving DPs
across levels will allow for gaining higher ranks in skills for
those Skill Categories that only get a few DPs each level.
Development Points may only be saved in the skill category
for which they are gained.
Example: Fred’s Warrior gets 5 DPs per level
in Combat. He cannot move 2 of those points to
Knowledge and then save the resulting Development
Point for a later level. The points must be saved in the
Combat Skill Category, and only moved once Fred is
ready to spend them in the Knowledge skill Category.

~Combat~

While we have a number of skills that fall within the Combat
Skill Category, we only have five that we refer to specifically as
Combat Skills, and which are notated as such in the Vocations.

Battle Frenzy

Stats: Insight
Description: By developing this skill, characters learn to
focus their rage into a destructive frenzy, enhancing their
combat abilities. Characters using this skill tend to laugh
uncontrollably, bite their shields, or gnash their teeth as
they fight, often proving unsettling even for their allies.
Characters with at least one rank in this skill can enter
this frenzy as a Full Action. Partial Success is enough to
enter a frenzied state, and they gain an additional +1 to
their AB for every Success Level earned. While frenzied,
the following applies:
•• May not Parry or perform other Defensive Actions
while frenzied.
•• Gain an additional +1 to their Attack Bonus for
every 5 ranks, or portion thereof, in this skill, up
to a maximum of +5.
•• Gain +4 to Brawn-related rolls, including attacks.
•• While Stunned, may make a Half Action attack
using half of their normal Attack Bonus (rounded
down), plus both Frenzy bonuses listed above.
The -4 for a Half Action attack applies if their
attack normally requires a Full Action.
However, they must engage in melee and attack the
nearest creature that they see. If they are not engaged
in melee during the Assessment phase, they must pass
a Battle Frenzy skill roll, modified by the movement
penalties of any armor worn. Failure means that they will
engage and attack a random nearby target as selected by
the GM. Success means that they can either end their
frenzy or engage and attack a target of their choosing.
Once the frenzy ends, the character becomes Weary.

Skill Descriptions

What follows are descriptions of the Core Skills found
in Fantasy Express, sorted by Skill Category. We have also
included some Drive Point uses for select skills where they
are appropriate. Refer to the section on Drive (p. 78) for
more information on them.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Combat Skills

Polearms
Stats: Brawn
Description: Polearms include any weapon capable of
various types of attacks. One thing that all polearms
have in common is that they consist of a head, or
striking surface attached to a shaft that is usually from 5
to 10 feet in length. This group includes such weapons
as Spears, Staves, Bardiches, Halberds, Military Forks,
Ranseurs and other similar weapons. The stat used with
this skill may vary based on the actual weapon used.

This set of skills determines how effectively your character
can perform an attack with or without a weapon. These
skills can also be used to assess an enemy’s combat skill and
to evaluate combat gear and equipment.
Rather than developing skill in each specific weapon, we
have made the skills into broad categories that encompass
weapons that are used in roughly the same manner. You will
spend your Development Points in this category purchasing
ranks in these, and possibly some Special Skills (p. 55).
Your total skill bonus is added to a 2d10 open-ended roll,
and then the foes Defensive Modifier (DM) is subtracted, and
the final result is looked up on the Fantasy Express Action/Task
table (p. 115), see Combat (p. 119) for more information.
The Combat skills do not list any potential Complications
because there are specific weapon fumble tables that would
apply if you receive a Critical Failure.

Ranged
Stats: Dexterity
Description: This skill encompasses all weapons that
either shoot projectiles of some sort, or are themselves
thrown as projectiles. This includes weapons such
as bows, crossbows and thrown weapons like spears,
javelins, daggers, darts, etc. The stat used with this skill
may vary based on the actual weapon used.

Blades
Stats: Brawn
Description: Bladed weapons are made to cut, slash and
stab through a target’s flesh. This skill encompasses
the use of blades of all types. Sw+ords long and short,
scimitars, rapiers, and many more all belong to this
category. The stat used with this skill may vary based
on the actual weapon used.

Intimidation

Stats: Charisma
Description: This skill represents the ability to browbeat,
coerce, and terrorize other people, through subtle threats
or vulgar displays of power. Upon using this skill, the
GM will roll on the Reaction Rolls (p. 225) table, with
the more favourable results resulting in the one being
intimidated more likely to perform as desired.
In combat, characters can use this skill to attempt
to shift their opponent’s current disposition to a more
favorable result on the Reaction Rolls (p. 225) table.
Complications: The target of the intimidation finds you
hilarious and cannot stop giggling or laughing at you;
their current disposition towards you worsens rather
than improves.

Blunt
Stats: Brawn
Description: Blunt weapons are often called mass weapons
as well. They produce damage by impacting the target
with blunt force to crush, smash and break the target.
This weapon group includes axes, hammers, maces and
clubs as well as any similar weapons. The stat used with
this skill may vary based on the actual weapon used.

Unarmed Damage Ratings by Size

Stats: Brawn
Description: This skill is a bit of a catch-all. It includes
all manner of fisticuffs, and unarmed techniques such
as grappling and wrestling. It also includes the use of
Hand weapons such as daggers, armored fists, cesti
and also improvised weapons like stones, table legs
and other objects. The stat used with this skill may
vary based on the actual weapon or object used. The
Unarmed Attacks table shows the Damage Ratings
for attacks based upon the character’s size. Refer to
Weapons (p. 102) and the Combat chapter (p. 119)
for more information.

Swashbuckling

Beastmastery

Stats: Dexterity
Description: This skill represents the ability to get
maximum advantage of a flamboyant, skirmishing
fighting style. To effectively take advantage of this
fighting style, the character must be either unarmored
or lightly armored (nothing heavier than soft leather),
unencumbered and must be using a single on-handed
weapon and no other weapon in their off-hand. For
example, a character fighting with an arming sword,
scimitar or a single dagger qualifies, but using a
longsword or a short sword with a shield, or two
daggers would not.
This skill would be used to perform moves or actions
such as swinging on a chandelier or diving from the
top of a ship’s rigging and using a dagger to cut the
sail as you also use it to slow your descent. Describe
the action you would like to perform, and the GM will
assign a difficulty, and if your roll is successful, you
have completed the action in style. A Critical Success
could even result in you achieving surprise against
your foes as they stare, not believing you just did that.
For every five ranks, or portion thereof, in this skill,
the character gains a +1 to his DM and reduces the
negative modifier of a Dashing Attack (p. 125) by one.

Stats: Charisma
Description: This Skill represents the ability to influence
the reactions of beasts and animals. The target may
not have a humanlike intelligence (or higher) and be
capable of communication via hearing or sight. If the
character is able to actually speak the language of beast
or animal, that will give a +4 bonus to this roll.
In or out of combat, a character can use this Skill to
attempt to shift their target’s current disposition to a more
favorable result on the Reaction Rolls (p. 225) table.

Cooking

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill allows character to turn simple
rations or raw ingredients into savory meals. Cooks
also know how to make the most of scraps and
leftovers. Once per travel, characters can attempt a
Hard (-4) Cooking roll to reduce rations consumption
in their party by one third (rounded down).

Hunting

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill is rolled whenever a character
wants to hunt down or trap a creature. It is also used
for finding and following tracks as well.

Warfare

Nature

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill represents the character’s general
knowledge of military tactics, as well as their ability
to operate siege weapons, such as catapults, arbalests,
battering rams, or siege towers.
Characters also gain a +1 bonus for every 5 ranks,
or portion thereof, that they have in this skill to all
their skill rolls made to lead troops into battle.

Stats: Insight
Description: This skill is used when a character wants to
apply their outdoor knowledge in order to recognize
plants, beasts, and natural phenomena, such as
upcoming weather, or actively interacting with animals
or with the surrounding environment. This skill is also
used to read and glean information from tracks.

~Adventuring~

Pilot

Stats: Insight
Description: This skill allows the character to control a
vehicle or vessel that is powered by something other
than animal power. This includes sailing on a lake, or
navigating a ship at sea, or other similar craft.

This category includes skills that are often used in an
outdoor environment.

Athletics

Stats: Brawn
Description: This skill is used when the characters have
to use their Brawn to overcome an obstacle. It is used
for things like climbing, running distances, swimming,
jumping, feats of strength (i.e. pulling an oxcart) and
other physical activities.

Ride

Stats: Dexterity
Description: This skill is roll when a character uses their
ability to control and maneuver a mount or drive an
animal-powered land vehicle. Horses are common
mounts for humans, but it can include other more
exotic mounts, especially for the different Kins, such
as Garm (riding wolves: p. 96), Korex (riding lizardlike creature: p. 98), Syris (large riding cat: p. 98)
and Tarq (riding goat-like creature: p. 98), or even
extremely rare mounts such as griffins and giant eagles
or such.

50

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Wandering

Gimmickry

Stats: Insight
Description: This skill is used when a character needs
to apply their knowledge of the outdoors in order to
properly navigate and survive in the wilderness.

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill allows the character to successfully
pick locks and padlocks, and to deal with traps,
mechanisms and similar devices of a mechanical nature.

~Roguery~

Perception

Stats: Insight
Description: This skill allows the character to gather
information and clues through the use of their five senses.

This category includes skills that are related to your
character’s swiftness, agility, dexterity and more general in
their ability to deceive or perceive deception and notice
things in their surroundings.

Stealth

Acrobatics

Stats: Dexterity
Description: This skill is rolled whenever the character
needs to avoid being seen or heard by an opponent in
order to gain an advantage against them or a situation.
This includes things like moving silently or unseen, and
things like pilfering items from another person. This
skill is often resolved as a Conflicting Action (p. 117).

Stats: Dexterity
Description: This skill is rolled when characters need to
perform maneuvers that require a great deal of agility,
balance, and/or motor coordination.

Ambuscade

Stats: Dexterity
Description: This skill represents the ability of the character
to effectively strike to cripple or kill a humanoid foe
when ambushing them. This skill may only be used in
conjunction with the Backstab (p. 103) Quality that
some weapons have.
It requires that the character perform a skill roll
for this skill, as well as making a normal melee attack
against the target.
The character will make his Ambuscade roll first. If
it is successful, the character will get to add any Success
Levels earned in his Ambuscade roll to those earned
from the actual attack roll against his foe.
Below are a few modifiers to this skill based on the
differences in size between the character and his target.
•• +0: Target is same size as the attacker
•• -2: For each size increment that the Attacker is
larger than the Target
•• +1: For each size increment that the Attacker is
smaller than the Target
•• -1 Ambuscade Success Level: For each size increment
that the Attacker is smaller than the Target

Trickery

Stats: Dexterity
Description: This skill is used to perform sleight of hand.
It includes the ability to perform various tricks and
legerdemain, including card tricks, palming (concealing
small objects in the hand – useful in picking pockets),
passing or swapping small objects without being
detected, ventriloquism, picking pockets, and so forth.
Character with this skill can employ it to check or “fix”
games of chance, or to detect others attempting to do
the same, presuming that they have good knowledge
of the game in question. This skill is often resolved as a
Conflicting Action (p. 117).

Breathing Mask:
Provides the
wearer with
fresh, clean air
while worn. This

would hinder normal
breathing. (AP: 27
Cost: 405 gp)

Deceive

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill allows the character to successfully
mislead others, disguise themselves, or provide a false
perception of reality. This skill is often resolved as a
Conflicting Action (p. 117).

51

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

~Knowledge~

Appraisal

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill is used to estimate or determine
the rough value of objects, such as furs, weapons,
jewels, etc. with a just a quick examination. The longer
the time spent examining the item, the more accurate
the valuation will be. You can appraise common objects
with a Partial Success or greater. Appraising a rare or
unfamiliar item requires a full Success or higher. If the
skill roll is successful, you estimate the value correctly,
to within +/-10% of its actual value.

This category includes those skills related to the character’s
mundane and academic learning of the world around them
and their ability to use that information to their advantage.

Acumen

Stats: Wits
Description: Depending on your social status, this skill
is either called Acumen, of for those who frequent the
seedier side of life, it is called Streetwise.
With this skill, regardless of what you call it, you are
able to gather information from a variety of sources
(i.e. asking innocuous questions, listening to gossip
and watching routines of people). You should specify
what information you are attempting to find and the
character must spend a minimum of 1 hour on the task
and be able to understand the language and customs of
the local culture.
A Difficulty level should be assigned based on the
type of information being sought, how familiar the
character is with the culture, the disposition of the
local population to the character’s kin or culture.

Arcana

Stats: Varies
Description: This skill is the study of most things magical.
In addition to being a source of knowledge about spells
and magical items and magical creatures, it also allows
the character to find Essential Salts (p. 137) and to
attune to magical items, and to also read and write
spell scrolls and temporary runes. Combined with the
Special Skill, Enchantment (p. 56), it allows for the
creation of more permanent items. The Stat to be used
is the same as their Magic Stat. For more information
on item creation, please refer to Alchemy 101 (p. 189).

Alkemics

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill is the study of Alchemy. It allows
for finding Essential Salts (p. 137), and the creation of
Herbal Remedies, Herbal Elixirs, Dusts, and Potions.
Combined with the Special Skill, Enchantment, it
allows for the creation of more potent and/or more
permanent items. For more information on item
creation, please refer to Alchemy 101 (p. 189).

Arts

Stats: Varies
Description: The Arts skill represents a character’s ability
to perform or create works of art, as well as learning
about and appreciation of the subject. This skill
includes performing arts such as singing and music
as well as creative arts such as painting, sculpting, or
illustration. Each type of Art would be a separate skill.
The Stat to be used would be Charisma for performing
arts, and Dexterity for those like sculpting or painting.

52

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Crafts

Influence

Stats: Insight
Description: This skill represents a characters ability to
work a specific kind of material (wood, leather, stone,
bone, etc.), or to create a particular type of item (such
as musical instruments, clothes, bows, or arrows). This
skill must be learned separately for each craft that they
wish to learn. Common crafts include Animal Trainer
(trains a specific type of animal), Armorer (creates
armor from various materials), Blacksmith (general
worker of metals), Leatherworker (works with
leather to create items), Woodworker (creates items
made from wood), Woodcarver (carver of wood and
bone, also called scrimshaw), Swordsmith (maker of
swords), Herbcraft (growing, finding, and using herbs
in medicinal capacities), and many more possibilities.
Characters developing this skill are able to become
true masters of their trade, able to manufacture items of a
quality that goes well beyond the capabilities of common
artisans. Given time and proper tools and materials, a
character can make a Crafts roll to create an appropriate
item of their choice, within their chosen craft.

Stats: Charisma
Description: This skill is rolled when the character is
trying to convince others to do something without
resorting to tricks or misdirection.

Leadership

Stats: Charisma
Description: This skill allows a character to lead others
to gain better effects than mere individuals working
together. The character may use the Leadership skill when
others are working together. Whenever anyone is making
a Skill Roll as a Help action, the character may also help
using the Leadership Skill. If successful, all those using the
Help action add an additional +1 to the aid they offer.

Lore

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill represents a character’s scholarly
education and knowledge of folklore, history, myths
and legends as well as their ability to tell or sing them
in an entertaining manner.

Cultures

Meditation

Healing

Sciences

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill represents a character’s knowledge
of the customs, beliefs, traditions, institutions, and
languages of the various cultures that they have
encountered in their travels.
It may also be purchased separately for a more
indepth knowldge of a single Culture than the general
version of this skill allows for.

Stats: Resolve
Description: Using this skill, the character can meditate
to focus their mind and awareness on a specific
subject, allowing them to Help (p. 116) themselves.
After meditating for an appropriate amount of time,
usually at least one minute for physical tasks or one
hour for mental tasks, the character can make a skill
roll and apply the results.

Stats: Insight
Description: This skill covers medical knowledge and it is
used to treat wounds and injuries or to cure diseases or
other ailments. The use of this skill is more thoroughly
detailed in the section on Health & Healing (p. 215).
Complications: Please refer to the section on Health &
Healing (p. 215) for some of the possible complications
that can arise from Healing rolls in various situations.

Stats: Wits
Description: This skill represents a character’s knowledge
and application of sciences such as advanced
mathematics, history, engineering, physics, chemistry,
or biology. As well as addressing scientific problems,
a character may also apply their knowledge to create
mechanical tools, non-magical elixirs, and even use
their knowledge of science to conduct investigations
such as an autopsy to determine clues.
It may also be purchased
separately for a specific
field of study, allowing for
a more indepth knowldge
of that field than the
general version of this
skill allows for.

Crafting Quality Items
Whan attempting to craft an item with a non-magical
quality bonus, the Difficulty of crafting the item
is Hard. For each additional Non-magical quality
bonus, the Difficulty is increased by another step.
The price of items with such bonuses, when sold by a
merchant, is multiplied by x3 for each +1 (i.e. x3 for a
+1, x6 for +2, x9 for +3, etc.)
53

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

~Spellcraft~

~Mana Points~

This category represents your character’s skill in magic.
Every School of Magic is treated as a separate Skill Category,
so if you have Vocations with 2 different Schools of Magic,
their Development Points (DPs) for the Spellcraft Skill
Cateogry cannot be shared, unless following the guidelines
for Shifting DPs (p. 48).
The character’s actual Vocational Kits will determine
which School of Magic(s) that they have access to.

Mana Points

Stats: Varies
Description: This skill represents the character’s ability
to draw upon and use Mana to cast spells. The Stat
used with this skill is the character’s Magic Stat, as
dictated by the character’s Vocational Kits. The total
skill bonus is used, as determined in the section on
Mana Points (p. 109), to determine the total number
of Mana Points that the character has.
If a character has multiple Schools of Magic, then they
must select one School of Magic as their primary and use
the Magic Stat from that School to determine their Mana.

Spells

Stats: Varies
Description: Each Spell must be learned as a separate
skill. The Stat to be used for a Spell is the Magic Stat
that applies to the School of Magic that the Spell
comes from. Universal Spells are treated as belonging
to the character’s primary School of Magic if they have
more than one School.
If a character does not have a Vocation that grants
them access to a School of Magic, they may use Wits as
their Magic Stat.

~Languages~
Languages

Stats: None
Description: Each language is treated as 2 separate skills, one
skill for speaking (S), and one skill for reading/writing (W).
Characters may only gain a maximum of 5 ranks in any
given language skill. Refer to the Language Rank Values
table for more information on what each rank represents.
Every Kin starts with a few language ranks, some of
which are in specific Languages, and others which you
may assign as you like.

~Body~
Body

Stats: Stamina
Description: This skill represents the character’s ability to
endure physical punishment like wounds, scratches, and
pain. The Body skill bonus is used to determine the total
number of Hit Points (HPs) that the character has. This is
done by multiplying the total Body skill bonus by the Hits
x number of their Kin. You then add in their Base Hit Points
and any Bonus Hits given by any Gifts that they might have.
Please note that while taking wounds and damage
reduce a character’s current HPs during the game, it
never reduces the Body skill bonus.
Some special effects, like Soul Damage, may reduce
the total Body skill bonus of the character. If this
occurs, it will also reduce the character’s maximum
HPs. If the Body skill bonus is reduced to zero (0) or
below, the character dies immediately.

Each School of Magic is treated as a separate Skill
Category and if a character has Vocational Kits for
2 different Schools, their DPs for Spells are treated
as belonging to those separate Skill Categories.

54

Language Rank Values
Speak: Allows for basic verbal communication through
simple phrases (i.e. “Where is bathroom?”, “Safe to
eat?”, “Cost?”, “Danger ahead?”).
Read/Write: Able to recognize the language in
written form. May read or write the simplest of
passages and concepts.
Speak: Allows conversation of simple topics using
simple sentences if both parties speak slowly and
with care.
Read/Write: Allows for the reading of simple
sentences for a basic overview, but very few details
and no complex concepts. Approximately at a
third grade level.
Speak: Allows conversations equal to that of an
average native speaker of the language.
Read/Write: Allows reading of most everyday writings
and normal books. Used can write on a ninth grade
level.
Speak: True fluency. Allows for understanding
of, and conversations with the most learned of
native speakers.
Read/Write: Allows one to write at a level equal to a
college student and reading and writing ability is that
of an average level of nobility.
Speak: Complete fluency in language and closely
related dialects.
Read/Write: Allows for reading and writing
complex ideas and concepts. May also read closely
related dialects.

Special Skills

Special Skills

Minstrel

This is a collection of single acquisition skills that alter
how you use other skills, or provide you with new or unusual
uses of those skills. The Special Skills are not learned like
other skills. Every Vocation lists three Special Skills for you
to select from to help define them. You get to choose one of
the three each time you take a Vocational Kit. This means
that a first level character will start with two Special Skills.
You can also gain additional Special Skills through the
use of Milestones (p. 80) as your character progresses.
Each Special Skill also includes an example of Drive Point
(p. 79) uses that could be used with the Special Skill.
Each Special Skill may only be acquired once, unless the
skill description states otherwise.

Alertness

This grants you a +2 bonus to your Perception skill for the
purpose of making Assessment Rolls to orient yourself during
combat. You are also able to make Standard Perception rolls
whilst asleep instead of it being a Hard Perception roll, like it
would normallly be.
Drive Point: For the duration of the scene, you do not
need to make any Assessment Rolls, automatically
knowing what is happening. You are also unaffected
by surprise for this duration.

Mounted Combat
Piety
Protection
Prowler
Quick Draw

Sea Legs
Second Sight
Sharpshooter
