Cursed Heirloom
Demonic Feature
Demonic Posession
Distinctive Habit
Distinctive Looks
Ego Signature
Fumble Fingers
Hemophilia
Illiterate
Incompetent

A player may choose Drawbacks for his character to gain
extra Background Points (BPs) for his character. Each Drawback
provides the character with one or more Background Points to
spend on Background options. A character may never gain
more than 3 Background Points from Drawbacks, even if they
take or later acquire more Drawbacks.
The Drawback must actually affect the character or it
does not provide any Background Points. For example, if a
Warrior takes the Physical Investment Drawback, he would
receive no BP from it since he does not cast spells.

Animal Mark
Gain 1 BP: The character has been marked so that one type
of animal will automatically be hostile in the presence
of the characters. The type of animal should not be
one that the character encounters daily, such as a
mount used by the character or his companions, but
it should not be rare either
Example: The character has taken the Shapechanger
Gift and this Drawback to help defer the cost. He
has chosen dogs. This means that any time he
encounters dogs, they will automatically growl and
bark at him as long as they can smell him.

1 — Paranoid

2 — Psychotic Temper

1 — Unlucky
1 — Vampyric Healing

Bloodlust
Gain 1 BP: The character has an addiction to the taste of
blood. He must drink a pint of blood at least once a
week or suffer a -2 to all actions until he is able to do
so. The penalty increases by -1 for every week that he
goes without drinking it.

Animal Spook
Gain 2 BP: The character’s scent scares nearby animals. Any
animals within 10’ of the character will be spooked by
him, scared and wanting to get away from him. This
means that the character receives a -4 to any actions
involving animals, such as Riding. If the animal is forced
to be within 30’ of the character for 24 hours, that
modifier, for those animals only, will be reduced to -2.

Chivalrous
Gain 1 BP: The character character has a strict Code of Honor
and will always fight in a chivalrous manner, meaning that
they will always give sentient foes the initiative on the first
round of combat. They will never fight from horseback if
their foe is on foot, and they will always allow a foe to pick
up their weapon if they drop it. If asked for it, they will
always grant quarter, accepting the surrender of the foe
and always treating them honorably.
Breaking this code means that the character can no
longer receive Drive points normally until they have
achieved Redemption (a Milestone). They may still receive
Drive for exceptional circumstances (GM’s determination).

Bleeder
Gain 1 BP: All Bleeding damage received by the character
is increased by 1 point.

Blood Guilt

Cold Skin

Gain 1 BP: The character experiences severe guilt (-4 to all
actions for 2d10 days) if he causes the death or injury
of a member of any sentient Kin. This occurs starting
right after whatever combat or situation that causes
the character to hurt or kill another is ended.

Gain 1 BP: The character’s skin is cold to the touch and this
often has the unfortunate effect of the character being
mistaken for dead if sleeping, or undead if he is awake.

73

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Craven Bloodline

Distinctive Habit

The renowned misdeeds of your ancestors, family or even
from your own, distant past continue to haunt you. People
have heard of your reputation, and they don’t like it.
Gain 1 BP: You are shunned by members of society. You
may select a normally friendly civilized society that
knows of your reputation and include the reasons
within your Passions. You receive a -4 penalty when
socially interacting with people from this society.

Gain 1 BP: The character has a distinctive physical habit
that he performs continually. This makes him
immediately identifiable since he cannot control
it. This could be defined as a twitch, a hand or arm
gesture, a specific noise that he makes uncontrollably,
or anything else that makes him readily identifiable.
The character would have to make a Will Save Roll
against his own level to not make the noise for a full
minute. To keep the habit under control longer will
requiring making a new Save Roll each minute, with
the level of the Save increasing by one each time.

Gain 3 BP: You are not welcome in many places, not just
the society you have chosen. Within your chosen
society, people will refuse to trade with you, offer you
any charity or help, and treat you with utter disdain.
Your reputation is so far-reaching that you suffer a -4
penalty to any social interactions with anyone who
recognizes you and is not your immediate ally.

Distinctive Looks
Gain 1 BP: The character has a prominent scar or some
other unique physical feature that is impossible to
mistake. This makes him instantly recognizable to
somebody who has seen him or had him described.

Cursed Heirloom

You have either inherited a cursed, ancient artifact or
acquired it under unusual circumstances. Whatever it is, it
continues to hinder you.
Gain 1 BP: Choose an item in your character’s starting
equipment. The item is cursed and applies a -2 penalty
to all Save Rolls whilst it is in your possession. The
curse is so strong that breaking it or destroying the
item will require much more than simple Spells (GM
discretion). Give the item a name and an origin. The
Cursed heirloom may also be an Ancient Heirloom if
that Background Option is also chosen.

Ego Signature
Gain 1 BP: The character is unable to do anything
anonymously. He must always sign his work (i.e. like
the mark of Zorro).

Fumble Fingers
Gain 1 BP: The character is clumsier than the average
person. HIs Critical Failure range is increased
by 1. This stacks with any Critical Failure range
adjustments from the Gift, Strange Wyrd, as well as
any CF adjustments for specific weapons.

Gain 3 BP: The item is connected to a great evil somehow.
Whenever the item is used in a task requiring a Skill Roll,
if the player rolls double on the dice, the GM must roll
on the Magical Resonance table and apply the results.

Hemophilia
Gain 1 BP: Anytime anyone attempts to stop any bleeding
you have using a Healing skill roll, it is made with a
-4 modifier.

Demonic Feature
Gain 1 BP: The character gains one easily identifiable
demonic feature, such as a forked tongue, cloven
hooves instead of feet, red scaly skin, small horns
growing from their head, or something similar. This
will make people automatically wary; if not afraid of
the character should they spot this feature.

Illiterate

You cannot read or write for some reason. Gain 1 BP:
You lose the 3 ranks of Written in your native language that
were originally gained from your Kin.
Gain 3 BP: You have a learning disability that makes reading
and writing more difficult. Each rank of of Written in a
language costs 2 Development Points per rank.

Demonic Possession
Gain 2 BP: The GM rolls 2d10 once for every week of game
time. On a result of 2, the character is possessed by
a demon (the GM) for 1d10 hours. The character
will never remember what happens during this time,
believing that he only just blacked out, unless the
demon wants him to.

Incompetent
Gain 1 BP: Decrease the total value of a Stat of your choice
by 1. Add a title, moniker, or epithet that describes the
trait you are known for to your name (i.e. Elon the
Clumsy, Mark the Ugly, etc).

74

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Lycanthropy

Nightstalker

Gain 3 BP: Your character has contracted lycanthropy.
Choose a Medium-sized wild animal, like a wolf,
a boar, or a mountain lion or other predator. You
change uncontrollably on the nights of the full moon.
You also change if you fail a Will Save Roll against
your own level any time you are injured. The level
that you are saving against is increased if you receive
a Critical Result as well. The level increases by double
the number of Success Levels earned in the attack.
Example: You are level 3 and you receive damage
from an attack. The attack spent 3 Success Levels
(SL) on a Critical Result against you. So, instead of
making a Save roll versus level 3, which would have
happened if you took just hit damage, you have to
save versus level 9 (3 [your level] + 6 [double the SL
that the attack earned]).
Upon changing, you receive a -10 to all mentally
based skills and are in a completely frenzied state,
referred to as Bestial Fury, attacking those nearest you,
even if they are friends, should you fail a Perception
roll and thus not recognize them as such.
You revert to your normal form if you are Incapacitated
or you succeed at a Perception roll (at -10) and there are
no enemies while controlled by Bestial Fury.
While in your alternative form, you have the AR, DM,
and natural physical abilities and attack types of that
form. When making attacks, you use either either your
Brawl skill bonus with a +2 modifier, or the alternative
form’s attack bonuses, whichever is higher. Perception
will use either the alternative form’s Roguery skill or
your Perception skill (with a +2 modifier), whichever is
higher. You are not able to speak or cast spells while in
your alternative form.
For every 3 levels that you have (3, 6, 9, etc), your
alternative form gains +1 level, up to double its starting
level. Each level grants a +2 to skills (including attacks) and
Saves; and +10 to Hit Points; it also grants a +1 to DM.

Gain 2 BP: The character has a negative reaction to
daylight. They receive a -2 modifier to all actions and
activities when operating outside during the day, if
the day is not overcast.

Paranoid
Gain 1 BP: The character is distrustful and believes that
everybody is out to get him. He must make a Will
Save Roll against his own level in order to suppress
this long enough to get through situations where
such accusations could be considered insults.
Gain 3 BP: The character is distrustful and believes that
everybody is out to get him. He must make a Will Save
Roll against his own level +5 (i.e. a level 2 character
has roll against a level 7 attack) in order to suppress
this long enough to get through situations where
such accusations could be considered insults.

Passive
Gain 2 BP: The character receives a -3 to attack rolls until
he gets worked up. The character makes a Will Save
Roll against his own level + 3 (i.e. a level 2 character
has roll against a level 5 attack) to get worked up
enough to get rid of the modifier. He may make a
Save Roll each round until he does pass one. If the
character does a Full Parry, his attack roll would still
get the -3 modifier.

Phobia
Gain 1 BP: The character has a fear of a specific, common
thing (e.g., fire, large crowds, blood, etc.), circumstance
(e.g., heights, drowning, tight places, etc.) or creature
(e.g., snakes, rats, spiders, the undead, etc.). The
character is at -4 to all actions when in the presence
of the phobia. For example, a phobia of spiders would
mean that the character is at -4 to attack enemies who
use spider symbology on their shields or clothing. A
successful Will Save Roll against his own level will
allow the character to attack with a -2 modifier instead.
Every three points that the Save Roll is made by will
decrease the modifier by another 1 point.

Naïve Outlook
Gain 1 BP: Whether through inexperience or your general
outlook, you are not prepared for the evils of the
world. This causes you to suffer a -2 penalty to Will
Save Rolls.

Example: A first level character making a Save Roll
against a level 1 attack requires an 21 or higher.
They have a +1 to their Save Roll from their level,
and the character gets a +3 from their Resolve, and
the +7 base for their Save, giving them a +11 total.
This means that they have to roll a 10 or higher to
succeed. If he rolls a 14 (total of 24), the modifier is
reduced to -1, if he rolls a 16 (total of 27, 6 points
above success), the modifier is reduced to 0.

Necromatic Legacy
Gain 1 BP: Upon death, the character will become a GM
controlled intelligent undead, often a less form of
lich, vampire spawn (Vampyri), skeleton or zombie.
The character knows this and so will all undead
encountered, who will seek to speed him along to his
destiny. The character must make a Will Save versus
the level of the undead when encountering undead in
any form or be unable to get within 5’ of them, due to
his natural revulsion to such a fate.
75

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Physical Investment

Terrible Fearlessness

Gain 1 BP: This Drawback is limited to those with at least one
Arcane or Hybrid Kit only. Any time that the character
casts a spell, he will take an amount of Hit Point damage
equal to the number of Mana Points he must spend to
cast the spell. The Hit Point damage is in addition to
the expenditure of Mana Points, not instead of.

Gain 1 BP: When present with a situation involving melee
combat, the character must make a Will Save Roll
against his own level or rush heedless into the combat.

Unlucky
Gain 1 BP: When bad things happen, they seem to happen
to you more severely. Whenever you receive a Critical
Failure an attack or spellcasting roll, you add +2 to
any Fumble rolls for it.

Poor Control
Gain 1 BP: This Drawback is limited to those with at least
one Arcane or Hybrid Kit only. The character receives
a +2 modifier to any Spell Failure rolls that they are
required to make.

Vampyric Healing
Gain 1 BP: The character does not heal naturally. He may only
heal naturally by drinking the blood of others. Drinking
a pint of blood from a living person or creature will
allow the character to heal normally for the next 8
hours. Healing spells and herbs and other magical forms
of healing will work normally on the character.

Prejudice
Gain 1 BP: The character has a deep, irrational hatred for
one non-player-character Kin. When encountering
a member of that Kindred, the character will grow
angry and want to attack them in any fashion that
he can.

Wanted Criminal
Gain 1 BP: The character is wrongly accused of an
extremely serious crime in the city or country where
the campaign begins. While he is not being actively
hunted, any encounters with law enforcement may
result in them recognizing him and attempting to
arrest him for this crime. The player should work with
the GM to determine what the crime is and whether or
not clearing his name is one of the character’s Passions.

Psychotic Temper
Gain 1 BP: The character must make a Will Save Roll or he
will respond to any perceived insult or offence with
attempts to immediately kill the offender in a fit of rage.

Scaly Skin
Gain 2 BP: The character suffers from a rare skin condition
resulting in his skin appearing scaly. This provides no
benefits and results in a -2 to all Charisma based skill rolls
and Reaction Rolls.

Wrath
Gain 1 BP: The character has earned the disfavor of a
particular god, demi-god, demon, or devil. The
followers and servants of that being will attack the
character whenever the opportunity presents itself,
but they are not actively seeking him. The player
should work with the GM to determine which entity
is after the character and why.

Split Personality
Gain 3 BP: The character has from 1 to 3 (roll 1d10, divide by 3,
round) additional personalities (so 2 to 4 personalities in
total). The player should create a character sheet for each
one. All stats and abilities, including Background Options,
Kin and Culture remain the same. Vocations, Passions,
and skill development can all be different. The character
will randomly change personalities if they fail a Will Save
Roll, which should be made in any stressful situation,
any time that they take damage, and with the rising or
setting of the sun. Any experience earned is split as evenly
as possible between the personalities that took part in the
adventures that gained the experience, with any left overs
going to the primary personality. The personalities may
or may not know about each other. It depends upon the
back story that the player comes up with to explain them.
The personalities should never be similar to one another,
they will usually be very different from one another.

Gain 3 BP: The character has earned the disfavor of a
particular god, demi-god, demon, or devil. The
followers and servants of that being will attack the
character at every opportunity and will actively seek
him out. The player should work with the GM to
determine which entity is after the character and why.

Note: This Drawback is very difficult to role play, and one
should only take it with extreme caution.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Passions & Drives

Passions

•• The love for my family drives me forward.
•• I will my companion and master, Eoin, wherever our
paths will lead us.
Motivation is what pushes the character forth. A goal set
in either the near future, or in some distant future.
It could be a personal belief, a strong conviction or a
burning desire to accomplish their goal. Here are a few
examples of Motivations that we hope inspire you:
•• I will find the fabled Sword of Tuatha, and prove myself
worthy of wielding it.
•• I will wipe out the Goblins that burned down my village
and killed my family.
•• I will reclaim the Crown of the Realm, which was stolen
from my grandfather.

Each character in Fantasy Express is driven by their
Passions. Passions are statements that tell something really
important about the character, such as why they went
adventuring in the first place, the reason why they fight, how
they deal with difficult or dangerous situations, who they
have sworn to protect or serve or who they have decided to
fight and try to destroy. Players choose three Passions for
their characters during character creation, writing them in
the space provided on the character sheet.
There are three standard Passions in Fantasy Express:
Nature, Allegiance, and Motivation.
Nature is how the character behaves in most situations, due
to their inherent instincts, demeanor, or ethical and
philosophical convictions. Here are a few examples of
statements that could be used for Nature:
•• I will live by the laws of nature under the Silver stars.
•• Trust no one, and always have your sword ready.
•• As a Holy Knight, I am sworn to protect the meek, avenge
the wrongs, and fight Evil.
Allegiance is who the character is loyal to, loves, or on the
other hand, has sworn to destroy. Some examples of
serviceable Allegiance may include:
•• My loyalty is to my King, whom I have sworn to protect
and serve.

Choosing Passions
Passions are decided upon during character creation by
the player for their character. The player should seek input
from the other players, and input and approval from the
GM. The player should also ensure that the Passions that
they select for their character does not put them at odds
with the other players (i.e. if one player has a character that
is an Orc, none of the other players should have Passions
that say that they hate Orcs – such a character would never
join a group containing one).

77

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Drive

It is recommended that creating Passions be a collective
process involving all of the players at the table, as it allows
the players to build vibrant characters and perhaps build in
some reasons that they may be traveling together, and helps
strengthen the game overall. This helps make character
more interesting, make the players more invested, and that
makes the game better all around.
It is possible that the player has reached this point with
one or more Passions already written or with guidance from
one or more Background options about what they should
write their Passions about. If this is the case, the player
should follow that guidance from the Backgrounds.

Drive is a measure of how strongly a character is motivated
and how far they would push themselves to get what they
are after. Drive has a fluctuating value during play; it can
grow and decrease over the course of the story and even in
a single session, following the character’s actions and other
circumstances. Drive can never be less than zero (0) or more
than five (5). Every character starts play 2 points of Drive.

Increasing Drive
There are two main ways to gain Drive for your character
during play. These are not the only ways to gain Drive, just
the two most common.
To make Drawbacks more important, and not just a way
to gain extra Background Points. If a character’s Drawback
impacts play in some fashion, they gain a Drive point. This
can happen once per scene.
Drive is also increased by pushing the game forward with
the character’s Passions. Whenever characters willingly put
themselves into a dangerous situation or a challenge, put
themselves in a bad light because of one of their Passions,
or make the story go in a new and interesting direction by
following their Passion, they then get to increase their Drive
by one point, up to a maximum of five.
Example: If a character is sworn to protect the King and
jumps into battle against overwhelming forces risking
their lives to, well, protect the name of their King, then the
GM will decide to award them a point of Drive.
It is recommended that GMs be generous when it comes
to awarding Drive points. The whole purpose is to help
increase player interaction with the game and make it more
fun overall, and being generous allows that to happen. And
since there is a limit of 5 Drive points, that also encourages
the player to use them rather than hoard them, if they know
that the GM gives them out when appropriate.
Drive per Session: It is also recommended that if
a player is at the session and participates, that they
receive at least 1 Drive Point for the session. This can
be awarded at the end of the session or the beginning
of the next session.

Changing Passions
Passions will change during play. We have had you
write them down to make them easier to remember, but
they should not be treated as if they are written in stone.
Characters can change as the game progresses, just as
everyone of us has changed as our lives had progressed, in
response to the events that have happened to us over time.
Examples of possible good motivations for changing a
character’s Passions are listed below:
•• The reason why the Passion existed in the first place
ceases to be – for example when the character has
fulfilled their vengeance, or when they lose the person
they had a bond with.
•• An event during the game makes the character (and
thus the player) change their mind about their whole
belief system; such as a loyal knight discovering that
their king was actually a treacherous betrayer.
•• The character goes through a heart-rending or mindbending experience, like coming back from the dead or
literally being through Hell.
Typically Passions are changed at the end of a session
or when the store reaches a significant turning point.
Motivation is the most volatile of the Passions; character
will change it quite often, as their goals are completed, or
become irrelevant or unattainable. Allegiance should change
less frequently, requiring more solid in-game reasons and
marking an important development in the character’s bonds
and relationships. Finally, a Nature change should be a
pretty rare event, representing an extremely significant shift
in the character’s core beliefs.
Players and Game Masters are encouraged to be creative
about Passions and how and when to change and evolve
them. On the other hand, we suggest not shifting Passions
too quickly and too often, instead giving each of them a fair
try to kick in during play.

Note to the Player: When you believe that
another player has done something that was
interesting or moves the game forward, feel free
to recommend to the GM to award Drive for it.
If another player recommends the awarding of a
Drive point, and you agree with their reasoning,
then feel free to second the idea.

Code of Honor

Note to the GM: When players recommend
another player should receive a Drive point. This
shows that they are taking a good interest in the
game and in the story being told, and you should
feel free to award that point as suggested.

The Passions may be considered a character’s Code
of Honor. If a character breaks this Code of Honor,
he may no longer receive Drive per Session until
they have achieved Redemption (a Milestone). They
may still receive Drive in exceptional circumstances
(GM’s discretion).
78

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

•• Increase Spell Attributes: For 2 Drive Points, the player
may double the Area of Effect, number of Targets,
Range, Duration, or Base Damage of one of their
character’s spells before they cast it.
•• Roll Natural 20: For 3 Drive points, the player can treat
the result of any roll, before or after rolling the dice, as
if they had rolled a natural 20 on the dice. This means
that the roll will be treated as open-ended, even if it was
not normally open-ended, and they will get to make a
second roll and add it to the first.
•• Ignore Damage for a Scene: For 5 Drive points, the player
may have his character ignore all penalties to actions
from wounds and adverse Conditions (i.e. prone, dazed,
stunned, etc.) for the duration of a whole scene.
As mentioned previously, Drive can be gained through
challenging a character’s own Passions.

Spending Drive
Drive can be spent by the player to mitigate harmful
effects suffered by their character during the game, to get
another chance after failing a roll, or to perform heroic deeds
that would otherwise be impossible for them to accomplish.
A player can spend one or more points of Drive for the
following things:
•• Bonus for Entire Scene: Receive a special +2 bonus for
each Drive point spent to all rolls for the duration of
the current scene (a whole combat, a travel hazard, an
entire negotiation, etc.) Drive used in this manner only
applies to rolls made after the Drive has been spent (i.e.
the player cannot roll poorly, then decide to spend 3
Drive to get a +6 to the roll they just made; it would
only apply to the rolls made after the points were spent).
•• Reroll Failed Rolls: Reroll any failed roll, with a special
+2 bonus for every Drive point spent on this option. If
this reroll fails, the player may continue adding more
Drive, getting another roll, and adding another +2 to
the previous Drive bonus.
Example: The player makes a roll and fails, spends
1 Drive and makes a reroll with a +2, and upon
failing that one, spends another Drive, getting
another reroll, at +4 this time, since he has spent 2
Drive total. You do not have to spend only 1 Drive
point at a time, you can spend multiple to do the
reroll, getting a +2 for each Drive spent.
•• Critical Reduction: Have a Critical that you just suffered
reduced, with its severity (the number of SLs used to
determine Critical damage) decreased by 1. You can
either abide by this new result, or spend another Drive
to have it lowered by 1 again. If you reduce the number
of SL to zero, then no Critical is received. Note that while
you can do this one Drive point at a time, you can also
spend the required Drive all at once as well.
•• Critical Reduction for Entire Scene: The character may
steel themselves against potential harm. For the entire
scene the character reduces all Success Levels from attacks
made against them by 1 severity (i.e. a SL3 becomes a SL2
or a single SL becomes no SL at all).
•• Special Skills: A character may also spend one or more
Drive Points in conjunction with any Special Skills that they
know, as described in the section on Special Skills (p. 55).
•• Make Saves Harder: For each Drive point spent, the
player can impose a -2 penalty on the Save roll made
to resist the effects of a spell that his character has just
cast. This must be done before the Save roll is made.
•• Increase Success Levels: For each Drive Point spent, you
may add +1 Success Level to your total for determining
the level of success for a roll (skill, attack, casting,
etc.). This can be done either before or after the roll if
desired. If done before, the Drive is lost if the roll fails.

Heroic Path

As they carry on with their journey, character turn into
true heroes, and the tales of their exploits into the stuff
of legends. The hard choices that they make, the unlikely
situations that they survive, and the great deeds they
accomplish by following their Passions are the paving stones
of this Heroic Path that they follow, which is what separates
them from the common folk.
Whenever they spend Drive, players must mark the exact
numbers of Drive spent on the Heroic Path track on their
character sheet. Every 10 marks on their Heroic Path awards
the character with a Milestone. In other words, for every 10
points of Drive spent during the game, the character will
achieve a Milestone.

Milestones & Revelations
Characters can use a Milestone that they have earned
to have a Revelation, an enlightening moment which leads
them to learn more about themselves, and to unlock part of
their heroic potential.
A Revelation marks a very important even in a hero’s
tale and, as such, it cannot happen just anytime, but needs
particular conditions to be triggered. Characters undergoing
a Revelation need time and peace to reflect, or a suitably
dramatic event to spur the change within them.
Some examples of moments in which a Revelation can
happen are:
•• A long downtime between adventures;
•• A period of rest and recovery at a place considered to
be a safe haven;
•• A critical or cathartic moment in game, related to one
of the character’s Passions – for example, when they
break their Allegiance or accomplish they set as their
Motivation;
•• At the end of an important mission of quest.

79

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

•• Flashing Blade: Whilst unarmored and unencumbered,
a character with the Swashbuckling skill has their weapon
(Blades only) dance in their hand. When using the
Dashing Attack option, the character does not suffer
the -6 penalty to their Attack Bonus. If the character is
wearing nothing heavier than Soft Leather, he may make
use of this ability once per combat.
•• Flattery: The character gains a +2 Special Bonus to
Influence and Deceive skill rolls when attempting to use
these skills against a target that is in authority, vain, or
who may be physically attracted to them.
•• Furious Charge: The character may make a skill roll
to enter a Battle Frenzy or Fury as a Free Action when
they make a Charge at an opponent. Additionally,
movement rate when charging at an opponent over
Rough Terrain is made at full move (not halved).
•• Heavier Armor: The character reduces all types of penalties
for wearing armor and using shields by 1 point. This may be
gained multiple times, but it can never raise those modifiers
above a zero (i.e. they erase the penalties, including
minimums, only). This is before the Armor skill is applied.
•• Hit & Run: The character may move (Half Movement)
and Aim (p. 125) a missile weapon in the same round,
without penalty. The character may only move once for
each missile that they fire in a given round.
•• Improved Health: You have discovered how to gain a +1
to your Kin’s Hits Multiplier. While this can be acquired
multiple times, the Hits Multiplier cannot be raised
beyond a maximum of x5.
•• Inspirational Leader: The character is an inspiration to
allies and those they command. Any allies who can see the
character gain a +1 bonus Leadership rolls and to Save rolls
against becoming Frightened. This inspiration is lost if the
character is knocked unconscious or not in control of their
own mind. This may be acquired up to 5 times.
•• Iron Strikes: The character’s unarmed attacks are
considered to be made of iron when attacking creatures
with weaknesses against iron. They also gain +1 damage
to their unarmed attacks.
•• Item Upgrade: This Milestone may be gained multiple
times. You are able to improve an item that you are
carrying an about which you have written a Passion, by
selecting one of the following options:
•• Increase the modifier the item grants by +1 (up to
a maximum of +5);
•• Allow the item to grant a +2 modifier to a single
appropriate non-combat skill of their choosing or
increase that bonus by +1 (up to a maximum of +5);
•• Swap out a spell that the item allows the character
to cast a number of times per day with a Scaled
Up version of the same spell, up to 3 Tiers higher
than the existing spell; or with a different spell, up
to 2nd Tier, from the same School;
•• Increase the number of times that the item’s
power can be activated each day by one, if the Tier
of the spell it allows the character to cast is equal
to or lower than the character’s level.

Milestones
If the GM agrees that the moment is right, a player can
spend a Milestone to trigger a Revelation, choosing one of the
following options for their character. Unless its description
states otherwise, a specific Milestone may only be gained once.
•• All The Tricks: The character knows all the tricks in the
book. This allows them to gain a special +1 bonus (+5
maximum) to Conflicting Actions when resisting Martial
Moves made against them. This Milestone may be taken
once for every 5 ranks they have in the Swashbuckling skill.
•• Beast Combat: The character is able to use their
understanding of animals to mimic their actions in combat
increasing the damage of their unarmed attacks by +1. This
Milestone may be taken once for every 5 ranks they have in
the Beastmastery skill.
•• Beast Senses: A character that has 10 skill ranks in the
Beastmastery skill is able to use their understanding of
animals to hone their senses, increasing their Perception
skill bonus by 2. If they do not already have it, they gain
Night Sight (p. 205) to half the normal ranges listed.
•• Beast Voice: A character with 10 ranks in the Beastmastery
skill is able to use their understanding of animals to mimic
them flawlessly, gaining +2 for communicating with
animals and beasts. If the character has the Gift, Animal
Speech, or some similar abilty, this gives them 1 free rank in
any of the animal languages that they know.
•• Bodyguard Reactions: The character may move up to
half their movement towards an ally as a Free Action, if
that ally is engaged in combat and the character has not
yet used their Free Action this round. This movement
may be taken outside of the normal Initiative order.
•• Brutish Reputation: The character may use their
Brawn stat in place of their Charisma stat when making
Intimidation skill rolls.
•• Change Vocation: You may swap out the Development
Points (DPs) that you receive from one Vocational Kit, to
those of another Vocational Kit. You do not gain any of the
skill ranks or Special Skills from the new Vocational Kit, only
the DPs to spend the next time you gain a new level. Spells
to be learned from the new Kit require Eldritch Training to
remove the Different School ASF Modifier (p. 135).
•• Defensive Fighter: If the character uses at least 2 points
of their Attack Bonus to Parry, they gain an additional
special bonus of +2 to their Defensive Modifier.
•• Dual Parry: If the character has Dual Weapons or Two
Weapon Combo, Parries against a single foe have the
subtractions from each weapon apply separately to
their Defensive Modifier (i.e. Subtracting 3 from each
weapon, gives +6 to DM, not +3).
•• Eldritch Defense: The character is so familiar with the
working of attack spells that they gain a +2 Special
Bonus to their Defensive Modifier against any physical
attack spell from any School of Magic.
•• Eldritch Training: The character treats one School of
Magic as if it were their own School of Magic. This
requires that the character first Change Vocations to one
that gives access to that School.
80

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

•• Look Out: The Specialty Skill, Evasion, may be used
to warn allies of impending danger. If the character
is successful in his Conflicting Actions roll, it allows
all allies within 30’ of the character to also gain the
benefits of his success. The character must be able to
communicate a warning to the allies.
•• Magical Boost: You are able to increase your total
Mana Points by 3. This Milestone may be gained up to
a maximum of five times in total.
•• More Force, Less Thought: The character increases their
Brawn Statistic by +2 but must reduce their choice of
one of the following Statistics by 1: Charisma, Insight,
Wits, or Resolve.
•• Mounted Attack: The character may force their mount to
make an attack in combat, even if the mount is not battle
trained. This requires that the character make a successful
Ride skill roll (requires a Half Action), and the attack uses
the mount’s stats. If the character’s mount is battle trained,
then it only requires a Free Action to make the Ride skill roll
to control the mount’s attack.
•• Multi-Parry: A character with a Swashbuckling skill
rank equal ot greater than their level may parry
multiple attackers as if they were Parrying a Single Foe
for how points of AB are shifted to DM (-1 AB = +1
DM against all foes.)
•• Mystic Strikes: The character’s unarmed attacks are
considered to be magical for the purpose of being
able to strike creatures that can only be hit by magical
weapons. Requires that the character already have the
Silver Strikes Milestone.
•• Outrageous Claims: The character gains a +2 modifier to
his Influence skill when making any trading related rolls,
such as on the Commerce Table (p. 226). If the trade is
a con, the patsy (whomever it is) will realize shortly
afterwards. Depending on who performed the con, this
could have repercussions for the character and his friends.
•• Pump You Up: You follow a special training regimen that
grants you a special +2 bonus to your Body skill bonus,
and increases your Hit Points by an additional +10 Hits
on top of any increase to the Body skill.
•• Redemption: The character has redeemed thier honor by
performing a penance (GM & player should determine
what this entails). He may now normally receive Drive
per Session once more. This Milestone may be acquired
more than once.
•• Silver Strikes: The character’s unarmed attacks are
considered to be silver for the purpose of being able to strike
creatures that can only be hit by silver weapons. Requires
that the character already have the Iron Strikes Milestone.
•• Sniper: If the character has the Special Skill, Ambush,
then any one Missile weapon that the character uses is
treated as having the Backstab quality. This Milestone
may be acquired for a different weapon each time.
•• Special Training: You have found a special teacher, and
you gain 1 Special Skill of your choice. This Milestone
may be acquired more than once.

•• Spell Aggression: The character gains a +1 to their
Attack Bonus on any attack spells that are against a
target’s Defensive Modifier. This Milestone may be
acquired up to a maximum of five times.
•• Stat Increase: Increase one Stat of their choice by 1,
permanently. The chosen stat may not be increased above
normal Kindred maximums (6 +/- Kindred modifier).
This Milestone may be acquired more than once.
•• Swift Travel: Gain +5 miles per day Overland
Movement when travelling alone or +3 miles per day
when travelling in a small group.
•• Tricky Combatant: The character adds the number of
ranks (purchased, Culture, and Vocational) they have in
the Deceive skill as a bonus to their attack bonus when
performing the attack portion of a Feint (p. 131).
•• Uncovered Secrets: The character has learned the secrets
of a spell from outside their normal Codex or Folio.
One spell that normally receives an Abnormal Spell
Failure (ASF) due to being one not normally learnable
has that ASF modifier removed. This Milestone may be
acquired more than once.
•• Vicious Attack: If the character has the Special Skill,
Ambush, then any one 1-handed weapon that uses the
Blades Skill or any one Unarmed attack that the character
uses is treated as having the Backstab quality. This may
be acquired for a different weapon/attack each time.
•• Weak Spot: If the character has the Special Skill,
Ambush, then the character can utilize the Backstab
quality of weapons against targets in natural armor.
While the final choice is up to the player and the GM, it
does not hurt to get input from the rest of the group, and if
at all possible the Revelation should be related to the events
that led up to the Revelation itself if possible.
The player should feel free to take a brief moment to
narrate their character’s actions during the Revelation,
keeping in mind that this should not require any rolls.
However, if it does introduce a new element that the GM can
later use to further the story, then the GM might consider
granting a Drive point for this.
Once chosen, the Revelation should be recorded on the
character sheet and it takes effect immediately.

Passing the Torch
If a character dies, half of their Heroic Path marks
(rounded up) are passed to the next character made by
that player for that same campaign. So, for example, if a
character with 11 marks on their Heroic Path dies, the next
character created by the player of that character will start
with 6 marks.
If the character sacrificed themselves for the good of
their companions, or if their death was deemed particularly
heroic by the group, all of their Heroic Path marks are
transferred instead.
If this is enough to gain one or more Milestones, the
player can spend them before introducing the new character
into the game.
81

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Equipment

The next step in character creation is to purchase any
equipment you think that your character needs. You got a
small list of equipment with your Vocation. This was done
to make things easier for the players overall. You also gained
some money along the way as well.

Coinage Standards

Coin
Abbr. Breakdown
1 Platinum piece pp = 10 Gold Pieces
1 Gold piece
gp = 10 Silver pieces
1 Silver piece
sp = 10 Bronze pieces
1 Bronze piece
bp = 10 Copper pieces (cp)

Money

Equipment

Even though each group/nation very likely has its own
unique coins, the weights and values were established long
ago by various Kins and groups that excelled in trading, so
that the coins from varying nations and groups are equivalent
enough to be used interchangeably. All coins are designed so
that 50 coins of any type weigh a single pound. The following
table shows the basic Coinage Standards that are used.
Also, the common names of the coins (copper pieces,
bronze pieces, etc) are not from the materials that they are
made of, but from the colors of the coins themselves. The
actual metallurgical composition of the coins are a closely
held secret that only a few smiths know.
In Anwyn it is possible to find coins from many strange
and foreign realms and those coins cannot actually be spent.
They are usually purchased by collectors of oddities or by
metal smiths who plan on smelting them down to create
other things with the materials that the coins are made from.

The following lists and their accompanying notes
represent only a portion of the type of things that may
be purchased. These lists are geared specifically towards
supplying the most pressing needs and requirements of
adventurers, so they do not include everything that might
be available. The GM is free to add to and expand these lists
as he sees fit.

82

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Adventuring Equipment

Adventuring Equipment

This section is essentially a catch-all for anything that
does not easily fall within another section. The tables
include a “Source” column, providing the type of merchant
or vendor that the item can be found at.
Armor Repair Kit – There are several versions of this
kit, one for each different type of armor. Some kits
contain heavy bone needles and heavy thread for
sewing back up tears, while the one for chain might
carry replacement rings. These kits are designed to
keep the type of armor that they are for serviceable
until they can be properly repaired or replaced.
Arrow Straightener – Made of bone, this will be able to
straighten any arrow on a roll of 10 or higher on 2d10
(no skill involved).
Arrows – Sold in a bundle of 12. Most arrows either need
straightening after use against live targets (as opposed
to practice targets)
Axe, Wood – A Wood Axe is meant for chopping wood.
The head of the Wood Axe is designed differently
than that of a weapon. While it might serve as one in
a pinch, it would be treated as a Battle Axe (-2 to the
Damage Rating).
Backpack – Can hold up to 2 cubic feet worth of items that
have a maximum weight of 40 lbs. It is water resistant.
Balance & Weights – This comes in a small wooden box.
It contains a set of small balance scales and a set of
weights that are used to determine the weights of
objects. The weights come in units of 1, 2, and 4
drams, 1, 2, 4, and 8 ounces, and 1 lb.
Beadroll, Heavy – Made for use in cold weather.
Bedroll, Light – Made for use in warmer weather.
Bit & Bridle – Made of leather and metal. The bridle is a
leather harness that slips over the head of the mount,
with the bit, a metal bar, sitting in the back of its
mouth. Attached to the bridle, where it connects to
the bit are two long strips of leather used to control
the direction that the mount goes.

Bowstring, Bow – This is a spare bowstring ready to strung on
the bow. They come in different sizes, based on the bow.
Bowstring, Crossbow – This is a spare bowstring ready to
strung on the crossbow. They come in different sizes,
based on the crossbow.

Blanket, Heavy – This is a heavy wool and fur blanket,
used to keep warm in colder weather.
Blanket, Light – This is a light cotton blanket, used on nights
that tend to be cooler than the days in warmer weather.

Caltrops – Sold in groups of 5, these are sharp little twists
of metal, about half an inch in size. Stepping on one
causes 1 Hit of damage.

Bone – This is a one pound length of bone used for carving.
Bone carving is called Scrimshaw.

Camp Cookware – Made of a lightweight metal, this is a
set of nested dishes, including 2 small pans, 2 small
bowls, 2 plates, and a small metal cup. When all
nested, they take up a small 6” diameter x 2” deep
cylinder of space.

Bow Case – This is a leather case used for storing a bow
when it is not in use. It is water resistant to help
protect it from the weather.

83

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Fishing Kit – Contains line, hook, and even a few glass
and/or cork floats.

Candles, Tallow – Tallow is a rendered form of animal fat.
It is used in things like making soap, ointments, in
cooking, and in the making of candles. A one pound
candle made from tallow will burn for a maximum of
8 hours total.

Fishing Line – Sold in lengths that are multiples of 10’, this
is a strong string that can be used in fishing in lakes
and rivers. It is usually used by attaching it to a long
supple stick to use as a fishing rod.

Candle, Calibrated – These wax candles have been calibrated
so that each section of the candle will last 1 hour. Each
candle has 8 usable, calibrated sections. Most candles
of this type use a different color wax for each hour.

Flask (glass) – This is a small glass flask that holds up to
1 pint of liquid. It comes with a cork (called subin in
Anwyn) stopper.

Candles, Beeswax – Beeswax candles burn cleanly, without
the smoke generated by a tallow candle. Beeswax
candles are often mixed with other ingredients to
help scent the air. A one pound beeswax candle will
burn for up to 12 hours.

Flask (metal) – This is a small metal flask with a screw on
top. It can hold up to 1 pint of liquid.
Framepack – This is similar to a backpack, except that it
is larger and has a lightweight rigid internal frame to
help it hold its shape. It can hold up to 5 cubic feet of
material that weigh up to a maximum of 100 lbs. The
pack is water resistant.

Chain, Heavy – This is a sturdy chain that can support of
up to 400 lbs of weight. The price listed is for each
foot of length required. Heavy Chain weighs 4 lbs for
each foot of length.

Gauntlet, Falconer’s – This is a heavy leather gauntlet that
covers the entire forearm. The heaviest portion is
along the forearm where a falcon would perch.

Chain, Light – This is a sturdy chain that can support of
up to 150 lbs of weight. The price listed is for each
foot of length required. Light Chain weighs 1 lb for
each foot of length.

Glass Beads – These are small glass beads about half an inch
in diameter. They are hollow and have a small hole on
one side that can be sealed with wax. The bead can
hold up to an ounce of powder or liquid. While they
can handle a little jostling, they are fragile enough that
they will shatter upon impact. Slingshot users often
use these to deliver various substances at a distance.

Chisel – These come in several shapes and relative sizes,
but they are often used for chipping stone
Compass – This is a shallow brass cup, about 2 inches in
diameter, with a glass lid. Inside is liquid which holds
a sliver of metal around a central spike. This sliver
can freely rotate around this spike, and one end, often
painted red in color, will always swing north, or to
other large magnetic sources, if they are within range.

Grappling Hook, Collapsible – Devised by a Gnomish
tinker, this is metal tube, with for hooks that fold out
from the one end of the tube to create the grappling
hook. It can support up to 150 lbs.

Cosmetics Kit – This is a small case holding several
different cosmetics such as rouge and kohl (often
used as an eye shadow) and lip coloring. It usually
has enough cosmetics for 3 applications.

Grappling Hook, Heavy – Made from heavy metal, it can
support up to 300 lbs of weight.

Crossbow bolts – Shorter and sturdier than arrows,
crossbow bolts are sold in lots of 12.
Disguise Kit – This kit contains a number of things that
can be used to craft disguises. Using it grants a +3
bonus to any skill rolls for making a disguise.

Grappling Hook, Light – Smaller than the Heavy Grappling
Hook, this will support up to 150 lbs of weight.

Feathers – This is a small sack of feathers that have been
prepared for use as fletching on arrows and crossbow
bolts. The feathers have already been dried and trimmed.

Hatchet, Wood – Made for chopping wood, not as a
weapon, it could still be used as one, but with a -2 to
the amount of damage it deals.

Fire-starting bow – This is sometimes called a Bow Drill.
A bow drill is a simple hand-operated type of tool,
consisting of a rod that is set in rapid rotary motion
by means of a cord wrapped around it, kept taut by a
bow which is pushed back and forth with one hand.

Hideworking Kit, Portable – This kit contains trimming
blades and scrapers as well as several smaller
containers of preserving agents, to allow a hunter or
adventurer to preserve hides long enough to be able
to get them to a professional hideworker.

First Aid Bag – This is a leather bag with a a dozen bandages,
splints, and a number of herbal ointments that help
prevent infection. It also includes a couple of bone
needles and some fine thread for sewing wounds shut.

Ink – This is a viscous liquid that is used to write on other
materials, such as parchment or vellum that also dries
quickly and stays legible for an extended period of
time. It is sold in small metal flasks that hold one pint
of ink. These small flasks are then often used to fill
small inkwells.
84

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Mirror, Steel – This is a small 4” round piece of polished and
silvered steel. It makes for a sturdy and versatile mirror.

Mortar & Pestle – This is a small bowl, called a mortar,
made out of hardwood or stone, such as granite. The
pestle, a small, heavy club-like object is used to grind
items in the mortar to the desired consistency.
Multi-Tool – This is a collection of items that may be
assembled in a number of different configurations.
It consists of 3 poles, each 2’ long, with 1” diameter
metal end caps. The end caps are threaded on one
end, and form a socket on the other, so that the poles
may be screwed together. In addition to the poles, the
Multi-Tool comes with a dagger head, a hatchet head,
a hammer head, a shovel head and 3 torch heads.
The torch heads have metal bases with a special
material in the cup-shaped base. This material is
wrapped in parchment and when lit will burn for 6
hours, lighting a 20’ diameter area. The torch heads
can be replaced for 1 bp each (5 bp if you do not have
a used torch head to exchange).
In addition to torches, this allows the Multi-Tool to
also be used as a shovel, a hammer (or a make-shift
war hammer), a hatchet or axe for chopping wood,
or even as a staff or spear. When the poles are used
to create weapons, any such weapon created has a -3
modifier. The Multi-Tool was designed by a Gnome
adventurer after he retired from adventuring.
Oil, Lamp – A single pint of oil can burn for up to 32 hours
in a lantern.
Paper Case, Leather – This is a hard leather case that can
hold up to 30 sheets of parchment or papyrus, or up
to 40 sheets of vellum.
Papyrus – Papyrus is a thick sheet of paper made from
various vegetable matter. It is cheaper than Parchment
or Vellum, but also more fragile as it will devolve into a
mush if gotten wet. The price is the cost of a single page.
Parchment – Parchment is a writing material made
from specially prepared untanned skins of animals;
primarily sheep, calves, and goats. The price is the
cost for a single page.

Inkwell – This is a small heavy copper container that holds
between one and two ounces of liquid, such as ink.
The container has a wide mouth to allow for the easy
use of pens to transfer the ink from pen to parchment.

Pegs/Stakes (10) – These are solid wooden stakes, about 8
inches long. They are used by hammering them into
the ground to attach lines from tents or other items,
to help hold them down. They are sold in lots of 10.

Lantern, Large – This is a metal and glass construct, with a
wick that feeds down into a reservoir that hold up to
a pint of oil at a time. It has a flat bottom, and s small
metal handle. It can illuminate up to a 50’ radius.

Pen (metal) – Developed by a Gnome tinker, this metal pen
has a small lever on the side, which allows the pen to
draw in a small reservoir of ink into the pen itself, thus
allowing for more continuous writing between refills.

Lantern, Small – This is a smaller version of the Large
Lantern. Its reservoir holds up to half a pint of oil
and can illuminate up to a 30’ radius.
Lock Pick Kit – This is a flat leather wallet that contains up
to 2 dozen picks and probes of various lengths. Using
a kit such as this grants a +1 bonus to the Gimmickry
skill when attempting to pick locks.

Pen (wood or quill) – These are either thin wooden
styluses or dried feather quills. They are sold in lots
of 12 since they wear out fairly quickly.

85

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Pick, Mining – This is a mining pick, with a heavy head
with a point on either side. While not designed as a
weapon, it can be used as one in a pinch. If used as
a weapon, it would be treated as a Battle Axe (-2),
except that it does puncture criticals).

Pipe, Smoking – This is a small carved wooden bowl with
a stem coming out in one side. It is used for smoking
pipeweed.
Pipeweed – This is made from the leaves of the tobacco
plant. It is priced and sold in one ounce lots.
Pitons/Stakes (10) – Similar to Pegs, these are made from
metal, which allow them to be driven into harder
surfaces, including into stone. They include rings
near the end that gets hammered to attach lines to.
They are sold in lots of 10.
Portable Shrine – This is a small box, about 6’ by 8” by
4” deep. It contains a small idol or religious symbol
and a tile to use in burning offerings to the deity in
question. This would be purchased from the temple
to which the shrine is dedicated.
Quick Release – Used to allow fast and easy, one-handed
removal of a backpack or framepack. Removal of
a pack requires only a Snap Action and may be
performed at the same time as other actions, so long
as the character has one hand free. It takes 2 minutes
(24 rounds) to put on a pack that has a Quick Release.
Quiver, Large – This is a large stiff leather tube, closed at
one end. It is made to be worn across the wearer’s
back. It can hold up to a maximum of 24 arrows.
Quiver, Small – This is smaller, thinner tube of stiff leather
tube that holds up to 12 arrows, or crossbow bolts. It
can be worn across the back or attached to a belt and
worn at the hip.
Razor, Shaving – This is a sharpened metal blade that fold
in half so that the sharp end is encased within the
wooden or bone handle when not in use. It is used
for shaving.

Saddle – This is a leather seat that is used for riding on
various types of mounts. It is designed differently
for each type of mount. It supports and cushions
the rider, allowing him to maintain a faster pace
and to ride for longer distances. It also helps protect
the mount from injuries that could be sustained by
simply being ridden.

Rope – This is a half inch thick rope made from hemp fibers.
A worn and knotted rope, that is not rotted, can hold
up to 330 lbs. A brand new rope can hold up to 600
lbs. The listed price is for a 10’ length, but it can be
purchased in 10’ increments up to 100’ in length.
Rope, Superior – This is a ½ inch thick rope made from
tough silk fibers. A worn and knotted silk rope can
support up to 500 lbs. A brand new rope can easily
support up to 1,000 lbs. The listed price is for a 10’
length, but it can be purchased in 10’ increments up
to 100’ in length.

Saddle bags – This is a pair of leather bags, connected by
a strap. The bags sit on either side of the mount and
the strap often is able to be easily attached to the back
side of a saddle. Each bag can hold 15 lbs of gear and
helps distribute the load on the mount.

Sack – This is a large canvas sack that can hold up to 50lbs
of weight.

86

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Scabbard – Often made of a combination of leather and
wood, scabbards are designed to hold blades of
certain lengths. Designed to be attached to a belt or a
baldric (a leather sash), so that it can be worn on the
back. The listed cost if for a scabbard for a 3 foot long
blade. For each foot less than that required for the
scabbard, subtracts 1 bp. For every additional foot of
length required, add another 1 bp to the cost.

Torch – Torches are lengths of
wood. The head of the
torch has been soaked in a
flammable substance and
then wrapped in papyrus
so that they will catch fire
quickly and they will burn
for up to 6 hours.

Scrimshaw Kit, Portable –This small kit contains a
variety of small carving tools used for carving bone,
including ivory.

Towel, Cotton – This is a 4’ x 6’
heavy cotton towel.
Trap, Hunting, Large – This
is a spring based trap.
Once set, if game steps on
it, its jaws snap shut, often breaking the limb of the
captured creature. This is sometimes referred to as a
“bear trap.”

Scroll Case – This is a hard leather tube designed to hold
documents that have been rolled up. It has a cap on
each end and is water resistant. A standard scroll case
can hold from 5 to 10 standard pages rolled up, or
even longer than average pages.

Trap, Hunting, Small – This is a cage trap, about 1’ tall x 1’
wide x 2’ long that captures the prey that enters it. It
is a cage that has one end that slides up. Bait is placed
in the trap and taking the bait releases the opening
so that the gate falls, closing the traps. This is used
for smaller animals. It can be collapsed down to a flat
bundle only 3 inches tall.
Twine – This is a heavy string. It is sold in rolls of
approximately 10 yards in length. The twine can
support up to 5 lbs of weight before breaking.

Shovel/Spade – this is about 5’ in length. It is a long
wooden handle with a metal shovel head.
Spanner (Belt Claw) – This is a device that hangs from the
belt of user of Hand and Light Crossbows. Once those
weapons are fired, this is then used to drawback and
rehook the string to the trigger mechanism, so that it
can be fired again.

Vellum – Vellum is a finer quality parchment made from
the skins of young animals such as lambs and young
calves. The price is the cost for a single page.
Waterskin, Large – This larger leather bottle can hold
up to 1 quart of liquid. It comes with a cork (subin)
stopper.

Spanner (Goat’s Foot Lever) – This is a lever that is used
to re-engage the string on a heavy crossbow with the
trigger so that it can be fired again.

Waterskin, Small – This is a small leather bottle for holding
liquids. It can hold up to one pint of liquid. It comes
with a cork (subin) stopper.

Tarp – This is a 5’x 8’ water resistant canvas cloth that can
be used as a ground cloth or even as a make-shift tent
or lean-to if needed. It can also be used to cover other
items that may be more susceptible to water damage.

Woodcarving Kit, Portable – This is a small bag containing
several small chisels and other wood working tools,
including a small mallet.

Tent, Conical – This tent has a 5’ radius and is in a conical
shape. It can house up to 3 men sleeping in it.

Writing Kit, Portable – This is a hard leather case that
contains a few sheets of papyrus, a couple of wooden
stylus and a small bottle holding 2 ounces of ink.

Tent, Dome – Not as tall as the Conical tent, this is in a
much smaller dome shape, about 7’ in diameter, and
it can sleep 3 mean.
Tinderbox – This is a small box containing tinder shavings,
flint and steel for use in starting fires.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Armor & Shields

•• Cover(#): The number listed in the parenthesis is
applied against ranged/reach attacks in addition to
any normal adjustments to DM against attacks that
the foe is aware of. Getting this bonus requires a Free
Action. This value also acts as AR against Ball, Cone,
and Line spells (p. 135; i.e. it reduces damage dealt)
•• Flammable: Armor of this type has a chance of
catching on fire, if any fire-based attacks exceed
the Armor Rating for Elemental attacks.
•• Heat(#): This armor provides the number in
parenthesis as a bonus to DM and Saves against Heat
based attacks and Extreme Temperatures (p. 204).
•• Cold(#): This armor provides the number in
parenthesis as a bonus to DM and Saves against Cold
based attacks and Extreme Temperatures (p. 204).
•• Metal: This armor has lots of metal in its construction.
Fire & Electrical attacks against this armor gain +1
SL if target is hit, even on a Partial Success. Slashing
attacks do Bash Critical Results instead of Slash.
•• Rigid: This armor is made of a hard, rigid material
and it provides an additional AR of SL1 against
Slash/Pierce Attacks only. The Armor skill may
only reduce the Move Penalty by half (rounded
up), the remainder always applies to applicable
skills. (i.e. Boiled Leather cannot be reduced below
-2, Full Plate cannot be reduced below -8).
Zones Protected: Most of listed armors protect the shoulders,
upper arms, torso (chest, abdomen, & back), groin and
hips. The Arming Cap, Skullcap, and Leather Helm protect
the head and cowls/coifs protect the head and neck. The
Full Helm protects the whole face, head, and neck. Bracers
protect the forearms, and Greaves protect the thighs and
lower legs.

Armor is extremely important to those who go into battle. It
helps protect them from wounds and aids in saving their lives.
However, armor also slows down the wearer and this can mean
that he tends to get hit more often, though for less damage overall.
Armors fall into several broad classifications based on
the types of materials that they are made from. Within these
classifications, there are also a variety of styles or ways that
armor can be made. Thus while two different suits of armor
might look different, they could easily fall into the same broad
group (i.e. brigandine and leather scale look different but both
are still considered to be Reinforced Leather).
The Armor & Shields tables include a number of columns
that need to be defined. They are as follows:
Cost: This is the average price for this type of armor or
piece of armor.
Weight (Wt): This is the weight of the armor, given in pounds.
It only counts against encumbrance if it is being carried.
Worn armor never counts against encumbrance.
Dexterity Modifier (Dx Mod): If you are wearing this type
of armor, you subtract this number from the amount
of Dexterity that you apply to your Defensive Modifier
(DM). This modifier can be reduced by the Armor skill.
Defensive Modifier (Def Mod): The number listed in this
column provides a bonus to your overall Defensive
Modifier (p. 122) when worn or carried (and used
actively in your defense). This could be from construction,
material, or magical bonuses.
Move Penalty (Mv Pen): This is also known as your Movement
Penalty. Skills/abilities affected by this modifier include:
Reflex Save Rolls, Spell casting, Athletics, Acrobatics, Ride,
Stealth, and Swashbuckling. This modifier can be reduced
by the Armor skill.

Armor Types
We have the armor descriptions below separated by the
basic material used in their construction.
No Armor – This represents normal clothing.

Attack Bonus Penalty (AB Pen): This modifier is applied to
all attacks made while wearing this armor or piece of
armor. This modifier can be reduced by the Armor skill.

Robes – These are heavy linen or wool robes that cover the
character from their neck to their feet. They can be
worn alone, or over other armor. The table shows the
adjustments for when worn alone or over armor.

Perception Penalty (Per Pen): This penalty is applied to
all Perception rolls that you make while wearing this
armor or piece of armor.
Armor Rating (AR): This is how protective the armor is against
a given type of damage. The types of damage, listed in
the order that they appear, are Bash (includes grab/
grasp/grapple attacks), Slash, Pierce, and Elemental. The
number listed is subtracted from the total amount of Hit
damage dealt by an attack. The final column is for SLs, the
SL cost of Critical Damage (as opposed to other Combat
Boons) against this armor are increased by this amount.

Padded Armor – This is also sometimes called Quilted
Armor. It is a sturdy cloth that is quilted and stuffed
with other materials. This other material could be
horse hair, layers of silk, or anything between.
Arming Jack – This is sometimes known as an aketon, and
is usually worn under other armors. It has reinforced
points for attaching other armors. The Arming Jack
can be worn under any other type of Armor without
incurring penalties for layering armors.
Gambeson – Heavier and providing more coverage,
this type of armor is a staple for many as it is easy to
produce and light enough for daily wear.

Qualities: This is a list of special qualities possessed by the
armor. These qualities can affect what results are used
on the critical table results.
•• ASF(#): The number listed is an Abnormal Spell
Failure (p. 135) modifier that is added to any spell
cast by somebody wearing the armor.

Chain Hauberk – This is a suit of chain that covers the
body including the arms and legs of the wearer. It is
often made by doubling the number of rings used and
having them essentially be two rings thick rather than
the normal one ring in your average shirt.
Scale – This is armor that is formed from attaching small
overlapping metal plates to a chain or leather undercoat.
More rarely, the small plates are attached solely to each
other. As with many other armors, this is often worn with
a padded cloth Arming Jack. The table only lists one type
of Scale Armor because the various versions described
below would have the same stats overall.

Soft Leather – This includes armor and clothing made from
sturdy, but soft and flexible leather.
Furs/Pelts – This is a collection of tanned hides with
the fur still on, usually worn in extreme cold weather.
They also serve the same purpose as soft leather as the
protection that they offer.
Soft Leather Byrnie – This is actual armor made from
supple leather, thick enough to protect the wearer
from some damage, while still allowing for relatively
easy movement. This type of armor is also sometimes
referred to as a Byrnie, which describes what the armor
covers, not how it is made.
Leather Hauberk – This is a long, sturdy leather coat, that
covers both the arms and the legs. It is light enough for
daily use, but heavy enough to offer decent protection.
Reinforced Leather – This is actually a fairly wide category.
It includes large rigid leather plates known as boiled
leather as well as various types of soft leather that is
reinforced by small hard leather plates, sometimes
called lames. It also includes a type of scale armor
that is formed using leather or other organic plates
(i.e. such as dragon scales or or heavy shells) or tough,
hard, organic materials (i.e. bamboo or other wood).
As with many other armors, this is usually worn with
an Arming Jack (already added in to the ARs).

Banded Mail – This is heavy cloth or soft leather that has
strips of metal attached to it in a horizontal pattern.
The width of the strips may vary up to several inches
from top to bottom.
Brigandine Armor – This armor is comprised of small
metal squares that are riveted to a cloth, leather, or
chain backing. This type of armor has the plates side
by side, not overlapping.
Metal Lamellar – This is a series of small metal plates that
are woven or strung together, often with a cloth, leather,
or chain backing. The plates in this type of armor often
overlap slightly along the top and bottom edges.
Splint Mail – This is made from strips of metal attached to
a cloth, leather or chain backing. The strips are attached
in multiple rows, with the longer dimension being in
a vertical orientation rather than the horizontal found
with Banded Mail.
Plate – This type of armor is made from interlocking plates of
metal designed to cover as much of the body as possible.
Joints in this type of armor are usually covered by
articulated pieces of metal. Full suits of Plate armor are
often custom made for a specific individual, thus making it
unlikely that others can wear it comfortably. As with many
other armors, this is usually worn with an Arming Jack
(already added in to the ARs).

Boiled Leather – This armor consists of thick boiled leather
breastplate, combined with pauldrons (covers shoulders
and upper arms) and tassets (covers groin and hips), to
provide the same amount of coverage as other armors.
Lamellar – This is usually formed using small plates of hard,
non-metalic material,
woven together in
rows,
or
slightly
overlapping each other.
Studded Leather – This
is heavy leather armor
covered in metal studs
to help reinforce it and
increase its protection.
Ring Mail – This leather
armor that has metal
rings sewn into it
to help turn attacks
against its wearer. It
is not as good as true
chain mail.
Chain – This is armor made from small, light metal rings
linked together to form a sturdy protection from attacks.
It is sometimes referred to as Chain Mail. As with many
other armors, this is usually worn with an Arming Jack
(already added in to the ARs).

Half Plate – This is a breastplate covering the torso, a set of
pauldrons covering the shoulders and upper arms, and
a set of tassets covering the hips and groin. Each section
is an individual unit that is strapped on using leather
buckles and also attached to the underlying Arming Jack.
Full Plate – This is similar as Half Plate, plus Bracers and
Greaves, except that the sections are joined to and the
gaps between them are filled with chain and/or the
joints are articulated and covered with smaller plates.

Chain Shirt – This is a simple short sleeved shirt woven
from interlinked metal rings. This is usually worn with
an Arming Jack (already added in to the ARs).
90

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Additional Armor Pieces
As mentioned above, there are 3 types of additional armor
pieces that could be added to the basic armors described
above. They are as follows:
Helms – These are, of course, worn on the head. The
heavier the helm, the better the protection it supplies.
However, this often also means a negative modifier
to your Perception skill as well since it affects your
peripheral vision in exchange for the protection.

Shields
Shields are devices that are held in the off-hand and used
to help deflect and block incoming attacks. They are often
made of a tough hide on a wooden frame, though smaller
shields might be made of metal or trimmed in metal to help
with the protection it provides.
The larger shields are quite heavy and can impact the
wielder’s moving and combat capabilities, so they are more
often used by those with more skill, or in units of soldiers
working in a tight formation, where the outer edge of the
formation focuses on defense while the second rank uses
polearms to make attacks
Buckler – This is the smallest type of shield, usually around
1’ in diameter and weighing about 3 lbs on average.

Arming Cap – This is a padded hood that covers the head
and neck of the wearer. It can be worn on its own, or
more usually, it is worn under a chain coif or a metal
helm gear to help protect the head.
Leather Skullcap – This is a close fitting cap of soft leather
worn on the head. In some cultures it is decorated to
show the wearer’s station or rank.
Leather Helm – This is a helm made of heavy leather,
worn on the head to help deflect blows.
Chain Coif – This is a hood and neck armor made of
metal rings woven together. It is normally worn with
an Arming Cap to help protect the wearer’s head.
Half Helm – This comes in many different designs. Some
include nasal bars, while others (sallets) may flare out
in the back to help deflect blows away from the head.
This is often worn with an Arming Cap under it.
Full Helm – This is a metal helm that includes coverage for
the neck, and a visor of some sort to protect the face as
well. This is often worn with an Arming Cap under it.
Note: Wearing an Arming Cap under a metal
helm does not count towards layering armors.

Round Shield – This shield is round in shape usually around
2’ in diameter and it weighs in at approximately 5 lbs.
Heater Shield – This shield is usually around 2’ to 3’ in size
and weighs approximately 6 lbs. It has a flat top and
the bottom curves into a point.
Kite Shield – This is similar to a Heater Shield, except that
the upper end is rounded and it is closer to the size of
a tower shield. It weighs about 9 lbs.
Tower Shield – This is the largest of the five types of shields.
It is usually about 3’ to 4’ in length and has a rectangular
convex shape. It weighs approximately 12 lbs.

Bracers – Bracers are sections of armor that protect the arms.
Usually this consists of plates of the material strapped
to the arms, but for chain, this would be considered to
be long sleeves attached to the main chain shirt.
Greaves/Pants – This is the leg armor, and like the other
additional pieces of armor, the benefits are based
upon the material used in their construction. As
with bracers, Greaves are often constructed of plates
strapped to the legs of the character, for Padded, Soft
Leather, or Chain armor, this would consist of leggings
made of the given material and either tied around the
waist or suspended in some other fashion.

Layering Armor
As with any system like this, some players will want to
start laying on armors to help increase their protection. The
following guidelines should be implemented when a player
wishes to do this.
When combining armors, all benefits and drawbacks
apply fully, with the following adjustments.
•• The the Move Penalty, the Dexterity Modifier, and the
AB Penalty for all armors worn are totalled and then
increased by 1.
•• The character’s Move Rate is decreased by 2 for every
type of armor worn beyond the first.
•• Any Armor Ratings are simply added together.

Note: Bracers and Greaves are often sold in sets (i.e. 2
Bracers or 2 Greaves), and information listed on the
Armor table are for a set of them. Should the character
only be wearing one of a set, then the modifiers are
halved, and rounded down.

91

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Clothing

Basic Clothing

We have 3 tables in this section. The first is for the common
clothing items that adventurers would need. The second is
for common accessories that often go with the clothing. The
third table is for materials, it is used to determine the costs
for higher quality clothing.
Clothing can be made of different materials. In the price
list for clothing, it is presumed that it is made from buckram,
which is a word used to describe a course linen material. The
percentage of coverage listed in the table actually determine the
costs, and the sections of body covered are also included to help
players better visualize what portions of the body are covered.

Articles of Clothing
Cloak – This is another piece of outer wear. It drapes over
the shoulders and down the back, though there is
usually enough material to cover the front as well.
Cloaks are often combined with Hoods into a single
garment known as a Hooded Cloak. While the pricing
for a cloak is based on it being made of buckram,
most cloaks are made of heavy wool, so their costs
should be increased accordingly.

(Buckram/Course Linen)

Cost

Socks – Socks are often worn to protect the feet in leather
shoes and boots.
Surcoat – This is an outer garment that extends to the top
of the knees, but is sleeveless. It is often worn over
armor as well as clothing.

Coat – This is a double-thickness article of clothing that goes
over other clothing. It covers the arms and body fully.

Tunic – A tunic is similar to a shirt, but it is long enough
to cover the hips and groin. However, it only covers to
the upper arms.

Cowl – This article of clothing combines a regular Hood
with material that covers the shoulders and upper
portion of the chest as well.

Vest – A vest is a sleeveless garment that covers the
shoulders, upper body and abdomen. It is worn
primarily, but not solely, by men.

Gloves – This article of clothing covers the hands of the
wearer. There are many different types of gloves,
from silk gloves worn by the nobility to heavy leather
gloves worn by workers to protect their hands.

Clothing Accessories

Hat – This is an item worn on the head of the wearer. It
covers everything from a basic skullcap to much
more ornate

In addition to basic clothing, many people also wear
items made of leather that does not fit the description of
normal clothing.

Hood – Hoods cover the head and neck of the wearer. They
are usually attached to other garments, such as cloaks
or coats.
