Leggings – There are a single garment that covers the wearer’s
hips, thighs, groin, knees, calves and feet. They are
sometimes called stockings since they cover the feet.
Pants – Pants covers the hips, groin, thighs, knees and
calves. Most folk prefer to have them made of tougher
materials when they can, especially if they have to
work, or ride a mounts.
Robe/Dress – A robe covers the entire body except for the
neck and head. Robes are often worn by scholars and
priests more than anybody. A woman’s dresses mostly
cover the same areas. Women tend to wear what is
referred to a pair of dresses. They have linen shift as
the under-dress, and then a more ornate over-dress.
Shirt – This garment covers the upper body, abdomen,
shoulders upper arms, elbows, and forearms. If is
often made of lighter materials.

a scabbard or quiver at the lowest end. Many also have
pouches for other items. Two of these may be worn across
opposite shoulders.

Belt Pouch (Buckram) – Small cloth pouch that can be attached
to a leather belt or be tucked inside other clothing. This
type of pouch can hold up to 5 lbs of weight.
Belt Pouch (Large, Leather) – Made of boiled leather, it is
3”x5” by 6” deep. It is often attached to a belt belt. This
pouch can hold up to 10 lbs of weight.
Belt Pouch, Silk – A Silk pouch is often considered the height
of wealth. This can normally hold up to 5 lbs of weight.
Belt Pouch (Small, Leather) – Small soft leather pouch
that can hold up to 5 lbs of weight. It is made to
attach to a belt or be tucked into clothing.
Belt, Equipment – This is a sturdy leather belt, 3 inches
wide. It is studded with metal rings for attaching
other items to the belt. It uses two separate straps and
buckles for holding it on.

The Alternative Clothing Materials table has 3 columns.
The second is the price for a square yard or other measure,
and the third column is if you want to make an entire article
of clothing out of a given material, treated as a multiplier
based on the percentage of covering given by that garment.
Beaver – This type of fur is the most popular for lining
heavier clothing for winter wear.

Belt, Leather – This is a standard leather belt with a metal
loop on one end. The end of the belt is often just
passed through the loop, folded back over and then
tucked around the belt to hang down.

Buckram (Course Linen) – This is the most common
material for standard clothing worn by most people
who are not wealthy.

Calf Boots, Leather – Boots of this type come up to just a
few inches above the ankle.
Knee Boots, Leather – These types of boots reach up to
just below the knee. They are often made so that any
pants worn would be tucked into the boots as well.
Most boots of this type also count as Boiled Leather
Greaves for the protection that they offer.

Coinyn (rabet) – Since Coinyn is so prevalent in Anwyn, it
is often used for lining clothing of those without the
means of using beaver fur.
Ermine – This is used almost exclusively by only the wealthiest.
It is also used primarily for trimming clothing, and
rarely for lining clothing, due to its expense.

Purse, Buckram – Made of buckram, this is a small bag for the
holding of coins. It is often kept tucked into one’s clothing.
It is often used to hold one’s most precious small items.

Lace – Lace is used as trim only. It is usually sold in ribbons
between a quarter inch and an inch wide. And it is
normally priced by the yard.

Purse, Silk – Made of silk, this is a small bag for the holding
of coins. It is often kept tucked into one’s clothing. It
is often used to hold one’s most precious small items.
It is usually only found among the well to do.

Leather – Often used as trim or as connecting pieces.
Clothing made from leather is not the same as the
leather used in Soft Leather armor, which receives
a special treatment to make it more durable and
damage resistant.

Sandals, Leather – This is a thick leather pad worn on the
underside of the foot, with leather straps or other
cords across the top of the foot to hold it into place.

Linen – Made from the flax plan, the making of linen is
often labor intensive. However, it

Scabbard, Leather – Usually made in general sizes to fit a wide
variety of blades, scabbards are often made of boiled
leather with wood or metal inserts to help it hold its shape.

Linen (Ymwydd) – The High Elves of Ymwydd produce
a type of linen that is of an extremely fine quality,
much better than that produced by the other nations.

Shoes, Leather – Only coming up to the ankle, most shoes

Russet (Homespun Cotton) – Garments made from this
material tend to be less refined

Alternative Clothing Materials
We have several types of fur on the following list. Fur has
two main purposes, the first is for lining clothing to make
winter wear to help keep the wearer warm. The second use
is for trim, such as collars, cuffs or hems.
Leather of various types is also sometimes used as trim or
to accent different pieces of clothing.

Sealskin – This is a rare and expensive type of leather that
is used in trimming and connecting other types of
cloth used in making clothes.

Quick Meals

Cider – Cider is a slightly alcoholic beverage made from
steeping apples in water and then allowing it to
ferment naturally.

Many inns and taverns, especially those catering to lots
of travelers will often keep something handy. The prices
usually vary with what it is and how fresh it is.
Cheap – This is basically just a bit of bread and cheese.
Cold – Many places will make a large pot of stew and
then continue serving it after it has grown cold, along
with some bread, to help sop up the juices.
Hot – Fresh hot stew and fresh hot bread are often served
together in the better inns and taverns.

Mead – This is beverage created through the fermentation
of honey and water, and a few other spices.
Whiskey – This is a highly alcoholic beverage made
by
distilling
a
fermented
grain
mash.
Different
grains often provide
different flavors.

Meat Rolls
A Meat Roll is often good travel food, at least for the first 2
days, before it starts spoiling. The Meat Roll is basically minced
and seasoned meat and vegetables in a thin wrapping of dough
that is then baked. Most places that sell Meat Rolls usually
only sell one type. They come in 5 main flavors; Beef, Chicken,
Mutton (lamb), Pork, and Coinyn (rabet). Meat Rolls are sold
in lots of 3, which makes up a single serving of them.

Wine – This is an alcoholic
beverage made from
grape juice that is
then fermented.

94

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Plum Pudding – This is a small open pie (a tart) filled with
a plum-based custard.

Hotpots
Hotpots are called such because they are baked in a small
pottery dish and served as soon as they come out of the oven.
They usually contain layers of meat and vegetables, and are
topped with sliced potatoes or balls of dough.
This is often a dish that can be slow-cooked over the
course of a number of hours, or more rapidly cooked under
higher temperatures. While the seasonings and vegetables
may differ, the price of a Hotpot is often based upon the
meat used, and the most common meats are Coinyn (rabet),
Freshwater fish, Fowl (various types), Kidneys & dumplings,
Livers & giblets, and Seafood.

Rose Pudding – This is a pudding that is flavored with blanched
rose petals (which are not in the finished pudding).
Sambocade – This is a small open pie made from elder
flower and cream cheese.

Rations
Explorers and Adventurers often look for Trail and Iron
Rations to take with them as it reduces the weight they have
to carry and feeds them when game is scarce.
Trail Rations – This is dried food, preserved to last up to
a month before spoiling. It is sold in portions that
would suffice one person for one day.

Meat & Sauce Dishes
The following dishes are usually only served at the finest
inns, or in the homes of the wealthy or nobility.
Capon – This is most often served with a black sauce made
from a number of different ingredients.

Iron Rations – This is a specially prepared bar of
nutritious, if somewhat bland dense bread filled with
nuts and herbs. These bars will last for six months
before spoiling. A single bar of Iron Rations will last
one person for one week.

Duck – This is usually served with an orange sauce.
Goose – This is often served with a fruit sauce of some sort,
or basted in brandy.

Lodgings

Ox Tongue – Many cultures serve this as a delicacy and
serve it with a savory herb sauce.

There are many different types of inns across the realms.
The following is meant to offer a representative cost of
staying in one, based on the type of accommodations that
they offer. We also include Ostling, the care and feeding of
riding animals in a second list under this category.

Pork – Pork is often served with a sauce made from apples
and similar fruit.
Salmon – Salmon is another delicacy and it is often served
with one of several mustard sauces.
Swan – This is the rarest of the delicacies, and it is usually
served with a nice berry sauce.

Soups
Soups are similar to stews, but usually thinner overall,
having more stock (broth) than a stew has. Soups also
often have simple egg noodles as well, or dumplings. The
soups also often use carrots, celery, and onion as part of the
vegetables as part of them. The various types of soup can
include the following: Beef, Chicken, Clam, Mutton, Oyster,
Pea & Bean, Pea & Ham.

Desserts
Desserts are sweet treats, usually reserved for after having
a meal.
Apple Tart – This is a small open pie that is filled with
apples in a sugary sauce.
Bannocks & Honey – This is a small oatcake filled with honey.
Fresh Dumplings – This is a small ball of dough wrapped
around a fruit filling.
Gooseberry Pie – This is a traditional pie made of
gooseberries in a sugary sauce.
Pears & Mead – This dish is also sometimes referred to as
Poached Pears, as the pears are steeped in the Honey
Wine (Mead) to help soften fruit that has not fully
ripened so that they do not go to waste.

Dorm Room, Poor – This is essentially any room where
multiple people might be sleeping, and could include
things like a hayloft above a stable.
Dorm Room – This is a room inside of a building,
specifically designed for multiple people to share. It
contains no beds but might
Furnished Room – This is a room with at least a single bed
in it. It could even include rooms with multiple beds.
Furnished Suite – This is found only in the best inns. It is a
central room with several different chambers off of it, and
often allows for multiple people to share such chambers.

Ostling
There are two entries on the table for each type of animal,
one just for stabling them overnight, and by stabling, we
mean keeping them in an individual stall for the night.
The second entry for each animal is for both the stall and
providing them with food.
Horses – Horses require foods such as hay and oats for
their food. They are the most common type of mount
and draft animal.
Garm – A Garm is a riding wolf used by the Ethori Gnomes
of Tanizwa and the Aeshi from both Vi-Ruma and TaiRuma. They are fed raw meat; usually things like coinyn
or chickens, but other feed animals are not unusual.
Garm are very rare and very hard to train. It is usually
difficult to find ostlers who can provide for them.
Korex – This is a reptilian mount that moves on 2 legs. Its front
two legs end in claws and its head is reminiscent of that of
a dragon, but it is not related. The Korex is an herbivore,
like the horse and Tarq, and has similar stabling and
feeding needs, regardless of its fierce appearance.
Syris – These are large felines that are ridden exclusively by
the Aeshi from Vi-Ruma or Tai-Ruma. They are also
carnivorous, and their feed usually includes coinyn
and chickens and sometimes bits of other feed animals.
Syris are very rare and very hard to train. It is usually
difficult to find ostlers who can provide for them.

Livestock

This list includes all sorts of animals that may be
purchased. Some are used for mounts, others for food, and
even more for certain specific types of uses.
Calf – This is a young cow. It is often purchased for getting
tender meats or by those wishing to raise cattle and
needing more stock.

Tarq – The Tarq are a species of goat that is ridden by both
the Gnomes of Tanizwa, and the Aeshi of both ViRuma and Tai-Ruma. They often use the same feed as
horses and thus are easier to stable safely.

Capon – This is a rooster that has been castrated. It is often
purchased for certain types of meals.
Chicken – Chickens are both a meat animal and a source
for eggs.
Coinyn – This is a small animal, similar to creatures called
rabbits, but they tend to breed even more quickly.
They tend to be a food staple for many peoples.

96

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Dog/Puppy, Hound – This is a hound that is bred for
helping flush out and hunting game. The listed price
is for a puppy of this type. Add 1 sp to the cost for a
fully trained dog.

Duck – Ducks are from the same family of waterfowl as
geese and swans. They are use for food, and their
feathers are also prized for use in quilted armor and
in lining some styles of coats.

Dog/Puppy, Ratter – This is a small terrier type of dog that
is trained to go into small tunnels after rats and other
rodents. The listed price is for a puppy of this type.
Add 1 sp to the cost for a fully trained dog.

Falcon, Trained – Falcons are favored pets of the wealthy.
They are usually trained to fly and hunt small game
such as coinyn, and to bring it back to the Falconer.
Garm – This is a large heavy wolf that has been especially
trained to be a mount for Gnomes and Aeshi. These
types of mounts are rare and hard to come by. Garm are
also taught to hunt for themselves at night, if given the
command to allow them to do so. This command allows
the Garm to range up to 2 miles from camp to hunt for
food. Garm are also intelligent mounts, able to detect
and warn their riders of danger that they can sense.

Dog/Puppy, Sheepdog – This is a relatively larger dog
who is good are helping herd sheep, goats and other
livestock. The listed price is for a puppy of this type.
Add 1 sp to the cost for a fully trained dog.
Dog/Puppy, Wolfhound – This is a very large dog that has
been bred to go after wolves and other large animals
that prey on livestock. The listed price is for a puppy
of this type. Add 1 sp to the cost for a fully trained dog.

Goat – Goats are a very versatile type of livestock. Some
breeds have a coat that is made into yarn for knitting
clothing, others give milk and provide meat in a
manner similar to cattle. They also are used for leather
as well. Goats can survive in almost any terrain, and
can eat a wide variety of things, including certain
kinds of tree bark.

Donkey – This animal is related to the horse, it is smaller
and is considered a working animal, which means that
it is used for performing jobs rather than for its meat.
Donkeys have a good weight hauling capability for
their size, but they are often considered obstinate and
this may make them less than ideal for certain tasks.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Mature Pony – Ponies are essentially a small horse. It
sometimes has a thicker coat but its head, barrel and legs
are fully proportionate. Many Dvargr (Dwarves) prefer
ponies over horses because they are closer to the ground.
Ponies also tend to get used for smaller buggies.

Goose – This is a large waterfowl that is often roasted and
served on special occasions. Geese are also notoriously
bad tempered, willing to chase and attack humans
who enter what they perceive as their territory.
Horse – Horses are large animals that are adapted to run.
They also have an excellent sense of balance and a
strong flight or fight response. Horse breeds are usually
loosely divided into three broad categories based on
temperament. Those referred to as hot bloods tend
to have high speeds and endurances, race horses and
those used by couriers. Those referred to as cold bloods
are those suited to slow or heavy work, such as plowing
fields or hauling wagons. And finally, there are the ones
referred to warm bloods. Those of this last group are
bred for specific purposes, such as war horses or the
mounts used by adventurers. The table lists a number
of different types of horses based upon their function.

Mule – A Mule is the offspring of a male donkey and a female
horse. Mules are more patient, hardy, and long-lived
than horses, and are described as slightly less obstinate
and much more intelligent than donkeys.
Oxen/Cows – A group of cows are often referred to as
cattle. They are raised for their milk and meat. Most
of the common sorts of leather are made from cow
hide. Cows are also all female. Oxen are bulls that
have been castrated. Oxen tend to be used more as
draft animals.
Pig – Pigs or hogs as they are sometimes called are kept
as a source of meat called pork. Pigs also seem to be
related to wild boars, a much more dangerous cousin
that is also often hunted for meat as well.

Korex – This is a reptilian creature about 10-12 feet long. It
has a head that resembles that of a dragon, though the
two are not related. The Korex is an herbivore, but can
eat many different things in a manner similar to a goat.
Korex are used primarily by the Odavi as a mount, since
it looks fierce and also has the spikes on its head and its
claws to protect itself. Over the course of the last 20 to 30
years, the Odavi have been trading them into Cymbri in
increasing numbers as they are just as sturdy as horses,
but less likely to be spooked than horses.

Pigeon – Pigeons, and doves, were an important resource,
valued primarily for their meat, eggs, and feathers.
Falconries often used them as quarry, and their guano
was a highly sought-after fertilizer.
Sheep – This is a herbivorous animal with a thick wooly
coat that is often sheared off to make into yarn and
then on into clothing. They are sometimes used for
food as well, but the meat from a full grown sheep has
a different flavor from that of lambs.

Lamb – Lambs are juvenile sheep, usually between 6
months and a year old. At that age, the meat has a
different flavor. Lambs do not have the same heavy
coat as adult sheep can grow.

Swan – This is a large waterfowl with a long neck and which
normally has white feathers. Swans were normally
eaten only by the nobility and the wealthy.
Syris – The Aeshi prefer to live in deep forest, which is
also where these cats live. Built along the same lines
as a tiger, but about one third to one half smaller,
they can be trained as mounts if caught young. They
are extremely rare as the kit’s parents are fiercely
protective. This protectiveness also means that once a
Syris has bonded to a rider, it will never be able to be
used for another rider without magical help.
Tarq – The Tarq is strongly related to goats. However, they
are stronger, tougher, and have a lot more endurance
then the average goat. Because of this, and because
of their ability to eat almost anything, they make
excellent mounts for the smaller Kins. Both the Ethori
Gnomes, and the Aeshi use these mounts.

Wild Korex
98

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Musical Instruments

Ocarina – This is an oblong enclosed chamber, about
4 to 6 inches in length and up to 2 inches in depth,
with a number of holes on the top and a mouthpiece
projecting from the side. It is used by blowing
through the mouthpiece and using the fingers to
cover different holes to produce different tones.

The Harpers Guild of Anwyn has halls in every town
large enough to support one. Many of their Halls include
craftsmen who work on making new instruments. They
only take a few apprentices a year, and not all make it to the
point where they can strike out on their own. However, even
apprentices are able to sell their efforts, and thus, you can find
instruments of lesser quality in some markets, instruments
made by the apprentices. Accordingly, the prices would also
be reflected by the skill of the crafter. The prices on the table
are for instruments made by the equivalent of a Tradesman

Pipes (reed) – This is a small musical instrument made
from several dried reeds of various lengths. The most
common versions have 5 or 7 reeds. Each is used to
make a specific note when blown through. This
arrangement of reeds allows for creating multiple
tones at once in a harmonic tone.

Land Transport
In addition to mounts, it is
Buggy – This is a light two-wheeled vehicle drawn by one
or two animals. It hold up to two people.
Carriage – This is heavier four-wheeled vehicle drawn by two
or four animals. It can hold up to 4 people in an enclosed
space and up to two people on the driver’s seat which sits
in front of the passenger compartment, often situated up
high, so that the driver can see above the animals.

Drum, Hand – This is a small leather skin stretched across a
wooden frame. It produces sound when it is beat upon.
The size of the frame and the tension of the stretched skin
are what determine the sounds made when it is struck.

Flute – This is a long tube with a single hole at one end and
several holes along the length of the tube. It produces
sound when air is blown across the mouthpiece hole. The
tone can be varied by opening or closing the holes along
its length. The length of the flute also impacts its tone.
Harp, Great – This is a large frame holding strings of varying
lengths. When strummed or picked, the strings produce
musical tones. It is often played with both hands.
Harp, Small – Similar to a Great Harp, this is small enough
to be held in one’s lap or even carried in one arm
while played with the other hand.
Lute – This is a wooden instrument, the body being
teardrop shaped and being hollow, with a hole in
the center. From the small end of the body extends
a neck. Across the body and up the neck are strung
multiple strings which then produce musical tones
when plucked or strummed. Variations of the lute
include the guitar and the dulcimer.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Cart – This is a two wheeled cart with a double-tongue
allowing it to be drawn by a single animal. It is up to
4’ in length and often can carry up to 500 lbs of cargo.
Covered Wagon – This is a larger wagon, from 8 to 12
feet in length. It usually has a large canvas covering
stretched over a rigid metal frame (flexible metal
bars bent into a semi-hoop). These type of wagons
are often used for carrying more delicate items that
need constant shielding from the sun and weather.
This type of wagon can easily carry 2,000 lbs of cargo.
Wagon – This is a four-wheeled wagon often drawn by two
animals. It is about 6’ long and can easily carry up to 1,000.
It is sometimes been referred to as a buckboard wagon.

Boats
Boats do not have sails. Thus they are propelled primarily
by oars.
Canoe (1-2 crew) – This is a lightweight, narrow boat. It is
pointed at both ends and is usually propelled by one
or two people, each using a single bladed oar.

Ships
The costs listed for ships are based on how much they cost
per square foot. To figure the cost of a given ship, multiply its
length by its length, and then multiply that by the price listed.
This would be the cost to purchase a relatively new ship.
Once recent advance that all of these ships have adopted
is the change from a steering oar to an actual rudder. In
some ships this is set in a newly added fixture, while in
others, it is built in from the ground up in a more complex
set of linkages between the rudder and the ship’s wheel.
Carrack – This is actually a relatively recent design that has
appeared less than 25 years ago. The Carrak is an all
purpose vessel designed for long voyages and capable
of handling all but the worst weather. Carracks range
in length from 60’ to 100’ in length. It often has
multiple decks plus both a forecastle and a quarter
deck. It also comes with two or three masts, holding
both square rigged or lateen rigged sails. Ships of this
sort often mix the type of rigging that they use.
Cog – This is slowly becoming one of the most popular
merchant vessels. These ships have their main deck
and a lower deck as well as both a forecastle and
quarter deck. Most Cogs use only a single mast with
square rigged sails. While they tend to be slower, they
are extremely sturdy in inclement weather.

Coracle (1 crew) – This is a small round boat, often made
of wicker-work and lined with some waterproof
material. It is propelled and steered using a single
bladed oar.
Kayak (1 crew) – This type of boat is similar to a canoe,
except that it is fully enclosed except for the cockpit
where the paddler sits. The paddler for this type boat
uses a single, double-bladed paddle.

Crayer – This is a wide ship with a shallow draft which makes
it well suited for operating on rivers and in shallow
coastal waters. These ships can be powered by either
oars, or sail. It has a single mast that is either square or
lateen rigged based on local customs. The ors are mainly
used for travel upriver and for docking. The mast can be
what is called stepped (taken down) to allow it to pass
under bridges. Larger versions of this ship may even
have a small cabin built in one end of the ship.

Pinnance – This is similar to a rowboat, but often much
larger. It is often used as a lifeboat or landing boat
on many larger ships. It is also characterized by the
fact that each crew member only controls a single
oar in an oarlock, and work with other rowers in
tandem. Most pinnances require a number of crew
equal to the number of tons it can carry divided by
4. A fully crewed pinnance can carry this crew, plus
an officer, and enough supplies to last for two days. If
not carrying supplies, the pinnance can carry a total
number of people equal to 4 times its crew (including
the crew). Unlike other boats, the Pinnance can
actually have a small mast raised (it is usually not)
with a lateen rigged sail for longer journeys.
Raft (1 crew) – This craft is a flat-topped structure of a
basic design. It is characterized by the fact that it does
not have a hull like other boats. It is made of buoyant
materials such as logs, sealed barrels, inflated bladders
(pontoons). It is normally propelled by a single crew
member using either an oar or by a long pole, if in
shallower water.
Rowboat (1 crew) – this is a small boat that is propelled
by a pair of single-bladed oars operated by a single
rower. The oars are attached to the boat using a
connection called oarlocks.

Karvel – This ship is a good mid-sized ship containing a
main deck, a lower deck, a poop deck and two masts
with lateen rigged sails. This is a very sea-worthy
Knarr – This is one of the most common merchant ships
in Anwyn. It often appears to be a larger version of
the Crayer. It is a wide ship with a shallow draft and
a single mast that normally has a square rigged sail.
This is primarily a coastal trader and is also popular
for fishing vessels. The ship itself contains a single
interior deck and may have a small building or shack
located in one end.

Passage
Sometimes, you just want to book passage on a ship. If
you are trying to take your animals with you, they will cost
as much as if you were getting a berth.
Berth – This is a small actual cabin that has one or more
bunks or hammocks in it for sleeping.

100

Steerage – This is basically any space available on the deck,
upper or lower).

Wages

The tables for this section refer to the average wages that
adventures might expect to make in certain professions. Or
for certain positions or for certain duties.

Hirelings
Hirelings are people who have been hired by a person for
any length of time. Not all potential jobs are listed here, only
those that might interest the player’s characters for some
reason or another.
Man-at-Arms – This is a person with some small combat
skills and is usually employed as a guard.

Adventurer – These would be your player’s characters. They
are often more skills in combat than your average
Man-at-Arms. Adventurers are widely considered to
be no better than Light Calvary.
Foot Soldiers – This sort of hirelings are used to fill out
the ranks of armies when needed. Their pay is often
dependent upon their skill and the weapons that they
are able to use.
Cavalry – Cavalry are fighters who fight from and on
horseback. The war bands of most noble lords in
Cymbri (a nation of Anwyn) are comprised of cavalry.
Archers – Archers are also normally support troops for the
cavalry. They are also used to protect fortifications
such as a town’s walls.
Engineers – Engineers are sometimes referred to sappers.
They usually work to breech or undermine a given
locations fortifications.
Harpers – Many nobles and wealthy will hire one or more
members of the Harper’s Guild to be a permanent
member of their households. The Harpers will often
work as basic teachers and entertainers.
Sages – Many nobles and wealthy will hire one or more
members of the Sage’s Guild. They often work as
scribes and heralds for their employers. They also
teach more advanced subjects as well. Sages may also
be hired to research a single topic as well. The amount
that they charge for such research depends upon the
specific topic.
Longshoremen – These are the men who labor on the
docks, loading and unloading ships
Deckhand (Unguilded) – Almost everybody who works
on board a ship is part of the Sailor’s Guild, from
the deck boys on up to the ship’s captain. However,
sometimes a shortage of guilded seamen or other
considerations will allow a captain to hire unguilded
men as deckhands.
Marine – Ships who sail in dangerous waters will also often
carry marines. Marines are fighters who know about
boarding ships and fighting at sea. They often double
as deckhands when not required to fight.
Masons/Carpenters – These are two types of Craftsmen
who earn more than normal craftsmen might.
Depending on your setting, you may have other
craftsmen fall within this category as well.
Other Craftsmen – This is your average craftsman. All
types of craftsmen that do not fall within the same
classification as Masons and Carpenters would use
this section as the guide for their wages.

Weapons

Even though there are a wide variety of weapons available,
not all are available to every character. Certain weapons may
be restricted based on the character’s Kin or Culture.
The Weapons table has a number of columns that need to
be explained. We provide this here:
Weapon Name: This is the common name of the weapon.
It may have other names for different cultures. For
example, the Bec de Corbin is also known as the Lucerne
Hammer, or as a Maul, depending on the culture.
Cost: How much it costs to purchase a new weapon of this
type, of average quality.
Hands (H): Whether this weapon requires one hand or two
hands to use. Some weapons could use both one or two
weapons, and those are indicated by their Qualities.
Skill: This is the skill that is used with the weapon. Some
weapons may be used with more than one skill, sometimes
with a minus to the secondary skill. These secondary skill
options are listed in the weapon’s description, not on the
table. Additionally, any weapon that does not list Ranged
as its skill, but has an entry in the Range column of the
table means that it can be thrown used Ranged as the skill.
This will also be in the weapon’s description.
Critical Failure (CF): Most weapons only receive a Critical
Failure on an unmodified roll of 2. Some weapons
may have a larger Critical Failure range and if that is
the case, this column provides the upper end of the
CF range. For example, the Ball & Chain has a CF of
3. This means that an unmodified roll of 2-3 means
that you rolled a Critical Failure.
Size: This is a general size of the weapon. This is used to
determine any initiative modifiers used when you are
rolling for initiative.

Damage Rating (DR): Each weapon listed has one or more
Damage Ratings. This is the amount of base damage
that is done upon making a successful attack using
this weapon. This consists of a number and lower case
letter, which describes the type of damage that the
weapon deals. This letter is important because armor
can reduce the damage received based on that type
of damage. If multiple types of damage are possible,
they are separated by a slash (/). If a weapon might or
might not have a given type of damage based on its
design, that portion is listed in brackets [].
Example: For its Damage Rating, the Battle Axe
lists 8s[/6b][/6p]. This means that the blade of
Battle Axe does 8 points of slashing/cutting. Since
some Battle Axes may also have a hammer head or
spike on its reverse side rather than another blade,
it has two types of optional Damage Ratings.
The letters that we will see listed in the Damage
Rating column are b (bash/blunt), s (slash/cut/rip/tear),
p (pierce/puncture), and g (grab/grasp/grapple).
Only one Damage Rating is delivered per attack. Many
weapons have multiple Damage Ratings because they
can be used in various ways, depending upon conditions,
such as a lack of swinging space requiring stabbing
attacks instead.
Example: The Arming Sword has a Damage Rating
of 8s/7p, which means it does 8 points when making
slashing attacks or 7 points when making stabbing/
piercing attacks. Should a character using an Arming
Sword be in a narrow corridor where he cannot make
proper swings, that is when he is most likely to make
stabbing attacks.

Length (Lg): This is the general length of the weapon.
Weight (Wt): This is how much the weapon weighs. The
value is given in pounds.

Range: This is the weapons basic attack range. There is no
modifier if the target of the attack is within that range.
If beyond that range, the attack receives a negative
modifier (see p. 125) for each increment of that range
that it is within. Half the range is considered Point Blank
(PB), and if within PB range, it gains a +4 modifier.
Example: A Heavy Crossbow has a range of 100,
which means attacks against foes that are betwee 0
and 50 feet are within Point Blank range, and attacks
against them receive a +2 modifier. Foes are more
than 50 feet, but closer than 100 feet receive no range
modifiers. If the foe is between 101 and 200 feet, the
attack is Medium Range and receives a -4. If the foe is
between 201 and 300 feet, the attack is Long Range a
-10, and if the foe is between 301 and 400 feet, that is
its Max Range, and the attack receives a -16. Any foes
401 or more feet away cannot be attacked as that is
beyond Max Range.

102

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Qualities: Each weapon can also have a number of special
Qualities that affect how it is or can be used. Each
Quality is described below:
•• Agile: Weapons with this Quality may use either Brawn or
Dexterity as the Stat when determining Attack Bonuses.
•• Backstab: Characters attacking a Surprised or Held enemy
with a weapon having this Quality, or even if attacking
with the On Rear modifier in melee, gets to ignore the
armor worn by the enemy. This Quality has no effect if the
foe is not wearing armor or if the foe has natural armor,
but it would still allow the use of the Ambuscade skill.
•• Entangling: Weapons with this Quality require that the
target of a successful attack make a Reflexes Save Roll
or be knocked Prone and Held. It takes a Full Action to
unentangle oneself if possible.
•• Flexible: Weapons with this Quality gain a +2 to Attack
Rolls if the target is using a shield. They may also, if
the weapon is not Heavy or Mighty, use either Brawn or
Dexterity as the Stat when determining Attack Bonuses.
•• Hand and a Half: Weapons with this Quality can be
used with two hands, or they can be used one-handed
with a -2 modifier to the Attack Roll and a +1 to CF.
•• Heavy: Weapons with this Quality require a Full Action
to make an attack using them.
•• Impale(#): This number is the amount of Bleeding
that successful Piercing attacks automatically deal
upon removal of the weapon from a wound it causes.
•• Load(#): This is the number of Half Actions required to
load or reload a weapon.
•• Martial: Weapons with this Quality gain a +2 bonus to any
Martial Moves attempted.
•• Mighty: The character gains a +2 to their Attack Bonus
if they attack without attempting to parry. These
weapons also do 2 hits per point over 20, max 4x DR.
•• Parry (#): If the weapon is used to Parry, the number
within the parenthesis is added to the character’s DM,
regardless of how much of the AB is used to parry. If
the character does a Full Parry, they may give up their
allowed attack to get double the number added to thier
DM. (Note: when used with various forms of two weapon
fighting, the doubling only occurs when both weapons
being wielded give up their attacks)
•• Quick Load: May perform 1 Load/Reload action each
round as a Free Action.
•• Reach: Weapons with this Quality are able to engage or
attack foes up to 10’ away. Weapons with this Quality may
also be used with the Martial Move, Maintain Distance,
with a +2 modifier. This modifier does not stack with
the modifier from the Martial Quality.
•• Swift: Weapons with this Quality are able to attack as a
Half Action without the normal -4 modifier.
•• Unreliable: Weapons with this quality will always
deliver some critical damage to its wielder upon
receiving a Critical Failure. Regardless of the Fumble
rolled, it will deal at least 1 SL of Critical Damage to
the wielder. If the player selects taking damage from the
Fumble result, that is increased by 1 SL.

Below is a short description of the weapons available,
along with any special notes about the given weapons.
Note: Weapon descriptions are intended for game
purposes only and may not be historically accurate.

103

Arming Sword — This is one of the most common types of
swords around. It has a blade that is approximately 30
inches long and about 2 inches wide and it is edged on
both sides, with the tip coming to a point. This weapon
is both light and flexible in its usage, being designed
for both stabbing and slicing. The arming sword is
sometimes called a war sword or a knight’s sword
because of how common it is.
Ball & Chain — This weapon is a type of flail consists of a
short haft that has length of rope or chain with a solid
metal ball, about 3” in diameter and often slightly spiked,
at one end. The user gains a +2 to his attacks when using
this weapon against a foe that is using a shield.
Bardiche — This is a type of pole arm that is primarily a
slicing weapon. Unlike other types of pole arms, the
Bardiche’s blade is attached to the pole at two points
instead of one. Thus the haft of the weapon extends
half way or more up the back side of the blade.
Bastard Sword — Often called a Hand-and-a-Half Sword.
It has a longer hilt that could easily accommodate
allow it to be used one handed or with both hands.
The approximately 36 inch blade is straight and
sharpened on both edges.
Baton — There are several varieties of this weapon, from
a simple short stout stick, to a slightly more flexible
handle topped with a small weight. Most Batons are
about 18 inches in length. They may be used with
either the Blunt or Brawl skill without any penalty.
Battle Axe — The Battle Axe is a large double-bladed axe that
is used in a two-handed fashion. The blades are roughly
shaped along the lines of a half moon
(or crescent moon) and they
usually mirror one another,
although there is some
variation possible. Although
the skill normally used with
this weapon is Blunt, you can
also used this weapon with your
Blades skill with a -4 modifier.
Bec de Corbin — This pole arm has a hammer
head on one side and slightly curved point
or beak on the other. The beak is most often
used when making attacks, but the hammer
side could be just as deadly. A variation on
this, called the Lucerne Hammer (use the
same stats), was very similar.
Bola — This is a type of throwing weapon made of weights
on the ends of interconnected cords, used to capture
animals by entangling their legs.

Broadsword — This double-edged blade is one of the most
common types of swords out there. Broadswords
have basket hilts that aid in parrying. The blade itself
is usually about 3” wide for the majority of its length.
Cestus — These are battle gloves, often worn by Boxers or other
types of Martial Artists to increase the amount of damage
that they deal with their fist attacks, no Weapon Kata
required. These gloves usually include built in bracers that
protect the forearms and allows the character to parry
attacks without harm. The Damage Rating is added to
that of a punch attack from the wearer.
Composite Bow — This is a strong recurve bow made
of several different materials that allow for greater
strength and range in a shorter bow.
Cudgel — Cudgels are usually thicker on the business
end, tapering down to the grip end. They are made
of wood, and usually have a rough-hewn appearance.
Dagger — Daggers are short, double-edged blades. They are
useful tools for close in fighting. Daggers can be used
with either the Brawl or Blades skill, without any penalty.
Daggers are also often treated as a thrown weapon, and
the character may use the Ranged skill for that purpose.
Dart — The Dart is small thrown blade. It is often used to
deliver poison to the target since it cannot do a lot of
damage in and of itself.
Falchion — The Falchion is a one-handed, single-edged
blade. It has a blade that usually has a heavy curved
end, making the tip of the blade wider than it is down
closer to the hilt.

105

Flail — This 2-handed weapon consists of a 4’ long shaft,
with a foot-long cylindrical head, often studded with
metal, attached to the end by a short chain.
Glaive — This type of pole arm has a singleedged blade at its end. Many variations
contain a Bill (a hook) on the side
opposite the edge. This hook is most
often used to grab and attempt to
unseat mounted foes.
Greatsword — This is a heavy sword.
It is a double-edged weapon that
comes in a variety of styles that all
require 2 hands for the wielder to use it.
Guisarme — This is a pole arm with a long spearlike point at the end and a hook on one side.
As with the Glaive, the purpose of the hook
is to grab and pull mounted riders off their
mounts. The Guisarme began as just a hook,
but the point was later incorporated as a way
of dealing damage until the foe could be
hooked.
Halberd — This is one of the most versatile of
the pole arms. It has an axe head one side,
a hook on the other, and spike jutting
out of the top. This allows it to be used
for grabbing, stabbing and chopping.
Hanbo — The Hanbo is a cylindrical rod
about three feet long and about an inch
thick. The tips are sometimes banded in
metal.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Handaxe — The Handaxe is characterized by its distinctly
arch-shaped head, widening toward the cutting edge and
terminating in a prominent point at both the upper and
lower corners. Although the skill normally used with this
weapon is Blunt, you can also used this weapon with your
Blades skill with a -4 modifier. This is also often treated as
a thrown weapon, and the character may use the Ranged
skill for that purpose.
Hand Crossbow — This is a small crossbow that can be
fired one handed. It is
rarely more than 6 to 8
inches from side to
side, and about 8
inches long. It fires
a smaller bolt than the
other crossbows, but it
still packs a good punch.
Hatchet — This is the smallest type of axe.
The hatchet, called a tomahawk in some cultures,
also works well as thrown weapon. Although the
skill normally used with this weapon is Blunt, you
can also used this weapon with your Blades skill with
a -4 modifier. This is also often treated as a thrown
weapon, and the character may use the Ranged skill
for that purpose.
Heavy Crossbow — This is a bow mounted on a long stock.
It is used to shoot projectiles, called bolts. The bow is
cocked by using a winding mechanism and then the
bolt is slid into a groove.
Javelin — The Javelin is basically a sharpened shaft that is
thrown at a target in most cases. Some Javelins will
have metal heads or metal sheaths protecting and
strengthening their tips.
Jitte — The Jitte is a thick long truncheon-like shaft with
a hooked prong protuding from the handle. The
Jitte can be used with either the Brawl or Blunt skill,
without any penalty. The prong on the side of the
main shaft is often used for catching and trapping
bladed weapons. The point is usually sharpened to
allow for stabbing. The Jitte also gains a +2 to the
Martial Moves, Disarm and Lock.
Jo Staff — The Jo Staff is a cylindrical rod about four feet
long and about an inch and a quarter in diameter. It
is sometimes banded in or tipped in metal.
Kama — This is a short-hafted weapon with a blade
sticking out at a right angle to the handle. It has both
a point, and the inner edge of the blade is sharpened.
Katana — This weapon has a long (24-30 inch) curved
blade with a single edge and a sharp tip. It is primarily
a slashing weapon. It is designed to be used two
handed, but it can be used one handed in a pinch. It
is usually worn with the edged side facing up.

106

Lance — This is usually the longest weapon of the pole arm
family. It is more often used mounted against other
mounted foes, as it is often a bit unwieldy in melee.
Light Crossbow — This is a smaller version of the Heavy
Crossbow. It is not as powerful as a Heavy Crossbow,
but it is a little more compact and easier and quicker
to reload.
Long Bow — This is a bow made from a single, long piece
of wood. When strung, it looks like a capital “D” from
the side as it doesn’t have the same sort of recurve
that a Composite Bow has. It is used to fire arrows.
Longsword — Longswords have long cruciform hilts with
grips over 10 to 15 inches in length providing room
for two hands. The straight double-edged blades are
often 40 to 48 inches in length, and typically weigh
between 2½ to 5 pounds.
The longsword is commonly held in combat with
both hands, though some may be used single-handed.
Longswords are used for hewing, slicing, and stabbing.
The specific offensive purpose of an individual
longsword is derived from its physical shape. All parts
of the sword are used for offensive purposes, including
the pommel and cross guard.
Mace — The Mace is a relatively simple weapon, being a
metal head, often knobbed or with flanges, attached
to a stout handle. It sometimes includes a spike on the
top that can be used as a stabbing weapon.
Meteor Hammer — This weapon consists of a length of rope
or light chain, usually 7 to 12 feet in length. with a solid
metal ball, about 3” in diameter at one or both ends. The
Meteor Hammer may be used with either the Blunt or
the Ranged skill.
Military Fork — This weapon has 2 straight tines or spikes
coming from the crosspiece mounted at the end of a
pole. It was originally developed from pitchforks and
is a good sturdy weapon.
Monkey Fist — This weapon consists of short length of
rope, from 1 to 3 feet in length, with a knot at one end.
The knot is called a Monkey Fist because it looks like
a small fist. The knot often contains a small weight or
stone to help make the weapon more effective.
Morningstar — The Morningstar is a type of
mace, topped with spiked metal ball. It
sometimes includes a spike on the top
that can be used as a stabbing weapon.
Net — This is a small, net about 6 feet in
diameter, often with small weights
along its outer edge. It is usually
held in the center and used to
parry or confuse a foe, or to
entangle his weapon.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Nunchaku — This weapon is comprised of 2 rods, between
12 and 18 inches in length, connected by a short
chain. May be used 1 handed or 2 handed. There is
a variation of this, sometimes referred to as a Tabak.
However, the rods on the Tabak are usually about 6
inches in length, and the connecting chain is longer,
between 5 and 8 inches normally. The user gains a +1
to his attacks when using a Tabak against a foe that is
using a shield, but its base damage is only 9b.
Parrying Dagger — The Parrying Dagger is essentially a
dagger with strong prongs sticking out from
the sides of the blade where it connects to the
hilt. Parrying Daggers can be used with either
the Brawl or Blades skill, without any
penalty. What makes it different from
other daggers is that its hilt is specially
designed to catch and trap blades, much like
the Sai. The Parrying Dagger also gains
a +2 to the Martial Moves, Disarm and
Lock. This weapon is sometimes called a
Main Gauche or Sykir.
Quarterstaff — The Quarterstaff is a long cylindrical rod about
an inch thick and the ends are often capped in metal.
Ranseur — This pole arm looks somewhat like a stylized
trident, but with wider tines that are not barbed. It
has a long central spike at the top, and two smaller,
crescent shaped blades down near the hilt.
Rapier — The Rapier is slim-bladed. It is primarily a
thrusting sword, though it sometimes has a sharp
edge to also allow for a little slashing.
Rope Dart — The Rope Dart is a long rope (usually 7-12 feet)
with several small rings and then a metal dart attached
to one end. The user gains a +2 to his attacks when using
this weapon against a foe that is using a shield. Some
rope darts have hooks on one side and can be used to
grab and pull foes as well. The Rope Dart may be used
with either the Blades or the Ranged skill.
Sai — The Sai is a three-pronged, with the central prong
being a thick long truncheon-like shaft with a sharp
point on the end. Sai can be used with either the Brawl
or Blunt skill, without any penalty. The two shorter
prongs on either side of the main shaft are used for
catching and trapping bladed weapons. The point is
usually sharpened to allow for stabbing. The Sai also
gains a +2 to the Martial Moves, Disarm and Lock.
Scimitar — The Scimitar is a long, curved blade, sharpened
on only the outer edge of the curve.

Short Bow — The Short Bow is a smaller version of the
Long Bow, made from a single piece of wood. One of
the benefits of the Short Bow is that if a rider is skilled
enough, it can be used from horseback.
Short Spear — The Short Spear is essentially a short shaft
with a bladed head attached to one end.
Short Sword — This weapon is a smaller version of the
Broadsword. Its blade is often double-edged, straight
and usually about 3” wide, though thinner versions
do exist.
Sling — A Sling is essentially a leather pouch with two
lines, one extending from either side. The pouch is
then whirled and a stone, held in the pouch, is then
released to fly at its target.
Sling Shot — A Sling Shot is essentially a “Y” shaped
handle with a pouch attached to the upper ends by
some elastic material, or certain designs could use
springs. It shoots stones, often called bullets.
Slingstaff — A Slingstaff is a normal quarterstaff with a fork
on one end with a pouch used to fling stones, often
called bullets. The stats on the table are for using the
Slingstaff as a ranged weapon. If you want to use it as
a Quaterstaff, then use the stats for the Quarterstaff.
Smallsword — The Smallsword has a thin, yet sturdy blade
that evolved out of the Rapier. It is made primarily
for thrusting attacks but may also be used in slashing
attacks as well. The smallsword is sometimes called
an epee or court sword.

Spear — Like the Short Spear, the Spear is a long shaft
with a bladed head on the end. It is most often used
by foot soldiers when defending against mounted
or flying opponents.
Stonebow — This device looks much like a Light Crossbow,
except that the string hold a pouch for a stone. Other
than that, it operates the same.
War Hammer — The War Hammer
resembles a hammer on one side, with
a single spike on the reverse, allowing
the wielder to do either a crush or
puncture critical at will, utilizing but a
single skill. Dwarves are often fond of
utilizing this as a thrown weapon as well.
Some War Hammers may not have the
spike on its reverse side, instead having a
double hammer head.
Whip — The Whip is a length of braided
leather that is often used to attack foes
at a reach.

107

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Finishing Touches

Your heroes are nearly ready to embark on their
adventures. You have generated their Stats, and determined
their Kin and Culture, and their Vocation.
You have then fleshed them by spending their Development
Points to purchase skills, and spending your Background
Option Points to help determine their back story and figured
out their Passions, their reasons for adventuring.
And finally, you took your starting money and purchased any
additional equipment that you felt your character might need.
Now, your next step is to fill in those few missing blanks
and figured numbers required to actually start play.

Defense

Character use their Defensive Modifier (DM) to avoid
being struck by foes during combat. The character’s DM is
determined by a number of various factors, such as their
Dexterity, the armor that they wear, whether they carry a
shield or not, and if so, what size shield they have.
On the character sheet, there is a whole section for this,
which allows you to list each of the factors that may be
involved, and any other modifiers received due to armor or
shield, and to total them all up.
To determine your base DM, you use the following formula:
Dexterity - your armor’s Dx Mod
You would then add any mods for armor or shield to this. Refer
to p. 122 for more information on your Defensive Modifier.
Note: Your DM can never be less than zero (0).
Anything lower than zero is treated as zero.

Note: Parrying is your friend! We strongly
recommend that you always do some parrying or
similar type of action when in melee combat.

Save Rolls

Not every type of attack can be dodged or parried. Save
Rolls represent the character’s ability to resist certain effects.
There are three basic types of Saves in Fantasy Express;
Toughness Saves, Reflex Saves and Will Saves. Your Save
bonus for each type of Save Roll is equal to your Kindred Save
Bonus plus your level plus any special modifiers you receive.
Toughness Saves are those that reflect resisting an effect
based on your Stamina.
Reflex Saves are where your Dexterity may allow you to
avoid the effects.
Will Saves represent resisting or overcoming an effect
based on one of your character’s Resolve. It is their
strength of mind and self.
Save Rolls are resolved in the same manner as skill rolls,
requiring a 20 or higher indicates success. These rolls have
a base of 7, and are modified by your Kindred Save Roll
bonuses, plus your level, plus the Stat relevant to the Save
in question. These rolls are also negatively modified by the
level of the effect that you are resisting. Therefore, if you are
resisting a 5th level poison, your roll receives a -5 modifier.

108

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Total Hit Points

Determining a character’s Total Hit Points requires a
little bit of math. And it involves using the three aspects of
your Kindred Stats that revolve around Hit Points and your
character’s Body skill total.
Base Hit Points: This is a number of Hit Points that every
member of your character’s Kin receives.
Hits Multiplier: This number, the Hits Multiplier (Hits
x), is multiplied by your character’s Body Skill Total
and added to your Base Hit Points. The sum of the two
equals your Total Hit Points.
Max Hit Points: This number is the average maximum
number of Hit Points a person from your Kin may
have. You add double your Stamina Stat to this number
to determine your character’s actual Maximum Hit
Points. Regardless of how high your Body Skill Total
is, your Total Hit Points can never exceed this number.

Height & Weight

Next up, you want to determine the height and weight of
your character. You have 2 choices on how to do this. You
can simply pick based on the information on the table, or
you can roll randomly.
To roll randomly, you would do the following:
1) Roll Height – Each Kin has a base height in inches,
and then you roll one or two d10 and treat the result as
additional inches on top of that base height.
2) Determine Weight – The numbers in parentheses is
the base weight of your character, for the given base
height. It also includes a modifier that is added to the
base weight for each inch above the base height that
your character is.
3) Determine Build – Again, you can either pick or roll
randomly. If you roll randomly, you should add in
your character’s Brawn without the Kindred modifier.
Example: You are making yourself a Dwarven
Rogue. His total Brawn Stat is a 3 (1 point is from
Kin plus 2 points from Stat Generation). You roll
2d10 for his height, getting a 7 and a 5, for total
of 12 inches added to the base of 47, making your
Dwarf 59 inches tall (4’11”). To determine his
weight, you add 12 x 9 lbs, or 108 lbs total to the
base weight of 90, making his weight 198 lbs. Now,
for build, we roll 2d10, and add in 2 (his total
Brawn minus the Kindred adjustment) for a total
of 17 (2 + 7 +8). This gives him a Heavy Build,
increasing his weight by 10%, or 20 lbs (19.8 lbs
rounded) for a total weight of 218 lbs.

Mana Points

Mana Points represent the amount of magic that a
character can handle or manipulate in a given day. Our next
thing to figure out is exactly how many Mana Points your
character has available to them each day.
This is done in a manner similar to that of your Hit Points,
as the formula is:
(Mana total skill bonus x 2) + Base Mana + Special
Your Base Mana is determined by simply adding 3
numbers together, Your Kindred Mana, and the Mana from
both of your Vocational Kits.
•• Arcane Vocational Kits: Each Arcane Vocational Kit gives
the character 5 Mana Points.
•• Hybrid Vocational Kits: Each Hybrid Vocational Kit
gives the character 3 Mana Points.
Height & Weight

Languages

Under the Kin Descriptions, we give each character 3
ranks in Written and Spoken in their native language and 3
ranks in Æglits. Under their Culture, they gain a number of ranks
equal to 4 + the character’s Wits stat
However, we do not explain what those languages are
and what languages are available.
Here is a list of available languages. These languages
are all those available in the Anwyn setting. If your GM is
not using that setting, the list of available languages may be
different from this list.
Æglits is the trade tongue, spoken by all of the Kindred. Part
of the magic that anchored Anwyn, to keep it from drifting
through the dimensions, is that any sentient being arriving
in, or having grown up in Anwyn will have a minimum of
3 ranks of speaking ability in this language.
Ainu is the language of the humans known as the Zhuan.
The Zhuan culture and language if very different from
that of the Cymbriots.
Ard Tafodd is the language of the High Elves, also known
as the Sylvari. The Grey Elves (also known as the
Yddari) also speak this language. This language almost
sounds lyrical when spoken quickly.
Cant is sometimes called Thieves’ Cant. It is a specialized
language, a sort of linguistic shorthand that can convey
a lot of information in short order. The written form of
this language is actually a series of codes and markers
that allow those who know this language to spot such
underworld locations as places to sell stolen goods, or
where the local guild can be found. This language is
never taught to anybody who is not part of the thieves’
guild, and they take precautions to make sure that it is
not learned by outsiders.

Gaelsh is the primary language used by the Human
population of Cymbri known as the D’Anui. It is also
used by most humans anywhere in Anwyn.
Goblinoid is the language spoken by Goblins and Hobgoblins.
It is unknown what they call their own language.
Lihasa is the language of the Aeshi, sometimes called
Shadowlings, or Dwelfs. This language is filled with
clicks and glottal stops.
Sleesh is the language of reptilian humanoids such as
Kobolds and Lizardmen. It is a soft and sibilant language.
Sprak is the language of the Dvargr, also known as
dwarves. It is a harsh and gutteral language.
Tauro is the language of the Ethori. They are sometimes
called Gnomes. Tauro is a gutteral, although not quite
as harsh as the language of the Dwarves. The two
languages are not related.
Teangai is the language of the Wood Elves, also known
as the Verdyri. It is related to Ard Tafodd, and shares
a few words, but they are not identical. Some scholars
occassionally refer to Teangai as Low Elven and Ard
Tafodd as High Elven.
Varni is the language of the Risi. They are the large
human-like Kin that live in the Mirr Valley.
Zabon is the language of the Odavi They are sometimes
called Orcs by the less enlightened.

Starting Equipment

In the Vocation chapter, your character received some
starting equipment, including some starting money. In your
Culture, you also received some starting funds. If you have not
done so yet, you should go through the equipment chapter
and purchase any additional equipment you want your
character to have and record this on your character sheet.

110

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Encumbrance

Once you have all your equipment, it is time to determine
whether or not your character is encumbered.
Any Encumbrance Penalties would be figured into your
character’s Move Penalty (which is totalled in Armor &
Shields section of the character sheet). Thus, your Armor
skill can work to reduce these penalties as well.
Since a strict accounting of the character’s equipment and
belongings would be tedious and undesirable, and just not
very much fun at all, we have therefore come up with the
following rules to try and keep it simple and a bit flexible.
We have 5 basic levels of Encumbrance. They are:
•• Unencumbered: The character suffers no penalties.
•• Lightly Encumbered: The character suffers no
penalties, but could be prevented from using
certain traits or abilities.
•• Encumbered: The character must reduce their Move
Rate by one third (round down) and will be slowed
when traveling. They also receive a -2 to all actions.
•• Heavily Encumbered: The character halves their
Move Rate and suffers a -4 to all actions and will be
greatly slowed down while traveling.
•• Over Encumbered: The character is limited to one
quarter of their Move Rate (round down). They
cannot Sprint, attack, or travel and will not be able
to add their Dexterity to their DM.
Note: It is up to the GM & Player to use common
sense along with the guidelines in the Encumbrance
Levels table for determining actual Encumbrance.

Move Rate

Every Medium-sized character has a Base Movement
Rate of 20 feet per round. This base is adjusted by adding
the character’s Dexterity Stat to the base of 20. If they have a
negative Dexterity stat, this reduces their Base Move.
The character’s Base Move is also adjusted based on the Size
of the character. Large characters, such as the Asgerdi, add 5 to
their Base Move, while Small characters, such as the Dwelfs and
Gnomes would subtract 5 from the Bave Move. These are the
same adjustments listed next to Size in the Kin Descriptions.
This is also modified by the Move Penalty of any armor that
the character is wearing. Of course, this Move Penalty is itself
modified by the character’s total Armor skill bonus, which
cannot do any more than reduce the Move Penalty to zero.
This Move Rate is considered to be done at a walk/jog as
needed to transverse that distance with a Full Action during
the course of a round. Characters may move up to double this
amount by using a run/sprint type of move with a Full Action.

Name Your Character

If you have not yet done so, now is the time to give
your character a name.

Tally Ho!

Now you are ready to go adventuring!

with up to half (20lbs) its weight capacity, or a Framepack filled up to a quarter (25 lbs) of its weight

equipment such as a tent or other heavy gear like a heavy rope and pulley, or chains.

Over
Encumbered

The character is really overburnened, like dragging a sled with a large load (or pulling or carrying
the body of a wounded companion). Generally, this is not how the character runs around while
adventuring, but more likely a particular condition the character can endure for a short period.

Character Advancement

Each player, together with the GM and the other at the
table should briefly review everything that has happened
during the game. The GM should review the XP Awards
table, and determine how many XP that the players receive.
Once he has these tallied, he will tell each player how many
that they have earned.
As a player, it is up to you to remind your GM of what has
happened, whether it was done by yourself or another player.
This is beneficial in the long run since it fosters the growth
together as a group and at some later point, you might forget
something that another player then brings up.

A character’s Level is a measure of his overall power,
competence and experience. During their adventures, your
character will visit new places, complete missions and face
challenging situations. By doing these things, he will gain
Experience Points (XP), and once they have enough, they
will go up in level, and then have to develop their skills and
abilities to become even more capable adventurers overall.

Levels & Progression
Your character will start at first
level with 10 XP. This reflects the
experience that they have already
earned from training, and possibly
past adventures.
As you progress in levels, the
amount of XPs required for the next
level will also slowly start increasing.
We do this increase in blocks of 5
levels. You need 10 XP to gain each
level up to level 5, and then you need
20 XP up to level 10, then you need 30
XP for each level up to level 15, and
you need 40 XP for each level up to
level 20, and then you need 50 XP for
each level beyond level 20.
Example: You have 18 XP total,
and you have just completed a
session. The GM tells you that
you gained 3 XP this session. This
gives you a total of 21 XP and
means that your character has
progressed from level 1 to level 2.

Gaining XP
Experience Points should be
awarded at the end of session, or
during breaks after 3-4 hours of play if
your group plays for 6 hours or more
at a time.

XP Awards Key

The Experience Awards table has several
sections. Each is described more fully below.
Group Awards – The following awards are used
to determine a number of Experience Points that
are added to every character equally. The total is
not split between the characters; each character
receives the full amount.
Base Adventure Reward – Every adventure will
have this as its base, to which the other award
modifiers are added or subtracted. This award
is only given out at the end of the adventure
though. Each character participating in the
adventure receives this award.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Adventure Result – This award is based upon whether or not
the characters successfully accomplished the main goal of
the adventure. They either did, or they did not but can still
fix things in the next session, or they failed to complete the
adventure, and did so in a manner that cannot be fixed.
It is quite possible that a GM has several adventures
running simultaneously or overlapping one another.
The GM should keep track of each plot or story line
and the Encounters and actions specific to each one.
Encounters – During the course of the adventure, the
characters will have encounters. These could be planned
encounters, such as the players having to negotiate with
a trader for some information, or it could be a random
encounter with a wandering monster. Either way, each
encounter adds to the total value of the adventure.
Successful means that the goal of that specific encounter
was accomplished. The information was gained, the
monster vanquished or chased off, etc. For example, the
goal of most encounters with dragons is to not be eaten.
Individual Awards – In addition to the group awards, each
individual character may also earn additional awards.
Per Game Session – A game session is defined as 3-4
hours of role-playing. The GM should award 1 XP at
the end of each session. This award would be given
only to those characters whose players are present.
Heroic/Dramatic Actions – Characters that perform
heroic or dramatics actions that add to the overall
enjoyment of the game gain additional Experience
Points. Also, if the actions pose a serious risk to the
health or life of the character, beyond the standard
risks involved in adventuring, they can get yet another
bonus to the Character Points earned.
Risky or foolhardy actions taken solely for the sake
of trying to earn more Experience Points should not be
awarded Experience Points. The idea is for players to
have their characters take calculated risks that advance
the game, not to go “base jumping” just because the
opportunity to do so presented itself. The actions should
ones that advance a plot or story in some fashion.
Accomplishing Goals – In order to complete an adventure,
the characters will have to complete one or more goals
associated with that adventure. The character that
completes a given goal gains XP for doing so.
Players should also be encouraged to draw up a list of
personal goals for their characters so that the GM can
give them opportunities to accomplish them. Personal
goals should never be normal mundane activities. They
can, however, include things like “joining a specific
organization”, but only when the joining requires
some special condition to be met, such as needing the
recommendation of an existing member, and existing
members never give recommendations until after the
candidate proves themselves in some capacity.

Plot Elements – A campaign is made up of numerous
adventures. During the course of the campaign, there
will be many plot elements that the characters can or may
follow. Some will lead to specific adventures, while others
will sometimes fade away. The players themselves are often
a good source for plot elements that are incorporated into
the ongoing adventures of the campaign.
When a player provides the GM with something that
can be made into a plot element, the GM should reward
the player by doling out additional Experience Points
for it. If the plot element is formed out of something
from the player’s character’s past or from an aspect of
the character that might otherwise be considered a flaw
of the character, so much the better because it will help
tie the character, and thus the interest of the players to
the game in a stronger fashion.
Don’t forget, however, that the ultimate goal of any game
is for everybody to have fun.

113

Drive Points
Just as a reminder, many of the Individual Awards
elements listed above can also be used for determining
when to award Drive Points as well. Doing this will
encourage players to spend them more often if they
know that they can earn them more often as well.
The use of Drive Points is a great way to increase
enjoyment of the game for everybody.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Resolving Actions

This chapter contains all the rules you will need to resolve
the actions of your characters, from the simplest to the most
complex, and adjudicate their outcome and consequences.
Most of the time, players only need to describe their
character’s actions and they automatically succeed. However,
when a character is facing some kind of opposition, or when
failure could lead the game into an interesting direction, or
when the GM wants to create more tension and excitement,
Fantasy Express (FX) uses dice rolls to determine the
outcome of an action.

Basic Resolution

Everything that players might want to do in FX uses this
one single table, the Fantasy Express Action/Task (FEAT)
table to resolve all actions. A roll on this table is sometimes
referred to as a FEAT Roll.
The table itself is relatively small and versatile. There is
even a copy of it on the second page of the character sheet for
reference. Below is a short explanation of the basic results.
The basic results from the table are as follows:

UM 2 — Critical Failure: You do not get what you were
trying to accomplish and you put yourself in danger,
break a piece of equipment, take twice the time
normally required, or grant your foes a +4 to their next
roll against you. If the action attempted was an Attack
or Casting Roll, you need to roll on the appropriate
Fumble table.
3-15 — Failure: You do not get the result that you were
attempting to accomplish. This also includes any
adjusted results below 3 as well.
16-19 — Failure/Partial Success: Your attempt at the task
either fails, or you only accomplish part of what you
were attempting to do, or manage to succeed in the
action, either at the bare minimum or with a cost,
complication, or trouble.
20-34 — Success: You accomplish what you were attempting
to do with a bit of flair. You gain from 1 to 4 Success
Levels (SL) to spend on Boons that may be available,
based upon your type of action.
35+ — Critical Success: You accomplish what you were
trying do in the best and most efficient way possible.
You gain 5 Success Levels to spend on Boons that may
be available, based upon your type of action.

114

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

When there is no hurry or particular stress put on a
character to accomplish a task, then the player can declare the
character Takes the Time to perform the action more carefully.
Judging if a situation is suited for Taking the Time must be
decided by the GM.
A character Taking the Time to accomplish a task gets a
special +4 bonus to his Skill Roll, but employs at least twice
the amount of time normally associated with the action.
If an action performed by Taking the Time fails or scores
a Partial Success, the GM should always add a time-based
complication to the task’s outcome.

Skill Rolls

When a character tries to accomplish a task whose
outcome has a meaningful and interesting influence on the
situation at hand, the GM should call for a Skill Roll.
The player controlling the character makes an open-ended
roll and then adds in their character’s relevant Skill Bonus,
plus any possible modifiers.
The final result is then looked up on the Action Table
to determine whether they succeeded or not. If they earn
Success Levels (SL), the player may then use the SL to
purchase Boons that can improve their skill result in some
fashion, based upon the type of skill roll that it is. Some
skills may not have apprpriate Boons for the Success Levels
to be used on, but most will.
If there is no opposition, no pressure, and nothing
interesting is at stake, there is no need to roll the dice. The
heroes simple take enough time to succeed in their task, unless
they are attempting something that is clearly impossible.
Some tasks will automatically succeed in some situations
but require a Skill Roll in others. For example, normally
characters would not need to roll to jump over a low fence.
However, if they are attempting it at night, or in the rain, or
while being chased by some ravenous wolves, then it is likely
worth a Skill Roll.
The section on Difficulty Levels will give you some
examples of different levels of difficulty for a number of
skills. This should aid in determining when and if a Skill
Roll is required.

Difficulty
Some tasks are more difficult to accomplish than
others, requiring greater skill or luck to be accomplished
successfully. When a Skill Roll is called for, the GM must
determine the Difficulty of the task. The higher the Difficulty
of the task, the higher the negative modifier that will apply
to the roll. Refer to the following section on Difficulty for
more information.

Tools
Sometimes, tools are needed to use a Skill and perform a
task: both expendables like nails and reusable like a hammer.
Tools are implied to be necessary to perform certain tasks.
For example, a spade is necessary to dig a pit, a lockpick is
essential to open a lock without a key, an herbalist’s kit is
necessary to prepare and apply medicinal herbs, and a rope
with a hook is often needed to climb a smooth wall.
If characters don’t have the necessary tools at hand to
accomplish a specific task, they get a -2 to -6 penalty to their
Skill Roll, or they may not be able to roll for it at all, at GM’s
discretion. Particularly well-built or magic tools can also
bestow a bonus to certain actions (i.e. a magical lockpick
conferring a +4 bonus to open locks attempts), as explained
in the Item Modifiers (p. 47) section of the Skills chapter.

The Die Is Cast
Once the dice have been rolled, their result is final. A
characters’ actions cannot be taken back and their outcome
must stand until or unless something else changes it.
So if the characters fail an action, they cannot just attempt
it again and again in exactly the same way, just hoping to do
better the next time. They must either change the situation
in their favor somehow (like getting Help), or find another
way to overcome the obstacle.
Much in the same way, the GM should not ask a player
to repeat a roll for the same task once the first one has been
made, unless the situation changes dramatically.
Example: Alaise jumps across a chasm with a
successful Acrobatics Skill Roll. Later on, while
fleeing from the enraged dragon Fafnard, she finds
herself forced to cross that same chasm again.
Normally, she wouldn’t have to roll to do it, as her
previous result would stand. However, since her
current situation is far worse than the previous one
(angry dragons tend to do that), the GM can ask
her to repeat the Skill Roll, at a higher Difficulty,
due to the increased stress of the situation.

115

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Success Levels

When making skill rolls, you can earn Success Levels. Use
the following table as a guide for what Boons you may spend
those Skill-based Success Levels on.
The Combat and Magic chapters also include Boon tables
for combat and spell casting respectively. All three Boon
tables are also repeated at the end of this product.
