1

Helping

When characters team up to accomplish a difficult task,
or are performing a single task as a group (such as searching
a room, trying to sneak past some guards, or lifting a heavy
object all together), one of them must take role of the lead
character, while the others will act as helpers.
Helpers must describe how they are aiding their companion,
and then make a Skill Roll based on the action they’re
performing. On a Success the helper grants a +1 bonus for each
Success Level gained to the lead character’s Roll, while with a
Critical Success they grant a +5 bonus. On a Partial Success the
helper still grants a +1 bonus, but they also expose themselves
to some kind of complication, cost, or trouble.
On a Failure the helper grants no bonus to the lead
character, and on a Critical Failure they expose themselves
to trouble without granting any bonus.
Should the lead character’s Skill Roll fail, helpers will
share the consequences of the lead’s failure, in addition to
any cost or complication coming from their helping roll.
Only Skill Rolls can benefit from the helping rules: Attack
Rolls, normal Spell Casting rolls, and Save Rolls can never be
helped. The GM always has the final say on which task can or
cannot be helped.
Example: Tobold, Gandrell, and Athelstane
suspect the underground chamber they have found
while exploring some Dwarven ruins hides a secret
passage, and they decide to search the room. They
all act together, but Tobold the Ethori Gnome
(with his Perception score of 11) leads the search,
while the others act as helpers. Athelstane helps by
lifting the Gnome to allow him to look into places
that otherwise he wouldn’t be able to reach. The
GM rules it as an Athletics Roll, and Athelstane
scores two Success Levels, granting Tobold a +2
bonus on his Roll.
Meanwhile, Gandrell uses his dagger to check some
suspicious- looking cracks on the wall, and the GM
asks for a Perception Roll. Gandrell scores a Partial
Success, so he’ll still grant a +1 bonus to Tobold but
will also suffer a complication of some sort. The
GM decides that the blade of the Elf ’s dagger snaps
as he’s using it to inspect one of the cracks.
Once his companions are done, Tobold rolls with a
total bonus of +14 (Perception bonus of 11, +2 for
Athelstane’s help, +1 for Gandrell’s help).

116

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Conflicting Actions

Conflicting Actions are those activities where characters
vie against each other and where the success of each action
is mutually exclusive, like a contest or a race.
Examples of Conflicting Actions could be: a character
trying to flee from melee, avoiding an opponent to strike
him at his back, an arm-wrestling competition, one character
chasing another character, or two minstrels singing their
best songs to see who can better impress a princess. A
Conflicting Action could also include things like one group
trying to sneak past a guard station while the guards are
looking for anybody attempting to get past their position.
Conflicting Actions are not limited to those involving
two opposing characters: any number of competitors can
roll for a Conflicting Action; for example, when multiple
athletes are sprinting to the finish.
Conflicting Actions are resolved by having all the
characters involved roll the appropriate Skill on the Action
Table. Generally all participants will use the same Skill, but
some situations may see different characters rolling different
Skills (for example, characters trying to hide would roll
Stealth, while those looking for them would oppose with
their Perception Skill).
The results of the conflicting rolls are then interpreted
as follows:
•• Any character rolling a Critical Failure fails to act and
eventually suffers a Fumble.
•• All other characters’ Rolls are compared: the higher
result wins the conflict.
•• If there’s a tie nobody wins and the characters will have
to find another way of resolving the situation, or make
another Conflicting Action roll, but only for those
involved in the tie.
Conflicting Actions rolls can have Difficulties on their
own, if the GM think it’s appropriate.
Example: Wilvarin is trying to sneak past the
Troll guarding the gates of the fortress of a fell
necromancer. The GM decides that the situation
calls for a Conflicting Action: Wilvarin’s Stealth
against the Troll’s Perception. Wilvarin gets a
result of 23, while the Troll scores a meager 15.
Since Wilvarin’s result is higher, she wins the
conflict and is able to pass without being noticed
by the Troll.

Save Rolls

Some attacks require their target to make a Save Roll
to avoid their effects. Save Rolls are divided into three
categories: Toughness, Reflexes, and Will.
Toughness Save Rolls (TSR) represent a character’s innate
resistance to physical threats such as fatigue, poisons,
diseases, and similar effects. A character’s TSR total is
equal to 7 plus their Stamina Stat, plus their Kindred
Toughness Save modifier, plus the character’s level and
any other special modifiers that they might receive.
Reflex Save Rolls (RSR) represent a character’s innate
reaction time to avoid sudden situations such as
a pit trap opening under them or reacting to other
sudden threats. A character’s RSR total is equal to 7
plus their Dexterity Stat, plus their Kindred Reflexes
Save modifier, plus the character’s level and any other
special modifiers that they might receive.
Will Save Rolls (WSR) represent a character’s innate
resistance to effects that influence their mind and/or
soul. A character’s WSR total is equal to 7 plus their
Resolve Stat, plus their Kindred Will Save modifier,
plus the character’s level and any other special
modifiers that they might receive.

Resolving Save Rolls
When a Save Roll is called for, the character must make
an open-ended roll and add in his relative Save Roll bonus,
plus any other applicable modifiers. This roll also receives a
negative modifier equal to the level or Tier of the attack (i.e.
a 5th Tier spell gives a -5 to the Save Roll). If the total roll is a
success on the Action table, then the Save succeeded.
If the Save is triggered by an action or ability of a
creature, the creature’s level is used as the attack level
unless specified otherwise.
Example: The Terrifying Presence ability of a
Fellwing instills fear in those seeing it. Since no
Attack Level is specified in the ability description,
its Attack Level is equal to the Fellwing’s own Level.
If the action or attack that triggers the Save Roll requires
a Skill Roll, a successful Skill Roll that earns more than 1
Success Level can use the total number of Success Levels as
an additional negative modifier.
Example: Vargun the Cunning is 5th level and
he attempts to use his Deceive skill to con you
into doing something you normally would not
do. The GM determines that this would result
in a Will Save Roll, rather than being treated
as a Conflicting Action. Vargus rolls and earns 3
Success Levels. This means that the Save receives a
-8 instead of a -5 for Vargun’s level.
In all other cases, such as attacks from traps, their Level
should be listed within their description.

117

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Points Of Failure
The effects of some attacks that require Save Roll will
depend upon the margin by which their targets fail their
Save Roll. For example, an attack could deliver 1d10 Hits of
damage for every 1 point that the Save is Failed by. Another
type of attack could have a duration equal to 3 Rounds plus
1 Round per point of failure.
Since 20 is the lowest result for success, just subtract the
total result from 20 to determine the margin of failure.

Attack Rolls

Attack Rolls are covered more fully in the Combat chapter
(p. 119). Options for spending Success Levels on Combat
Boons can be found on p. 123.

Casting Rolls

Casting Rolls for spells are covered more fully in the
Magic chapter (p. 133). However, you can use the following
table to determine the Boons on which you can spend
Success Levels from spell casting rolls.

Difficulty Levels

In most instances, when the character has a given skill,
unless in tense situations, or under specific time constraints,
simply taking enough time should allow for the success in
completely most everyday tasks.
However, we do realize that some tasks will be harder
than others and so for a number of the skills, we will list
examples of skills at differing levels of difficulty. These
Difficulty Levels (DLs) automatically give a modifier to the
task being attempted, and you should keep in mind that the
examples starting on p. 199 are just that, examples, and not
meant to be a comprehensive list of actions.
Below is the list of standard Difficulty Levels and their
definitions and the modifiers associated with them.
Easy (+4): Given enough time and perhaps a tiny bit of
luck, an apprentice can complete tasks of this rating.
An averagely skilled character can accomplish this
type of task with no trouble at all.

Casting Boons

SLs Success Level Effects

Standard/Normal (+/-0): A task that an averagely skilled
character can accomplish without much trouble,
unless in a hurry or stressed. This is considered to
be the average difficulty inherent in any standard
adventuring situation. Any task or action, in such
circumstances, that seems to be the most common
for a given skill is usually of this Difficulty Rating.
Challenging (-3): A task easily accomplished by skilled
characters; however it can be tricky for a novice or
unskilled character.

Attack Advantage: Gain a +1 modifier to the caster’s attack
roll for this spell.
Harder Save: Increase the negative modifier applied to the
1+
Save Roll by 1.
Increased Targets: Spell affects 1 extra target more than
1+
normal.
Increased Range: The range of the spell is increased by 1
2+ increment. A range of Self can be increased to Touch, and
a range of Touch can be increased to 10’.
Increased Duration: The duration of the spell is increased
2+
by 1 increment. May not be used on spells with no duration.
Increased Radius: The radius of the spell is increased by 1
2+ increment. May not be used on spells that do not have an
effect with a radius.
Increased Distance: Some spells have an effect that
2+ includes a specific distance (i.e. moves point of sight 10’).
This increases that type of effect by 1 increment.
Increase Numerical Effect: When used on any spell whose
2+ non-damaging effect is measured by a number, that effect
is increased by one increment.
+ = Each Success Level beyond the intitial amount required adds
another instance of the Boon to the spell.
Increment = A number of the options refer to “increment”. An
increment is considered to be what is normal for the the
spell as it was cast (i.e. a range of 10’ means the increment
is 10’, but another spell with a range of 50’ would have an
increment of 50’; a Duration of 1 round per rank would
become 2 rounds per rank; etc.). Increment never applies to
the damage a spell attack might do.
1+

Hard (-6): A task requiring dedication and effort even
by skills characters. Even an expert needs time to
successfully complete these types of task or action.
Very Hard (-9): That is a task challenging even for a
skilled character and possibly requiring some luck
to be accomplished.
Heroic (-12): Possibly something out of reach for many
characters except for highly trained professionals.
Only an extremely skilled and lucky expert or
someone with unbelievable luck would be able to
accomplish tasks or actions of this difficulty.
Legendary (-15): Something really tough to accomplish
even by the most skilled masters without aid or with
greater luck. This difficulty is reserved for efforts that
are considered to be on the edge of human capabilities.
You could refer to a book of world records for examples
of tasks or actions of this level of difficulty.
Mythic (-20): You should not even think about it, to begin
with! These tasks or actions are a step above the
normal possibilities of the vast majority of people.
Such tasks or actions should only be attempted by
those who desire to be heroes.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Combat

Combat is a serious thing in Fantasy Express. Characters
are likely to see combat at some point or other as it is not
a safe world. There are dangers all around them and a
character never knows when he is going to have to fight.
While characters are presumed to be heroic, even the most
skillful fighter must approach combat cautiously because
of the high chance of being wounded or kills with a single
blow, even by less skilled opponents.
The rules covered in this section will aid in resolving
those inevitable conflicts and fights that the characters
always seem to get into.
First, we will go over the Combat Round and how it is
handled in general, and then we will cover the aspects of
combat such as your Defense, and your Attack Bonus, and
then how combat is actually resolved. And then, finally,
we will cover the various Combat Options that you have
available to you.

The Tactical Round

A Round, in game terms, is a convention used to denote a
short time interval, during which a series of tactical actions
can take place, when it is important to determine which
actions fit during this time frame and whoever gets to act first.

When time is not a relevant factor to consider, there is
no real need to mark its passage other than for generalized
game purposes. A single action can happen in minutes,
hours, or even span across whole days and weeks. This can
be true, for example, when heroes are traveling overland (i.e.
a single Wandering roll may cover several days of travel)
or researching complicated topics (i.e. a Lore roll may
encompass several weeks of studying and research).
However, for more frantic action, like melee combat,
missile fire, spell casting and movement in a teactical
situation, it is necessary to keep track of the passage of
time by the assumption of a standardized, countable time
unit, and that is referred to as the Tactical Round or simply
Round (rnd).
How long is a Round?
Your standard Round will last for about 5 seconds.
However, when counting down Rounds, there is no actual
need to keep track of any time unit other than the Round
itself. As soon as one Round ends, the next automatically
begins. There is a lot of action that can take place in this
short amount of time.

119

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

There are two main factors involved in resolving what
happens during a Round of combat. Those are Initiative and
Actions. Initiative is the order in which things are resolved
in a Round, and Actions are the things which characters are
attempting to accomplish.

Initiative

As mentioned above, Initiative is what determines
the order in which Actions are resolved. Given the short
duration of a Round, all Actions are considered to be
happening simultaneously or nearly so. Therefore, our use
of Initiative helps to bring order to the chaos of combat.
Note: It is recommended that Initiative only be
determined once per combat, but there is nothing
wrong with rerolling it each Round if that is what the
GM and players prefer.
To determine your character’s Initiative, you simply roll
2d10 (not open-ended) and add in your Dexterity and any
modifiers from the following list. Please note that depending
on your declared Actions for the round, those modifiers can
change, and thus change your final Initiative for the Round.
Initiative
-10
+ varies
+ varies
+5
-5
-5
-varies
-20
0
-5
-10
-10
-varies

Modifiers
Weapon Not Ready (first round only)
Shorter Weapon (in CQ - see note below)
Longer Weapon (at SMD - see note below)
Longer weapon (when closing to combat)
Two Weapon Fighting
Weapon with Heavy Quality
Shield (-1 per size; Target = -1, Tower = -5)
Surprised (first round only)
Lightly Encumbered
Medium Encumbered
Heavily Encumbered
Wounded More Than 50%
Cast Spell (-1 per 2 Tiers, rounded up)

It is recommended that GMs only roll once for all
opponents involved, to simplify things on his end. However,
if he wants to make things more dynamic, he could choose
to roll for each individual opponent.

Combat Round Sequence

Now that we know the order in which things will be resolved,
it is time to go over the individual phases of the Round.
Phase 1: Initiative & Upkeep
If you are rolling Initiative each round, this is when you
would roll it. If not rolling each round, then just check your
Initiative Modifiers to see if they have changed. Depending
on what you want to do this round, it is possible that your
Initiative gets adjusted slightly.
This is also where you perform Upkeep for the round.
Upkeep includes things like marking off Hit Points from
Bleeding your character has received, removing 1 Round of
Stun if you were Stunned for the entirety of the previous
Round. Any spell effects that ended in the previous Round
are removed at this point also.
Phase 2: Declare Actions
The GM should start of by declaring what the Actions of
the opponents will be. Once that is done, the players should
then declare their Actions for the round. It does not matter
at this point the order of declaration, and it is always possible
that one player may change his declaration after hearing the
declaration of another player. This should be allowed.
It is possible that some Declared Actions may trigger
Conflicting Actions with other characters or opponents. If
so, they are resolved in the next phase. This is also where
characters will determine how much of their Attack Bonus
(AB) they will be shifting for Parrying.
In a given Round, the character may do one of the
following:
• 1 Full Action and a Free Action OR
• 2 Half Actions and a Free Action OR
• 1 Full Action, a Half Action and a Free Action (at -4 to
all Actions) OR
• 3 Half Actions and a Free Action (at -4 to all Actions)
On the following page is the list of possible Actions, sorted
by Full, Half, or Free. It should be noted that character may
only declare 1 Attack Action or 1 Spell Casting Action per
Round. Attack Actions may involve multiple Attack Rolls,
but would still count as a single Attack Action.
Optional Rule: Some GMs may prefer to combine
the Declaration (Phase2) and Resolution (Phase
3) Phases into one single phase, by going down the
Initiative order, and having the player declare and then
resolve their actions at the same time.

Note: The weapon size modifier is +2 for each step.
This applies to the smaller weapon when within Close
Quarters (CQ; 4’ or less), and for the longer weapon
when within Standard Melee Distance (SMD; 5’ for
most weapons, 10’ for weapons with Reach).

This is quite alright and can speed up the round.
However, if handling things this way, then the GM
should be aware that this could cause issues with
Conflicting Actions, that may not appear until after
one of the two parties involved has already performed
thier Actions for the round.

Monster Initiative
For the Game Master (GM) to determine
Initiative for monsters, and/or NPCs, the GM should
subtract the creature’s (Level + 7) from their RSR to get
their Initiative Modifier.
Example: The Giant Army Ant has an RSR of 11
and it is level 1. So we subtract 8 (1 + 7 = 8) from
11 for a total Initiative Modifier of 3.

If this happens, then any participant in a Conflicting
Action who does not have at least one free Half Action
left to handle the Conflicting Action for the round
should lose a Half Action on the following round.
120

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Full Actions
• Make a single Melee Attack with no modifiers
• Aim a Ranged weapon (+4 to attack roll next round)
• Casting a Scaled Up spell
• Overcasting a Spell*
• Set vs. Charge (see p. 125)
• Walk/Jog Base Move distance
• Sprint double Base Move (-4 to DM or other attempted
actions while moving)
Half Actions
• Make a Ranged Attack
• Make a Melee Attack at -4 (weapons with Heavy quality
may not make Half Action attacks)
• Make a Melee attack using weapons with Swift quality
• Load/Reload Action (some weapons require multiple
load/reload actions)
• Aim a ranged weapon (+2 to roll)
• Walk/Jog half of Base Move
• Sprint Base Move (-4 to DM and other actions
attempted while moving)
• Casting a non-Instantaneous, non-Scaled Spell
• Concentrating on a spell or other ability
• Ready an item or drawing a weapon
• Retrieve item from pack (if pack not worn)
• Remove/don backpack
Free Actions
• Load/Reload Action with Quick Load
• Casting an Instantaneous Spell
• Casting a Cantrip
• Aim a ranged weapon (+1 to roll)
• Quick Step (Move up to 5’)
• Drop held item
• Change/Maintain Engagement Distance
• Make an Assessment Roll†
• Verbalization (i.e. talking, singing, or chanting)
• Activating certain Special Abilities or activating a
magical item
• Remove/consume item from belt pouch (i.e. herb,
potion, etc) or other readied location
* = If the Spell Caster is Overcasting (casting a spell
with a Tier higher than their own level), it requires
2 Full Actions (usually 2 rounds) to cast.
† = An Assessment Roll is essentially just a Perception
Roll made for the character to assess their current
situation. This occupies the character’s Free Action
for the round.

Phase 3: Resolve Actions
Starting at the highest Initiative and working down, each
character or opponent resolves their declared Actions in
order. However, it is possible that once resolving Actions has
begun, that a player may decide to hold their Action until
later in the Round, or cancel it. The following notes should
handle these situations.
Cancelling an Action – Any Action may be canceled before
it is resolved. The character may then perform one of
the following Actions:
•• Melee with half normal Attack Bonus.
•• Move half of his normal movement.
•• Make a Skill Roll modified by -6.
•• Perform a Free Action
Opportunity Action – Any action may be delayed by making
the action an opportunity action. Once an action
is delayed, no other action may take place until the
opportunity action is resolved or canceled. However the
opportunity action may be initiated at any time during
the current round or a following round.
Opportunity Attack – If somebody moves through your
combat zone (5’ radius around character), you may
attempt an attack against them. This is not a Free
Action; it replaces your normal attack for the round.
This is very dangerous if you are already engaged with
another foe.
Multi-Round Actions – This is any Action that requires
more than a full round to complete. A Multi-Round
Action can only be combined with Free Actions, never
with Half Actions in rounds in which it requires you to
use a Full Action on it.
Moving & Shifting Items at same time – A character may
shift items and equipment on his person (e.g. draw a
weapon, sling a shield, take out some herbs, etc.), but
the distance that he may move is decreased by 5 feet
for each item shifted (for that round). Movement also
pre-supposes relatively flat, clear space in which to
move. Terrain can reduce this distance as well.
Sprinting – May move double distance, all other actions in
the round are at -4. If attempting to shift items while
sprinting, reduce distance by 10’ for each item shifted.

Engagement Distance Note: Standard Melee Distance (SMD) is 5’ from one combatant to another for most
weapons. Weapons with Reach have an SMD of 10’. Hand Weapons are best in Close Quarters (CQ) which is 4’
or less between the combatants.
Hand weapons fight at a -1 AB per step of difference in size when fighting at SMD. Weapons larger than Hand
receive a -1 AB for each step in size above Hand. This does not affect Weapon Brawling for larger weapons in CQ.
Combatants attempting to change Engagement Distance in opposite fashions, would resolve this as a Conflicting
Action using their RSR.
121

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Defensive Capabilities

The Attack Roll

There are two main attributes to your character’s defensive
capabilities. The first is their Defensive Modifier (DM), and
the second is their Armor Rating (AR).

Defensive Modifier

This is the number that is subtracted from attacks made
against you. It is determined by your Dexterity Stat along
with several other potential modifiers.
Base Defensive Modifier: Every character has a Base
Defensive Modifier (DM). This is their Dexterity stat.
The only time that a character will not receive his
Base DB is if he is unconscious or otherwise completely
prevented from moving. A Prone character (i.e. laying
on the ground) will only receive half of his Base DM.
The DM that you record on your character sheet is
comprised of the following:
Defensive Modifier = Dexterity
- Dx Mod from armor
+ Any Quality or Magical Armor Bonuses
+ Shield Bonus (if character has/uses a shield)
+ Bonuses from any magic items that aid DM
+ Bonuses from conditions (Dim Light, Cover, etc.)
+/- Bonuses from Skills/Actions (Parrying, etc.)
The above modifiers should be recorded on the character
sheet and totaled. This is your static DM, it applies against
all incoming attacks that you are aware of.
A character’s DM may also be further modified by
positional/situational modifiers, cover, spells, and/or
Parrying. These types of modifiers would be applied on a
case by case basis at the time of the combat in which the
character is involved.

Offensive Capabilities

On the opposite side of combat, we also want to take a
look at your character’s ability to make attacks and what is
involved there.

The Attack Bonus

The Attack Bonus (AB) measures the overall effectiveness
of a character’s attacks with a given weapon, spell, or special
ability. In other words, the AB is the number that players
add to the dice roll to determine if the attack hits and how
much damage is dealt.
The character’s Attack Bonus is his total skill bonus for
one of the 5 Combat Skills (Blades, Blunt, Brawl, Polearms,
or Ranged), plus any special modifiers for the specific
weapon being used.

To make an attack, the player makes an open-ended roll
and adds in their Attack Bonus (AB) and any other applicable
modifiers. They then subtract the foe’s Defensive Modifier
(DM) from the total.
The final result is then checked on the FEAT table (p.
115). The result achieved on the table determines the result
of the attack.
• Critical Failure: The character has Fumbled the attack,
and must roll on the Weapon Fumbles table.
• Failure: The character’s attack missed or only did a
glancing blow that dealt no damage.
• Partial Success: The attack deals the Damage Rating (DR)
in Hit Damage. This is reduced by the the foe’s Armor
Rating (AR) against this type of attack.
• Success (1-4 Success Levels): The character earns one
or more Success Levels as determined by how well they
make their attack. Use the following steps to determine
what damage is dealt.
•• Determine how much base Hit Damage is dealt by
the attack. This is the Damage Rating (DR) for the
type of attack being made, plus 1 Hit of damage for
every point that the attack roll is over 20 (i.e. a total
attack roll of 24 will deal DR + 4 Hits). This cannot
exceed triple (3x) the DR of the attack, so if a weapon
has a DR of 8, you can only get another 16 Hits (24
Hits total) from results over 20.
•• Spend your Success Levels (SL) on the Combat
Boons table on the next page to determine the full
results of your attack. You may spend the SL on
Critical Damage or Combat Options, splitting the
SL between the two as you see fit. If you choose
Critical Damage, the SL costs are first adjusted
according to the foe’s SL portion of their Armor
Rating to determine how much SL is required for
each amount of Critical Damage.
•• Subtract foe’s AR for the type of attack you made
from the total amount of Hit damage dealt. Any
remaining Hit Damage and any other Critical
effects are applied to the foe.
• Critical Success (5 Success Levels)
•• Figure the results of the attack using the guidelines
given in Success above.
•• Death Strike — The foe is automatically subject
to the Death Strike entry from the Combat Boons
table on the next page. This does not use any of
the Success Levels earned by the attack. This is
also in addition to any and all damage actually
dealt by the attack.

Damage Types

Weapons and other attacks are each given a type of damage,
and a Damage Rating (DR) for that type. The Damage Rating
is a number that indicates how many Hit Points of damage
are dealt by the attack. For example, the Arming Sword has a
DR of 10s/8p. This means that when attacking the character
wielding it can choose to make a slashing attack for 10 points
of damage, or a stabbing attack for 8 points.
The types of damage dealt are as follows: bash (b), slash (s),
pierce (p), elemental (e), or grapple/grab (g). If an attack lists
more than 1 letter, that means it does both types of damage,
and when checking against the target’s Armor Rating, you use
the higher rating for reducing the number of hits delivered.
Example: The Halberd lists 8gs as part of its
Damage Rating. This refers to the hooked blade on
the back of Halberd which is used to both grab and
slash the foe. Any Hit Point damage dealt by the
attack would be reduced by the foe’s Armor Rating
for Slash attacks. However, that still leaves the
Grab/Grapple attack, and the attacker may spend
his SL from the attack to unbalance (Knock Prone)
or hold the foe until he frees himself.

Critical Damage

Critical Damage is purchased using the Success Levels
earned in the attack. Here is a quick review of what the
possible types of critical damage are and what they mean.
Bleed #
Bleeding damage does not always mean blood loss. It
stands for any type of continuing damage that further hurts
the character. It could be a number of, or combination of
separate things like bones grinding together, blood loss,
frostbite, burns, etc.
Regardless, the number after Bleed is how many Hit
Points are lost during the Upkeep Phase of every round.
This means that the Bleed damage does not actually start
until the round after it is received.
The important thing is that the damage continues
happening each round until healed or properly bandaged.
Dazed (#)
This means that the character is Dazed for a number of
Rounds equal to the number given with the result. Refer to
p. 128 for more information on this Condition.
+# Hits
Each Critical Result does an additional amount of Hit
Damage based on its severity and the type of critical. These
Hits do not count against the maximum number of Hits
allowed from the Damage Rating of the weapon.
Pain (#)
This could be sprained or injured muscles, broken bones, or
any other damage that impairs how well the character functions.
These penalties should be treated as Move Penalties that the
Armor skill cannot affect. For example, Pain (3) would result in a
-3 penalty being applied.

Stun (#)
This means that the character is Stunned for a number of
Rounds equal to the number given with the result. Refer to
p. 129 for more information on this Condition.
Held
This means that the character is Held for the remainder
of the Round in which the Condition is applied. He may not
attempt to escape until the following Round. Refer to p. 129
for more information on this Condition.
Incapacitated
This means that the character is Incapacitated as
decribed in the Condition section. Refer to p. 129 for more
information on this Condition.
Dying/Death
With either of these results, the target of the attack must
make a Save Roll or suffer the effects.

Critical Severity

The actual severity of the Critical Damage of a single attack
is based upon the overall level of damage dealt in the attack.
However, all damage is cumulative, and you may want to see if
you can determine how badly another person or foe is injured.
Doing so would require making an Assessment Roll (Perception
skill roll), with Partial Success providing their general degree of
injury. The better the success, the more you can determine.
We use 5 degrees of injury when making such determinations.
A character can be said to be wounded to a given degree so long
as he meets any one of the criteria given for a given rating.
The degrees are as follows:
Light – This includes 1-3 points of bleeding or up to -6 in move
penalties, or up to 1/4 of their total Hits in damage. This
could also include such specific injuries as pulled and
strained muscles, minor (1st degree) burns/frostbite and
other similarly minor damage.

124

Moderate – This includes 4-6 points of bleeding, move
penalties between -6 and -12, or having taken up to 1/2
their Hits in damage. Specific damage for this injury level
could include broken bones, 2nd degree burns/frostbite,
and other damage of a similar severity.
Severe – This includes 7-9 points of bleeding per round,
move penalties between -12 and -18, or taking more
than 1/2, but less than3/4 of their Hits in damage. This
could include such specific damage as shattered bones,
damaged organs, limbs that are made useless for a limited
amount of time, and other similar types of damage.
Dire – This includes bleeding more than 10 hits per round,
move penalties greater than -18, or taking more than 3/4
of their Hits in damage. Specific could include destroyed
organs, severed limbs, destroyed limbs, and other similar
types of damage.
Mortal – This condition basically means that the character
is dying. This should only be used to describe critical
results that include “dead in # rounds” results.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Offensive Actions

There are several possible types of Offensive Actions that
can be performed each Round other than a basic Attack.
They are detailed below:

Aiming
Characters wielding a missile weapon can spend extra
time to Aim at their target, increasing their chances of
finding their mark.
• Aiming is a Half Action and each Half Action spent
grants a +2 bonus to the attack roll.
• Bonuses from Aiming cannot exceed +8 in total.
• Characters taking any other Actions, except for Aiming
or making their attack with their missile weapon, will
lose all of the bonuses from Aiming accrued so far.
• Characters attacking an Aiming foe gain a +4 to AB.

Charge
Charging means heading up against an opponent at
maximum speed, running through the battlefield to deliver
the most powerful blow possible.
• A Charge is a Full Action, allowing the character to move
up to half their Base Move and attack an opponent in
melee with a +4 to their Attack Roll.
• Charging characters must move at least 10’ to reach
their target before attacking.
• Engaged characters cannot declare a Charge.
• Charging characters cannot Parry in the same Round
that they Charge.
Set vs Charge
• Set requires a Full Action (combined prepare & attack).
• Set weapon gains +4 AB (and -2 DR if not braced
against hard, unmoving surface, such as the ground)
• Longer weapon strikes first, regardless of Initiative.
• Only Polearms may be set against Mounted attacks.

Dashing Attack
A Dashing Attack is an audacious and daring attempt at
lunging at an opponent, trying to take them off gaurd with
a surprise blow.
•• A Dashing Attack is always a Full Action.
•• The character receives a -6 modifier to their AB.
•• The character gains a +10 to their Initiative for the round.
•• The character is not allowed to Parry while doing this.

Ranged Attacks
Ranged attacks allow characters to hit targets from a
distance. Such attacks are made with missile or thrown
weapons, as well as certain spells.
To make a Ranged attack, the character must have a clear
Line of Sight to the target, and the target must be within the
range of the weapon or spell.
Line of Sight
Characters have Line of Sight if they can clearly see at
least part of the target. See the section on Cover for more
information on partially hidden targets.

Attack Range
The Weapons table has a column for Range. This is the
base distance in which an attack can be made with no
modifiers for Range. If the character wishes to attack a target
that is farther than the Range for the given weapon, then the
following is applied.
• Between 0x and 0.5x Range: This is considered to be
Point Blank Range and the attack receives a +4 modifier.
• Between 0.5x and 1x Range: This is considered to be
Short Range and receives no Range modifiers.
• Between 1x and 2x Range: The attack receives a -4
modifier. This is considered to be Medium Range.
• Between 2x and 3x Range: The attack receives a -10
modifier. This is considered to be Long Range.
• Between 3x and 4x Range: the attack receives a -16
modifier. This is considered to be Extreme Range.
• Greater than 4x Range: No attack is possible.
Reloading
Missile weapons must be loaded, and thrown weapons readied
to be used to attack. Reloading a weapon requires a number of
Half Actions to accomplish, and could even take more than a full
round to accomplish. The number of Half Actions required to
load each type of weapon is listed in the Weapon’s table.
Readying a thrown weapon is a Half Action if it is not
already in hand. If already holding the weapon to be thrown,
readying it would be considered a Free Action.
Some weapons have a Quality known as Quick Load.
Weapons with this Quality are able to replace 1 Half Action
of loading each round with a Free Action.

Defensive Actions

There are several types of Defensive Actions that a
character can perform during the course of the Round. Each
is detailed below:

Block
This is a Half Action that is resolved as a Conflicting Action,
using Attack Bonus versus Attack Bonus. Blocks have the
following potential results.
• All weapons are given a size (i.e. Hand, Short, Long,
Longest) on the Weapons table (p. 104). Each step
difference in size results in a -1 modifier to the Blocker’s
roll. For example, if one character is using a Hand
weapon (dagger), and the other a Long weapon (Arming
Sword), then the modifier is -2 to the Blocker, regardless
of who is wielding which weapon.
• Characters may attempt to Block with Improvised
Weapons (p. 129), using the guidelines for them.
• Characters rolling within the Critical Failure range of
their weapon will Fumble their weapon.
• If the Blocking (defending) character wins the roll, the
incoming attack fails.
• If the attacking character wins the roll; the attack is
resolved normally against the defender’s DM.
• In the case of a draw, the defender receives one third of
his Attack Bonus (rounded up) as a bonus to his DM,
and the attack is then resolved normally.

125

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Parrying
Parrying is a method of fighting that includes, but is not
limited to, deflecting an incoming attack. This is accomplished
by shifting points from your Attack Bonus (AB) to your
Defensive Modifier (DM). The basics are as follows:
Parrying a Single Foe: for every point shifted from AB,
you get +1 to your DM (1:1).
Parrying Multiple Foes: For every 2 points shifted from
your AB, you get a +1 to your DM against all foes (2:1).
Parrying also has a few special rules and cases to be
considered as follows:
• Unarmed characters, without the Special Skill, Martial
Arts, cannot Parry armed attacks, but can Parry
unarmed or animal attacks.
• Characters wielding a missile weapon (i.e. bow, etc.) would
treat it as an Improvised Weapon for Parrying.
• Improvised Weapons: The amount shifted for Parrying
is increased by 1 (i.e. from 1:1 and 2:1 to 2:1 and 3:1
respectively. Refer to Improvised Weapons (p. 129) for
more information about what skill would be used. This
also applies to characters wielding two-handed weapons
that do not have the Quality, Swift.
• A character using a Shield may Parry multiple foes as if they
were Parrying a single foe. The bonus for Parrying comes
from the weapon being wielded along with the shield.
• Foes who receive bonuses for On Rear or Surprise may
not be Parried.
• Stunned characters Parry by getting +1 to DM for every
3 points subtracted from their Attack Bonus (3:1). They
do not get any attack rolls while stunned.
• Incapacitated, Held, or Surprised characters, or
characters suffering other conditions that negate their
DM are not able to Parry at all.
Even if a character shifts all of his Attack Bonus to his
DM for the round, he will still gets a +0 bonus Attack Roll,
unless one of the above conditions preventing attacks apply.

Cover
Objects and terrain features like trees, overturned tables,
or low walls can be used by characters to gain Cover, making
themselves harder to hit or damage by their enemy’s attacks.
Hard objects, such as rocks and wooden barricades,
overturned tables and such represent types of Hard Cover
that can be used. Soft objects, such as tree branches or a
Giant Spider’s web, and other things that hide a body, but do
not actually stop an attack would represent Soft Cover.
• Half Soft Cover: up to 50% hidden by soft objects (i.e.
webbing, Dim Light, etc.), gain +2 DM
• Half Hard Cover: up to 50% hidden by hard objects
(i.e. trees, rocks, etc.), gain +4 DM
• Full Soft Cover: 50%-90% hidden, gain +4 DM
• Full Hard Cover: 50%-90% hidden, gain +10 DM

Diving For Cover
Characters aware of an incoming attack can drop Prone
(see Combat Conditions) to the ground or behind nearby
Cover. This allows for a small Move, and Actions may be
Cancelled to do this.
• Dive For Cover: May move up to 5’ to dive behind
Cover as a Free Action, ending with character being
Prone afterwards.

Disengaging
Character can opt to Disengage from melee by taking
a Full Action to do so. While Disengaging, they can use
their Attack Bonus to Parry, but without any Attack Rolls.
Characters who are Disengaging are considered to no longer
be Engaged at the end of the round.

Dodging
Dodging is the act of deliberately giving up other actions to
move out of the way of an incoming attack.
Performing a Dodge is a Full Action, and the character cannot
attack in the same round. The character may also cancel any
declared, but unperformed actions to perform a Dodge.
To perform a Dodge, the character makes a Reflex Save Roll,
adding his skill ranks (not total bonus) from his Acrobatics
skill to his Save Roll. The attack level of the Save is the attackers
AB for the attack. Attempting to Dodge a ranged attack is at -2
against thrown weapons, and -4 against fired weapons.
If the Dodge prevents the character from being hit, he
may use it both as a method of Disengaging, and to move the
character up to 10’ away from their foe. A Dodge does not
allow a character to move past their foe.

Running Away
Desperate character may simply attempt to escape their
attackers, by Running Away as fast as possible.
Running Away is a Conflicting Action, resolved with
opposed Athletics skill roll:
• Any character scoring a Critical Failure trips and falls Prone.
• If the escaping character wins, they can immediately use a
Full Action to move away from their attackers.
• If the attacker wins, they can strike at the escaping
characters, gaining positional bonuses for an On Rear
attack, before the escaping character can move away.
The escaping character can then move away, if they are
still standing after the attack.
• If there is a draw, the attacker gets to attack the escaping
characters with half of their normal Attack Bonus (no
bonus for On Rear; then the escaping characters can
move out of their reach.

126

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Weapon Fumbles
Whenever a character makes an unmodified
rolls within the Critical Failure (CF) range for the
weapon that they are wielding, that is an automatic
Fumble of their weapon. Most weapons have a
Critical Failure range of 2, but some weapons have
a CF range of 3 or 4 or higher. Refer to the Weapons
table (p. 104) for more information. The player
would then make a roll on the Weapon Fumbles
table, adding in modifiers from the Weapon Fumble
Modifiers table.
Note: Some results on the Weapon Fumbles
table are marked if applicable. These options
cannot be chosen if the conditions do not apply
to your character (i.e. cannot chose to break a
string if not using a weapon that has a string).

Conditions

Facing

Conditions are special effects or situations that may influence
characters during a fight or other parts of their adventures.
Some of them are consequences of being struck or wounded,
while others depend upon positioning on the battlefield.
Unless otherwise specified, different Conditions can
stack with one another, while multiples instances of the
same Condition do not stack (i.e. a Prone character does not
become “more Prone” by receiving that Condition a second
time). However, some Conditions will stack by extending
the duration of the Condition (i.e. a Stunned character who
receives another Stunned result is Stunned for an extra
Round, they are not double Stunned).

Bruised
A character who has received half or more of their Total
Hit Points in damage is considered Bruised. This also means
that he receieves a -4 to all Actions (except DM and Saves).

Dazed
Characters are slightly staggered, unbalanced, and/or
disoriented for one or more rounds.
• Dazed is considered to be a type of Stun for the
purposes of relieving Stun.
• Dazed characters are at -4 to all actions while Dazed.
• Dazed characters who are also Stunned resolve the
rounds of Stun before they resolve the Rounds of Dazed.
• A character who receives one or more rounds of Dazed
before they act for the round, are still able to complete
their Actions, but with a -2 modifier, and they are then
Dazed the following round. If they have already taken
their Actions, they are simply Dazed the following round.

During combat, characters are constantly moving. If the
character is only up against one foe, it is presumed that they
will be constantly shifting position so that they are facing that
foe. However, if facing multiple foes, or if attacked by Surprise,
the character might not be attacked from the front. Of course,
the same applies to multiple characters attacking a single foe.
To that end, we have included the following Facing
guidelines. Please keep in mind that they usually only apply
when a single character is facing off against multiple characters,
or if they are taken by Surprise or are unable to change their
Facing for some reason. The image shown below is meant to
only provide a general idea of what we are referencing.
Flanking
Characters that are attacking an opponent from the side
are considered to be Flanking.
• A Flanking attacker gets a +3 to their attacks.
• A Flanked character may only apply their Shield’s bonus
to DM against attacks coming from the Shield side.
On Rear
Characters attacking foes from behind are considered to
be On Rear.
• Attackers On Rear gain a +6 bonus to their attacks.
• Characters do not receive their Shield’s bonus to DM
against attacks from On Rear.

Dying
A Dying character will die in a given number of Rounds
if this Condition is not removed.
Characters Dying from HP loss can be saved by simply
raising their current HP above their death threshold.
Otherwise the Dying condition will be removed as soon as
its causes are healed (i.e. a character Dying from Bleeding
will be saved once the bleeding is stopped).
Note: Threshold for death from Hit damage is equal to
the character’s Kin Base Hits + (2 x the his Stamina).

Engaged
Characters that are within melee range of a foe’s weapon,
when that foe is aware of their presence, are considered to
be Engaged. Engaged characters may not make Movement
Actions unless they Disengage or try to Run Away first.
Failure to do either of those Actions while attempting to
move away from an Engaged foe will result in the foe(s) that
they are engaged with being able to make a free Attack, with
bonuses for On Rear and/or Flank if they have not yet made
their attack for the round. Characters may be Engaged with
multiple foes at once.

Frightened
Some fear inducing spells or special abilities may cause
character to become Frightened if the fail a Will Save.
Frightened creatures cannot attack the object of their fear,
but can still Parry if attacked. Frightened creatures will
attempt to flee from the source of their fear if possible. The
duration of this Condition is specified in the description of
the spell or ability that caused it.

128

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Held

Surprised

Held characters are restrained by some other creature or
force and cannot move freely.
• Held characters cannot use their Actions to move and
suffer a -6 penalty to both their AB and DM.
• Attacks against a Held character gain a special +6 bonus,
in addition to the -6 to both AB & DM listed above.
• Held characters may attempt to break free once per Round
using any means available, based on how they are Held.
• Held characters can only use Hand or Short weapons.
• A Held character cannot use Ranged Weapons.
Note that while unable to move, Held characters are
not completely paralyzed. Paralyzed characters would be
considered Incapacitated.

A character is considered Surprised when they are
attacked without being aware of it. Generally, the Surprised
condition only lasts a single Round.
• To determine Surprise, make a Conflicting Actions
roll using Perception. If one group already knows of
the other, they cannot normally be Surprised, so the
Conflicting Action is used to determine the Surprise of
the other group only.
•• Both Groups succeed: Neither is Surprised
•• Both Groups tie: Neither is Surprised
•• One Group Succeeds, One Fails: Group that fails
is Surprised
•• Both Groups fail: Both groups are Surprised
• Surprised characters cannot Attack or cast Spells.
• Surprised characters may only perform Half or Free Actions.
• Surprised characters cannot Parry and do not receive
any Shield bonus to their DM.
• Attacks against a Surprised character get a +4 modifier.

Incapacitated
Characters that are knocked out, sleeping, paralyzed, or
otherwise unable to defend themselves are Incapacitated.
• Incapacitated characters cannot take Actions and
cannot Parry.
• Attacks against Incapacitated characters are always
treated as if the player had a total result of 35. No
modifiers are applied to this result.

Prone
Characters that are knocked down or lying on the ground
are considered to be Prone.
• Characters only receive half of their DM while Prone.
• Prone characters fighting from the ground suffer a -4
modifier to their AB and cannot use two-handed weapons.
• Against Ranged attacks, Prone characters may make a
side roll as a Free Action. This grants them +4 to DM.
• Standing characters attacking a Prone character gain a
Higher Ground (+4 AB) positional bonus.
• Standing up from Prone is a Full Action that requires the
character be free to move (i.e. not Held or Incapacitated).
While standing up, the character gets his full DM and
can Parry, but they are still considered Prone.
• Prone characters can crawl as a Full Action at 1/10th of
their Base Move (rounded off).

Stunned
Characters are severely staggered, unbalanced, and/or
disoriented for one or more rounds.
• Stunned characters cannot take Full Actions.
• Stunned characters cannot make any Attacks or cast
any Spells, except Spells that relieve Stun.
• Stunned characters may defend themselves by Parrying,
gaining +1 to their DM for every 3 points that they
have in their Attack Bonus (3:1).
• A character who receives a Stun before they act for the
round, are still able to complete their Actions, but with
a -4 modifier, and they are then Stunned the following
round. If they have already taken their Actions, they are
simply Stunned the following round.

Weary
Weary characters cannot move faster than half their Base
Move (rounded down) and can only perform a Single Action
each Round. They also cannot recover Hit Points or heal from
Bleeding or other injuries until this Condition is removed.
The Weary condition is removed by resting for at least 8
hours in a safe environment.

Combat Options

The following guidelines are intended to help make
combat more dynamic and fun overall. Many of the listed
options are for special case scenarios.

Improvised Weapons
When caught in a pinch, heroes could be forced to defend
themselves using work tools, rocks, pieces of furniture, or
other improvised weapons.
Characters using an improvised weapon can attack using
an appropriate Combat Skill with a -4 modifier or using
their Brawl skill bonus.
To resolve the attack, use the stats of the weapon most
similar to what the character is wielding. The Damage Rating
of such attacks would be 2 points less than the similar weapon.
The Critical Failure range for the improvised weapon would
also be 1 point higher than the actual weapon would be.

Mounted Fighting
Fighting while mounted can be tricky, but it can also
provide a big advantage to the mounted combatant.
Mounted Weapons
First of all, for characters wanting to fight from horseback,
they must wield a proper weapon to do so.
Only Long or Longest one-handed weapons and ranged
weapons like Short Bows and all types of crossbows may be
used while mounted.

129

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Ride Check
Characters wishing to fight while mounted must pass a
Ride skill roll the first time that they declare their intention
to do so in combat, with the following possible results:
Critical Failure: The character falls from the mount
and suffers any consequences deemed appropriate.
Typically, this is falling damage, plus ending up Prone,
but it could include being trampled by other mounts.
Failure: The rider remains mounted, but must take a Half
Action each Round to control the mount. Uncontrolled
mounts will try to flee from the battle, unhorse their
rider, or attack a random enemy, according to their
nature and training. Characters suffer a -4 to their DM
and cannot attack while riding an uncontrolled mount.
Partial Success: The character can control the mount as a Free
Action, and is considered as having Higher Ground (+4 AB)
for attacks against foes on foot for this Round. They must
make another Ride skill roll on the following round.
Success: The character can control the mount, no further
rolls required, as a Free Action, and is considered as having
Higher Ground (+4 AB) for attacks against foes on foot.
The character also does +1 Hit of damage for any attacks
against foes on foot, for each SL gained in the Ride roll.
Critical Success: As Success, but the character also gets
+4 to their DM for the whole combat while mounted.
The effects of the skill roll persists for the entire combat,
unless stated otherwise. Characters only need to reroll when
instructed to (i.e. such as in Partial Success), their situation
changes dramatically (i.e. the mount panics or has to get
through an obstacle), or if they receive a blow that might
unmount them.
Only characters riding into battle need to roll. No skill rolls
are required for combatants on mounts that are not moving.
Attacking the Mount
Sometimes a combatant will strike at the mount instead
of the rider. This attack is resolved normally, but if the
mount suffers Critical Damage, its rider must make another
Ride skill roll, regardless of the effects of the attack itself.
If the mount is killed or seriously injured, of course, there
is no way for the rider to continue fighting while mounted,
and the character must either dismount as quickly as
possible or fall to the ground.
Charging while Mounted
Characters charging into melee while mounted and
having succeeded in their Ride skill roll will receive an
additional +4 to their Attack Roll, on top of the standard
bonuses from Charging.

Ranged Attacks in Melee
Normally, ranged attacks are directed against distant foes,
but there are occassions in which characters may be forced
to use a ranged weapon or spell while Engaged in melee. In
these cases, the following applies:
• Engaged characters suffer a -4 to all ranged Attack Rolls.
• Combatants may Parry non-magical ranged attacks
made by characters Engaged with them as if they were
wielding a Shield one size larger than they have, or as if
they are using a Buckler if they had no Shield.
• Readied thrown weapons would not suffer the -4
mentioned above.

Shooting into Melee
Characters Engaged in melee have Partial Hard Cover (see
section on Cover) against all ranged attacks aimed at them.
Furthermore, if a ranged attack against a target Engaged
in melee misses, then the original attack roll must be
checked against each potential target in the line of fire,
starting with those closest to the attacking character. Line
of Fire is defined as a 5’ wide path between the attacker and
his intended target, extending past that target out to the
Extreme Range of the weapon.

Fighting with Two Weapons
Characters desiring to fight wielding two weapons at once
must keep in mind that this is often hardly practical. Skilled
fighters attacking with two weapons simultaneously, however,
can be very effective against lesser skilled opponents.
• Weapons that are 2-handed or have the Weapon Quality
of Heavy cannot be used in two weapon fighting. Hand
and a Half weapons may be used 1-handed (with the
normal -2 modifier).
• Attacks follow the normal guidelines for how what
Actions are required (i.e. Full or Half, and along with
any modifiers associated with those Actions) for attacks.
• Both attacks receive a -2 modifier to the Attack Roll.
• Off-hand Attacks receive an additional -4 modifier.
• Both attacks must be directed at a single foe in front of
the character, unless they have one of the Special Skills,
Dual Weapons (p. 56) or Two Weapon Combo (p. 59).
• The Critical Failure range for both weapons is increased
by 2, so attacks Fumble on an unmodified roll of 4 or less,
or more if one of the weapons has a higher CF range.
• The character’s initiative is affected when using two
weapons. They receive a -5 to Initiative rolls (this is also
listed under the Initiative Modifiers).
• If Parrying, the same amount is subtracted equally
from both attacks (i.e. to add +2 to DM, the character
subtracts 2 from each weapon while Parrying).

130

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Martial Moves

Grapple

Martial Moves are special attacks or defenses that a combatant
may want to use in certain situations. They include all those
tactics, tricks, and feats of arms that characters may attempt to
obtain particular effects not covered by a normal attack, like
disarming their foe or knocking them to the ground.
The following Martial Moves are just a few possibilities of
what can be done. Not every Move is suitable for every weapon,
so just use your best judgment on which weapons can do what.
Players are encouraged to come up with their own tactics and
Martial Moves. GMs and players both are encouraged to use the
following as templates the creation of new Martial Moves.

Disarm
Character may attempt to Disarm opponents that they
are Engaged with, removing the weapon that the opponent
is holding from their grip, instead of attacking. A Disarm
attempt is a Full Action, however, character may still attempt
to Parry while performing a Disarm. This action would
be resolved as a Conflicting Action, the character’s Attack
Bonus, minus the amount shifted for Parrying, against the
foe’s Attack Bonus.
• If the character rolls within the CF range of the weapon
that they are using, they Fumble their weapon and must
roll on the Weapon Fumbles table.
• If there is a draw, or the character performing the
Disarm loses, the Disarm attempt fails.
• If the character wins, the opponent is Disarmed, and
their weapon flies from 1 to 10’ away.
• If the Disarming character gets a Critical Success, the
opponent is Disarmed, and the character may grab the
weapon if they have a free hand, otherwise the weapon
goes flying 6-15’ (5 + 1d10) away.
• If the defending character wins with a Critical Success, the
Disarming character automatically Fumbles their weapon.

Feint
A Feint is a special maneuver used to trick the target into
Parrying a false attack, followed up with a deadly strike.
Characters can use a Half Action to attempt a Feint against
an opponent that they are Engaged with, followed by a Half
Action attack. The Feint itself is resolved as a Conflicting
Action, using the Feinting character’s Deceive skill against
their opponent’s Perception skill.
• Characters rolling within the Critical Failure range of their
weapon on the Deceive skill roll will Fumble their weapon.
• If the Feinting character wins the roll, they get a special
bonus equal to the difference between their Deceive roll
and thier opponent’s Perception roll to all their Attack rolls
against that opponent for the remainder of the round.
• If the defending character wins; they get a special bonus
equal to the difference between the rolls to their DM against
the Feinting character for the remainder of the round.
• In the case of a draw, neither receive any bonus.

A Grapple, also called a Grab, is an attempt to prevent the
target of the attack from being able to move or take Actions.
Grappling an enemy requires a Full Action, and is considered
an attack. Characters attempting to Grapple a foe must take a
Conflicting Action against their target, pitting their Brawl skill
against the foe’s Brawl skill (or the RSR of creatures or animals).
Grapple attempts using Martial Arts may also inflict damage.
• Critical Failure on either side results in a roll on the
Weapon Fumbles table.
• If the attacking character wins, the target is Held.
• If the attacking character wins with a Critical Success, the
target is considered to be both Held and Incapacitated for
as long as the attacker desires to continue to hold him.
• If the defender wins, the attacker is thrown off balance,
and must make an Assessment Roll at the beginning of
the next Round.
• If the defender wins with a Critical Success, the attacker
is considered to be Held.
• A Held character may attempt to break free once per
Round by initiating another Grapple contest (at a -6 for
being Held) if they are wanting to place their foe into a
hold of their own, or by using a Toughness Save Roll (using
Brawn instead of Stamina) against the number of ranks
in Brawl that the opponent has as the level of the attack.

Knock Down
A Knock Down is an attempt to make an opponent fall to the
ground. Knocking Down an enemy requires a Full Action, and
is considered an attack. Characters attempting a Knock Down
must take a Conflicting Action against their target, pitting their
Brawl skill against the foe’s Brawl skill (or the Reflex Save Roll of
creatures or animals). Knock Down attempts using Martial Arts,
often called Throws, may also inflict damage.
• If either results in a Critical Failure, they must make a
roll on the Weapon Fumbles table.
• If the attacker wins, the target is knocked Prone.
• If the attacker wins with a Critical Success, the target is
Prone and Stunned for a number of rounds equal to the
difference between the rolls.
• If the defender wins, the attacker must make an
Assessment Roll at the beginning of the next Round.
• If the defender wins with a Critical Success, the attacker
is knocked Prone and Stunned 1 Round.

131

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Lock

Riposte

Locking is a special maneuver used to prevent opponents
from attacking or defending themselves by binding or
trapping the foe’s weapon. For those trained in the Martial
Arts, this is considered to also be a specialized type of
Grapple attack.
A Lock attempt is similar to a Disarm attempt, as it requires
a Full Action, and allows the character performing this move
to use their Attack Bonus to Parry, should they wish to do so.
Characters attempting this move follow the rules for Conflicting
Actions, using their Attack Bonus, minus any amount shifted
for Parrying against the foe’s Attack Bonus.
• Character rolling a Critical Failure, must roll on the
Weapon Fumbles table for their Attack.
• If the Locking character wins or the roll results in a tie, both
the Locking character and their target become Locked. As
long as they are Locked, they cannot move, attack, or Parry.
They must take another Conflicting Action each Round to
see if the situation changes. Characters may also escape
from a Lock by dropping their weapon. Locked characters
are considered to be Held when it comes to attacks from
those not involved in the Lock.
• If the defending character wins, the attacker loses the
action, and fumbles their weapon, rolling on Weapon
Fumbles table.

A Riposte is a special maneuver that combines a Parry
with a counterattack. By allowing their foe to attack first, the
character uses their Parry to pull their foe out of position,
allowing their attack to be more powerful.
The Riposte is a Full Action. The character declares how
much of their Attack Bonus that they are putting into Parrying
their foe. They then hold their own Attack action until the foe
strikes. If the character is wielding a weapon with the Quality,
Martial, the +2 bonus from it is added to their Attack Bonus
before they decide how much to use for Parrying.
If the foe’s attack is unsuccessful (does no Critical
Damage), the Riposting character then may make his attack,
and he gains a special bonus to that attack. This
• If the foe does Hit Point Damage to the character, he
only receives a bonus of +2 to his attack.
• If the foe’s attack does no damage at all, the character
gains a +4 to their attack.

Maintain Distance
Weapons with Reach allow characters to engage with foes
at a distance. It can also allow a character to keep a foe with a
shorter weapon out of melee range, or at least out of its most
effective melee range.
This Move is sometimes referred to as Hold at Bay. It
requires a Full Action to perform and if successful, the foe is
prevented from closing and may also receive damage.
This Move is resolved as a Conflicting Action, using the
character’s effective Attack Bonus, after Parry and other
potential adjustments, against their opponent’s Athletics or
Acrobatics skill bonus.
• Character who roll a Critical Failure, must roll on the
Weapon Fumbles table for the weapon they have in hand.
• If the result is a tie, then the distance is maintained, and
neither character may attack this round, nor may they
close distance or move away from each other.
• If the character performing this Move wins, he may
then make an attack, as part of this Move’s Full Action,
against his foe using the same bonus as the Conficting
Action, but with an additional -4 modifier.
• If the character perfoming this Move wins with a
Critical Success, then he may also make an attack, as
part of this Move’s Full Action, against his foe using the
same bonus as is used for the Conflicting Action.
• If the defending character wins, he is able to close with
the character attempting this Move and make a normal
attack, or he instead be considered to have successfully
Disengaged if that is what he wants.

Shield Bash
In the hands of a skill fighter, a shield is not only a defensive
item, but it can be turned into a dangerous weapon.
Characters wielding a shield can attempt a Shield Bash as
a Half Action, attacking with either their Brawl skill bonus
with a -4 modifier, or their Blunt skill bonus.
If a shield is used to attack, however, the character loses
its bonus to his DM for the Round. If the shield has already
been used defensively against an attack (i.e. its bonus applied
to DM against an attack), it cannot be used to attack in the
same Round.
When used to attack, the shield will have a Damage
Rating equal to double its DM. Thus a Round Shield, which
has a DM of 3, would have a Damage Rating of 6b. Some
shields may be embossed with a spike to enable them to do
piercing damage as well.
A shield would be considered as a secondary weapon for
the purpose of the rules for Fighting with Two Weapons, and
thus adjustments from those rules would also apply to any
attacks made with a Shield.
Note: Shields never have the Weapon Quality,
Martial, therefore the Shield Bash does not
receive a +2 bonus for this Move, even if the
character is wielding a weapon with that Quality.

132

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Magic

Magic is often a big part of many fantasy campaigns. Our
goal here is to provide a flexible and robust system of magic
that can be incorporated into many different styles of play.
As always, it up to the GM to determine if this fits well with
his campaign.

How Magic Works

There are several different elements involves in casting
a spell. In the simplest of terms, magic users access energy
referred to as Mana and weave this energy into a matrix,
which, when complete, will cause something to happen. The
creation of this energy matrix is referred to as casting a spell
or more rarely, weaving a spell.
Those who are capable of casting spells are called spell
casters or magic users. Each magic user has access to one or
two Schools of Magic. A School of Magic is a collection of
philosophies about how to tap into and weave Mana into
actual spells. Schools determine the sorts of spells that are
cast and what they look like.
Each School of Magic has a Codex (list) of 30 spells that
can be learned by Arcanists. Each School also has a subset
of 12 spells, known as a Folio, that represent the spells that
Hybrids are able to learn. This Folio is part of the Codex that
Arcanists have access to.
There is also a Folio of 10 Universal spells that any caster
may learn.
Each spell, regardless of where it comes from, is learned
as a separate skill.

Mana

In short, Mana is a special type of energy that bleeds into
the physical world from, according to some scholars, the
Astral Plane. Other scholars have conflicting ideas.
These include Mana channeled to some spell users from
higher powers (deities and/or infernal lords), that there
is ambient Mana in all things and casters just siphon it to
power their spell, that some casters absorb Mana and then
focus it through their minds
What often sets magic users apart from others is their
ability and skill in tapping into that energy, regardless of its
source, and using it to craft and power changes to reality
known as spells. Refer to p. 109 for more information on
figuring how much Mana your character can manipulate
each day.

Recovering Mana
As magic users cast spells, they must spend an amount of
Mana equal to the Tier of the spell. Once spent, that Mana
is no longer available until the caster can recover it. Mana is
recovered through sleep. Eight hours of uninterrupted sleep
is required for a caster to regain all of their Mana. Four hours
of sleep will allow them to recover at least half their Mana.
A minimum of two hours of sleep will allow a caster to
recover up to one quarter (rounded down) of their Mana.
If a caster gets less than two hours of sleep, they will not
recover any Mana.

133

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Casting Spells

Spells are way of manipulating what is sometimes referred
to as psycho-active energy, commonly called Mana, to produce
repeatable effects, for the most part.
Spellcasting can be dangerous, especially if those energies
get away from the caster. To this end, we treat every spell as
its own skill. Each spell has a base effect that happens when it
is cast correctly at its least powerful Tier. Each spell can also be
altered as it is being cast, to produce more powerful effects. This
is referred to as Scaling Up the spell, and the manner in which a
spell may be altered are referred to its Scaling Options.
Some Scaling Options increase the Tier of the spell, and
thus increase the amount of Mana required by the spell. Other
Scaling Options provide what are called Casting Modifiers
(CM) and they make the spell harder to cast overall.
Additionally, all spells have a few other casting requirements
that must be met or else the caster risks Abnormal Spell
Failure (ASF), and will need to make roll on the Spell Fumble
table should they receive a Critical Failure.

Casting Resolution
Once you have determined all the modifiers for your Casting
Roll, you then make the roll, using the Spell Lore skill for the
spell to be cast. Here is a listing of the potential results:
Critical Failure: The caster has fumbled the spell. Requires
making a roll on the Spell Fumbles table.
Failure: The spell completely fails. The Mana Points for
the spell are still expended.
Failure/Partial Success: Spell either fails with no mana cost,
has half normal effect, if possible, at normal mana cost, or
is cast as intended at double mana cost (player’s choice).
Success: The caster succeeds in casting the spell as
intended. The caster may spend any Success Levels
earned on the Casting Boons table.
Critical Success: All effects/attributes of the spell are
doubled, and the character gains 5 Success Levels to
purchase effects from the Casting Boons table.

Casting Requirements
The casting of spells have a few requirements that apply
regardless of their School of Magic, and some Schools may
have other specific requirements as well.
•• The spell to be cast must be from the caster’s Codex
and/or Folio(s).
•• The caster must have a number of skill ranks in the
spell equal to double the Tier of the spell to be cast.
•• The caster must have enough Mana and expend it
to power the spell. This can be their own personal
Mana, from using Essential Salts, or other sources.
•• The caster must be able to speak the verbal
components of the spell in a normal voice.
•• The caster must have at least one hand that is either
free or holding a Casting Focus, such as a wand or
holy symbol.
Casting Modifiers
The following are methods that casters can use to offset
negative modifiers from Casting Options and Abnormal Spell
Failure (ASF). They include the following:
Casting Focus: Many casters will use a Casting Focus of
some sort in the casting of their spells. This could be a
wand, rod, holy symbol, or another item specific to the
caster. Some Mages also use spell components that are
consumed in the casting of their spells. While using
this Casting Focus, the character gains a +4 to their
rolls, but only to offset Casting Modifiers.
Flamboyant Gestures: By using larger, more flamboyant
gestures, the character receives a +2 to their Casting
Roll to offset Casting Modifiers.
Flamboyant Incantations: By speaking more loudly and
emphatically, the character gains a +2 to their Casting
Roll to offset Casting Modifiers.

134

Casting Boons

SLs Success Level Effects

Attack Advantage: Gain a +1 modifier to the caster’s attack
roll for this spell.
Harder Save: Increase the negative modifier applied to the
1+
Save Roll by 1.
Increased Targets: Spell affects 1 extra target more than
1+
normal.
Increased Range: The range of the spell is increased by 1
2+ increment. A range of Self can be increased to Touch, and
a range of Touch can be increased to 10’.
Increased Duration: The duration of the spell is increased
2+
by 1 increment. May not be used on spells with no duration.
Increased Radius: The radius of the spell is increased by 1
2+ increment. May not be used on spells that do not have an
effect with a radius.
Increased Distance: Some spells have an effect that
2+ includes a specific distance (i.e. moves point of sight 10’).
This increases that type of effect by 1 increment.
Increase Numerical Effect: When used on any spell whose
2+ non-damaging effect is measured by a number, that effect
is increased by one increment.
+ = Each Success Level beyond the intitial amount required adds
another instance of the Boon to the spell.
Increment = A number of the options refer to “increment”. An
increment is considered to be what is normal for the the spell
being cast (i.e. a range of 10’ means 10’ increment, but a spell
with a base range of 50’ would have a 50’ increment’; a Duration
of 1 round per rank would become 2 rounds per rank; etc.).
Increment never applies to the damage a spell attack might do.
