Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Spell Casting Notes

Attack Spells

Abnormal Spell Failures

Save Rolls

The following sections provide guidelines and notes
regarding various aspects of casting spells.
This is actually a group of related modifiers to the Casting
Rolls where the caster is unable to meet the basic Casting
Requirements as listed under the section for Casting Spells.
This is very dangerous since it makes Critical Failures
much more likely and the results of such failures more
dangerous in many ways.
The Critical Failure (CF) range for any spell with ASF will
have the ASF modifier added to it.
Example: If Overcasting a spell that requires a
minimum of 8 ranks in it, and you only have 6 ranks,
that spell will have a Critical Failure range of 2-4 (2 base
CF range + 1 for each missing rank (2) = 4). So any
unmodified dice roll within that range will result in a
Critical Failure. If also not using Gestures (+4 ASF), the
CF range would be 2-10, since the ASF modifiers would
total to 8. All ASF modifiers are cumulative.
Should the character receive a Critical Failure result while
using an ASF modifier, he must make a roll on the Spell Fumble
table, using triple his ASF modifier as a modifier to that roll.
Here is short list of potential ASF modifiers:
Spells within School/Outside Codex/Folio..............+5
Spells from Different School....................................+10
Overcasting Non-Istantaneous Spell............... +1/rank
Overcasting Instantaneous Spell..................... +2/rank
Undercasting.......................................... +3/Mana Point
No Gestures..................................................................+4
Subtle Gestures............................................................+2
No Incantations...........................................................+4
Quiet Incantations.......................................................+2
Soul Burn.......................................... +5/1 Soul Damage
Armor..................................................................... varies
Here is a small definition of some of the above:
Spells that are not normally learnable: These modifiers are
applied for spells that a caster is not normally allowed to learn.
This includes spells from the Codex that are not part of a
Hybrid’s Folio, or spells from a different School altogether.
Overcasting: This is applied for each missing skill rank required
by the spell’s Tier (2x Tier). Overcasting also affects the spell’s
Casting Time (p. 136).
Undercasting: This is applied for each point of required
Mana that is missing when casting the spell.
Gestures: These modifiers are used if you cannot make the
required gestures.
Incantations: These modifiers are used if you cannot speak
the words/incantations of the spell as required.
Soul Burn: For each point of Soul Damage, the caster gains
up to 5 Mana to use in a spell currently being cast. Refer
to Soul Damage (p. 219) for more information.
Armor: Refer to Armor & Shields (p. 88) for more information
on the amount of ASF applied.

There are two types of attacks spells. There are spells that
require Save Rolls and those that make physical attacks
against their targets.
For Spells that require Save Rolls, the magic user casts
the spell as normal, using the results as described under the
Casting Spells section. The Tier of the attacking spell is used
as a negative modifier on the target’s Save Roll. If they achieve
Success in their Save Roll, they resist the effects of the spell.

Bolt Spells
Many physical attacks against a single foe are called Bolt
spells simply because they resemble the type of attack you
might see from an arrow or crossbow bolt. For spells of this
type, the caster must first cast the spell correctly. He must
then make an Attack Roll using either his Ranged skill or
his Arcana skill, whichever is higher. This Attack Roll is then
resolved as any other ranged attack, with the sole exception
being that the spell has only the range determined by the
spell, it does not have a Medium, Long, or Extreme Range as
other thrown or missile weapons have. If the spell exceeds
its range, it simply dissipates harmlessly.

Ball Spells
Ball spells are spells that create a small sphere or other shape
which are then thrown at their target, and upon reaching that
distance, they explode to fill up the radius determined by the
spell. If there is something blocking part of the radius, the spell
fills up what it can. A 5’ radius spell thrown against a wall does
not fill up the free half of that 5’ radius with double the amount
of energy (i.e. doing double damage), it simply fills up what
space is available within its confines.
When making Ball Attacks, the caster has a choice of
attempting to hit a specific target or to hit an empty space
near one or more targets. In either case, the caster first casts
the spell as normal.
They then they make a second roll for the Attack Roll, using
the higher of their Ranged or Arcana skill. Success Levels from
this roll are spent on the Combat Boons table and if used for
Critical Damage, apply equally to all affected, except as noted
below. Any damage received is still mitigated by armor worn.
All within the radius of the spell will have this damage
applied to them. If the spell is aimed at a specific target, that
target gets a Reflex Saving Roll to avoid being the center of
effect. If they fail that Save, they take +4 hits of damage. If
they make a Critical Success on the Save, they take only half
damage (rounded down).
Those within 3’ of the edge of the radius may make a Reflexes
Saving Roll to take only half damage on a success (round
down). If they make a Critical Success on their Save, they
take no damage. Those who attempt a RSR to avoid damage
must do so by canceling their current actions if they have not
been performed yet. Those who have already performed their
actions lose a Half Action the following round.

135

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Cone Spells
Cone Spells work just like Ball Spells, except that they fill a
cone shaped area with the caster at the apex of the cone. The
main difference being that there is no center of effect possible.
The cone has a width of 1’ at the caster’s end, and the far
end has a width of 2.5 feet for every 5 feet of length that the
cone has.
Damage is determined and/or avoided in the same way as
for Ball Spells.

Line Spell
A line spell has a width of 1’ for its entire length. It
attacks all foes within the line of attack, even if a foe with
fully within the line, seemingly blocking it, it will continue
on past him to the full length, only being stopped by solid
barriers such as walls or doors.
Just as with Ball and Cone attack spells, the caster makes his
casting roll, and then makes an Attack Roll separately. For Line
spells, a successful Reflex Saving Roll means that the target is
able to dodge out of the way and takes no damage. The Save is
handled in the same manner as Ball and Cone Spells.

Casting Tier

Spells cost a number of Mana Points to cast equal to their
Tier. If the caster is of a higher level than the spell’s Tier,
he may cast the spell with any number of Mana Points up
to his level without Scaling the spell up, thus increasing the
effective Tier of the spell to be the same as his own level.
Example: Vargan the Warlock wants to scare a
Hobgoblin that he is facing. Vargan is 3rd level and his
Spell, Cause Fear is 1st Tier. To make it harder to resist,
Vargan decides to cast it as a 3rd Tier spell by spending
3 Mana to cast it instead of the 1 it normally requires.
This means that the Hobgoblin has to Save versus a
Tier 3 spell rather than a Tier 1 spell.

Casting Time

Spells take differing amounts of time to cast, depending
upon the type of spell that is being cast.
Overcasting: This refers to any spell where the castyer does
not have the minimum number of skill ranks for the Tier
being cast. Casting such spells will always require spending
2 Full Actions (2 rounds) to prepare and cast the spell.
Normal Non-Scaled Spells: Spells that have enough skill
ranks for its base Tier, require a Half Action to cast.
Scaled Up Spells: Spells that have been Scaled Up, always take
a Full Action to cast, as long as the caster has a number of
skill ranks in the spell equal to double the new Tier.
Instantaneous Spells: Spells of this type are always cast as a
Free Action, even if they are being Overcast.

Circles

There are various uses for Circles, both for protection spells
in when performing summonings, among other things. If the
Circle is made to keep something out or in, then nothing that
the focus of the circle is holding can pass through either.
Example: A Wizard casts a Word of Warding spell
that creates a Circle of Protection against Elves,
and an Elf fails his Save against it. This means that
the Elf who failed his Save, nor any weapon he is
holding, can pass through the circle.
The radius of the circle determines the maximum number
of occupants that the circle can hold. A normal, human-sized
person requires 7 square feet of space. Larger sized Kins such
as Asgerdi count as two occupants, while smaller Kins such as
Dwelfs and Gnomes only count as half an occupant each.
The following table give you those maximum occupancies
based on human-sized occupants.

Converting a Circle to a Wall
Some spells allow for the conversion of a Circle into a
Wall. To determine the maximum possible length of such a
Wall, simply multiply the interior radius by 6. This is slightly
less than the actual circumference, but works exceedingly
well for our purposes.

Counterspells

Counterspells are used to disrupt spells as they are
being cast. Attempting to do so is never an easy task, but if
successful, it can help out in the long run. There are several
methods of countering a spell as it is being cast.
The first method is to cast an opposing spell which will
cancel the effects, such as casting a darkness spell to counter
a light spell.
The second method of countering a spell is with the
spell named Counterspell, whose sole purpose is to disrupt
somebody casting a spell.
The final method is to wing it using your Arcana skill.
This method requires using more Mana than the spell,
Counterspell, or in casting an opposing spell. In fact, this
method requires you using double the amount of Mana
required for the spell being countered.
All 3 methods have several things in common. And use
the following steps:
•• You make an Assessment Roll using your Perception
skill OR your Arcana skill, whichever is higher. If
successful, you learn the Tier of the spell you want to
counter, and you might even learn which spell, if it is
one that you know or is from your school. If the spell
is not from your School of Magic, you will receive a
-4 to your attempt to counter it, unless you are using
the Opposing Spell method.
•• Then you choose the method you are using to
counter the spell and make your attempt. Your
attempt is further modified by the amount of Mana
in your counter versus the amount of Mana in the
spell to be countered.
Example: Nuihc, the 3rd level Odavi Mystic is
attempting to counter a spell by Myddan, a 5th level
D’Anui Magus (Magician/Bard). He knows that
Myddan’s spell is 5th Tier, but his Assessment was
not good enough to determine the actual spell, only
that it is from a different School. Nuihc decides to
cast Counterspell at his maximum Tier without
risking Abnormal Spell Failure, so he is using 3
Mana to cast it at 3rd Tier. Myddan had cast his
own spell using 5 Mana, so Nuihc gets a -6 to his
Counterspell roll. He gets -4 because Myddan’s spell
is from a different School, and another -2 for it
being 2 Tiers higher than Nuihc’s own Counterspell.
The Counterspell, in whichever form or method used, and
the spell to be countered are then resolved as a Conflicting
Action, with the spell being countered if there is a tie or if the
character performing the counter wins the Conflicting Action.

Essential Salts

In addition to the mana that casters normally draw upon
in order to cast their spells, there is also something known as
Essential Salts. Essential Salts are also sometimes known as
Rare Earths or other more esoteric names like Earth’s Blood
or the Tears of Mhyrddwn — or any other relevant deity.
Essential Salts are actually an elemental substance
containing trace amounts of all elements, but most
importantly, it also includes crystallized mana. In
appearance, Essential Salts resemble fine grains of sand
that sparkle irridescently, and they can be found in small
amounts in any terrain.
Essential Salts are, quite likely, the most important
alchemical ingredient there is. They are the most common
catalyst used in alchemy, allowing alchemists to unlock and
activate the innate powers and abilities of other ingredients
in their experiments. Many alchemists will be loath to part
with their supply and therefore they are very expensive.
Alchemists who are willing to part with them, will only do
so for a rate of 10 gp per ounce (there are 8 drams in an
ounce) of Essential Salts. Alchemists will often pay up to
1 gold piece per ounce of Essential Salts from adventurers
who are willing to sell.
Casting With Essential Salts
Essential Salts may be used in place of normal mana when
casting a spell. A spell caster may replace all but 1 point
of the Mana required by a spell with 1 dram of Essential
Salts per Mana point to be replaced. The Essential Salts are
consumed in this process.
Finding Essential Salts
In order to acquire some Essential Salts, a character must
spend at least an hour sifting through soil and dirt. At the
end of the hour, the player will make an Arcana or Alkemics
skill roll. If successful, the character will have found 2 drams
of Essential Salts (8 drams equals 1 ounce) for every Success
Level achieved. Drive may be used to allow the character
to find 5 additional drams of Essential Salts for every Drive
Point spent. Searching for Essential Salts is such a grueling
and demanding process that it may only be done up to 3
times a day.
Note: After a Wyrstorm, double the normal amount
of Essential Salts may be found in locations where
lightning from the Wyrstorm has struck.
Characters are limited in how much Essential Salts they
may have in their possession (on their person) at any given
time. The maximum number of ounces that they are allowed
is equal to double their Magic Stat (or their Wits stat if they
are not a spellcaster). Thus, a character with a Magic Stat of
3 may have no more than 6 ounces (48 drams) of Essential
Salts on his person at any given time.
Any more than this maximum will cause a chain reaction
that consumes all of the Essential Salts, causing them to
explode dealing 1 point of damage for each dram involved
to all within a 10-foot radius.

137

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Magical Resonance

The use of magic is never completely safe. Even the
casting of the smallest of spells can send ripples out among
the astral. This ripple has a chance of attracting the attention
of other magic users, most especially powerful ones such
as the Darkmaster and his servants. Even the characters
themselves have the ability to sense others casting spells.
A spell user has a Resonance Detection Range of 10 miles
for each level that they have. For a character to detect spells
being cast within their range, they must be actively watching
for such astral ripples, or have a spell or magical item that
can detect such. Even then, it takes a successful Heroic
Arcana roll just to detect such Resonance. It would require a
Legendary Arcana success to determine the direction of the
spell just cast, and a Mythical Arcana success to determine
the direction and distance of such a spell.
What such casters do upon detecting such ripples is
completely up to them. The following guidelines include how
to tell if the casting of a spell creates ripples, and what your
setting’s Darkmaster will usually do if they detect such ripples.
Detecting Resonance
Any time that a character rolls doubles on their Casting Roll,
where the doubled numbers are equal to or less than the Tier of
the spell being cast, they create ripples on the astral, and the GM
should make a roll on the Magical Resonance table to determine
whether or not your setting’s Darkmaster has taken notice.

Magical Resonance Modifiers
Tier of spell being cast
Spell cast with Abnormal Spell Failure modifiers
In a Safe Haven
In a Blighted Land or Darkland
Healing or beneficial spell
Nature-based or Illusionary spell
Attack or harmful spell
Dark or Infernal Spell

+varies
+(ASF)
-4
+4
-4
-2
+4
+6

Example: Myddan is casting a 3rd Tier spell. If he
rolls 1 on both dice, 2 on both dice, or 3 on both
dice, he triggers a Magical Resonance roll. If he
rolled double 4, or double 5, or any other doubles,
no Resonance is triggered.
It should also be noted that the results of the Magical
Resonance may not be felt right away. It could take
anywhere from a few hours to days or weeks for creatures
or servants of the Darkmaster to arrive at the location where
the Magical Resonance occurred and then for them to track
the character from that point.

Magical Resonance
Roll

Effect

≤ 14

Nothing: You fully escaped notice.

15-18

Shiver: An inquisitive shadow passes over the caster, but soon its attention is drawn somewhere else. The
character is safe, for now…

19-22

Awareness: The Darkmaster is aware of the caster’s presence but unable to locate their current position. The
next Spell that the character casts within the next hour automatically results in a Magical Resonance roll.

23-26

Attention: The GM chooses one:
•• The Darkmaster becomes aware of the general location of the caster, and will send agents and spies to
investigate.
•• The caster is plagued by a terrifying vision sent by the Darkmaster, and become Stunned for 1-4 Rounds
(Magical Resonance total roll minus 22 = # of rounds Stunned).

27-30

Pursuit: The GM chooses one:
•• The caster has been located and deemed worthy of the Darkmaster’s attention. A small band of servants
will be sent to kidnap or apprehend the caster and their allies.
•• The caster’s mind is assailed by nightmarish visions. The caster is oblivious to their surroundings and
is unable to take either Full or Half Actions until they are able to pass an Assessment Roll.

31-34

Assault: The GM chooses one:
•• The Darkmaster has located the caster, and send a band of capable servants to destroy them.
•• The caster’s mind is scorched by the baleful eye of the Darkmaster. The caster falls to the ground unable
to act for 1d10 Rounds, and must choose losing all their remaining Mana for the day or answering
truthfully to a single question the Darkmaster asks in their mind.

≥ 35

Lieutenant: The character has been found by an overwhelmingly powerful servant of the Darkmaster, sent
to bring the caster over to the dark side or to utterly destroy them.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Meditation

Some characters may prefer to meditate in place of sleep
as doing so can often replace an amount of sleep that is
greater than the amount of time spent in mediation.
Upon a successful Mediation skill roll, the character treats one
hour of meditation as two hours of sleep for each Success Level
achieved. This would mean that a result that gains 4 Success Levels
will treat four hours of meditation as 8 hours of sleep.
Meditation used in this manner works just like sleep,
so that the character recovers Hits, and Mana just as they
would if they were sleeping normally.

Spellbooks

A character’s spellbook is where he records his notes and
conclusions regarding spells. It is also where he records any spells
that he wants to remember correctly.
There are two types of spellbooks, Standard and Travel. A
Standard spellbook measures 12” x 24” and is usually about 6”
thick and has 50 pages. A Travel spellbook is about 6” x 10” and
about 2” thick and has 15 pages. Most spell casters keep their
standard spellbooks in their homes or in the Guild of Arcane Lore
to which they belong, perhaps in their library for all to peruse.
They will also usually have one or two travel spellbooks with
them, since these will easily fit in a backpack.
The standard spellbook contains all of a caster’s research notes
as well as their spells. A travel spellbook contains only their notes
on the spells themselves.
Travel spellbooks require 1 page per Tier of the base spell, plus
1 additional page for all Scaling Options for that spell. Standard
spellbooks require 1 page for every Tier required by the spell, in
both its base and Scaled up forms.
Any first level spell caster will have at least a few spells starting
out. Once play begins, it is up to the GM and Player to determine

the amount of role-playing that they require to add more spells to
the spellbook. Recording spells in either type requires 15 minutes
per page required. It will also require source materials and a quiet
place to work.
It is presumed that a spell caster will spend 1 minute per
recorded spell reviewing his spellbook every morning so that
he will not forget the details of his spells. This is considered part
of a caster’s morning routine, just as taking care of his weapons
and armor are part of a warrior’s morning routine.
If the spell caster loses his spellbook, or does not have
one, or is for some reason, unable to review it, then his spells
will take double the amount of time normally required.

Spell Fumble

Another danger of casting spells is taking the chance
of Spell Fumble. If a character rolls a Critical Failure when
attempting to cast a spell, he has fumbled the spell.
When this happens, the character rolls on the Spell
Fumble table, modifying their result with those listed on the
Spell Fumble Modifiers table.

Spell Fumble Modifiers
Level of spell being cast

+varies

Abnormal Spell Failure modifiers

+(3 x mod)

Skill Ranks (not total bonus) in Spell

-(ranks)

Healing, informational or divination spells

+0

Utility, self, defensive, or nature-based spells

+2

Enchantment magic

+4

Alteration magic (changes target in some way)

+6

Dark magic or elemental magic

+6

Spell Fumble
Roll

Effect

≤ 18

The caster loses the Mana Points for the spell he attempted to cast.

19-22

The caster loses the Mana Points required by the spell and is Stunned for 1 Round.

23-26

The caster is Stunned 1 Round and chooses one:
•• Loses double the Mana Points for the spell.
•• The Spell goes off 2 Rounds after it was cast, but the caster must concentrate (Half Action) each round from the
round he cast it until it goes off in order to get it right. The Stun takes effect the round after the spell goes off.

27-30

The caster is Stunned 2 Rounds and chooses one
•• Loses double the Mana Points for the spell.
•• The Spell goes off on a different target within range, if applicable. Determine randomly or GM chooses.

31-34

The caster is Stunned 3 Rounds and chooses two of the following:
•• Loses triple the Mana Points for the spell.
•• The Spell goes off on a different target within range, if applicable. Determine randomly or GM chooses.
•• Roll on the Magical Resonance table with a special +4 to the roll.

≥ 35

The caster is Stunned 4 Rounds and chooses two of the following:
•• Loses triple the Mana Points for the spell and becomes Weary.
•• The Spell goes off on a different target within range, if applicable. Determine randomly or GM chooses.
•• Roll on the Magical Resonance table with a special +10 to the roll.
•• The caster is knocked out for 6 hours (starting after the Stun Rounds).

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Summoning Spells & Rituals

Threat of Imprisonment: If the caster has a device or
spell that can imprison the summoned creature, it will
receive a -4 modifier to its Save.
Attacks: If a caster attacks the summoned creature and
does at least half its hits in damage to it, he may force
the summoned creature to make a Save vs. Will or it
must immediately agree to sealing a pact. However,
attacking a creature you just summoned is extremely
dangerous because attacking the creature will
automatically free the summoned creature by negating
the power of the Summoning Circle. This then allows
the summoned creature to attack in turn.
Magical Constraints & Spells: This is the safest method
of sealing a pact because once cast, the summoned
creature must make a Will Save against the spell or it
must seal the pact.
Summoning by Name: If the character knows the
common name of the summoned creature, he may use
that common name to gain a +1 to his Will Contest rolls.
True Name: If the caster is able to learn the True Name
of a creature, that allows other spells to be cast upon
the creature without a Save. The creature will also
automatically submit to sealing a Pact if the caster
knows its True Name, no Will Contest required.
However, if the creature is aware that the caster
knows its True Name, it will not rest until the caster
is destroyed.
Additionally, there may be other beings or creatures
who wish to learn the True Name of the summoned
creature, and they may very well attempt to coerce
this information from the caster using force or other
painful methods.

The Summoning Circle
In order to summon a creature or being from another
plane of existance, the caster is required to draw a
Summoning Circle. This circle must be a minimum of 3’ in
diameter for an Order I or Type I Infernal creature. More
powerful creatures and beings will require larger circles.
This circle may be drawn upon the ground or floor. It takes 5
minutes per foot of diameter to complete a standard Summoning
Circle and it requires a successful Arcana skill roll.
Some casters may even have cloths that they can spread
out that already have these sewn or embroidered into them.
These are expensive and usually outlawed, but there are
often those who can be found to create them to specification
for the right price.
The Summoning
Once everything has been prepared, the caster then casts
the desired spell of summoning. The summoned entity will
arrive in 1-5 rounds, appearing within the confines of the
circle. In the case of elementals, the creature will arise out of
the elemental source provided.
Sealing a Pact
Once the creature summoned by the caster has arrived,
he must attempt to seal a pact with the creature.
If the summoned creature is beneficially disposed towards
the caster who summoned him, it will likely offer to perform
a service for the caster, especially if this gives him greater
access to the Mortal Plane.
Each attempt to seal a pact with a demon causes the
summoned creature and the spell caster to have a Will Contest.
A Will Contest is handled as a Contested Roll where both make
Will Saves, using the level of the other as a negative modifier.
This Will Contest takes one minute to perform, and if the Caster
wins, the creature or being must obey the caster and perform one
service within its capabilities.
If the Will Contest is a tie, or the creature wins, the caster
may try again, up to once per minute for the duration of the
Summoning.
The caster may adjust his Will Save while attempting to Seal a
Pact with the following:
Offering Wealth: If the summoned creature is greedy, the
caster can gain a +1 to his Will Save roll if he offers 2 gp
for every level that the creature has.
Offering a Sacrifice: Infernal and/or other evil creatures
are often fond of the sacrifice of sentient beings and will
usually accept a pact if offered this evil act.
Threat of Harm: Most of the time threats of harm will never
make a summoned creature agree to a pact. The only
exception is if the caster possesses a weapon or magical
item that the creature specifically has cause to fear, such
as Devil’s Bane Sword or a Wand of Demon Smiting. If the
caster possesses such a device, the creature suffers a -1
modifier on his Save for each +1 that the item has. If the
item has additional abilities, each additional ability will also
provide another -1 modifier.

Results of the Summoning
Summoning spells and rituals may result in one of the
following circumstances:
Failure To Correctly Inscribe A Summoning Circle:
Failure to correctly inscribe the Summoning Circle will
allow the summoned creature to leave the Circle and act
freely. If the circle is damaged while the creature is in it, it
will attempt to destroy its summoner before fleeing into
the wider world.
Failure To Seal A Pact: Failure to seal a pact results in the
creature being immediately returned to its home plane.
Successfully Sealing A Pact: Once a pact has been successfully
sealed, the summoned creature may be made to perform
a service for the caster. The exact type of service depends
upon the type of creature and its capabilities.

140

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Cantrips

Many spell users often learn a few cantrips during their
training. Cantrips are the simplest of spells. They are often
easier to cast than normal spells, and Cantrips are always
cast as Free Actions.
The number of Cantrips that a spell user knows is based
on several cumultative factors.
•• Any Kindred Trait that grants ranks in spells also allows
the character to know 1 Cantrip plus 1 Cantrip for each
rank gained in this manner (i.e. if the character gains 4
ranks, he gets 5 Cantrips).
•• If the character has one or more Arcane Kits, he
learns 5 Cantrips per Kit.
•• If the character has one or more Hybrid Kits, he
learns 3 Cantrips per Kit.
•• The character may spend 1 Development Point in
the Spellcraft Skill Category to learn 2 Cantrips.
Example: Nuihc is an Odavi Mystic (Mystic Kit x
2). This means that he starts knowing 10 Cantrips.
If he had been a Grey Elf or Gnome, he would have
started with 15 Cantrips.
Zhoran, being a Gnome Scout (Scout Kit x 2),
gains 4 ranks in 2 spells just from being a Gnome.
This means he also starts with 5 Cantrips.
In order to cast a Cantrip, the character will use his best
Spell skill bonus. With the results as follows:
Critical Failure: The character takes 1 Hit of
damage as the Cantrip backfires. This will not trigger
a Spell Fumble or Magical Resonance roll.
Failure: The Cantrip fizzles in a sputter of harmless
sparks. This will not trigger a Spell Fumble or Magical
Resonance roll.
Partial Success: The Cantrip succeeds, but it costs 1 Mana
Point to cast.
Success: The Cantrips succeeds and is cast without any
Mana Point cost.
Critical Success: The Cantrip is cast so perfectly, that for the
next 24 hours, any Cantrip you cast will automatically
succeed (no roll required, & no Mana Point cost).
Unless a Cantrip’s description explicitly says otherwise,
a cantrip cannot affect a living target, or object within a
target’s possession. Also, all Cantrips have a range of 20’
unless the description says otherwise.
Here is a list of all of the available Cantrips and descriptions
of their effects:
Alarm — The caster creates an alarm that goes off in his ear
at a specified time within the next 24 hours. Nobody else
can hear the alarm but the caster. Once the alarm begins
sounding, the caster must deliberately cancel the Cantrip
for it to stop. This is done by performing a specific motion
determined at the time of casting. Caster may have a
number of alarms set equal to his Wits stat.

Clean — Caster is able to remove all dirt and grime from
a single object, such as a cloak, robe, or even a pair of
boots. It takes a full minute for this to be accomplished.
Colorize — This can freshen and brighten the colors
of any one object. It takes a full minute for this to be
accomplished. This often makes it look newer at first
glance, but a close inspection will reveal any wear. This
effect will last for a week before the colors fade back to
their normal luster over the course of a few moments.
Cool — This allows the caster to reduce the temperature of
any one object, such as a bowl or a small cask of liquid,
over the course of one minute. The caster may reduce
the object’s temperature by up to 50 degrees, compared
to the ambient temperature. However, this cannot cause
the object to freeze or reduce the temperature below the
freezing point of water. Once cooled, the object will warm
up as any other object normally would.
Count — This Cantrip counts the total number of a single
object within a 1’ radius, as long as the object to be
counted is part of a pile or within some other container
and the caster can touch the object to be counted. For
example, in a pile of coins, the caster could count all
the silver pieces. But this spell would not count all of
the silver pieces among people scattered about a small
room. It takes a full minute for the effect of this Cantrip
to be accomplished.
Dry — This removes the surface dampness from a 5’ radius
area, or it can be used to completely remove all water
from a single object, such as a cloak or other item of
clothing. It takes a full minute for the effect of this cantrip
to be accomplished.
Dust — This gathers all dust within a 5’ radius and places
it into a single pile at one point, chosen by the caster,
within the radius. It takes a full minute for the effect of
this cantrip to be accomplished.
Dustify — This causes all surfaces within a 5’ radius to be
covered with a fine layer of dust. It takes a full minute
for the effect of this Cantrip to be accomplished.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Firejet — Caster is able to cause a small jet of flame, one
inch in length, to erupt from the tip of one of his fingers.
This flame will be enough to ignite combustible materials
given enough time. The flame lasts for as long as the
caster concentrates (requires a Half Action each round),
and it will not harm the finger from which it emerges.
Flavor — This is a trivial illusion that alters the flavor
of a single dish to any flavor desired. This does not
change the nutritional content nor make it edible. The
more food within the dish the weaker the flavor and it
cannot flavor anything if there is more than enough for
a dozen people. The flavor lasts for an hour.
Footsteps — This Cantrip creates the illusionary sound
of a set of footsteps approaching or receding from the
target location (within 20’ of the caster). The footsteps
can be light or heavy, slow and measured or rapid and
hurried, as desired by the caster.
Gather — The caster causes all objects of a single type
within a 5’ radius to be gathered together into a single
pile at the center point of the radius. This could pull all
of the silver out of a pile of money, forming it into its
own separate pile. It takes a full minute for the effect of
this cantrip to be accomplished.
Glare — This cantrip allows the character to have his eyes
glow and flash in a bright, noticeable color. This effects
only lasts for a second or two before it fades. This
cantrip gets its name from the fact that elder spell users
often use this cantrip to punctuate the displeasure that
they feel with the person they are talking to.
Glowsphere — This Cantrip creates a small, 2-inch
diameter sphere of colored light that will follow the
caster around. The caster chooses the color at the
time of casting. This light sheds no shadows. It gives
off enough light to illuminate a 2’ radius and lasts for
5 minutes. This light does not help nor hinder the
various types of vision (i.e. Dark vision, Night vision,
etc.), nor can it be seen from more than 50’ away.
Grow — This Cantrip can cause a seed to germinate, and
to grow about an inch’s worth over the course of a few
minutes. It can also be used on a more mature plant. It can
cause fruits or vegetables to ripen, buds to flower, etc. If
used on a plant that has fruits or vegetables that are already
ripe, it can cause them to over ripen and spoil. It cannot
affect a plant that is more than 3’ tall, wide or long. Using
this Cantrip always deals the caster 1 Hit of damage as it
uses his life essence to enhance that of the plant.

142

Gust — This Cantrip causes a gust of wind to move
through 20’ radius area centered upon the caster. This
gust could be cool or warm, and while it will be strong
enough rustle paper, or blow loose leaves about, it is
not strong enough to put out anything stronger than a
candle, or to cause any other sort of damage. This puff
of wind lasts for only a single round.
Heat — This allows the caster to increase the heat
of an object by up to 50 degrees, from its starting
temperature, over the course of one minute. This
increase in temperature cannot raise the temperature
above the boiling point of water. Nor can it affect more
than the contents of a large cooking pot. Once the
object has reached its desired temperature, it will then
begin to cool naturally if continuous heat is not applied.
Multiple uses will not raise the object’s temperature
more than 50 degrees over its natural temperature.
Ignite/Douse — This allows the caster to ignite any one
object within 10’ that is designed for burning, such as
a candle, torch, lantern, or even a pile of kindling that
has been prepped for starting a fire. The target object
must be dry, and this Cantrip cannot be used as any
sort of attack. The reverse of this Cantrip allows the
caster to put out any one flame of the sort that could
be lit using this Cantrip.
Insect — This Cantrip allows the caster to summon a
small insect, such as a bee, a large beetle, a spider, or a
small cloud of gnats (6” sphere) and have it appear at
any point within 20’ about one minute after casting. The
insect(s) will be annoyed and unhappy with the person
nearest to it. It will attempt to bite or sting that person.
This would not be enough to injure them, but it could
cause them to lose concentration or distract them for
a moment (the target must make a Will Save against
his own level, with a +2 modifier, or be distracted for a
second or two, just enough to spoil spell casting).
Knot — This Cantrip causes 1 or 2 strings, laces, or even
ropes to become knotted and tied in whichever manner
that the caster chooses. It could be a slipknot, a full hitch,
a half hitch, or even a tangled mess of a knot. The caster
chooses the type of knot when casting this cantrip. The
ends to be knotted together must be within 10’ of the
caster and it takes a full minute for the knot to be formed.
Tangled knots are tied so tightly, that it would take a
person (2d10 minus their Dex) rounds to untie them.
Mist — This Cantrip causes everything within a 5’ radius
to be covered in a fine misting of water. This is enough
to extinguish small flames, such as from a candle or
lantern, but not enough to douse a torch. It takes about
a round for the mist to fill the area, and then another
round for it to settle.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Noise — This Cantrip allows the caster to produce a
single, simple noise lasting about 3 seconds (half a
round). It could be used to create a creak, a moan or
even a clanking noise such chains might make. The
caster can make the noise come from any location
within 20’ and it can be as soft as whisper or as loud a
person talking at normal volume.
Polish — This Cantrip will remove the buildup of corrosion
and tarnish on metal, working the metal up to a nice
shine. This will only work on a single small object or on
an expanse of metal from a larger obect that can fill a
6” radius. This means that it would take several uses of
this Cantrip to polish a sword, let alone a suit of armor.
It takes a full minute for the effect of this Cantrip to be
accomplished and this Cantrip may not be recast on the
same object until the previous casting has run its course.
Refresh — This allows a caster to restore something to
freshness. It can undo, at most, about 1 week’s worth of
natural aging of an object. This can cause a wilted flower
to come back to bloom; remove a spoiled taint from milk,
and other things of that nature. Using this Cantrip will
always cause the caster 1 Hit point of damage as it uses
the caster’s own life force to restore the item. It takes a full
minute for the effect of this cantrip to be accomplished.
Season — This Cantrip allows the caster to properly
season enough food to feed about a dozen people. The
food must already exist and either be cooking or have
recently finished cooking (depending upon the type of
seasoning desired). And the caster must have access to
the seasonings to be used.
It can be used to sweeten a drink, simply add a little
salt to a dish, or to properly combine a mix of herbs and
other seasonings to an entire dish (this is the sort of thing
that needs to be done while the dish is cooking).
When cast, the spell user selects the seasonings
and how much, they then are added to the food in
the targeted container and fully mixed as appropriate
for the given seasoning. The seasonings cannot be
added to an empty container, they must be added to a
container containing a food or beverage. It takes a full
minute for the effect of this cantrip to be accomplished.
Additionally, poison and drugs are never considered
to be a seasoning of any sort.
Sew — This Cantrip causes a seam or tear to be sewn up
as if sewn by somebody who was very good at sewing.
This cantrip can sew up to 5’ of seams in cloth or up
to 1’ worth of seams in leather. The resulting seams
will be neat and sturdy, but completely mundane in
nature. The caster must have the material to be used
in the sewing the material (i.e. thread, sinew, etc.), and
it takes a full minute for the sewing to be completed.

143

Sigil — This Cantrip allows the caster to permanently
mark a non-magical object with his own personal mark.
This mark may be visible or invisible, the caster decides
when this is cast. The caster may use this Cantrip to
make an already existing mark glow with just a single
round of concentration (this will make an invisible
mark visible). The caster must be within 20’ of the object
to make the sigil glow. The glow is bright enough to be
visible in daylight, but sheds no light otherwise.
Skeleton Key — This Cantrip allows the caster to open
any one lock, by projecting a small bit of force into the
lock like a skeleton key. This cannot be used to open
complex locks, such as pin and tumbler locks, puzzle
locks or combination locks of any sort. This Cantrip
cannot work on locks that have a Challenging or higher
Difficulty Level when it comes to picking the lock.

Smokeflash — This Cantrip causes a puff of smoke to
appear within 10’ of the caster. It is large enough to
hide a normal sized Human for a single round. The
puff of smoke will fill its given volume and remain for
one round and then dissipate normally. The caster may
make this smoke be any color that he desires.
Sort — This cantrip will magically sort a small pile, not
greater than a foot in diameter, of objects into distinct
piles separate from one another. This does not stack or pile
them neatly, it simply separates the items from each other.
The objects cannot be smaller than a pebble or tiny gem.
Sparks — This cantrip is used to either make sparks jump
between the caster’s fingertips or to make his eyes look
like they are filled with crackling electrical energy. The
effects will last for 1 round.
Spoil — This Cantrip will cause objects spoil or curdle or
turn sour or wilt, according to the nature of the object
effected. In most cases, this basically ages the target
object about a week or so, in a way that is natural to
the target. So milk would curdle, meat might go bad,
cheese might get moldy, flowers might wilt, or any
other appropriate result. The caster must touch the
object to be affected by this spell. Using this Cantrip
always deals the caster 1 Hit of damage as it uses his
life essence to weaken and damage that of the target.
Sully — This Cantrip causes an object to be covered in dirt
and grime. This accumulates on the object over the course
of a few minutes, and once done, the object will look as if
he had been used, and not cleaned, for about a week.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Timer — This allows the caster to setup a timer for any
length of time up to 24 hours. This Cantrip will tell the
caster when the desired amount of time has passed by
sounding a small chime that only the caster can hear.
The caster may set the tone and pitch of the Timer
upon casting and they may have a number of active
Timers equal to their Wits stat.
Tip — This Cantrip exerts a small force, enough to knock
over a mug or box or other container less than 1’ in each
dimension. Should this container be open, or not properly
secured, the contents of the container will likely spill out.
Tweak — With this Cantrip, the caster can lightly pinch
exposed skin or give a tiny tug on a target’s hair.
Neither of these are enough to cause another spell
caster to interrupt the casting of a spell so long as the
target can make a Will Save Roll against his own level
(he receives a +2 modifier to this roll).
Unravel - This Cantrip can be used to untie a knot in a
rope, or to unravel threads in a seam, providing that the
seam contains a loose or broken thread. It takes a full
minute for the effects of this cantrip to be completed.
Wax — This Cantrip allows the caster to bring a shine and
texture to objects made of leather, tile, stone, ceramic
or wood. The item must be clean, and it cannot be
too large. If used on something like a floor, the space
affected cannot be greater than a 5’ radius.
Wrap — This Cantrip causes the target material to be
wrapped in suitable material that is currently present
as well. A dose of herbs might be wrapped in a small
edible paper package or gems might be wrapped in a
soft cloth envelope or bag. It takes a full minute for the
wrapping to be properly formed and secured.
Zap — This Cantrip is used to exterminate pests, such
as a mouse, or some bees, gnats or other bugs, within
a 1 foot radius area. The area will stay clear of such
mundane pests for up to an hour. Alternatively, the
caster could use this cantrip to form a shield around
himself, about 1 inch from his body that will repel all
such pests for an hour.

Wyrstorm Effects
Roll

Effects

2

One random magic item is destroyed completely

3-5

One random magic item has its overall power
permanently reduced in some fashion (GM’s choice)

6-16

Odd Rolls: All magical items are completely
drained for 24 hours
Even Rolls: No effects to the magical items

17-9

One random magic item has its power doubled
for 24 hours

20

One random magic item has its overall power
permanently increased in some fashion (GM’s choice)

Wyrstorms

Magic is often very wild and hard to control. One of the
side effects of the way that Anwyn was stabilized is that there
are sometimes what are called Wyrstorms (WEER storms)
that can crop up after the casting of spells.
When a player rolls doubles on the dice when casting a
spell, you will want to check for a Wyrstorm. If this roll also
falls within the check range for Magical Resonance (the doubled
number is equal or less than the Tier of the spell being cast), you
would only check for that after checking for a Wyrstorm, as a
Wyrstorm will erase all traces of magic in the area, preventing
Magical Resonsance from working properly.

Wyrstorm Check

To determine whether or not there will be a Wyrstorm,
the GM rolls 2d10 open-ended, and adds in a number equal
to double the Tier of spell just cast.
Cantrips always are a 1 (after doubling) for this roll, and if
more than one spell caster has cast magic in the same round as
the one that triggered this check, then the Tiers for their spells
(no doubling of these) are also added to the total.
If the result is higher than 20, then a Wyrstorm will form
within 2-20 minutes. It will have a radius of 1-10 miles, and
will last for 20 + (2d10 x 5) minutes.

Wyrstorm Results

During the storm, there will be multi-colored lighting
strikes once per minute. To determine if any strikes are near
the characters, roll 2d10, and on a result of 18-20, there are
strikes near enough to the characters to hurt them. Roll 1d10
to determine how many strikes are close to the characters.
They then take 5 Hits of damage for each strike unless they
are under cover solid enough to block the strikes. Armor
provides no protection against these strikes.
The GM should also roll on the Wyrstorm Effects table to
determine if any magical items within the storm are affected.
The Wyrstorm also erases any and all magical traces that
might be followed by spell or detected by Magical Resonance.

Rifts
The GM should also check, once per storm to see if the storm
opens a rift to another world and pulls something through to
near where the characters are. Almost anything could be pulled
through. This happens on a roll of 11 or higher on 2d10.
If the Wyrstorm happens in Esker Archia, where there are
many portals that already open in a random fashion, all of those
portals will also activate for the duration of the Wyrstorm,
pulling creatures and beings from random worlds.

Wyrstorm After-effects

Once the Wyrstorm has passed, all magic that does
not come from items will receive a -4 to casting rolls for
24 hours. Additionally, during this 24 hours after the
Wyrstorm, any rolls on the Magical Resonance table will
receive a +4 modifier due to the lack of ambient magic in
the region where the storm occurred.
144

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Schools of Magic

As described elsewhere, there are eight Schools of Magic
available to characters, from which they can learn spells.
Here is a short description of each School.
•• Universal Spells — These spells belong to no School
and to all of them. These spells are learnable by all
characters, and when learned, they are treated as
belonging to the School that the caster belongs to.
•• Diabolism — This is a study of the darker aspects of
the universe. Practitioners of this School often deal
with Undead, and Infernal creatures such as Demons
and Devils. Warlocks are the primary practitioners
of this School, while Blackguards are Hybrid casters
who also focus on the darker aspects of life. Those
from this School who specialize in the dead are
sometimes referred to as Necromancers.
•• Divinism — This is a group of spells that appeal to the
higher powers of the universe. These higher powers
are often called deities, although some scholars want
to classify them as immensely powerful spirits. Envoys,
who are sometimes called Clerics, are the primary
practitioners of this School. However, it is important
to note that Envoys usually tend to worship and call
upon a single deity, and this tends to customize the list
of spells that an Envoy has access to. This also applies to
Champions, the Hybrid casters of this School, as well.
Champions are also sometimes called Paladins.
•• Druidism — This is a study of nature and the
natural world. Practitioners of this School often have
a strong desire to protect nature, both plants and
animals. Druids are the primary practitioners of this
School, while Rangers are Hybrid casters who focus
on exploring and protecting nature from all dangers.
145

••

••

••

••

Magery — This is actually the largest School of Magic
and it has the widest range of spells. The primary
practitioners of this School are known as Magicians,
although many Magicians will tend to focus their
casting into a single field, and may also be known by
this focus. Such names include Elementalists, Illusionists,
Conjurers, and others. Warrior Mages are the Hybrid
casters for this School, and their spells almost always
revolve around enhancing their combat capabilities.
Mysticism — Practitioners of this School focus
inwards, using their magic to enhance their mind,
body, and spirit in unison. Mystics are the primary
practitioners, though some who like peering into
other times and places may be called Seers. Monks,
the Hybrid casters of this School, focus more on
using their magic to enhance their physicality.
Sorcery — Those from this School of Magic treat all
magic as if it were a science, always experimenting
with ways to use thier spells. The primary practitioners
are known as Sorcerers. Dabblers, sometimes called
Shadowkin, are Hybrid casters and often tend to mix
their magic with more mechanically inclined skills, often
found in those who like to relieve others of their wealth.
Spiritism — The world is full of spirits, and those of
this School are not only able to see them, but they work
with those spirits in harmony. Shamans are the primary
practitioners of this School, and they are friends to the
spirits, aiding the spirits and being aided by the spirits
in all their works. Spiortor, sometimes called Spirit
Warriors, are Hybrid casters of this School and they use
the spirits to enhance their own abilities in various ways.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

••

Wizardry — The philosophy of this School is that
words have power, and as such, casters of this School
study how those sounds translate into actual spells.
The primary practitioners of this School are called
Wizards. Bards, as Hybrid casters of this School also
use sounds, of both words, and music to cast their
spells, as well as entertain others.

Spell Descriptions

Dispel Magic

The spells that we list for the various Schools are mostly
self-explanatory, but there are some details that could be
better explained, and we do that here.

Heal Bruise
Jump
Safe Landing*
Summon Familiar

Spell Name: This is the generic name of the spell. If the
name has an asterisk (*) next to it, this means it can be
cast as a Free Action. If it has a dagger (†) next to it, this
means that this spell belongs to the Folio learnable by
Hybrids from that School of Magic. It is recommended
that GMs and Players come up with their own names for
the spells to add more flavor to their games.
Tier: This is sometimes referred to as the level of the spell. It
is also the Mana cost of the spell. The caster must have a
number of skill ranks in the spell equal to double the Mana
cost of the spell, or they will suffer the chance of an Abnormal
Spell Failure (p. 135).
CM: Some spells will have Casting Modifiers, which means
that they are harder to cast than other spells, even if you
have a similar number of skill ranks in it.
Range: How far the target of the spell is from the caster. For
spells that have an area effect, the center-point of the spell
must be within the range itself.
Vs: This stands for Versus. If the spell can be resisted using
a Saving Roll, it is listed here (TSR, RSR, or WSR). If the
spell is against a foe’s Defensive Modifier (DM), that will
be listed instead. If the spell is against a target’s DM, the
caster must make a second roll, an Attack Roll, to target
their foes. This attack roll will use either the caster’s
Ranged or Arcana skill, whichever is higher.
Duration: this is how long the spell lasts. If it has a “—”
listed, this means that the spell takes effect and is then
over, never lasting more than a few moments. If a duration
has “/PPF” that means that the spell requires a Save and
the duration is “per point of failure” on that Save.
Description: This is the basic effects of the spell. It does not
have or actually need a label.
Scaling Options: This is a list of ways that the caster may
customize the spell at the time of casting. In many
instances, this is done by increasing the Tier (and Mana
Point cost) in casting the spell, which also increases the
number of ranks required to cast the spell without having
to deal with the Abnormal Spell Failure (p. 135) rules.
Other options give a Casting Modifier that simply makes
the spell harder to cast, but do not increase the number of
skill ranks required.

Learning Spells
Each School of Magic is treated as a separate Skill Category and if a character has Vocational Kits for 2 different
Schools, their Development Points (DPs) for Spells are treated as belonging to those separate Skill Categories.
If a character has one or more Hybrid Vocational Kits, the other Spells within that School that are not part
of the Hybrid’s Folio are also treated as belonging a separate Skill Category.

Note: There is a single spell in each of the Schools
of Magic that allows those with one of the Arcanist
Vocational Kits to craft a personal magic item. The
names of these spells are: Darkstaff, Holy Symbol,
Druidstaff, Magestaff, Focal, Staff of Sorcery, Soulstaff,
and Wizardstaff.
These spells allow for the creation wooden or leather
items such as wands, rods, a beaded mala necklace,
bracelets, bracers, and so forth, but nothing larger
than a quarterstaff if of wood, or bracers if leather.

Most of these spells use the word staff within their
title simply because that is the item most often
made by the Vocations who access those various
spells. However, regardless of the shape that the item
takes, if it is not a weapon, then the AB and Damage
bonuses would only apply to Unarmed Punches, not
any other type of attack, armed or unarmed.

Control Mortal †
Tier: 2
CM: —
Range: 50’
Vs: WSR
Duration: 1 hour
Target must Save or obey all
commands from the caster for the
duration. Any commands that will
cause the target to hurt themselves or
perform actions that will cause others
to hurt them (i.e. fight somebody) will
trigger another chance to Save against
this spell. Each additional Save is made
with a cumulative +2 modifier (+2 for
the first additional Save, +4 for the
second, etc.)
•• Possession: This allows the caster
to take over the body of the target,
while their own body is comatose.
The caster will have access to the
target’s memories for the duration,
and still be able to use both his own
and the target’s knowledge, skills,
and spells. Once the Posession is
over, the target must make another
Will Save, with failure meaning that
he has no memory of the time he
was Posessed.
Scaling Options
-4 CM to increase duration to 1 hour/rank
+6 Tiers for Possession

Curses

Dark Omen †

Detect Presences

Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: 50’
Vs: WSR
Duration: permanent
Allows the caster to lay a curse upon a
target, causing them to receive a -1 to
all Saves. This spell may also be scaled
up to use one of the following specific
curses instead of the Save penalty.
•• Age: The target ages 10 years instantly.
•• Dread: Target is filled with dread,
unable to sleep well or rest, leaving
hism cranky and irritable. Receives a
-1 to all Brawn, Stamina, or Charisma
related skill rolls.
•• Ugliness: Target receives a -2 to all
Charisma skill rolls and Reaction
Rolls due to their features turning
haggard and worn.
•• Wither: 5’ radius of vegetation withers
and dies over a 24 hour period.
•• Animal Bane: Caster chooses one type
of animal that will always react with
hostility in the presense of the target
•• Clumsiness: Whenever faced with
danger, target will drop any held object
(roll of 11+ on 2d10). This check is
made once per minute (12 rounds).
•• Nightmare: Target is subject to
terrifying nightmares. They lose 1
point from their Will Save bonus each
day until it reaches zero, when they
die, having lost the Will to live.
•• Death: Target dies after 13 hours of
suffering strange burning fever.
•• Decay: 100’ x 100’ area of vegetation
withers and dies over 13 hours.
•• Destruction: Small to medium sized
building falls into ruin, completely
collapsing at the end of 13 days.
Scaling Options

Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: Self
Vs: —
Duration: 1 minute
Caster asks a single yes-no question
(i.e. is it safe to cross the swamp by
day). After a few moments (within
the duration), he will see an omen
providing the answer. Favorable results
might include bats, buzzards, crows,
or serpents, while unfavorable might
include butterfiles, doves, etc. If the
GM is unsure, then perhaps both are
seen. The GM should be as accurate as
possible in providing the omen.
Scaling Options

Tier: 2
CM: —
Range: Self
Vs: —
Duration: 1 round
Allows the caster to detect the
presences of beings (i.e. astral, spirits,
invisible, ethereal, etc.) Within a 20’
radius. This spell does not normally
reveal the nature of those detected,
only their presence and direction.
Scaling Options

-1 CM for each +10’ range
+2 Tiers for each additional -1 applied
(maximum of -5)
+2 Tiers to make minus apply to all
rolls, both skills and Saves
+1 Tier for the Aging Curse

Darkstaff
Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: Touch Vs: —
Duration: Permanent
Caster is able to enchant a wooden or
leather item that he has crafted himself,
that is no larger than a quarterstaff.
When cast, this spell grants the item
a +1 bonus to one of several options
as follows:
•• Attack Bonus: Grants a +1 to the
caster’s AB when using the item;
•• Casting Bonus: The caster gains a
+1 to casting spells;
•• Damage Bonus: Grants a +1 to the
damage dealt with the item;
•• Mana Battery: The item adds 1
bonus Mana to any spell cast, as
long as that spell requires 2 or more
Mana to cast.
The item cannot have more than 5
bonuses added to it in total, no matter
how they are spread across the options.
Should the item be destroyed, the
caster will be at -4 for 1 week, then -3 for
1 week, then -2 for 1 week, and finally -1
for one week. The caster will not be able
to create a new one until this negative
modifier is completely gone.
Scaling Options
+2 Tiers to add a second bonus
+4 Tiers to add a third bonus
+6 Tiers to add a fourth bonus
+8 Tiers to add a fifth bonus

151

+1 Tier to know presence locations
+2 Tiers to reveal nature of presence
-1 CM for each +10’ to the radius
-2 CM for 1 round/rank duration

Mists
Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: 50’
Vs: varies
Duration: 1 minute/rank
Caster creates a 5’ radius of mist at
any point within range. Once cast, the
caster may concentrate (Half Action)
to move it up to 10’ per round, as long
as it is still within line of sight. Those
within the mist are unable to see more
than 1’. At higher Tiers, the Mists may
also produce other effects as follows:
•• Sleep: Those within must make TSR or
fall into magical sleep lasing 1 hour.
•• Entrapment: Must make TSR or be
unable to move while within the mist.
•• Strangling: Those within take 1d10
damage each round as the mists
choke and strangle them. No spell
casting while choking.

•• Madness: Those within must make a
WSR or they will believe that there are
creatures in the mist attempting to kill
them. Any allies also in the mist will
appear as those creatures.
•• Death: Those within must make a TSR
or die within 1d10 minutes from the
toxic fumes. Only a magical antidote
or a spell that neutralizes poisons will
stop them from dying.
Once a person has successfully Saved
against a Mist, it will not affect them
again unless they leave and re-enter
the mists.
Scaling Options
+1 Tier for each +5’ radius added
+1 Tier for Sleep Mist
+2 Tiers for Entrapment Mist
+3 Tiers for Stangling Mist
+4 Tiers for Mists of Madness
+5 Tiers for Death Mist
-4 CM for 10 minutes/rank duration

vampire bat, a wolf or a small cloud

at a rate of 1’ per round.
Scaling Options

forms for the duration
-6 CM for 1 hour/rank duration

Summon Infernal

Unholy Word

want to keep under surveillance, to
interogate later.

back to its home plane.

be unable to move
•• Dark Ally: All undead with a level
lower than that of the caster will
obey caster for 1 hour, no Save.

all types of control spells affecting any
within the radius, no Save required.

Spirit Thrall
Tier: 4
CM: —
Range: 10’
Vs: WSR
Duration: permanent
If the spirit that this is cast upon fails
its Save, it will be under the complete
control of the caster, even willing to
perform actions that may injure or kill
it. This spell may only be cast upon
spirits whose level is lower than that
of the caster. A caster may only have a
number of Thralls equal to his level.
•• Spirit Link: This may only be cast
upon spirits who are already Thralls.
This links the spirit to the caster, so that
it cannot go more than 100’ feet from
him without explicit direction and
permission. All damage that the caster
receieves is split evenly between the
caster and any linked spirits. A caster
may only have a number of linked
spirits equal to his Resolve stat.

Tier: 4

Caster blesses 4 ounces of water or oil,

for Hand, 2 oz for Small, etc.).

against Infernal/Undead will deal an

strike Infernal/Undead creatures that
require magic weapons to strike them,
but it does not deal extra damage.
This blessing lasts 5 minutes.
Holy Water, not Oil, may be thrown
upon Infernal/Undead creatures. Each
ounce will deal 5 + 1d10 hits of Holy
damage to the creature.

Holy Symbol

Exorcism

Free Will

Tier: 2
CM: —
Range: 10’
Vs: WSR
Duration: —
Caster is able to force a target spirit
or Infernal presence that is possessing
a person out of that person’s body.
The target gets a WSR to remain in
possession of the person.
•• Exorcise Building: Force target spirit
out of a dwelling that the caster is
within. Possessed individuals must
leave the building (no Save).
•• Greater Exorcism: Force target out of
the body of a person (no Save). May
also be used to prevent a dead body
from being raised as Undead.
•• Exorcism True: May force all spirits or
Infernal presences from a building and
from all within the building. They do
not receive a Save unless their level is
higher than the caster.
Scaling Options

Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: Touch Vs: —
Duration: —
Caster allows a target who is suffering
from some sort of magical control
(Charm, Control Mortal, etc.) to
make another Save against that spell,
with a +1 to the roll.
Scaling Options

+2 Tiers to Exorcise Building
+3 Tiers for Greater Exorcism
+4 Tiers for Exorcism True

Miracles
Tier: 3
CM: —
Range: varies Vs: varies
Duration: varies
The base version of this spell allows
the caster to undue the results of one
fumble or mishap, treating it as if had
never happened. It may also be scaled
up for other miraculous effects.
•• Circle of Calm: Creates a 3’ radius
circle that glows with astral light. It
is impervious to inclement weather,
and stay dry and comfortable in any
weather. It lasts 24 hours.
•• Restoration: Caster heals one target
of all damage, diseases, poisons,
lost senses, insanity, etc. It cannot
regrow missing body parts, or heal
Soul Damage.
•• Circle of Tranquility: Creates 10’ radius
similar to Circle of Calm, including the
same effects, along with the fact that
no attacks can be made into or out of
the Circle. It lasts as long as the caster
Concentrates (Half Action).
•• Cleanse: All enchantments and
spells are removed from a 5’ radius.
Temporary spells and enchantmants
are dispelled entirely. Permanent ones
are gone for 1 day.

•• Major Restoration: As Restoration,
excep that it can regrow limbs and heal
Soul Damage.
•• Halt Nature: Stops one natural
disaster, such as an avalache, cave-in,
flood, plague, etc. for 1 hour per rank if
natural. It completely dispels any spells
that causes such (no Save).
•• Resurrection: Restores one body to life,
regardless of condition. If the target is
not of the caster’s faith, he must make a
TSR against this spell (but he gets a +1
per level of the caster).
Scaling Options
+2 Tier for Circle of Calm
-1 CM for +1’ radius specific effects
+1 Tier to shape a Circle into a Wall, that
can act like a barrier
+2 Tiers for Restoration
+4 Tiers for Circle of Tranquility
+4 Tiers for Cleanse
+4 Tiers for Major Restoration
+4 Tiers for Halt Nature
+5 Tiers for Resurrection

as follows:

•• Casting Bonus: The caster gains a

•• Damage Bonus: Grants a +1 to the
damage dealt with the item;

spell requires 2 or more Mana to cast.
The item cannot have more than 5
bonuses added to it in total, no matter
how they are spread across the options.
Should the item be destroyed, the
caster will be at -4 for 1 week, then -3 for
1 week, then -2 for 1 week, and finally -1
for one week. The caster will not be able
to create a new one until this negative
modifier is completely gone.

Body Control †

Tier: 3
CM: —
Range: Self
Vs: —
Duration: 1 minute/rank
Caster enters a trance and his spirit
travels to the Astral Plane while his
body remains behind. On the Astral
Plane, the caster’s Astral Form may
travel anywhere within 10 miles for
each rank that they have in this spell,
except over large bodies of water,
which can destroy their Soul Form, as
it is sometimes called.. Their Soul Form
is attached to their body with a silver
cord. This cord can only be severed by
killing the caster on the physical plane
or killing their Soul Form.
While on the Astral, the characters
is limited what they can see and
determine, and they are unable to
influence the physical world at all,
and unable to be seen except for those
with certain types of vision or spells.
Casters on the Astral may cast spells
at one another, but not at those upon
the mortal planes normally.

of the target’s aura, and able to

good or evil in varying degrees).

Focal
Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: Touch Vs: —
Duration: Permanent
Caster is able to enchant a wooden or
leather item that he has crafted himself,
that is no larger than a quarterstaff.
Alternatively, the Caster may enchant
a crystal that is worn as a pendant or as
part of another piece of jewelry.
When cast, this spell grants the item
a +1 bonus to one of several options
as follows:
•• Attack Bonus: Grants a +1 to the
caster’s AB when using the item;
•• Casting Bonus: The caster gains a
+1 to casting spells;
•• Damage Bonus: Grants a +1 to the
damage dealt with the item;
•• Mana Battery: The item adds 1
bonus Mana to any spell cast, as
long as that spell requires 2 or more
Mana to cast.
The item cannot have more than 5
bonuses added to it in total, no matter
how they are spread across the options.
Should the item be destroyed, the
caster will be at -4 for 1 week, then -3 for
1 week, then -2 for 1 week, and finally -1
for one week. The caster will not be able
to create a new one until this negative
modifier is completely gone.
Scaling Options
+2 Tiers to add a second bonus
+4 Tiers to add a third bonus
+6 Tiers to add a fourth bonus
+8 Tiers to add a fifth bonus

+2 Tiers for each +1 to AB (max of +5)

•• Ethereal: Caster is able to turn ethereal

Psychic Assault
Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: 50’
Vs: WSR
Duration: varies
Caster attacks the targets mind in a
very specific manner. The basic form
of this spell uses Confusion.
•• Confusion: If target fails their Save,
they will become confused for 1
minute for every point that they
failed their Save by. While confused,
they cannot attack, cast spells, are
indecisive, and unable to partake of
any planned activity. They may still
defend themselves if attacked.
•• Fear: If the target fails their Save, they
are Frightened for 1 minute for each
point that they fail the Save by.

•• Mind Drain: If the target fails their
WSR, they lose 1 point of Wits,
Resolve, Insight, or Charisma for
each point that they fail the Save by.
They lose one point from each stat,
in the order listed above, in order
(i.e. failing the WSR by 3 means
losing 1 each from Wits, Resolve,
and then Insight). The loss is treated
as a curse and is permanent unless
removed like a curse is removed.
Scaling Options
+1 Tier for Fear
+1 Tier for Confusion/Fear to have a 5’
radius effect around target location
within range
+1 Tier for each +5’ radius
+4 Tiers for Mind Drain
-1 CM for each +10’ range

Variable Illumination

Tier: 1
CM: —
Range: Touch Vs: —
Duration: Permanent
Caster is able to enchant a wooden or
leather item that he has crafted himself,
that is no larger than a quarterstaff.
When cast, this spell grants the item
a +1 bonus to one of several options
as follows:
•• Attack Bonus: Grants a +1 to the
caster’s AB when using the item;
•• Casting Bonus: The caster gains a
+1 to casting spells;
•• Damage Bonus: Grants a +1 to the
damage dealt with the item;
•• Mana Battery: The item adds 1
bonus Mana to any spell cast, as
long as that spell requires 2 or more
Mana to cast.
The item cannot have more than 5
bonuses added to it in total, no matter
how they are spread across the options.
Should the item be destroyed, the
caster will be at -4 for 1 week, then -3 for
1 week, then -2 for 1 week, and finally -1
for one week. The caster will not be able
to create a new one until this negative
modifier is completely gone.

Vs: —

Spirit Contact
Tier: 4
CM: —
Range: 10’
Vs: —
Duration: special
Caster is able to summon and speak
with the deceased Spirit of an individual
or sentient creature. The caster may ask
the Spirit up to 3 questions, with the
chances of being answered as follows:
•• Personal friend of caster: 100%
•• Unknown to Caster; same general
alignment/outlook: roll of 9+ on 2d10
•• Unkown to Caster; non-opposing
alignment/outlook: roll of 11+ on
2d10
•• Unknown to Caster; opposing
alignment/outlook: roll of 14+ on
2d10
•• Enemy of the Caster: will answer
on roll of 9+ on 2d10, Spirit will
attempt to lie or mislead caster on
rolls of 6+ on 2d10
Contact with Spirits who are of opposing
disposition and alignment (i.e. the Spirit
of an evil person where the Caster is
more generally good) runs the risk of
an attack by the hostile Spirit. If the
Spirit refuses to answer, it will attempt
to possess the nearest person or creature
(Conflicting Actions using WSR) if they
are not protected.
Killing the host or Banishing the Spirit
will return it to its own plane, otherwise
it will be free to travel the material plane,
and attempt to possess somebody else up
to 3 times. Or be trapped in the mortal
plane in non-corporeal form.
Scaling Options
+1 Tier for each additional question

Spirit Self
Tier: 3
CM: —
Range: Self
Vs: —
Duration: 1 minute/rank
Caster enters a trance and his spirit
travels to the Astral Plane while his
body remains behind. On the Astral
Plane, the caster’s Astral Form may
travel anywhere within 10 miles for
each rank that they have in this spell,
except over large bodies of water,
which can destroy their Soul Form, as
it is sometimes called.. Their Soul Form
is attached to their body with a silver
cord. This cord can only be severed by
killing the caster on the physical plane
or killing their Soul Form.
While on the Astral, the characters
is limited what they can see and
determine, and they are unable to
influence the physical world at all,
and unable to be seen except for those
with certain types of vision or spells.
Casters on the Astral may cast spells
at one another, but not at those upon
the mortal planes normally.
Scaling Options

+2 Tiers to able to cast spells while on
the Astral
-4 CM for 10 minutes/rank duration
-8 for 1 hour/rank duration

Confusion †

Tier: 2
CM: —
Range: Self

Duration: 10 minutes
Caster may use this spell to make

•• Aura of Free Action: Caster is immune

not hindered by terrain, such as mud,

•• Aura of Protection: This reduces
all damage dealt to the caster by
half (rounded down) after all other
damage adjustments have been made.
•• Aura of Awareness: Caster is able to

The Caster will know direction and

Tier: 1+
CM: —
Range: 50’
Vs: WSR
Duration: 1 round/PPF
Command Words must be forcefully

of the following options when casting
this spell. Unless the Option states
other, duration is based on Per Point
of Failure (PPF), which means that if a
target fails their Save, they are normally
affected for 1 round for each point that
they failed their Save by.
•• Sleep: If the target fails their Save,
they plunge into a deep, magical sleep,
where they cannot be awoken by nonmagical means for the duration.
•• Forget: If the target fails their Save,
they are made to forget one piece
of information (i.e. incident, fact,
etc.) that they know. This is treated
as a curse, so is permanent until it
is removed by a spell that removes
curses or restores memory.
•• Answer: If the target fails their Save,
they must answer one question fully
and truthfully. Caster will know if the
target Saves. This cannot be used to
force a being to reveal his True Name.
•• Stop: If the target fails their Save, they
must cease whatever actions they are
performing. Even if they make their
Save, they will stop for one round.
•• Away: If the target fails their Save, they
must travel away from the Caster for
the duration. Even if they make their
Save, they will back away for 1 round.
•• Obey: If the target fails their Save, they
can be made to perform one relatively
simple service or action that does not
involve killing or hurting themselves.
