Spheres of Influence
The School of Divinism is a Codex of generic spells relating to
the Divine. This list works well for a generic deity or for a setting
that includes only a single deity.
However, it can sometimes fall a bit short when the campaign
takes place in a setting with multiple deities. Each with their
own religion and each with their own Codex of spells.
In fact, a campaign setting could include multiple religious
sects for any single deity, and thus have multiple types of Envoys
and Champions for that deity. These competing religious sects
could even be working at cross purposes by simply focusing on
different aspects of the deity that they worship.
Towards this end, we want to make it easier for the GM and
to be able to customize his clerical orders accordingly, and for
players to customize their characters.
•• Envoys: May exchange up to 4 Divinism spells for
4 spells from other Schools of Magic for each time
that they have the Envoy Vocation.
•• Champions: May exchange up to 2 Divinism
spells for 2 spells from other Schools of Magic for
each time that they have the Champion Vocation.
The spells exchanged must be from other Hybrid
Folios, they cannot be from the greater Codices
(i.e. a Champion cannot select a spell from the
Magery Codex that is in the Warrior Mage Folio).
•• Game Masters should approve all of the swaps, and
may in some rare cases, allow Champions to access
to spells that they may normally not have access
to, but only if those spells fit the description and
conceptualization of the religious order in question.
Any spells in a given deity’s or religion’s customized spell
lists should reflect the nature and focus of the deity, this is
otherwise known as the deity’s Sphere of Influence, for the
specific religion that follows that deity. This is also known as
the Sphere Codex.
Note: It is recommended that the GM and Player
rename spells in the Sphere Codices as needed to better
reflect the nature of the deities and the religious order
that worships them.
For Anwyn, there are a total of 12 deities, so what follows
are descriptions for those deities, and S short description of
the main focus of the primary religious order for each deity.

Focus: Clerics of Wodyn are
considered to be arbitrators
and judges. They sit beside
any lords or judges appointed
by various lords to maintain the
laws and advise on judgements.
When not doing this, these Clerics
help those in need, feeding the
hungry when possible.

Anu
Earth Mother, Goddess of Healing, the Seasons, The
Endless Cycle, The Lady of Harvests
Anu is the wife of The Dagda. She is considered to be
the Mother of the D’Anui. Life springs from her and
returns to her in the end. She is the Goddess of Cycles
of all sorts. Be it the seasons, or falling
into love and then losing it later on.
Focus: Clerics of Anu work as
healers and as advisors to
farmers and those who deal
with the endless cycle of the
seasons. She is often the
patron for many Druids
and Rangers as well.

Belnos

Wodyn
The Dagda, The All-Father, The One Above All, He Who
Stands Alone
Wodyn is considered to be the first god. He is thought to
be the one who created the other gods. Wodyn stands as
the guardian of order. He is said to have created all the
worlds out of the chaos. He is also said to have a cauldron
that can feed all life. It is said that Wodyn likes to travel
the world as an old man, to view those under his care.

182

God of the Sun, The Shining One, Keeper of the Day,
Lord of Spring
Belnos is the god of the Sun, a potent warrior in his own
right. He is the enemy of darkness (as in evil, not night),
and especially of those from the Ocher Realms where his
power cannot reach.
Focus: Clerics of Belnos
are the enemies of
necromancers and any others
who deal with undead. This
religion also has the
largest order of Paladins,
all adventuring to search
for and destroy undead.

Cerriwn

Mhyrddwn

Moon Goddess, Beacon of the Night, the Inner Beacon,
The Triple Goddess, The Dark Lady, The Huntress
Cerriwn rules the night. She is resolute and relentless
in guarding her domain. She does
not like sharing it with unnatural
creatures, such as undead,
demons or devils. She is also
a hunter, striking from
the shadows. She is the
patron of all who hunt,
be it for sport, excitement,
life, or pay.
Focus: Clerics of Cerriwn protect
those who travel by night and
hunt the unnatural things in it.
Many hunters will either ask for
aid in an upcoming hunt, or give
thanks to her afterwards by burning
the liver of their prey.

The Lord of Magic, the Salt Lord, Keeper of Secrets,
Master of the Mother Roads
Mhyrddwn is the god of magic. He is the one who
sprinkles the land with the Essential Salts that are
believed to be solidified magic. He is
also a master of technology,
often considered to be
another form of magic.
He keeps the secrets of
the universe. He is also
the master of the Mother
Roads that connect Anwyn
to all other worlds. It is his
adherents, his Wayfinders of the
Voyager’s Guild, who guide the ships
to and from Anwyn.
Focus: Clerics of Mhryddwn work to expand the boundries
of magic. They promote magical experimentation and
into discovering new magics and spells.

Ogmion

Kernos

The Maker, The Wise One, The Crafter, The Eternal Musician
They say that Knowledge is Power. If that is so, then
Ogmion may be one of the most powerful of the Gods.
He collects knowledge. There are many who worship him
who feel that knowledge should be
earned, not given, and who
work to keep it that way.
Others worship only one
aspect of him, The Eternal
Musician is the patron
of Minstrels and Bards, while those of
the various craft guilds tend to pray to
The Crafter, and Dwarven smiths
venerate The Maker and his works.
Focus: The main clergy of Ogmion
work as librarians and work to
spread the use of books. They
also work to preserve knowledge no matter where it
is found.

The Forest Lord, The Green Man, The Fey Lord, The
Hunter, The Traveler, The Wylde Lord
Kernos is a nature god. He is the lord of the wilderness.
He is also the lord of all outside the
realms of the towns and cities,
which puts all roads and paths
under his purview. Kernos aslo
seems to be the patron of the
creatures and beings known
as the Fey.
Focus: Clerics of Kernos work
to preserve nature. Whether
it be animals or forests, they
tend to them. However, they
also believe in the survival of the
fittest and so they support healthy competition too.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Focus: Clerics of Arwn often have to hide their true
nature, as they are usually seen as evil by many
cultures. And they are also seen as the instigators of
many conflicts.

Scatha
The Warrior Maid, The Shadowy One, The Protector,
Goddess of Protection, The Unarmed Avenger
Scatha is a Warrior Goddess, one devoted to the martial
arts, rather than weapons. She is also a
goddess of protection, striking from
the shadows and of healing, but
usually only through herbalism.
Her adherents often have
good healing skills and the

and others.

also tend to be more like Monks

Dhynos
God of Death, God of Unlife, The Ocher Lord, The

Dhynos rules over the lands of the unwanted dead. He
is also the God of the Unlife, those who survive past
death and prey upon the living. He is also the patron
of those who believe that in death,
they can gain power over the living.
This makes him the patron of many
intelligent undead who sought that
state, such as liches and vampires.
Focus: Clerics of Dhynos often have to
hide their true nature, as many hate the
idea of consorting with the undead.
Many Clerics of Dhynos hope to become

Tyris
The Storm Lord, The Thunderer, The Striker, the Lord

Tyris is the Lord of Storms. His symbol is a hammer, his
weapon of choice. He is often called
the Lord of Oaks due to how often

and these trees are considered to
be touched by Tyris. He is also a
warrior, a god of combat and strife,
as all life is a struggle, but one that

Focus: Clerics of Tyris follow
the tenets of their deity.
They believe that honorable
combat is a necessary component of
life. While they do not like to create strife, they do like
to seek out areas where strife is already present and
then to meet that strife with honor.

Balar

Arwn
Grief Lord, Strife Lord, God of War and Conquest
Arwn is a god of war and conquest, where only the
strong and powerful rule over the weak. Many think

strife and combat and the

order and heirarchy as well. For

as the patron of the Nine Hells,
and the Devils and other creatures
that dwell within them. His goals
often coincide with theirs, to bring the world to its
knees under the rule of an iron fist.

The Demon Lord, God of Chaos and Destruction
Balar is the dark reflection of Wodyn. Where Wodyn

Planar Cosmology

The Inner Planes

This section is meant solely as a primer on Planar
Cosmology, not as the definitive guide on the subject. It is
meant solely to give an overview to a players and GMs alike;
a point of reference for the inclusion of spells and other
terminology that might appear in this and other works.
The terminology that is used can sometimes be very
confusing. You have the Inner Planes and the Outer Planes.
You also have the Upper Planes and the Lower Planes. And this
doesn’t even begin to start the discussion about the various
individual planes, which are seemingly without number.
The following is a brief overview, meant to provide a
frame of reference for characters
Each plane has its own internal natural laws that
determine how everything works, but there are greater
natural laws in play as well. One such law is the fact that the
more powerful the being or creature, the more energy must
expended for it to be able to breach the planar barriers. This
even holds true for the Mortal Planes, although it seems to
be easier for somebody from that “central” planar location
to reach out to the Outer Planes than it is for a creature from
the Outer Planes to reach the Mortal Planes.

This is a collection of several planes that are closest to
the Mortal or Material Planes. They consist of the Mortal
Planes, the Ethereal Plane, the Lower Astral Plane and the
Upper Astral Plane. Each of which is described briefly below.

The Mortal Planes
The Mortal Plane is the plane in which the characters come
from. It is their physical world. However, there is not just a
single physical world, but many, an almost endless number
that sit side by side in separate dimensions, separated by the
thinnest of veils know as the Ethereal Plane.
This multitude of physical worlds range from being very
similar to one another, almost identical even, to being very,
very different. For the characters that inhabit a given world,
the laws of nature found in another dimension may be
radically different than those found in his home dimension.
GMs could easily have characters from multiple campaign
settings (such as those produced by other companies) that
end up in the same place, and adventuring from there. Travel
between these dimensions happens via the Ethereal Plane.

185

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

The Ethereal Plane
The Ethereal Plane is the veil that separates the multitude
of dimensions. In appearance, it is essentially a featureless
area surrounded by a bluish fog. At most, a character might
see the road beneath his feet, but quite often that is usually
covered in mist as well. Travelers who become separated
while on the Ethereal Plane rarely ever find one another
again as the formless void is nearly impossible to navigate
unless one knows how.
The Ethereal Plane is also home to the Mother Roads.
These “roads” can be used as short-cuts from one place to
another on the mortal plane or even traveling from one
mortal plane to another, if one knows how to access them.
The roads connecting different points on a single world are
known as the Low Roads, and ones that connect different
worlds are known as the High Roads. High Roads can only
be accessed from the Low Roads, and the Low Roads may be
accessed from many places, but often a secluded spot with
an unusual natural formation of some sort.
However, traveling the Mother Roads is extremely
dangerous, and a few minutes spent on the Ethereal Plane
could equate to days or even weeks passing on the Mortal
Plane if the traveler is not careful.
The reverse is also possible, spending what seems like
minutes or hours traveling the Low Roads only to find that
mere seconds or minutes at most have passed.
When one travels upon the Ethereal Plane, the character’s
physical body is often transformed into a little charm that
hangs around the neck of the character’s Ethereal Body (i.e.
his soul). It is this transformation of the physical boy that
allows beings to move from one dimension to the next, or
to move along the Mother Roads without being prematurely
aged, as the character’s physical body is restored from the
charm upon his leaving the Ethereal Plane for a Mortal Plane.
The Wayfarers of Anwyn have learned how to shield
others, including whole ships worth of people from the
Ethereal Plane as they travel the Mother Roads of the Sea.

The Lower Astral
The plane closest to the Mortal Plane is the Lower
Astral. This plane actually reflects the mortal world in most
respects. This is because the viewer is actually looking at the
Mortal Plane through an Astral Veil. Everything is seen as
though through a bluish light, though there are also a few
other changes as well.

Living beings are often seen with a form of light
overlaying their normal form, Shaman consider this to be
the soul-form. When seen from the Astral, persons who are
unknown to the character will appear featureless and rough
of form; while those are personally known to the character
will be identifiable.
Vegetation often appears as a rusty red in color, and stone
as a dark grey. Some spirits, seen on the Astral, appear as a
nexus of pulsing, glowing lines. This is often very different
from the physical forms they take on the Mortal Planes. This
actually holds true for many of the beings from the Outer
Planes as well.
When traveling upon the Astral, the character’s soul is
what does the traveling while his body remains on the
Mortal Plane. This soul-self, often referred to as the “body
of light,” is attached to the physical body by a silver cord.
When a character’s body dies, the silver cord breaks and the
soul is then free to travel to the Outer Planes, and its final
destination. It is also possible that actions taken by the body
of light, or that a battle upon the astral can cause this silver
cord to part, killing the physical body.
The body of light is not affected by the normal physical
laws that a physical body is. It can fly, and move much faster
than the physical body can. This astral traveling is often used
as a method of scrying when the character doesn’t personally
know the subject or location. It takes longer, and can be more
dangerous, but it can allow for the gathering of information
that might not normally be known (i.e. such as locating an
opposing army or approximating its general size).

The Upper Astral
If one goes up high enough on the Lower Astral, they will
transition naturally to the Upper Astral. The Upper Astral is
a formless blue void suffused with an underlying light that
appears to have no discernable source. In fact, the only way
a character has of returning to his body from the Upper
Astral is to follow the silver cord from his body of light back
to his physical body.
When upon the Upper Astral, it is easier to open gateways
to the Outer Planes. However, there is also no way to control
who or what may pass through such gateways or portals.
Additionally, there are natural portals from the Upper
Astral to the various Outer Planes, but these are usually one
way only, allowing souls to reach their final destinations.
Also to be found among the Upper Astral are several
places that can only be described as mental constructs. Most
such places are created by extremely powerful magic users,
but there are a few that are naturally occurring. One such
natural place is the Hall of Akashic Records, a library of all
that has ever happened. Many magic users have spent their
lives searching for it or searching for the way to unlock more
than just the smallest portions of it.

186

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

The Outer Planes

The Upper Planes

Beyond the Upper Astral are the Outer Planes. These are
made up of three groups of planes. The Lower Planes, the
Upper Planes, and the Elemental Planes.
Beyond the Outer Planes there is the Void, which is
sometimes called the Pale. Many scholars believe the Void
is uninhabited or inhabited by creatures so alien that that
they would be inimical to all life on the Mortal Planes.
Some scholars even postulate that there may be twisted
places or creatures that come from Beyond the Pale.

The Lower Planes
We have 3 main regions among the Lower Planes that
are of interest. They are the Abyss, Hades, and the Ocher
Realms. The Abyss is also known as the Nether Realms, and
it is the home of many types of Demons, ruled over by the
Demon Lords. Hades is also known as the Nine Hells, and
it is the home of Devils, ruled over by ArchDevils. Demons
and Devils have been at war with each other for eternity and
thankfully they will never work together.
The Ocher Realms are also known as the Planes of the
Dead, and contains specific planes such as the Land of Husks
and Rinds, Tartarus, Hel, and Purgatory and many others.
The Undead of the Mortal Planes draw their energy and
power from these planes.
The creatures who live upon these planes are collectively
referred to as Infernals, regardless of whether they are
Demons, Devils, or something else entirely. Undead are
also said to draw their power and abilities from somewhere
among the Lower Realms.

On the opposite end of the spectrum, we have the Upper
Planes, sometimes called the Celestial Planes. They are called
the Celestial Planes because of the beings collectively known
as Celestials who reside there, as do the various deities upon
the uppermost planes.
The upper planes are too numerous to count. There are
planes where conceptual spirits reside, and planes dedicated
to an idyllic existence, there are also planes that serve as the
homes to beings based upon a single focus or concept.
Some planes are classified as being of Chaos while others
are considered to be of Order. Some planes, such as the
Nine Hells are often considered to be examples of being too
orderly, as the Devils who reside there follow a strict and
rigid life and seek to impose that order upon others. Just
as the Demons of the Abyss seek to sow and let loose chaos
upon the world.
The vast majority of the upper planes are too difficult
to reach, just as the planes in which the deities reside are
usually too far for them to effect the mortal planes directly.
The most that the deities can do is to send omens or dreams
or visions to their followers. In rare cases, they can direct
other powerful Celestial beings, who are closer to the mortal
realms, and less powerful overall, to do their bidding and to
deliver messages or to, more rarely, perform tasks directly.
Both of these methods of communication have their own
drawbacks as the end result of such is usually couched in
omens and symbolism that if quite often too difficult to
decipher until much too late.

The Elemental Planes
Each of these planes is devoted to a specific element.
Considering that different systems of magic and theology
conceive of and include different elements, it is quite
possible that there are many more planes that fall under this
classification than one might suspect at first.
Each plane, however, is populated by spirits, creatures,
and beings, and even a mighty, nearly god-like king or ruler.
These planes are considered by many to be Upper Planes
while some scholars consider them to be Lower Planes, and
yet other scholars believe that they touch upon both the
Upper and the Lower Planes equally.

The Dimensional Nexus

Scholars believe that there may be, among the many
planes and dimensions, something of a nexus of realities. A
place that is essentially closer to all planes and all dimensions
than any other single plane by itself.
Some scholars even postulate that such a location might
be where malfunctioning portals or dimensional rifts
eventually lead to; a land of the lost, as it were.
If such a place exists, it would undoubtedly be a wondrous
source for magical materials, and for creatures not seen
anywhere else.
Some of these scholars even believe that Anwyn may be
just such a place.
187

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

The Spirit World

Totem Spirits

The Spirit World isn’t a single plane as many people tend
to think. It is actually made of a number of different planes.
This includes both the Lower and Upper Astral Planes and
an unspecified number of the Outer Planes as well. For the
most part, many magic users consider the Lower and Upper
Astral to be the major portion, if not all, of the Spirit World.

Types of Spirits

As stated, the Spirit World isn’t a single plane, but a
number of actual planes conceptualized as part of a specific
world-view. There are many different types of spirits. The
Bestiary list Familiar Spirits and Nature Spirits, but those are
not the only types. Here is a short description of some of the
other types of spirits that might be encountered.
For these types of Spirits, they will have a WSR that is
equal to 9 plus the Spirit’s level (i.e. a 3rd level Spirit has a
WSR of 3 (its level) + 9 = 12).

Angry Spirits
There are magic users out there who will abuse spirits.
When a spirit takes too much abuse, it can become an angry
spirits, bent upon unleashing its wrath upon all who are
around it. This means that almost any other type of Spirit
can become an Angry Spirit. Angry Spirits drive conflict.
Its attacks will always lead to those affected attacking the
nearest person, be it friend or foe.

Simple Spirits
There are many Spirits that encompass a single idea or
concept, such as love, hate, logic, exhaustion, etc. These
are Lesser Spirits that are often called according to the
concept that they embody, such as a Spirit of Calmness, or
a Spirit of Rage. There are also Rational Spirits that embody
unemotional thought and decision making.
Attacks by these types of Spirits result in the targets either
feeling the emotion or concept for one round per point of
failure. If the concept is one such as logic, that adds a bonus
to actions that embody the concept (GM’s determination)
equal to one half of the Spirit’s level, rounded up.

Complex Spirits
Greater Spirits are sometimes called Complex Spirits
because they embody complex concepts and/or thematic
ideas. They can embody such concepts as murder, marriage,
Easter, or even such ideas as the Spirit of Christmas Past.
These spirits are often highly individual and likely unique.
Some scholars believe that the gods are actually nothing
more than extreme examples of Complex Spirits.

There is a class of spirits known as Totem Spirits. These are
spirits who willingly serve Shaman in much the same way that
Familiar Spirits serve other spell users. Totem Spirits, however,
have a stronger connection to the Shaman, who is well versed
in the ways of the Spirit World. This connection allows for a few
additional abilities to manifest for the Totem Spirit.

Undead Spirits
There are a number of incorporeal undead. These are
almost always manifestations of a being’s spirit, tied to the
Mortal Planes through some traumatic experience, such as
a violent death.

Spirit Attacks

While many spirits will have unique or individual
methods of attack, many will also be able to use at least one
of the following types of attack.

Emanation
This type of attack is usually limited to Simple Spirits,
more specifically those who are focused on a single emotion
or simple concept. Those affected will often be overcome
with the focus of the spirit. For example, if a Spirit of Joy
successfully attacks a person, that person will be overcome
with feelings of joy.
In order to make this type of attack, the Spirit initiates
a Will Contest against all beings within a radius equal to
5 per level of the Spirit. This Will Contest is resolved as a
Conflicting Action of WSR against WSR. Each Will Contest
is determined separately.
If the Spirit is not detailed, it has a WSR equal to 9 + its
level (i.e. a Level 1 Spirit would have a WSR of 10).
Any effects from this type of attack will last for 10 minutes
per point that the target failed the Will Contest by.

Possession
Many spirits will attempt to enter the body of a target and
take possession of it.
In such cases, both the spirit and the person being attacked
will enter into a Will Contest as described above. However,
if neither one beat the other by 10 points or more, the Will
Contest will continue the following round.
If the Spirit fails to win the Will Contest 3 times in a row,
or fails to win it by 15 or more points, then he will be forced
to leave the body that he was attempting to possess. Should
the Spirit win, he will be in complete control of the body, but
not have any access to its memories (that requires winning
the Will Contest by 20 or more points).

Elemental Spirits
This classification is given to any spirit who is connected
to the elements in any way. It includes Nature Spirits and the
much less powerful Wildlings as well.

188

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Alchemy 101

The term Alchemy often is used to represent the creation
of any and all types of magical items. There are two main
skills involved in the performance of Alchemy, they are
Alkemics and Arcana. Each skill has its own uses in the
crafting of various magical items.
The following provides guidelines are for GMs who have
characters who want to craft magical items of various types.
Each type of item is covered separately.

Basic Alchemy

Basic Alchemy is considered to consist of the items that
can be made without having the Special Skill, Enchantment.
This means that they are consumable items, sometimes
called one shot or single use items.
These are items that can also be made while on
adventures. Doing so would not be easy, but it would still
be possible. Rather than give Difficulty Levels for each type
of roll required, we provide you with what we call Alchemy
Modifiers (AM) which are applied against a normal skill roll.

Charms & Talismans
Charms and Talismans are essentially the same thing.
The difference being that Talismans are purely defensive
in nature, while Charms can hold any type of spell.
Using the Alkemics skill, characters are able to
temporarily enchant items that are not made of iron or
any other type of metal. The resulting item allows the
possessor of the item to cast the embedded spell at will.
Once all castings in an item have been used, the item will
then disintegrate.
The character determines what item that they want to
enchant, and what type of spell or spells that they want to
embed into the item before making any rolls. The person
crafting the item does not need to be the one casting the
embedded spell.

Preparing the Item
To prepare the item to receive the spell, the character
must expend a number of Mana Points equal to the Tier
of the spell to be embedded. He must also use 1 dram
of Essential Salts per Tier of the spell to be embedded.
If more than one spell to be embedded, this process will
require another Mana Point and an additional dram of
Essential Salts for each spell beyond the first, in addition
to the Mana and Essential Salts for each spell. Once all
this is ready, the character must then spend 10 minutes
per Tier of the spell(s) to be embedded actually prepping
the item to receive the spell(s). The character also must
make an Alkemics skill roll that has an AM equal to 2 plus
the amount of Mana Points used to prep the item. Each
Success Level gained in this skill roll reduces the number
of Mana required by the preparation process by 1.
Mana spent preparing to embed a spell is not
recovered until the item has been used (which causes it
to crumble into dust once the last of the embedded magic
is used). Once the item is gone, the character will regain
these Mana Points during their next sleep.
Characters are also limited by the number of ranks
that they in the Alkemics skill. If they only have 10 ranks,
they can only use a maximum of 10 Mana Points in all
items created in this manner.
Example: Myddan is making a Charm to hold two
Tier 2 spells. This means that he will need to spend
5 Mana Points, and use 5 drams of Essential Salts to
create the item. This is 2 Mana for each spell, plus
1 Mana for having a second spell. Myddan is also
required to have a minimum of 5 ranks in Alkemics,
and his Alkemics roll for preparing the item will
receive an Alchemy Modifier of -7 (2 [base] + 5
[mana]). Myddan will not regain those 5 Mana
spent until the night after the items have been used.
Once the item has been prepared, then the spell(s) to
be embedded are cast into the item, using the standard
rules for casting spells, by either the character or a
companion. Any Success Levels may be spent on Casting
Boons to enhance the embedded spells as they are being
embedded.
After the enchantment is complete, the spell(s) may
be cast from the item at any time without need for a
Spellcasting roll. Once all spells in the item have been
cast, the item disintegrates into dust.
If the embedded spell is an attack spell that requires a
Save, the Save is based on the spell itself, not the user of
the item or the person who embedded it. If it is an attack
spell against a target’s Defensive Modifier (DM), the user
of the item must make the actual attack roll themselves,
using their Ranged or Arcana skill, whichever is higher.

189

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Herbals

Dusts

Herbals is a single term used in creating both Herbal
Remedies and Herbal Elixirs. Both items also require that
the character have either the Craft(Herbcraft), Nature,
or Arcana skill to identify the proper herbs and required
to be utilized, as well as the Alkemics skill to bring those
properties forth. For our purposes, in the descriptions for
Herbal Remedies and Elixirs when we say Herbcraft, we
mean any of the three appropriate skills. The character
may use whichever of the three he has the highest skill
bonus in.
Herbal Remedies
To create an Herbal Remedy, a character must have
a mortar and pestle and a small bowl or pot for boiling
and/or mixing the ingredients.
To create a single, 2 fluid ounce, dose of the Remedy,
the character starts off using 16 fluid ounces of clear
water and the choicest parts of the appropriate plants.
This requires an Herbcraft (AM -3) skill roll, to know
what plants are required for each Remedy. It takes 40
+ 2d10 minutes to create an Herbal Remedy and at the
end of the time, the character adds 1 dram of Essential
Salts and makes an Alkemics skill roll (AM -3) in order to
activate the magical properties of the remedy.
Once prepared, the remedy must be used immediately
or stored in an appropriate air-tight container within 10
minutes or it will lose its potency. Herbal Remedies that
are in a properly sealed vial have an unlimited shelf life.
Herbal Elixirs
To create Herbal Elixirs, a character must have a mortar
and pestle and a small bowl or pot for boiling and/or
mixing the ingredients.
To create a single, 2 fluid ounce, dose of the Elixir, the
character starts off using 16 fluid ounces of clear water
and the choicest parts of the appropriate plants. This
requires an Herbcraft (AM -5) skill roll to know what
plants are required for each Elixir. It takes 60 + (10 x
2d10) minutes to create an Herbal Elixir and at the end of
the time, the character adds 2 drams of Essential Salts and
makes a Alkemics (AM -5) skill roll in order to activate
the magical properties of the Elixir.
Once prepared, the Elixir must be used or stored in
an appropriate air-tight container within 10 minutes or it
will lose its potency. Herbal Elixirs that are in a properly
sealed vial have an unlimited shelf life.

190

There are a number of different types of Dusts that can
be created using Alchemy. They are all made using the
same basic foundation, and then specific ingredients are
added to create the finished Dusts. It takes a minimum of
eight days in total to create magical Dusts and Powders.
This foundation consists of 5 drams of Essential Salts, 5
drams of powdered sulphur, and 1 dram each of powered
gold, silver, platinum and at least 3 drams of powdered
gemstones (any type of precious stone) for each 4 ounce
dose of a powder. Then the Alchemist must also add in
16 drams (2 ounces) of the ingredients that are unique to
the type of dust or powder he is attempting to create. This
makes roughly 4 ounces of powder, which can, under the
correct conditions, expand to fill a 5’ diameter area.
Creating magical dusts require the use of a mortar &
pestle, and a hermetic vase (a special airtight vase) to store
the mixture while it is not being worked on. The Alchemist
will spend a total of 14 hours slowly grinding and mixing
all of the ingredients, except the Essential Salts, using the
mortal & pestle. The character may also produce multiple
doses at once. Each additional dose requires the proper
amount of ingredients and adds 50% to the time required
for each step (i.e. making 3 does takes twice as long as
making 1 dose).
Once that is completed, the character will then add in 5
drams of Essential Salts for each dose of powder, carefully
mixing and grinding it in, and then seal the powder in a
special airtight vase (called a hermetic vase), allowing it
to spend a week to finish the transmutation process.
After that, the Dusts can be packaged in ways to make
their use relatively easy (i.e. encased in small clay balls to
make throwing or use in a sling easy, paper packets for
easy carry, small cartridges for use in blowguns, etc.). If
a Dust or Powder is left in its vase longer than one week,
that will not hurt it. Also the size of the vase only has
to be large enough to hold the amount of powder being
created. In fact, some Alchemists use the vases themselves
as the delivery mechanism, throwing them against a hard
surface to release the Dust into its small cloud. Once
created, the Dust or Powder will last until it is used.
To know what ingredients are required for making a
specific type of Dust or Powder, the character needs to
make an Arcana (AM -5) roll. At the end of the week of
transmutation, the character makes an Alkemics (AM -5)
roll to determine if he was successful.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Potions

Rune Stones

Creating potions are a lot more difficult than creating
Herbal Remedies or Elixirs. The character requires a
mortar & pestle, a small cauldron or alembic and a
furnace or other steady heat source in order to create and
distill potions. The base, from which a potion is made,
consists of 1 pint of clear water, and 1 dram each of gold,
silver, copper, 1 dram each of 8 different gemstones, all
crushed into a fine powder, and 7 drams of Essential Salts.
The character combines the base ingredients listed
above, along with the ingredients required for the specific
potion he is attempting to make in the cauldron or
alembic, which is then heated for one week.
At the end of this week, the Alchemist makes a Alkemics
(AM -7) skill roll to determine whether or not the creation
of the potion was successful. If it was successful, then the
Alchemist has created a single dose (2 fluid ounces) of
the desired potion, which must then be transferred to an
appropriate container (i.e. vial) within 10 minutes.
To know which ingredients are required for which
potion, the character must succeed in an Arcana (AM
-7) skill roll. Potions often contain esoteric ingredients
related to the effects that they are supposed to produce. For
example, a Potion of Flight might contain blood or feathers
from a Gryphon or other flying creature, while a Potion of
Healing might contain Troll’s blood or some extremely rare
and potentially magical herbs that can also do healing.

Spell Scrolls
This is simply the inscribing of spells upon a suitable
surface, such as paper, vellum, papyrus or some other portable
medium. The paper itself is, contrary to what some spell
casters might want you to think, it relatively unimportant,
other than being large enough to hold the spell.
It is the ink used which is magical in nature. The ink
used in spell scrolls is made using the Alkemics skill (AM -7;
takes one week and a full alchemical lab to make), but many
Alchemists craft and sell the spell ink for just this purpose.
Alchemists who sell this ink will sell enough ink for a single
spell for 5 sp or enough to scribe 7 spells for 3 gp.
Inscribing a spell upon a scroll or parchment requires
using this magical ink, and the character must make an
Arcana roll with an Alchemy Modifier equal to the Tier of
the spell plus 5 (i.e. inscribing a Tier 3 spell has a modifier
of -8). When scribing a spell in this manner, the character
must also expend the Mana Points for the spell. He will
then recover those Mana Points normally. A character
may only scribe spells that he knows and has recorded in
his Spellbook.
Once the spell has been scribed, anybody else who
tries to determine what it is has to make an Arcana skill
roll with a negative modifier equal to the Tier of the spell.
Once deciphered, the spell may be cast with a simple
Arcana skill roll (no modifiers). The deciphering and
casting are not tied together. They can be done one after
the other or even years apart.
191

Rune Stones are specially prepared thin wafers in an
oblong shape, about one inch by one and a half inches,
and about a quarter inch thick, that have been etched
with a Spell Rune.
Creating the wafer upon which Runes may be inscribed
requires 3 days, and one dram of Essential Salts per wafer,
and the character must make a roll, either Craft(Pottery)
or Alkemics skill roll. This roll has an AM of -5. There are
some Alchemists who sell these blank wafers for 1 sp per
wafer.
Once the wafers are completed, they may be stored
indefinitely until a character wishes to inscribe them
with a spell. To etch the spell into the wafer requires 10
minutes for each point of Mana in the spell being etched.
A character may only etch spells that he knows and has
recorded in his spellbook.
To successfully etch a rune, the character must make a
successful Arcana skill roll with a negative modifier equal
to the Tier of the spell being etched plus 5 (i.e. etching a
Tier 3 rune has an AM of -8 and it takes 80 minutes).
Etching the rune also requires that the character uses a
glaze made from 1 dram of Essential Salts per rune to be
glazed plus a few other common ingredients (anybody who
has at least 3 ranks of Alkemics knows how to make this glaze,
no skill roll required). This glaze is spread inside the etched
groove of the spell, and then the character projects the Mana
needed to cast the spell into the glazed wafer and the rune is
then energized and ready to be used. The glaze must be used
within an hour of it being made. Once energized, the Rune
Stone, as it is now called, lasts until it is used. Empowered
Rune Stones usually sell for 3 sp per Tier of the etched spell.
There are some Alchemists who will not only sell
blank wafers, but also sell pre-etched, unglazed wafers, at
a cost of 2 sp plus 1 sp per Tier of the etched spell. Those
Alchemists who sell pre-etched wafers often pay other
spell users 1 sp per Tier for each spell successfully etched.
With pre-etched, unglazed wafers, a caster need only
make the glaze and then project the Mana into the rune
to energize it. He need not actually know the spell that he
is energizing, just so long as he knows what it is, so that
he knows how much Mana is needed.
Deciphering the rune on an unknown Rune Stone
that requires an Arcana skill roll with a negative modifier
equal to the Tier of the etched Rune.
Using a Rune Stone requires only that the wielder
breaks the wafer into two or more pieces, which then
crumbles to dust. It need not be deciphered first.
This makes empowered Rune Stones popular with
those who do not cast spells. The spell on the rune then
immediately takes effect. (i.e. a Rune Stone holding a Fire
Ball rune would allow the breaker to immediately throw
a Fire Ball at some targets). If the spell upon a Rune Stone
requires a Save, the Save is made against the Tier of the
spell, not the person using the Rune Stone.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Enchantments

Magical Materials

These are items that require the Special Skill, Enchantments
to make. The making of these items requires special tools
and equipment, or possibly a full Alchemist’s lab, depending
on the item to be made and how it gets made. We will go
into the Methods of creation later in this section.
For the following guidelines, we use the term Alchemical
Pips (AP), which could also be used to mean level or ranks.
For Enchantments, we use the total AP to determine several
aspects of item creation.

Creation Overview
Making a magical item is pretty simple when it comes to
the rules.
• Determine the total AP required for the item. This
determines the Difficulty Level of creating the item.
• Determine the Method of creation, this can provide
modifiers to the Alkemics roll.
• Make an Alkemics skill roll, including both the
Difficulty and Method modifiers.
Item Costs
Characters who find or make items will sometimes
want to sell them to others. To determine the sale price of
a magical item, we want to look at the total AP required
for creating the item, and multiply that by 15. If magical
materials were used in making the item, the cost of those
materials are added to any cost from the enchantments.
The result will be the market price in gold pieces. Since we
are talking about gold pieces here, we normally just round off.
Example: A Dagger of Returning has an AP of 19.
And it is made from Orichalcum, which gives a +1
bonus. Since the cost of an Orichalcum Dagger is
15x its normal cost of 1 sp, that makes it cost 15 sp
(rounded up to 2 gp). Multiplying the 19 AP times
15, which equals 285 gp, and then adding in the 2
gp from the Orichalcum gives us a total cost of 287
gp for the Dagger of Returning.
The costs for the alchemist to create the item are usually
about 50% to 60% of the price that it sells for. This includes
maintaining the costs of the laboratory and ingredients
required to make the item.
When players want to sell items, the GM should use the
Commerce Table (p. 227) to see what price they might get
for it. Most magical items would be considered to be in the
Outrageously Expensive category.

There are a number of different materials that, if used in
the creation of an item, will provide bonuses to using those
items in the manner in which they are intended. The cost
multipliers listed for the materials below are for if the items
are made using these materials. Any further enchantments
beyond this would simply add to the adjusted base costs.
Mythral – This silvery metal is sometimes called Beacon Silver
because of the association that it has with worshippers
of Cerriwn, Goddess of the Moon and Beacon of the
Night. This metal can be used to make chain armor that
is as light as soft leather. Weapons made from Mythral
are easier to make “Of Slaying” against Lycanthropes
(requires only half of the normal item creation
modifier). Anything made from Mythral will have a +2
bonus. Mythral items cost 10x their normal cost.

192

Nerok – This is a shiny black metal, too brittle on its
own, so often mixed into an alloy. This alloy grants
a +2 modifier to both attack bonus and the Damage
Rating of any weapons made using this modifier.
It often looks like it is wet or oiled and it holds an
edge extremely well. Weapons made of this material
usually cost about 5x their normal price.
Skyris – Meteorites have always fallen from the sky. This
dull, dark grey metal is forged from those fragments
that have been collected from such meteorites. Once
forged, which is very difficult, it is extremely tough,
granting a +9 magical bonus to anything made from
it. Items made from Skyris usually cost about 200x
their normal price.
Tanium – This is a very light, flexible, and yet tough
material. Its flexibility prevents it from being used
for weapons and armor, but other tools, such as
lockpicks, instrument strings, and similar items that
are made from this will have a bonus of +4. Items
made using Tanium cost 10x their normal price.
Volss – This is a form of magical volcanic glass. In its natural
form, it is usually a smoky grey in color, with iridescent
sparkles throughout. It can often be tinted, the color of
the tint often reflects the sorts of additional properties
that items made from Volss may utilize. Items made
from this material have an inherent magical +5 bonus
and cost 50x their normal price.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Orichalcum – This metal alloy is made from a number of
rare and precious substances. It takes 2 weeks, and an
Alkemics (with a -15 modifier) roll to make. The end
result of this process appears as 3” long, 1/2” wide by
1/2” tall ingots of metal that has a color between that
of brass and bronze. Using these ingots in the forging
of weapons and armor, in combination with the
normal metals can grant them innate magical bonuses,
depending on how many ingots are used.
These ingots often have a value on the open market
of 1 gp each. Items made using Orichalcum, usually go
for 15x their listed prices.
The creation of magical items using these ingots
requires the use of an appropriate smithing skill to mix the
ingots with the other materials being used to craft the item.
Using the ingots does not require any special magical skills,
so this may be performed by any competent smith.
The number of ingots required to craft a specific item
will be based upon the size of the item to be created. Each
ingot or group of ingots required to craft an item will grant
the device a +1 bonus to all uses or aspects of the device.
This means that for weapons, the bonus is to both Accuracy
(attack bonus) and Damage Ratings, while for Armor, the
bonus if for both Defensive Modifier (DM) and all Armor
Ratings (except SL). Bonuses to armor would not affect
Move or AB penalties, since Orichalcum is not lighter than
other metals. No item may have a bonus greater than +3
from Orichalcum. Also, these bonuses do count against the
total bonus allowed for further Enchantments.
The number of ingots required for each type
of weapon or armor is based upon its size and the
following list will provide more information as to the
number of ingots required.
Hand & Short Weapons – This includes daggers, batons,
cesti, hand axes, short swords and other Hand and
Short weapons. Each ingot used provides a +1 bonus
to the Accuracy (attack bonus) and to the Damage
Rating of the weapon.
Long & Longest Weapons – This includes such things most
swords, ball & chain, battle axes and other Long and
Longest weapons not specified elsewhere. It requires 2
ingots to provide a single +1 bonus to both accuracy and
Damage Ratings. Using a single ingot will have no effect.
Pole Weapons – This includes staves, pole arms, pole axes,
spears, and any other long weapon that has a smaller
striking surface. For weapons of this type, it requires 1 and
a half ingots for each +1 to accuracy and Damage Rating.
Missiles – A missile means an arrow, crossbow bolt,
or sling bullet, or any other item that is fired from a
hand-held weapon. A single ingot of Orichalcum can
provide a +1 to the accuracy and Damage Rating of 12
missiles of a single type. Alternatively, a single ingot
of Orichalcum could be used to grant a +2 bonus to
accuracy and Damage Rating for 6 missiles of a single
type, or a single ingot may be used to give a +3 bonus
to accuracy and Damage Rating to 3 missiles.

Shields– It requires 1 ingot per size of the shield (i.e. a
Buckler requires 1 while a Tower Shield requires 5
ingots) to grant a +1 to the DM that the shield provides.
Torso Armor – It requires 4 ingots of Orichalcum to grant
metal torso armor a +1 to both DM and Armor Rating.
Bracers, Greaves & Helms – These are primarily defensive
items, and a single ingot of Orichalcum can be used to
grant a +1 bonus to both the DM and Armor Rating
of a helm, or a single pair of Bracers, or a single set of
Greaves.

Base Items

4
Armor (AP 3): Each individual
piece of armor gets its own AP. So, for a full suit, which
would include helm, torso armor, bracers, and greaves,
you would have an AP of 12, while a set of bracers
would have an AP of 3.
Jewelry (AP 7): Jewelry includes things like rings, broaches,
amulets, tiaras, headbands, armbands, and any other
item made of gems and precious metals.
Other Items (AP 5): This includes any items not covered by
another item on this list. It would include things like
clothing, lock picks, hammers, knives, anvils, and more.
Rods (AP 4): Rods are small staves that are between 2’ and
3’ in length and usually about 1” in thickness. Some
have sturdy and possibly ornate heads upon their tops.
They can be used as weapons, like a baton if they do
not have a head piece and like a mace if they do.
Shields (AP 3): The size of the shield does not have any bearing
on what sort of magics are often embedded into them.
Staves (AP 4): Many magic users will use their staff as a focus
for casting. Staves are the largest of the three, usually
being about 6’ in length on average and up to 2” in
thickness, and like the rod, may be used as a weapon in
addition to a magical item.
Wands (AP 3): Wands are small sticks, between 8” and 16” in
length. They are often slender, being less than half an inch
in diameter, often tapering at one end. Wands cannot be
used as weapons in combat. However, they can be used
as an aid in casting spells, especially if they have been
enchanted for such.
Weapons (AP 4): This category of item applies to all weapons,
including staves and rods that are also used as weapons.

Specific Enchantments

The following list of specific enchantments should not be
considered to be the only enchantments possible. They are
meant to act as a guideline to help the GM determine the
overall AP for other enchantments that are not listed.

Armor Rating: This enchantment allows the item to increase
the AR of a given item. It has an initial AP of 4. Then
the alchemist must select which attribute of AR they are
enhancing, and by how much. Each +1 in a specific AR
attribute (Bash, Slash, Pierce, or Elemental) adds +1 to
the initial AP of this enchantment. For example, adding 1
to each of the 4 AR ratings will cost 8 AP total.

194

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Armor (SL Adjustment): This enchantment allows armor
to reduce the Critical Damage of a person wearing the
armor by adding to the SL cost of the Critical Damage This
adjustment has an AP cost equal to (2+#) x (2+#), where
# is equal to the amount of SL adjustment (i.e. to increase
the SL cost of Critical Damage by 1 point, that will add 9
AP to the item, Increasing by 2 SL adds 16 AP to the item).
Attack Bonus: This enchantment allows the Alchemist to
increase the Attack Bonus of a weapon or a specific type of
attack (i.e. spells). This adds 2 AP to the item, and then an
additional amount of AP equal to the bonus times itself (i.e.
# x #, a +2 bonus would add 2 + (2 x 2) = 6 AP total).
At-Will: This enchantment is added to allow spells and
spell-like abilities to be activated whenever the wielder of
the item wishes to activate it. This adds 10 to the overall
AP of the item.
Automatic Recharge: This enchantment allows an item
that uses charges to automatically recharge itself. This
adds 5 to the AP of the item. When used, the Alchemist
must decide what triggers the recharge. It could be the
rising of the sun, or each night at midnight, or recharging
a limited amount every hour that the item is not used.
Once set, the recharge interval cannot ever be changed.
Bleeding: This enchantment allows weapons to deal extra
Bleeding damage upon making a successful attack that
earns Success Levels (SL). The wielder of the weapon does
not have to spend any SLs for this Bleeding to take effect.
This enchantment adds a number of AP to the item equal
to 1 + (# x #). Thus, adding 3 Hits of Bleeding to attacks
will add 1 + (3 x 3) = 10 AP to the item.
Charged Item: This enchantment allows an item to hold
5 charges for every 2 AP that is added to the item. Any
spells or spell-like abilities that the item has will use a
number of charges equal to its Tier. Any charged item
may be recharged by making a Very Hard Arcana or a
Hard Alkemics skill roll, along with the expenditure of
1 Mana Point (or 2 Hit Points) for each charge to be
returned to the item.
Constant: This enchantment allows another enchantment
on the item, that normally has a duration to work
continuously for as long as the item is wielded or worn,
such as a ring that turns its wearer invisible when worn,
or a hooded cloak that does the same when the hood is
worn. This adds 15 AP to the overall total.

Daily: This enchantment allows a spell or spell-like ability
to be used once per for each level of this ability that is
added. The cost of this is # x # where # is the number of
times per day that it can be used. When this is chosen, the
break-point of the day must be selected (i.e. midnight or
daybreak, etc.) and it cannot be changed afterwards.
Damage Rating: This enchantment increases the Damage
Rating of a weapon. Each +1 applies to all the different
Damage Ratings that a weapon has. The AP cost for this
is # x #, so that a +3 to the Damage Rating adds 9 AP (3
x 3 = 9) total.
Dancing: This enchantment allows for a weapon or shield
to float and operate on its own. The wielder of the item
must spend a Half Action each round to control the item,
otherwise it will act as it is normally used and stay within
5’ of the wielder, directly in front of the wielder (i.e. a
weapon will attack or a shield will defend). The item
must also be enchanted with any skill bonuses that the
creator wants the item to have. This enchantment adds
10 AP to the overall amount required by the item. For an
additional 5 AP, the wielder need not concentrate. The
duration is normally based on the wielder’s Resolve stat
as a number of rounds per day.
Defensive Modifier: For each +1 that this enchantment
adds to the item, the alchemist adds a total number of
AP equal to 3 + (# x #). Thus a +3 bonus to the Defensive
Modifier (DM) will add 12 (3 + (3 x 3) = 12) AP to the
total for the item.
Detection: This enchantment allows the wielder of the item
to detect 1 specific type of non-living thing (i.e. illusions,
spells, traps, secret doors, etc.) within a 10’ radius for each
increment of 5 AP added to the item. Two increments of
the same detection focus give the item a range of 20’ and
additional increments can increase it further. When adding
this enchantment, the alchemist must also decide upon how
the wielder of the item will be notified, the most common
method being that the item glows or emits a noise.
Direction: This enchantment allows the wielder of the
item to determine which direction its focus is in with a
Full Action spent concentrating it. This is often added to
items that have a Detection enchantment, or it is set for a
single target (i.e. which direction is north), and gives the
direction to the target, but not the distance. When added
to a Detection enchantment, the item must first detect
the focus, and then a Full Action spent concentrating
can give the distance, within the range, of the focus. This
enchantment may be added to an item for 5 AP.

195

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Divinity: This enchantment makes a weapon be Holy or
Unholy. Holy weapons deal double damage against
creatures from the Infernal Realms. Unholy weapons
deal double damage against creatures from the Celestial
Realms. Characters with at least one Envoy or Champion
Vocational Kit dedicated to the same deity to whom
this weapon is dedicated also gain double the number
of Success Levels earned in any attack. Adding this
capability adds 15 AP to the overall total.

Keyed: This enchantment allows the other enchantments to
be set to only work when held by a person of a specific
Kin. On one world, this has been used to enchant daggers
that automatically glow if held by somebody with Elven
blood; while on another world, there was a set of magical
stones that only worked for those of Elven blood. This
adds 5 AP to the overall total. If added a second time, the
item could be keyed to an even tighter group, such as only
those with Elven Blood from a single family.

Drawbacks: These are options that put a limit of sorts on
the item. They can also reduce the amount of AP in the
creation of the item, making it easier to create. A drawback
will be worth from -1 to -5 AP, depending upon how severe
it is. If the drawback only lasts up to a minute, then you
would give it a -1. If the drawback lasts up to 10 minutes, it
would be worth -2, and if it lasts up to an hour, it would be
worth -3. If the drawback lasts up to a day, then it is worth
-4, and if it lasts for longer than a day, it is worth a -5 to the
total AP required to make the item.

Light: This enchantment allows the item to glow with
light, providing the 5’ radius of light for each instance of
this enchantment included (i.e. 3 instances equals a 15’
radius). Each instance adds 2 AP to the overall total.

Elemental Ability: This enchantment grants a singular
elemental ability upon its wielder when activated. This
could an immunity to fire attacks, or the ability to breathe
under water, etc. The ability is chosen when the item is
created and lasts for 30 minutes for each increment of this
enchantment that is added to the item. A weapon with this
ability could burst into flame, be coated in ice or be crackling
with electrical energy, etc. and doing an amount of damage
equal to half that of weapon it is on. Each instance of this
enchantment adds 7 AP to the item’s overall total.
Free Hand: This enchantment allows for two-handed
weapons to used as Hand and a Half weapons. It also allows
for Hand and a Half Weapons to be used one handed with
no modifiers. If added twice, it can allow a two-handed
weapon to be used one handed. This adds 10 AP to the
overall total.

Return Flight: This enchantment allows a thrown weapon
to return to its thrower the round after it is thrown. When
it returns, the wielder must spend their Free Action for
the round to catch it, or else it will fall to their feet, and
require a Half Action to pick up later. This adds 10 AP to
the overall total.
Save Bonus (all): This enchantment provides a bonus to all
Save rolls that the character who owns the item has to
make. The AP cost of this is equal to 5 + (# x #), where #
is the amount of the Save bonus.
Save vs. [specific thing]: This enchantment provides a
bonus to Saves against a specific instance of an item. It
could be against poison, or against magic from the School
of Sorcery, etc. The cost for adding this to an item is triple
the Save Bonus provided.
Sensing: This enchantment allows for the wielder of the
enchanted item to sense one type of living creature or
being within 50’ for every time it is added to the item.
Items with this enchantment will begin to glow if the
focus of the sensing is within the radius. Each time this is
added to an item, it adds 7 to the total AP overall.

Impact: This enchantment adds +1 Stun to any attack that
deals Critical Damage
Increased Range: This enchantment allows for items that
are not normally thrown to have a thrown range, and for
items used in ranged attack to have greater ranges. Each
+5’ added to the range of an object adds +1 AP to the
overall AP of the item.
Invisibility: This enchantment allows the wielder of the item
to turn invisible upon activation. This invisibility will last
for 1 minute per level of the wielder of the item, if another
enchantment is not used to extend it. Any attempt to
cast a spell or make an attack will cause the character to
immediately become visible again. This enchantment will
add 8 AP to the overall total.

196

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Shadow: This enchantment allows the object to deepen the
shadows around it. A single instance of this enchantment
creates a 5’ radius where the shadows deepen in Dimly
Lit or dark areas, granting a +2 to Stealth rolls. Each
additional instance can either increase that radius by +5’
or increase the bonus by +1. Each instance adds 5 AP to
the total overall.
Sharpness: This enchantment allows an edged weapon to
be a bit sharper than normal, which means that each
instance grants a -1 modifier to all actions of any person
hit by the weapon, as long as the attack gained Success
Levels. Each -1 adds a number of AP equal to # x # where
the # is equal to the amount of the penalty. Thus a -2 on
all attacks that earn Success Levels will require adding 4
AP (2 x 2 = 4) to the overall total.
Shifting: This enchantment allows an item to shape shift into
a similarly sized item (i.e. a long sword into a falchion or
a long bow into a quarterstaff). Each additional time this
enchantment is included, another item can be included
for shifting, or the item can shift into something one size
category in difference. For example, to allow a long sword
to shift to a dagger would require this to be added 3 times,
once to allow it to change to a dagger, and twice more to
allow it to shift from a Long weapon to a Hand weapon
(two steps in size). Those same 3 instances could have
also allowed the long sword to shift into a falchion, battle
axe or bec de corbin. This enchantment adds 5 AP to the
overall total each time it is included.

Shrink/Grow: This enchantment allows the item so
enchanted to shrink or grow by 10% of its normal size
for 2 AP increment added to the overall total. Once this
enchantment has been activated, it remains in effect until
it is activated again to return its normal size.
Skill Bonus: This enchantment adds a +1 bonus to a single skill
for each increment added to the item. This enchantment
cannot apply to any of the Combat Skills (Blades, Blunt,
Brawl, Polearms, and Ranged). The AP cost for this bonus
is equal to # x #, where # equals the bonus (i.e. a +2 bonus
will have an AP cost of 2 x 2 = 4 AP).
Slaying: This enchantment is one of the most powerful, but
it only applies against a single type of Kin or creature. If a
weapon has this enchantment on it, any strike that deals
damage and earns Success Levels will automatically deliver
the Critical Success result (Save vs Death Strike) in addition
to any other Critical Damage dealt by the Success Levels
the attack earns. If the attack results in a Critical Success,
it deals Instant Death instead of Save Vs Death Strike. This
adds 20 AP to the overall total of the item.

Spellcasting: This enchantment allows the embedding of a
specific spell into the item. The AP cost is equal to 2 +
the spell’s Tier. Any Casting Modifiers that the Spell has
should be divided in half (rounded up) and treated as
part of the spell’s Tier (i.e. a CM of -5 increases the spell’s
Tier by +3 for calculations in enchanting it). This must be
combined with another option, such as Daily or At-Will
or Charges, etc. to allow it to be cast more than once. If
not combined with another option, once the spell is cast,
it is gone.

Spell Storing: This enchantment allows an item to store a
single spell for an AP cost equal to 5 plus the maximum
Tier of the spell to be stored. Unless other options are
used during the creation of the item, once a stored spell
is cast, it is gone. However, the item will retain the abilitiy
to store other spells of up to the same Tier.
Stat Bonus: This enchantment grants a bonus to a character’s
stat when they are using the enchanted item. The AP cost
for this bonus 6 + (# x #), where # is the amount of the
bonus. Therefore, an item that grants a +2 bonus would
add 10 AP (6 + (2 x 2) = 10) to the overall total.
True Return: This enchantment allows for a ranged attack
item to teleport back to its quiver, scabbard, etc. once
it strikes its target or if it misses its target. Adding this
enchantment adds 15 AP to the overall total.
Unencumbering: This enchantment makes the item either
weigh less and/or be more easily used. Each increment
of this enchantment either reduces the weight of an item
by 10% or reduces penalties by 1 point. For armor, this
would reduce the Move Penalty, then any AB penalty,
and then any Dexterity penalties. Each increment of this
enchantment adds 3 AP to the overall total.
Vampiric Healing: This enchantment, when added to a
weapon, allows any damage dealt by the weapon to heal
an equal amount of damage to the wielder. This adds 15
AP to the overall total.
Warning: This enchantment allows the wielder of the item to
activate it and it will then warn him of any unauthorized
presences within a 50’ range. Upon activation, the
wielder has 2 minutes to touch up to four individuals to
mark them as authorized to be within the radius. Each
instance of this enchantment adds 50’ to the radius and
up to 4 more additional individuals to be authorized.
This Warning will only work against intelligent, sentient
individuals, not animals or creatures. Each instance of
this enchantment adds 7 AP to the overall total.

197

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Running Fantasy Express

This chapter is not designed to explain how to be Game
Master (GM) or how to build an adventure or campaign.
It will presume that you have experience playing and even
running one or more other games.
Our goal here is to cover any additional information
that you, as GM, may need to run Fantasy Express more
efficiently and to cover any information not already covered
elsewhere in this book.

Difficulty Levels

One of the most common tasks for a GM is to determine
the difficulty level of a task that the players are attempting
to perform. When determining the difficulty of a task, you
should not consider what the abilities of the characters are,
only how the difficulty of the task would compare against
the average person (which our heroes are anything but).
Below, we repeat the list of standard Difficulty Levels
from earlier in the book as well as their definitions and the
modifiers associated with them. We do this as a reminder.
Easy (+4): Given enough time and perhaps a tiny bit of
luck, an apprentice can complete tasks of this rating.
An averagely skilled character can accomplish this type
of task with no trouble at all.
Standard/Normal (+/-0): A task that an averagely skill
character can accomplish without much trouble,
unless in a hurry or stressed. This is considered to
be the average difficulty inherent in any standard
adventuring situation. Any task or action, in such
circumstances, that seems to be the most common for
a given skill is usually of this Difficulty Rating.
198

Challenging (-3): A task easily accomplished by skilled
characters; however it can be tricky for a novice or
unskilled character.
Hard (-6): A task requiring dedication and effort even
by skills characters. Even an expert needs time to
successfully complete these types of task or action.
Very Hard (-9): That is a task challenging even for a
skilled character and possibly requiring some luck to
be accomplished.
Heroic (-12): Possibly something out of reach for many
characters except for highly trained professionals. Only
an extremely skilled and lucky expert or someone with
unbelievable luck would be able to accomplish tasks or
actions of this difficulty.
Legendary (-15): Something really tough to accomplish
even by the most skilled masters without aid or with
greater luck. This difficulty is reserved for efforts that
are considered to be on the edge of human capabilities.
You could refer to a book of world records for examples
of tasks or actions of this level of difficulty.
Mythic (-20): You should not even think about it, to
begin with! These tasks or actions are a step above
the normal possibilities of the vast majority of people.
Such tasks or actions should only be attempted by
those who desire to be heroes.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Example Difficulties
The following examples cover many, but not all of the skills
and/or common tasks that a character may want to perform.
They do not cover every skill, nor every use of every skill.
Our examples only cover from Standard Difficulties on up.
They are meant to give you, the GM some examples,
which you can use as a guideline for any other task that a
character may want to perform.
They should never be considered a complete list of what
may or may not be possible.
Acrobatics
• Standard (+0): Swinging from a chandelier;
• Challenging (-3): Balancing on a narrow surface;
• Hard (-6): Tumbling away to avoid an activated trap;
• Very Hard (-9): Escape from bindings;
• Heroic (-12): Safely landing after falling or jumping
from a running horse or chariot;
• Legendary (-15): Performing a wall run;
• Mythic (-20): Balancing on a narrow surface
blindfolded while buffeted by strong winds.
Acumen
• Standard (+0): General mundane rumors such as
Aunt Sally’s cow is pregnant (assuming Aunt Sally
has been telling people);
• Challenging (-3): Specific information about a
particular place; who’s important, who’s a bully,
who’s a victim, etc.;
• Hard (-6): Finding a place of illicit means such as
a gambling den in a place where they are against
the law;
• Very Hard (-9): News about foreign lands gathered
from passing travelers. Knowing that someone is
hiding a secret, just not what it may be;
• Heroic (-12): Finding someone who does not
want to be found;
• Legendary (-15): Rumors of Lost or Primeval places;
• Mythic (-20): Magically hidden secrets and the
machinations of the Darkmaster.
Arcana
• Standard (+0): Attuning to a magical item;
• Challenging (-3): Recognizing the type (demon,
undead, spirit, etc) of a supernatural creature you
can see;
• Hard (-6): Identifying a Spell as being from your
School of Magic as it’s being cast;
• Very Hard (-9): Deciphering a text in a forgotten
arcane language or identifying a magical glyph;
• Heroic (-12): Identifying the School of Magic and
the Vocational Kit who would cast a given spell as
it’s being cast;
• Legendary (-15): Recognizing a supernatural
creature by the tracks it leaves behind;
• Mythic (-20): Navigating through a different
plane of existence.

Athletics
• Standard (+0): Climbing a rock wall or a tree;
• Challenging (-3): Jogging or hiking for a
prolonged time across a rough terrain;
• Hard (-6): Swimming against the current;
• Very Hard (-9): Jumping across a pit from a
standing position;
• Heroic (-12): Climbing a smooth wall;
• Legendary (-15): Pulling a fully loaded ox cart;
• Mythic (-20): Swimming against strong rapids.
Beastmastery
• Standard (+0): The beast is a domesticated
animal;
• Challenging (-3): The beast is wounded or ill;
• Hard (-6): The beast is currently Frightened; the
beast is a wild, undomesticated animal (herbivore);
• Very Hard (-9): The beast is currently in combat;
undomesticated omnivore;
• Heroic (-12): The beast is a wild animal and
hungry (carnivore);
• Legendary (-15): The beast is currently in combat
and has been wounded by the character;
• Mythic (-20): The beast is in a frenzied state and
being attacked by the character.
Climbing
This will use either the character’s Acrobatics or Athletics skill.
• Standard (+0): Climbing a tree or surface with
clear handholds;
• Challenging (-3): Climbing a rugged surface or rope;
• Hard (-6): Climbing a rugged surface in high
winds, snow, or rain;
• Very Hard (-9): Climbing a free rope in high
winds, rain, or snow;
• Heroic (-12): Climbing a smooth wall;
• Legendary (-15): Climbing a smooth wall in
strong winds, rain, or snow;
• Mythic (-20): Climbing a sheer glass wall.

199

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Cultures
• Standard (+0): Recognizing a written language
that is not one you know;
• Challenging (-3): Recognizing the banner of a
clan or family from the character’s own Culture;
• Hard (-6): Knowing how to properly address a
lord or lady from another Kin;
• Very Hard (-9): Knowing the uncommon
customs of a nearby Culture that is not your own;
• Heroic (-12): Knowing the secret customer of a
particular group that you do not belong to within
your own Culture;
• Legendary (-15): Knowing secret customs of a
particular group from a different Culture;
• Mythic (-20): Recognizing a culture or language
from another plane of existence.
Decieve
• Standard (+0): Distract someone while your
friends are sneaking behind their back;
• Challenging (-3): Convincibly feign a limp or
other physical ailment for a prolonged time;
• Hard (-6): Disguise oneself as a member of a
different Culture;
• Very Hard (-9): Convince the gatekeeper that the
character is the person the thane is waiting for;
• Heroic (-12): Trick a group of Trolls into talking
until the Sun rises;
• Legendary (-15): Disguise oneself as a member
of a very different Kin;
• Mythic (-20): Trick a dragon into showing you its
vulnerable spot.
Feats of Strength
• Standard (+0): Snapping a wooden pole, pushing
open a stuck door;
• Challenging (-3): Smashing down an interior
wooden door; pulling a stuck lever;
• Hard (-6): Snapping a metal weapon;
• Very Hard (-9): Breaking down an exterior or
reinforced wooden door; breaking out of rope bonds;
• Heroic (-12): Bending the bars on a prison door;
breaking open a reinforced wooden chest;
• Legendary (-15): Breaking down a stone door;
• Mythic (-20): Breaking out of thick, iron
manacles; breaking down an iron door; pushing
down an established large tree.

Gimmickry
• Standard (+0): Breaking a lock with a hammer
or rock;
• Challenging (-3): Pick a normal lock without
breaking it;
• Hard (-6): Determining the purpose of a complex
mechanism never seen before;
• Very Hard (-9): Disarm or design a complex
mechanical trap;
• Heroic (-12): Picking a lock without seeing it;
• Legendary (-15): Opening a barred door without
making a sound;
• Mythic (-20): Picking the lock of the manacles
you are currently wearing.
Hunting
• Standard (+0): Catching enough game to feed a
party of travelers for a day in a forest;
• Challenging (-3): Follow a trail across a grass field;
• Hard (-6): Setting up a trap that affects a Large
creature, or several Medium-sized creatures;
• Very Hard (-9): Catching enough game to feed a
party of travelers for a day in a tundra;
• Heroic (-12): Follow a trail across a hard rock surface;
• Legendary (-15): Setting up a trap that affects a
Huge creature, or multiple Large creatures;
• Mythic (-20): Catching enough game to feed a
party of travelers for a day in a Darkland.
Influence
• Standard (+0): Negotiating with a merchant;
• Challenging (-3): Inspiring or issuing orders to a
small group of people;
• Hard (-6): Convincing someone to follow you for
a small fee and a share of treasure;
• Very Hard (-9): Inspiring or issuing orders to a
large group of people;
• Heroic (-12): Making an impression on nobles at
a foreign court;
• Legendary (-15): Convincing someone to follow
you only for a share of treasure;
• Mythic (-20): Rallying routing troops.

200

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Leaping
This will use either the Acrobatics or Athletics skill. The
following examples also presume that this is a running leap.
• Standard (+0): Leaping half of the character’s
height horizontally or one quarter of it vertically;
• Challenging (-3): Leaping up to character’s
height horizontally or half of it vertically;
• Hard (-6): Leaping up to one and a half times the
character’s height horizontally or three quarters
of his height vertically;
• Very Hard (-9): Leaping up to twice the character’s
height horizontally or up to his height vertically;
• Heroic (-12): Leaping up to three times character’s
height horizontally or up to one and a half times
the character’s height vertically;
• Legendary (-15): Leaping up to four times
character’s height horizontally or twice the
character’s height vertically;
• Mythic (-20): Leaping up to five times character’s
height horizontally or up to three times character’s
height vertically.
Note: Reduce the distance for leaping by 50% from
a standing jump.
Lifting/Carrying
This will use the Athletics skill. A character’s weight limit
for what they can normally move or lift is considered to
be 50 lbs plus their Brawn times 50 lbs. This means that
a character with a Brawn of 3 would have a normal lift or
move capacity of 200lbs. Carrying this amount would have
the character be treated as being Encumbered (p. 111).
• Standard (+0): Up to the character’s limit;
• Challenging (-3): Between 101-120% of the
character’s weight limit;
• Hard (-6): Between 121-130%% of the character’s
weight limit;
• Very Hard (-9): Between 131-150%% of the
character’s weight limit;
• Heroic (-12): Between 151-175%% of the
character’s weight limit;
• Legendary (-15): Between 176-200%% of the
character’s weight limit;
• Mythic (-20): Between 200-300%% of the
character’s weight limit.

Lore
•
•
•
•
•
•
•

Standard (+0): Knowing the lay of the land of a
known area or region;
Challenging (-3): Entertaining a small crowd in
a tavern;
Hard (-6): Remembering the legends surrounding
a feared tomb located nearby;
Very Hard (-9): Knowing the history of the
dynasty of a local lord;
Heroic (-12): Entertaining the court of an Elven
lord;
Legendary (-15): Reciting a poem about the
deeds of an obscure minor hero;
Mythic (-20): Knowing a rhyme that reveals how
to lift a specific curse.

Nature
• Standard (+0): Anticipating the general behavior
of a known species of animals;
• Challenging (-3): Identifying an uncommon
type of herb or beast;
• Hard (-6): Taming a hungry predator;
• Very Hard (-9): Anticipating the general behavior
of a species of animals never seen before;
• Heroic (-12): Growing a plant or herb in a climate
or environment that’s radically different from its
natural habitat;
• Legendary (-15): Taming a monstrous or magical
beast;
• Mythic (-20): Growing healing herbs in a
Darkland.
Perception
• Standard (+0): Detecting a poorly concealed
ambush, recognize a well known type of item by
touch alone;
• Challenging (-3): Finding a hidden door or
concealed passage in a well lit room;
• Hard (-6): Recognizing an unknown item by
touch alone;
• Very Hard (-9): Following a faint sound or smell;
• Heroic (-12): Detecting a small hidden compartment
or cleverly hidden trap or ambush;
• Legendary (-15): Detecting the presence of an
invisible creature;
• Mythic (-20): Detecting a flavorless poison in
your cup of wine.

Pilot
