Standard (+0): Controlling a vessel whilst near
other vessels on open water;
Challenging (-3): Piloting a vessel to evade an
obstacle in its immediate path; docking in a marina;
Hard (-6): Piloting a vessel in choppy waters;
controlling a ship with half crew in normal conditions;
Very Hard (-9): Piloting a boat through extensive
rapids; evading an enemy vessel attempting to ram;
Heroic (-12): Piloting a vessel in heavy swell or
large waves; controlling a ship with less than
onequarter crew in normal conditions;
Legendary (-15): Piloting a ship in huge waves or
a storm at sea;
Mythic (-20): Piloting a ship in a hurricane.
Standard (+0): Controlling a trained mount in
battle;
Challenging (-3): Driving a chariot in combat;
Hard (-6): Leaping an obstacle with a mount;
Very Hard (-9): Controlling a spooked animal;
Heroic (-12): Convincing an untrained animal to
charge;
Legendary (-15): Bareback bronc riding;
Mythic (-20): Convincing a mount to charge a
dragon.

Sciences
• Standard (+0): Common knowledge.; basic
understanding;
• Challenging (-3): Simple reactions, forces, and
equations; simple mechanics;
• Hard (-6): Advanced reactions, forces, and
equations and mechanics; simple engineering;
• Very Hard (-9): Advanced engineering;
• Heroic (-12): Interaction with the supernatural
or Wyrd materials;
• Legendary (-15): Advanced engineering using
forces not yet discovered;
• Mythic (-20): Primeval technologies.

Sprinting
This will use the Athletics skill.
• Standard (+0): Sprinting on a level surface;
• Challenging (-3): Sprinting on rough grass or
sand;
• Hard (-6): Sprinting across rough (arduous)
terrain;
• Very Hard (-9): Sprinting up stairs or an incline/
decline of up to 30 degrees;
• Heroic (-12): Springing on an incline/decline of
31-60 degrees;
• Legendary (-15): Sprinting up a ladder, or across
a slippery surface;
• Mythic (-20): Sprinting across an extremely
slippery surface such as wet ice.
Stealth
• Standard (+0): Moving without being heard on a
hard, flat surface;
• Challenging (-3): Pilfering a small object from
the pockets of a target;
• Hard (-6): Hiding behind a window curtain in a
lit environment;
• Very Hard (-9): Moving silently across fallen
leaves or snow;
• Heroic (-12): Blending in a crowd of members of
a different Kin;
• Legendary (-15): Stealing a medium-sized object
(like a weapon or a book) carried by another creature;
• Mythic (-20): Hiding in plain sight.
Swimming
This will use the Athletics skill.
• Standard (+0): Swimming in slight current;
• Challenging (-3): Swimming against the tide, or
just below the surface;
• Hard (-6): Swimming against the current, or in
small waves;
• Very Hard (-9): Swimming in water with a strong
under-current, or more than 3m below the surface;
• Heroic (-12): Swimming in large waves;
• Legendary (-15): Swimming in huge waves or a
storm;
• Mythic (-20): Swimming against strong rapids,
whirlpools, or waterfalls.

202

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Tracking
This would use the Nature skill or Perception skill at a -2.
• Standard (+0): Large animal; large numbers;
favorable ground;
• Challenging (-3): Single animal or target;
vegetation in the area (or other sources of clues);
• Hard (-6): Solid ground such as stone;
• Very Hard (-9): Heavy rainfall since the tracks were
made; environment with lots of different footfall;
• Heroic (-12): Shifting ground such as sand dunes;
high winds;
• Legendary (-15): Through running (shallow)
water; a very busy thoroughfare;
• Mythic (-20): Heavy snowfall.
Trickery
• Standard (+0): Open pouch or bag, palming a
tiny object about own person;
• Challenging (-3): Hiding a small object (Hand
weapon); simple card or dice trick;
• Hard (-6): Inner pocket;
• Very Hard (-9): Hiding a larger object (Short
weapon). Complex card trick;
• Heroic (-12): Secured, locked, or hidden pocket
pouch or bag. Hiding a larger object (Long weapon);
• Legendary (-15): Stealing something affixed to a
target such as the shirt off their back;
• Mythic (-20): Stealing an opponent’s weapon in
combat.
Tumbling
This would use the Acrobatics skill or the Athletics skill at a -2.
• Standard (+0): Just a series of gymnastic rolls and
flips; recovering from the Prone Condition;
• Challenging (-3): Vaulting over a single obstacle;
• Hard (-6): Tumbling over Rough terrain;
• Very Hard (-9): Vaulting over a series of obstacles;
• Heroic (-12): Tumbling over Arduous terrain;
• Legendary (-15): Vaulting off walls (or other
structures) to avoid touching the ground (for the
entire move);
• Mythic (-20): Tumbling up or down a vertical
surface (for the entire move).

Wandering
• Standard (+0): Finding the way through a lightly
forested area;
• Challenging (-3): Traversing a dangerous natural
environment, such as a swamp or a jungle;
• Hard (-6): Traversing a harsh natural environment,
such as a desert or a glacier;
• Very Hard (-9): Finding the way through the
woods on a clear night;
• Heroic (-12): Finding shelter from a storm on
open ground;
• Legendary (-15): Traversing an actively hostile
environment, such as a Blighted Land or Darkland;
• Mythic (-20): Finding the way in complete
darkness through rough terrain.

Occupational Hazards

Adventurers face many dangers when they go exploring
ruins, chasing after bad guys, or generally just having a good
time. In this section we will cover some of those dangers
and provide you, the GM, with some guidelines on how to
handle them.

Falling Damage

Adventurers are sometimes clumsy folk. They occasionally
fall or get pushed off things such as ladders, walls, ropes, or
even cliffs. When a character falls, he is going to get hurt.
To resolve a fall that is not caused by a trap, the GM
should roll 1d10 points of damage for every 10 feet fallen,
up to a maximum of 15 dice of damage. This damage is not
reduced by armor.
Every 2 dice of damage from falling also gives the fall one
Success Level (SL) to be used for Critical Damage from the
Combat Boons table.
If the character has the Acrobatics skill, he may make a skill
roll (10’ fall is Easy, 20’ fall is Normal, 30’ fall is Challenging,
etc.). A successful Acrobatics roll reduces the fall 10’ plus
another 10’ reduction for every Success Level gained. If all
of the damage dice are removed in this manner, then the
character lands safely.

Foraging

Characters can hunt and forage for food while traveling
instead of consuming rations. A successful Hunting or
Nature skill roll provides enough food and water to sustain
a party of travelers for one day, provided that the area they’re
crossing is capable of sustaining life.
Foraging and hunting takes time: characters gathering
food will move at half their speed for the day (characters
foraging while Pathfinding (p. 211) will move at one
quarter their normal speed).

203

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Extreme Temperatures

Adventuring characters will often travel to areas where
they are exposed to extremes of temperature. These extreme
temperatures can be as deadly as the most ferocious monster.
Should a character receive a -5 or larger modifier from
either Heat or Cold, they will become Weary (p. 129), as
per the Condition.
Heat
When operating in temperatures above 90 degrees
Fahrenheit (32 degrees Celsius) a character must make
a Toughness Save every hour or receive a cumulative -1
modifier to all Actions, excluding Saves. If the temperature
is above 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius), the
Save must be made every 10 minutes.
The modifiers will remain until the character can cool off
by locating shade, immersing himself in water, or waiting
until night falls. These modifiers will be reduced by 1 for
each hour spent in the cool and resting.
If the character is wearing heavy clothes or armor, the
Save will have modifier of -2 for each step of armor worn
(i.e. quilted/soft leather is -2, boiled/reinforced leather is -4,
chain is -6, scale is -8, and plate is -10).
If the temperature is above 130 degrees Fahrenheit (54
degrees Celsius), the character will take 1d10 points of
heat damage for every failed Save as well. If the character
is wearing metal armor, it will be 2d10 hits of heat damage.
Note: Proper attire, such as loose robes and head
coverings, will offer a bonus to the Save. See the
Armor Quality of Heat for more information.

Cold
Hypothermia and freezing to death are two of the main
hazards when dealing with extreme cold.
When operating in temperatures below 40 degrees
Fahrenheit (4 degrees Celsius) a character must make
a Toughness Save every hour or receive a cumulative -1
modifier to all Actions, excluding Saves. If the temperature
is below 0 degrees Fahrenheit (-18 degrees Celsius), the Save
must be made every 10 minutes.
These modifiers can only be reduced by the character
finding a place of warmth in which he can warm up. The
modifiers will be reduced by -1 for every 10 minutes spent
enjoying the warmth. Should a character reach a modifier
of -20, he will need to make another Toughness Save at -5 or
he will fall asleep and freeze to death in a number of hours
equal to 1d10 plus his Stamina Stat.
Note: Proper attire, such as furs and robes and
head coverings, will offer a bonus to the Save. See
the Armor Quality of Cold for more information.

Handling Traps

At some point or another, players are going to go
adventuring and run into a trap of some sort. These
guidelines will help you, as the GM, be able to resolve them
in a consistent manner. A Trap has 3 main attributes: its
difficulty to detect, its difficulty to disarm and its attack
(usually an AB-based attack or a poison attack).
Detecting (Searching for) Traps
Rather than give standard Difficulty Levels for traps, we
provide a specific modifier. We do this because the Difficulty
Levels are generic modifiers, and this allows us to have a
greater variety in the general difficulty overall. The Difficulty
modifier given for detecting a trap presumes that the
character is actively searching for one. If a character is not
specifically searching for a trap, then the modifier should be
doubled, or given a -4 modifier, whichever is larger. Thus, a
trap that is listed as having a -3 to detect will be -7 to detect
it if the player isn’t actively looking for traps.

Disarming Traps
A trap’s description will also give the Difficulty modifier
for disarming it. The difficulty of disarming the trap will
take into account the location of the mechanisms of the trap
in relation to its trigger and what is involved in disarming it.
Triggering Traps
If a character triggers a trap, whether by accident or on
purpose, then use the following procedure to resolve it:
Roll Initiative: The trap gets a straight 2d10 while the
character gets all normal modifiers. If the character
was unaware of the trap when he triggered it, he
receives a modifier to his initiative for being Surprised.
If the character wins initiative, this means that he
has glimpsed something and can make a Reflex Save to
avoid the effects of the trap. Treat the AB of trap as the
level that the character has to Save against.
If he fails the Save, then the effect of the attack takes
place according to its description. Depending upon
the nature of the trap and the action declared, the trap
could miss (i.e. dodging an arrow trap) or the action
could have no effect (i.e. dodging inside a gas cloud).
If the trap wins the initiative, then it is triggered and
takes effect according to its description. The character
would not receive a Reflex Save to avoid it.
The notation for describing traps is as follows:
Trap Name: S[Search]/D[Disarm]; AB# Type of Attack
(Base Damage); Additional Description/Notes

204

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Sample Traps
The following samples are just a small selection of the
possibilities. Variations also exist, some being easier to detect
and/or disarm, some being harder. The Attack Bonus of a given
trap may also vary, depending upon how well it is constructed.
Arrow Trap: S -3/D -6; +15 Arrow/Bolt (10p); Triggering
the trap fires an arrow or crossbow bolt at the target.
Blade Trap: S -6/D -4; +24 Large Blade (15s); A large
scything blade springs out of a hidden recess to strike
the target.
Dart Storm (10’R): S -1/D -10; +10 Darts (6p); Each
person within the radius takes 2d10 dart attacks. For
each dart attacking a person, add +1 to the AB and +1
to the amount of damage done. These darts are often
coated in poison, increase the level of any Saves against
the poison by 1 for each dart that hits a target.
Example: Tyln sets off the Dart Storm trap and fails
his initiative roll, so he does not receive a Save to avoid
it. The GM rolls 2d10, resulting in 8 darts against
Tyln, so Tyln receives a +18 (base of +10, plus 8 darts)
attack that has a Damage Rating of 14p (6p + 8) if it
hits him. And this does not even take into account the
chance of the darts being coated in poison.
Pit Trap (20’): S -5/D -10; +20 Fall (10b); A mechanism
drops the floor out from under character(s). It is usually
spring loaded to snap back into place. Sometimes, such
traps also have spikes setup on their floors.

Landslides/Cave-ins

One of the hazards of adventuring is falling objects, such as
from landslides and cave-ins. Depending upon the size of the
falling objects and the area that they cover, and how close the
character is to the edge, the GM may allow for a Reflex Save
or an Acrobatics roll for the character to attempt to escape
the danger zone. Attempts to escape should be handled like
attempting to escape the effects of a Ball spell (p. 135).
If the character is unable to escape, then he will likely take
damage from things falling on him.
A landslide or avalanche is often very deadly. Anybody
caught in the middle will take a +30 attack that has a Damage
Rating 15b for each round for the duration of the landslide
(normally 2-10 rounds - roll 2d10, divide by 2).
A cave-in is like a landslide, but it is usually confined to a
much smaller, enclosed area and it often does not last nearly
as long as a landslide can. Cave-ins will last for 1-5 rounds
(roll 1d10, divide by 2, round up), and they have an attack
bonus of +20. The Damage Rating for a cave-in is 15b per
round, the same as a landslide.
It is possible for there to be variations to both these events.
Some might be smaller and/or lighter while others might
be longer, larger and/or be more damaging. The above rules
represent the average cave-in and landslide.
Characters who survive damage received from a landslide
or cave-in are Weary (p. 129), as per the Condition.

Light & Vision

Adventures take place in many different settings; and
lighting, or the lack of it, can play a key role in how the
adventure plays out.
Visibility Conditions
Fog, darkness, or other environmental conditions like
heavy rain can hinder a character’s vision and prove a
serious obstacle to adventuring. Lighting conditions in
Fantasy Express are divided into three categories: Bright
Light, Dim Light, and, Total Darkness.
• Bright Light: This describes Well Lit areas, such as
those bathed in sunlight, or illuminated by torches,
lanterns, or bonfires. Characters can usually see and
act normally under this lightning condition.
• Dim Light: This describes shadowy and feebly
illuminated areas, like a field in the moonlight, most
city streets at night, or a cavern lit by a single candle.
Characters in Dim Light suffer a -4 penalty to their
Perception and Wandering Rolls and must halve
their Move Rate while traveling. If in an enclosed
place, a Well Lit area will be surrounded by a Dimly
Lit are equal to half of the distance of the Well Lit
area (i.e. a torch lighting a 20’ radius will consider
the 20’ radius as Well Lit, and then another 10’ radius
beyond that as Dimly Lit).
• Total Darkness: describes areas completely obscured by
shadows or covered in darkness. Normally, characters
in this lighting condition cannot see at all. Darkness is
treated as an additional Hazard while traveling.
Fog, mist, and heavy rain can be treated as Dim Light in
regards to the rules, while blizzards, whiteouts, and similarly
severe weather conditions can impair a character’s sight as
much as Total Darkness.
Characters will generally have one of four separate types
of vision: Normal Sight, Night Sight, Star Sight, and Dark
Sight. Each provides a character with the unique capability
to see in environments where illumination is insufficient.
Normal Sight: With normal vision, characters can see
clearly during the day. On a starlit night, a character can
see up to 30’ clearly. With nothing more than the ambient
light of a full moon, the character can see up to 150’. In
an interior setting, using artificial illumination (such as
a torch or lantern), a character can see clearly within the
limits of the lighting, and is able to see dimly out to an
additional distance equal to one half of the illuminated
radius, but not beyond that distance.
Night Sight: With Night Sight, characters can see in natural
moonlight or starlight as if they were seeing during a
cloudy day. In Dim Light, they can see up to a maximum
100’ while treating the first 50’ of that distance as if it were
Well Lit. For artificial light sources in enclosed spaces, the
character can see double the normal distance as if Well
Lit. For example, a torch provides a 20’ radius of light
normally, for a person with Night Sight, they can see 40’
as if Well Lit.

205

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Star Sight: This is similar to Night Sight, except that the
character can see as if it were a cloudy day in moon
light. In star light, and in Dim Light, they can see up
to a maximum of 50’ while treating the first 20’ of that
distance as if it were Well Lit. For artificial light sources
in enclosed spaces, the character can see one and a half
times the normal distance as if Well Lit. For example, a
torch provides a 20’ radius of light normally, for a person
with Star Sight, they can see 30’ as if Well Lit.
Dark Sight: With Dark Sight, the character can see in moon
light as if it were Well Lit. In star light or in a Dimly Lit
area, they can see out to 75’ and treat the first 30’ of that
as if it were Well Lit. They can also see up to 10’ in Total
Darkness. For artificial light sources in enclosed spaces,
the character can see double the normal distance, plus 10’
as if Well Lit. For example, a torch provides a 20’ radius
of light normally, for a person with Dark Sight, they can
see 50’ as if Well Lit.

Light Sources
The number of light sources available in a fantasy game
can range widely from simple torches to several spells. Each
light source, however, illuminates a certain radius.
The following list offers a few examples of light sources
for easy reference:

Starvation & Thirst

In a moderate climate, a character will require the
equivalent of approximately 1 gallon of water and 1 pound of
food per day. These measures constitute one “ration” of each.
If the character does not meet those requirements, he will
deteriorate and eventually die. Characters in an extremely hot
climate will require an extra ration of water each day, while those
in an extremely cold climate require an extra ration of food.
Characters who receive modifiers of -10 or larger from
starvation or thirst will become Weary (p. 129), as per the
Condition.
Starvation: A character can survive for about a month
without food. For each daily ration that is missed, the
character will receive a -1 modifier. When the character
reaches -20 he will no longer be able to feed himself, and
when he reaches -30, he will die.
Thirst: Dying of thirst is faster than dying of starvation. Each
day without a ration of water will result in the character
receiving a -3 modifier. As with Starvation, at -20, he will be
helpless and when he reaches -30, he will die.

Half-rations: If a character, who has received modifiers for
either starvation or thirst or both, is able to consume at
least half of a normal ration, he will not deteriorate any
further, but he will not get better either.
Recovery: The only way to remove the modifiers from
starvation and thirst is by eating and drinking. Healing
magic will not work. Each day that the character
consumes a normal ration of food, the negative modifier
for starvation is reduced by 1 and if he consumes a
normal ration of water as well, the negative modifier for
thirst will be reduced by 3.

Watery Hazards

While rivers and lakes have always been important
avenues of travel, they can be both a nuisance and hazard
for characters that must somehow cross them.
A character may freely wade through still or slowly
moving water that is not above his head at a rate of 10’ per
round without being required to make a roll. If the water
is fast-moving, or the ground under the water is especially
slick, the GM may require a Reflexes Save for a character to
be able to keep his feet.
Swimming: If the water is above the head of the character, he
will have to swim. Swimming will require an Athletics roll
(see p. 202 for example Difficulty levels). The penalties for
armor and encumbrance are tripled when swimming.
Drowning: A character is able to hold his breath for 25
rounds plus a number of rounds equal to his Stamina. Once
this time has expired, the character must begin making
Toughness Saves against his own level each round. Should
the character fail one roll, he immediately falls unconscious
and will die in 1d10 rounds. Should the character be saved,
he will be Weary (p. 129), as per the Condition.
Quicksand: Quicksand can appear in any location where
sand and water mix. Shallow quicksand is a nuisance
and can be escaped easily, but deep pits of quicksand
are more problematic. Attempting to float and/or “dog
paddle” towards the edge of a quicksand pool will be at
least a Hard Athletics roll.
If the character panics or even just flails about, they
will sink at a rate of 5” inches per round if they are
unarmored. Increase the rate of sinking by 2 inches for
every -1 modifier from armor and encumbrance. Also,
once a character sinks below the surface, he will drown
as described above.
Pulling oneself or another out of quicksand requires a
Hard Athletics roll at the very least.

206

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Weather

Cool: This encompasses temperatures from the high 40s
up to about 65 degrees Fahrenheit. Those out in this
weather would want to make sure that they had things
like jackets, but sufficient exercise and movement would
also keep individuals warm enough.

While we have already covered how to deal with extremes
of temperatures, our goal in this section is to provide the
GM with some guidelines on determining the weather in
his campaign setting. These guidelines do presume that the
characters are within Cool Temperate zone, such as is found
in much of Europe, which most fantasy settings emulate.

Warm: From the high 60s on up to about 90 degrees
Fahrenheit. Individuals would wear a wide variety
of clothing, based on their station, but no special
requirements would be needed.
Hot: Temperatures above 90 degrees Fahrenheit would
be considered hot. When it gets up this high, the
character must contend with the effects of Extreme
Heat (p. 204).

Generating Weather

We have two primary methods of generating weather that
can be used.
The first is to simply roll 2d10 each day and look up the results
on the Weather Generation table under the correct Season.
The second is a bit more involved. For it, you make an initial
roll of 2d10 and put a marker of some sort Daily Shift
on the result under the correct Season. Then
1
-1
each day, you make a roll on the Daily Shift
2-7
0
table to determine how many rows to move
8-9
+1
the marker up (-) or down (+).
10
+2
Should you happen to reach either end of
the column for the Season, just wrap around to the other end of
the column and keep on going.
When the Season changes in your Setting, you simply move
columns to the correct Season, starting on the same row you
were on as before.

Cloud Cover

The upper right corner of each square on the Weather
Generation table provides an image showing how much
Cloud Cover there is. Cloud Cover falls into 3 main
categories as detailed below:
Clear
: When you get this result, it means that there
are few to no clouds in the sky. By few, we mean that,
at most, clouds cover up to 10% of the sky. There is
no chance of precipitation in a Clear sky.
Cloudy
: If you get this result, you should roll another
1d10, and that result tells you how much of the sky
the clouds cover, from 10% to 100%.
Overcast
: This cloud cover rating is special. It
represents 100% cloud cover, but the clouds are so
thick and dark that undead who are susceptible to
sunlight may actually move about during the day.

Reading the Table

Each square on the Weather Generation table is comprised
of 4 sections. We will go over each section in more detail.

Temperature
Since most fantasy settings do not have an accurate
method of determining the temperature, we are sticking to
5 generalizations.
The daily temperature is listed in the upper left corner of
each square on the table. If two are listed, the second will be
in parenthesis (), and it refers to the temperature at night,
while the first refers to just the day. If only one is listed, then
that is the temperature for both the day and the night.
Frigid: Anything below the freezing point of water is
considered to be frigid. When out in this type of
weather for any extended period, characters would be
subject to the rules for Extreme Cold (p. 204).

Wind

Wind can have an impact on everything around it. As
such, we provide you, in the lower left corner of each square,
two pieces of information about the wind. The first is the
direction from which the wind is blowing. The second is the
Wind Factor.
This is a rating from 0 to 5 that allows you to easily
determine how powerful the wind it. As you can see on the
Wind Factor table, we provide a description for the wind,
and then the speed of the wind in Miles Per Hour (MPH)
for each category. Winds typically will fluctuate between the
two extremes given.
Then finally, we provide the Random column, in case you
want to generate the actual wind speed.

Cold: This temperature rating encompasses temperatures
from about 10 to 15 degrees Fahrenheit above the
freezing point of water on down to the freezing
point of water. As above, characters out in this type
of weather for extended periods of time would be
subject to the effects of Extreme Cold, but not as
quickly as if it were Frigid.

Precipitation

The Weather Generation table, in the bottom right corner
of the square, lists the type of precipitation that is possible for
a given day. If there is no image listed there, that means that
there is no precipitation for the given day. If there is an image,
that will tell you the type of precipitation that can be expected.
Drizzle
: This is very slight rain or heavy misting,
resulting in approximately a quarter of inch of rain
per hour. The drizzle can last for up to 10-12 hours.
Drizzles usually have a Wind Factor of 0 or 1.
Fog, (Light
or Heavy
): Fog is a cloud that touches
the ground. Light fog is thin and limits visibility
to about half what it would normally be, out to a
maximum distance of about 100’. Heavy fog is much
thicker and limits visibility to about a quarter of
normal, out to a maximum distance of about 30’. Fog
usually has a Wind Factor of 0 or 1, or else the wind
will blow it away fairly quickly. Fog is usually found
in the early mornings or early evenings into the night,
and burns away quickly during the day when there is
no cloud cover, but on overcast days, fog could easily
last all day long.
Hailstorm
: Hail forms in Cool or Warm weather
usually. It is created as water droplet freeze and then
are pushed back up into the clouds by winds over and
over, until you eventually have icy stones falling from
the sky. Hailstorms are also Thunderstorms for the
purpose of describing them.
Hurricane
: Hurricanes are massive rain storms with
winds up in the Wind Force 5 range. Hurricanes
are extremely destructive and the high winds can
do massive amounts of damage. Hurricanes always
form out at sea and move inland and along coastal
regions, with the eye of the hurricane never travelling
more than 100 to 200 miles from the coast. However,
hurricanes tend to be anywhere from 100 to 600 miles
wide, although some have been reported up to 1,000
miles wide. The larger the hurricane, the longer it will
last. A good rule of thumb is to have it last 1.5 days for
every 50 miles of width that it has.

208

or Heavy
): Rain drops are larger
Rain, (Light
and more numerous than the drops found in a
drizzle. Light rain can result in up to a potential 1-2
inches of rain each hour. Heavy rain often results in
3-5 inches of rain per hour. Rain storms often last
from 3 to 12 hours (1d10 + 2) and are accompanied
by winds with a Wind Factor of 1 or 2 normally, but
some could have Wind Factor as low as 0, while severe
storms could have a Wind Factor as high as a 3 or
more rarely, even a 4. Rain can sometimes have some
lightning and thunder, but not much.
Sleetstorm
: Sleet is formed by snow passing through
a warm layer of air and melting and then refreezing
again before it hits the ground. It happens only
during colder weather. Treat it as rain for how much
sleet might be falling. On unprotected skin, it can feel
like being hit by icy needles.
Snow, (Light
or Heavy
): Treat snow the same
as you would rain. The same amounts falling per
hour and the same number of hours, and the same
Wind Factors involved. The main difference is that it
falls in frozen flakes rather than liquid drops. Snow
only occurs in cold areas or higher elevations. If the
temperature is above freezing, it can still snow, but
the snow will quickly melt after it lands unless the
ground is already frozen from previous cold snaps.
Snowstorm
: A snowstorm or blizzard is just like heavy
snow, except that it usually dumps about twice as
much snow within the same period of time. Visibility
during a snowstorm is usually only 20 to 30 feet at
most, and may be even less if it comes with a higher
Wind Factor.
Thunderstorm
: A thunderstorm would be just like
a heavy rain (listed above), except with a lot more
thunder and lightning. Thunderstorms usually last
up to a maximum of about 6 hours, often bracketed
by rain storms on either side. Lightning will strike
during a thunderstorm a minimum of once every
10 minutes. However, more severe storms can have
lightning striking even more frequently.

Knowledge Tiers

Preparing for Travel

Among the skills that a player may have his character
learn are a number of Lores or other knowledge related
skills or skills that also encompass knowledge in some form
or another. Many of the Lore skills allow the player to define
the focus of his knowledge, allowing it to be broadly based
or more focused overall.
The Knowledge Tiers table can be used to give the GM an
idea of the sorts or level of knowledge that could be known
based upon the number of skill ranks that the character
has in the appropriate skill. The skill ranks known often
correspond along for determining levels of mastery for craft
skills as well.
If the character has a broad field of knowledge, and is
attempting to provide information on a specific instance of
the topic (i.e. information on a specific Demon when the
Lore skill is for Infernal Creatures), he should be treated as
being one level lower than he actually is.

Title
Initiate

Travel Hazards

It is a dangerous world, and a good part of that danger
happen just trying to get from one place to another. The
purpose of this section is to provide some guidance on how
to handle travel and the hazards that could happen.
Unless the party has some sort of encounter, the GM
should usually just summarize their travel in a few sentences.
If the GM wants to heighten tension a little bit, he could
break down his description into shorter blocks of time, and
ask for things like a watch list, to see who is standing guard
and when, and get the occasional Perception roll. But he
would not want to do this for every single night, or too often
overall, as it could slow down the pace of the game cause
players to lose interest.
The overall idea is to make things exciting for the players,
not tedious.

Before the actual journey can start, the players will have
to set a destination for their characters, and choose the path
they’ll follow to reach it. If a general map of the area the
heroes are about to cross is present, the GM can show it to
the players, quickly pointing out its main features and routes
leading to their destination.
If you don’t have a map, the GM can simply describe the lay
of the land the characters will travel through, with its dangers
and points of interest, presenting the players at least two
different paths their heroes could follow to their destination.
During this phase, the players can ask a few questions of
the GM, to better prepare themselves for the journey ahead.
The GM must answer fairly, but could require a Skill Roll if
the answer isn’t common knowledge. Don’t get bogged down
too much in this planning phase, though. The characters
should be heroes, not tour operators!
Example: The PCs are traveling to the Dragon
Mountain, to free their ancestral home from the
ancient evil that claimed it. Since they have no
map of the region that they will be travelling
through, the Darkwood, the GM briefly describes
the land and choices before them: “The journey
to the Dragon Mountain isn’t exactly going to be
a stroll in the park. You’ll have to cross a large
stretch of untamed wilderness, far from any sign of
civilization. The quickest route to the Mountains
is probably through the Darkwood, which lies
exactly between you and your destination. The
way through the Darkwood, however, is dangerous
and difficult. It is common knowledge that it
would be easy to lose one’s way inside the forest,
and food and water may be hard to find in there.
Or you could travel north, going around the woods
and through the Blasted Heath, where it will also
be hard to food and water. That way is probably
safer, but it’s going to take more time. Conversely,
you could also circle the Darkwood to the south,
where the lands are gentler and it will be easier to
find supplies, but that will take you at least twice
as long as going around to the north.”
Once the characters know their options, then they can
make their choices.

210

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Calculating Travel Time

Once the path is set, the GM establishes the time required
to travel to the chosen location, using the Overland
Movement table below. The distance covered each day is
influenced by the character’s Encumbrance Level and by the
type of Terrain crossed.
Roads, open plains, light forests, and similar areas, where
characters can advance and travel easily, are considered to
be Normal Terrain.
Heavy woods, forested areas, deserts, hills, and others
areas where advancement is slowed down by rugged ground
or small obstacles, are considered Rough Terrain.
Lastly, mountains, bogs, swamps, jungles, thick forests,
underground passages, and other hard to cross areas are
considered Arduous Terrain.
Groups usually travel at the speed of their slowest
member, unless they’re actively trying to leave them behind!
Example (continued): The players have decided to
cross the Darkwood, which is a forested region and
thus counts as Rough Terrain. They’re bringing
(Heavily Encumbered) ponies loaded with water,
rations, and equipment for the journey, so their
traveling speed is approximately 10 miles per day.
The Darkwood is about 200 miles wide, which means
it will take more or less 3 weeks (20 days) for them to
cross it. For each day of travel, each character must
consume a ration or suffer the effects of weariness, as
detailed in the Starvation & Thirst section.

Camping

Characters are assumed to camp and rest regularly while
they travel. They will normally spend an hour each morning
and evening either breaking or preparing to camp. This time
also includes other such standard activities as reviewing
their spellbooks, maintaining weapons and armor, cooking
meals, and so forth.
Normally this is part of their routine, so there’s no need to
roll or pay particular attention to what they do when resting.
However, on some occasions, they’ll need to find a safe
spot to recover from their injuries and conditions or perhaps
to hide from their foes. Travelers in dire need may try to set
up a long-term camp in the middle of the wilderness. This
solution is usually avoided, save for desperate situations, as
camps like these tend to attract unwelcome attention and
rarely stay safe for long.

Once the characters have decided to set up a camp, one
of them must take the lead, finding a safe and defensible
camping spot and guiding the group to it. The others should
describe how they are preparing, and what precautions they
are taking to ensure the safety of their camp.
The leading character must make a Wandering or Nature skill
roll with a Difficulty based on the size of the group, the type of
terrain chosen, and the general danger level of the area. Other
heroes making themselves useful are considered to be Helping.
If no character is Helping the leading character with the camp
preparations, this roll suffers an additional -4 penalty.
If this roll succeeds, the party can safely rest for one day
in their camp, but will have to make a new Wandering skill
roll the next day.
A Partial Success means that the heroes will be able to
rest, but will also be plagued by some minor complication,
possibly taxing their resources or slowing them down.
For example, they could find that some of their rations
have rotted away; or that one of their pack beasts was injured
during travel.
In case of a Failure, their rest will definitely be interrupted.
Another option, instead of Camping, is that the characters
could attempt to reach a Safe Haven (p. 214) if they know
of one.

Pathfinding

If the location of their destination is uncertain, or if the
characters are lost and thus not sure of their own position,
they’ll have to proceed at a slower pace, exploring their
surroundings in search of clues and landmarks. This is
called Pathfinding.
While Pathfinding, the characters move at half their
normal speed for the day. Additionally, they must make a
Wandering skill roll each time they attempt to cross a new
type of Terrain (for example, when they first enter a forest
after traveling through a grassland), to avoid losing their way.
Finding a hidden or unknown destination is a Hazard,
which is added to those the heroes are already facing
during their journey (see the following section for more
information on Hazards).

Hazards

After calculating the length of their trip, the GM must
determine the Hazards that the heroes will face during their
travel. Hazards represent challenges, obstacles, or encounters
the characters will have to overcome (or avoid) to reach their
destination. The number and nature of the Hazards encountered
depends on the length of the journey and on the notable locations
and regions the characters will travel through.
Heroes will usually encounter one hazard per week of
travel (or portion thereof), plus one for each notable location
or obstacle (mountain range, marshy area, large river, etc) in
their way. This means that characters will usually face 2-3
Hazards during a medium-length journey.
If you come up with more than 6 Hazards, consider
breaking the journey down into multiple shorter steps, as it
will probably take more than one gaming session to resolve.
Hazards are divided into several broad categories
(described in length later in this section), according to the
type of obstacle they represent. The GM should try to pick
each Hazard from a different category to give the characters
a greater variety of challenges to overcome.
Once the GM has chosen the Hazards, he must announce
those that are evident or otherwise known to the characters
(for example, a difficult mountain pass they have to cross),
keeping the rest secret until they’re revealed.
Example (continued): The trek through the
Darkwood takes three weeks, so the characters will
have to face at least three Hazards. Additionally,
the Darkwood is home to the palace of the High
King of the Grey Elves, which is definitely a notable
location and thus brings the total of the Hazards
encountered to four.
Looking at the Hazard categories, the GM chooses
Natural Obstacle, Free People, Perils from
the Ancient World, and Wild Beasts. He then
announces the first two, since their characters
are very likely to be aware of them: “As I’ve said,
navigating through the Darkwood isn’t going
to be easy. You’ll have to be very careful to avoid
losing your way (Natural Obstacle). Also, keep in
mind that the region within the wood is the reign
of the Grey Elves. They aren’t necessarily hostile,
but they’re wary of strangers and may question or
even detain you, should they catch you crossing
their domains without permission (Free People)”.
The GM keeps the Wild Beasts (Giant Spiders,
that have recently made their nest in the deepest
recesses of the wood) and the Perils from the
Ancient World (ghost lights and will-o’-thewisps, that mark the sites of an ancient battle and
could lead the travelers astray) for himself. The
characters couldn’t possibly know about them, so
they will be revealed when the heroes meet them.
At this point, the characters are committed and the
journey may begin.

Resolving Hazards
Each Hazard is resolved as a separate scene. The GM
zooms in, describes the obstacle, and the PCs face it as they
deem appropriate. Note that the GM should never suggest
(or force) a single solution to a Hazard, but rather present
the situation fairly and leave the characters decide their
course of action.
If they’re successful, the characters will forge ahead,
carrying on with their journey and proceeding to the next
Hazard, until they’ve reached their destination.
A Failure or Partial Success, on the other hand, means a
setback, and generally more trouble for the characters.
The GM should come up with appropriate consequences
based on the Hazard itself, on the degree of failure, and on
the PCs’ decisions and actions.
On a Partial Success, the GM can impose a Condition, a
Minor Injury (see Health & Healing section, p. 215), or a loss
of time or resources on the party. For example, the characters
could become Weary after a long, exhausting march, they could
be forced to take a detour (lengthening their trip by a few days
and thus consuming more rations) to avoid enemy patrols, or
one of them could fall and sprain their ankle (suffering a Minor
Injury and taking a -4 penalty to their Rolls) while trying to
cross a treacherous ford.
On a Failure, the GM can present a brand new Hazard, that
the characters must face immediately. For example, the heroes
could be ambushed or cornered by the enemies they were
trying to avoid. Or they could find their way shut, and forced
to take a different, darker, and more dangerous path to reach
their destination.
This means that each Hazard could potentially become
an adventure in itself, as the heroes could decide or be
forced to deviate from their original itinerary, stop to
resolve a particular problem, or take their time to investigate
something on their way.
Example (continued): Our heroes are finally
crossing the Darkwood, hacking their way through
the forest. The GM brings the first Hazard into play
and asks the party for a Wandering roll to navigate
the treacherous path across the wood. Madoc, the
PC who’s acting as their guide, unfortunately rolls
a Failure. The GM nods and narrates: “You don’t
know when, but at some point you must have taken
a wrong turn, because the path you were following
abruptly stops at the foot of a sheer rock cliff. You’re
at a dead end. Suddenly, a blood-curdling howl
sounds from the woods behind you. Moments later,
a second howl seems to answer the first one, this
time much closer to you. The ponies start stomping
their hooves and roll their eyes, menacing to bolt
away at any moment, carrying your provisions
with them. What do you do?”
After each Hazard, the PCs regroup and decide whether
to push on and proceed to the next step of their journey or
stop to rest and/or resupply.

212

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Hazard Categories

Below you’ll find a few examples of possible Hazards the
heroes may have to face, divided into several different categories.
We obviously couldn’t list all the possible problems characters
could encounter during their travels, but we tried to give the
GMs some ideas on how to generate their own Hazards.
For each category, a brief discussion of which Skills
may be used to face that kind of Hazard, along with a list
of possible complications in case of failure, is given. Keep
in mind that the solutions and Skills listed are in no way
intended to be the only possibilities but rather to give
examples of how they could be solved. In other words, the
GM should always consider the characters’ actions before
deciding which Skill to use.
Note: The GM should always try to match the
difficulty of the Hazard to the abilities of the
characters or make sure that they have some
options to survive the Hazard. This takes practice.
Example (continued): Madoc and his
companions are besieged by wolves in the middle
of the Darkwood, and are beginning to regret
the moment they set foot in this accursed forest.
Deirdre’s player is the first to react, telling the GM:
“I’ll use my magic to speak with the ponies. I want
to reassure them, tell them that we’ll protect them
and that there’s nothing to worry about.”
Madoc then has an idea and says: “I want to scare
these stupid wolves away. Astarise, help me cut
down some wood, we’ll need a big fire!”
Mornien smiles and replies: “Great idea, Madoc!
I’ll use my Ignite spell to light the fire as quickly
as possible.” “I-I think I’ll keep my sling readied,”
says Tobold “in case the fire isn’t enough to scare
the wolves off...”
The GM briefly considers the characters’ actions,
then says: “Ok, Deirdre and Mornien, cast your
spells; Maedoc, make an Athletics Roll to see how
quickly you can gather the wood. Astariste, you may
help him. Tobold, you don’t have to roll anything for
now; you’ve readied your sling, so it will be loaded
in case the wolves end up attacking you.”
The players grab their dice and start rolling...

Ancient Perils
The default setting that Fantasy Express uses, Anwyn,
has many ruins and ancient locations that could fit this
description. Especially in the lands of Ilthach, otherwise
known as the Haunted Steppes, where tombs, crypts,
barrows and many other places of the dead continually
appear and disappear. Nobody knows for sure how many
other civilizations attempted to settle Anwyn before its
current inhabitants.
Thus, the world is full of relics and ruins from the ages past,
which sometimes hide horrible dangers, ready to spring on
the unwary travelers. Haunted ruins or enchanted streams
could lure adventurers who fail to resist their magic to their
doom. A Lore or Arcana skill roll could permit the heroes to
recognize the signs of the dangers lurking before them.
Characters failing to overcome these Hazards may find
themselves pursued by a legendary foe, trapped by mystical
forces, or suffering the effects of a terrible curse.
Dark Minions
Anwyn is home to several different potential Darkmasters,
each with their own servants and spies and other minions
prowling the land. They are often secretive, sowing chaos
when they can, or hunting those who dare defy the will of
their cruel lords.
Perception and Hunting will help the heroes spot ambushes
and other traps set by their enemies. Stealth or Deceive Rolls
will allow the characters to avoid confrontation in some cases,
but other times they’ll have to fight or flee for their lives.
The fate of characters defeated by these evil creatures is
dark indeed. Those who survive are often captured to be
dragged before their masters, tortured, or worse...
Locals
Even among those who do not serve the darkness, not
everyone is friendly. Old grudges separate kin from kin, and fear
makes people suspicious of wandering strangers. Alternatively,
the heroes could meet people in need, begging for their help or
asking them to perform an urgent task of some sort.
Characters may have to resort to Influence or Deceive
rolls to persuade others of their good intentions. In other
situations, the heroes may be saved by a Cultures roll, or
simply by the payment of a toll of some kind.
Complications coming from this category of Hazards
could mean being denied hospitality or even being chased
out of a region. In the worse cases the characters may be
imprisoned or forced to fight.

213

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Natural Obstacles
Steep mountain cliffs, thick forests, fetid swamps, and
scalding deserts are some examples of the natural obstacles
the heroes may have to overcome during their journeys.
Hacking your way through a forest or jungle may require
a Wandering Roll, while crossing obstacles like a chasm
or climbing a treacherous mountain path may call for an
Athletics or Acrobatics Roll.
Failures coming from facing natural obstacles could lead
to injuries, loss of equipment, or being forced to choose a
different trail.
Weather
Bad weather includes heat waves, snow storms,
downpours, heavy fog, strong winds, or any other dramatic
atmospheric event that can negatively affect a journey.
Dealing with the weather may require Nature or
Wandering Rolls, to stay the course despite the adverse
conditions, find shelter, or avoid suffering the consequences
of exposure. For more inrformation on how to determine
the weather, please refer to Weather (p. 207).
Failing to deal successfully with this kind of Hazard can
lead to a long detour or forced rest (and thus the expense
of additional rations), the Weary Condition, becoming
hopelessly lost in the middle of the wilderness, or blindly
walking into an enemy’s ambush.
Wild Beasts
Heroes may have to deal with wolf packs, poisonous
snakes, stampeding herds or swarms of biting insects while
scouting the wilderness.
Encounters with wild beasts may often be avoided with
Nature or Hunting Skill Rolls, but sometimes a fight is
inevitable. Typical complications coming from this type of
Hazard include Injuries, Save Rolls against Poison, and long
and tiring chases.

For this reason, Safe Haves are hidden in secluded or
inaccessible locations, concealed by magic, heavily guarded,
or a combination of all of the above.
Unless the characters already know how to find it (either
because they’ve been there, or because someone can guide
them there), reaching a Safe Haven won’t be easy.
Heroes seeking a Safe Haven should make a Lore skill roll,
with a Difficulty based on the influence of the Darkmaster
in the area. Here are some modifiers:
Free Lands (Hard -6): These are civilized areas whose
inhabitants valiantly oppose the Darkmaster, and
would almost certainly attack his minions on sight.
Wildernesses (Very Hard -9): These are large unclaimed or
uninhabited regions, far from civilization but also free
from the Darkmaster’s influence.
Borderlands (Heroic -12): These are those areas whose
inhabitants neither directly oppose the Darkmaster
nor ally with him; or Free Lands that border with
Darklands or Blighted Lands.
Blighted Lands (Legendary -15): These are areas where
the Darkmaster’s influence is strong and palpable, or
accursed places forever tainted by terrible tragedies and
heinous acts.
Darklands (Mythic -20): These are regions completely under
the control of the Darkmaster and his minions: his
strongholds, fortresses, and the breeding grounds of his
fell army.
Example: A close encounter with a Wraith, one
of the Darkmaster’s most fearsome servants, left
Tobold in quite a bad shape. The poor fellow has
been poisoned by the Wraith’s fell blade, and none
of his companion is skilled enough to help him.
In a desperate attempt to save her friend, Mornien
struggles to recall the location of the nearest Safe
Haven.

Safe Havens

A much better option for characters seeking refuge would
be heading to a Safe Haven.
Safe Havens are a beacon of light in the wilderness, houses
of healing, and bastions against the forces of the Darkmaster.
They are places where the heroes can rest without having to
worry about their enemies, and tend to their wounds with
the help of some of the greatest healers of the land.
Characters resting in a Safe Haven have their recovery
time for Injuries and Conditions cut in half, and will recover
double the normal amount of HPs.
Safe Havens are also a great opportunity for characters
to replace or repair broken pieces of equipment, meet new
friends and allies, research information, or to ask the locals
for guidance on a difficult subject.
Unfortunately, Safe Havens are very rare and usually
difficult to find. The Darkmaster sees them as a threat to His
dominion, and would certainly send his minions to burn
them to the ground, should he ever find them.

The heroes are just across the borders of the Ashen
Lands, an accursed region, devastated by the
Darkmaster’s forces during the Starfall Wars. The
GM rules that the area counts as a Borderland, so
Mornien’s Roll will be Heroic...
A Successful Roll means the character remembers a tale
or legend describing the general location of a Safe Haven
within 1d5 days of the party’s position. The group can then
use the Pathfinding rules to reach it.
A Partial Success counts as a Success, save for the fact
that either the Safe Haven’s inhabitants will be wary of
the characters’ motives, or the heroes will encounter an
additional Hazard on their way.
A Failure means the character got something wrong
and either leads the party to an unforeseen obstacle, or to
the ruins of a haven long fallen in disrepair or under the
influence of Dark forces.

214

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Example (continued): Luckily, Mornien scores a
Success, and she remembers a song about Béla the
Skinchanger, a powerful Druid and fierce enemy
of the Darkmaster, who lives all alone in these
forsaken lands. She rolls 1d5 and gets a result of
3, meaning that a 3-days walk separates the party
from Béla’s abode.
Once found, Safe Havens are marked on the world map
by the GM, and characters will be able to visit them without
having to roll again. Remember that Safe Havens are rare
points of Light standing against a tide of Darkness: no more
than one of them should exist in a given area.

Types of Injuries

Critical Damage, spells, poisons and all other damage
inducing substances and situations will do one or more of 4
specific types of damage.
Hits – This includes the hits from the attack tables, and
any additional hits given by a specific Critical Damage
results, as well as generic damage from other sources,
such as some poisons. If a character receives enough
hit damage to reduce his hits to zero or below, he then
becomes unconscious until such time as his hits are
once again above zero.

Health & Healing

The challenge of adventure brings with it a great risk of
injury or death. This heightens the sense of danger and makes
the rewards of successful adventuring all the more meaningful.
A taste of fright gets the adrenaline flowing. Because of these
risks, we provide guidelines on injuries, healing, and death.

Injuries

The damage that a character can receive falls into two
main categories, Hit Damage and Critical Injuries.
Hit Damage – This represents damage dealt to the character’s
Hit Point total (see p. 109 to determine how to figure
Total Hit Points). The most common cause of this type
of damage is from attack. However, some spells and
poisons may also deal hit damage.
Critical Injuries – Generally, injuries usually occur as a
result of damage from attacks. Players use the Success
Levels from their attack to purchase Critical Damage.
There are a variety of results that can be purchased,
so that no two strikes are ever completely the same.

215

Stuns – Many critical results, as well as some spells, will
either Daze or Stun the character, and together they
are collectively referred to as Stun. The specific effects
can be found on p. 128 (Dazed) or p. 129 (Stun).
The number of Rounds of Stuns that a character has
will automatically decrease by 1 during the Upkeep
phase of each Round, with rounds of Stun being
removed before rounds of Dazed. Should a character
receive a number rounds of Stuns equal to twice his
Stamina stat, he will be knocked unconscious for 1
minute for each round of Stun he has over that limit.
The Stuns may come from multiple sources, and
unconsciousness is checked for during the Upkeep
phase of the Round.
Bleed – This represents large amounts of pain and/or
blood loss, or any other type of continuing damage.
The ends of a broken bone rubbing together could
be considered as Bleeding, just as could the excessive
pain from major burns. It is reflected by the character
losing a specific number of Hit Points during the
Upkeep phase of the Round.
Pain – Critical Results can also include penalties to
all actions (the same Actions that Move Penalties
from Armor affect). In all cases, the penalties are
cumulative, and should a character have a maneuver
penalty of -20 or larger, then he will be unable to
move or act, other than for small motions (such as
dragging an herb from a pouch to his mouth, as a
Full Action). A maneuver penalty larger than -30 will
mean that the character is Incapacitated (p. 129) and
they will remain incapacitated until the penalty is
once again -20 or smaller.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

General Degrees of Injuries

Sometimes it is useful to generically classify how damaged
a character is. This can be helpful for determining what and
how much healing is required to bring the character back to
full health.
In the heat of battle it is sometimes impossible to
determine exactly how injured a comrade or foe might be,
but these classifications can be used to give a rough estimate
(i.e. Joe looks to be moderately wounded; the Kobold is
mortally wounded, etc.), providing that the character
successfully makes an Assessment Roll (a Perception skill roll).
The classification includes all damage that the character has
received up to that point.
There are 5 degrees of injury used. A character can be
said to be wounded to a given degree so long as he meets
any one of the criteria given for a given rating. The degrees
are as follows:
Light – This includes 1-3 points of bleeding or up to -6 in move
penalties, or up to 1/4 of their total Hits in damage. This
could also include such specific injuries as pulled and
strained muscles, minor (1st degree) burns/frostbite and
other similarly minor damage.
Moderate – This includes 4-6 points of bleeding, move
penalties between -6 and -12, or having taken up to 1/2
their Hits in damage. Specific damage for this injury level
could include broken bones, 2nd degree burns/frostbite,
and other damage of a similar severity.
Severe – This includes 7-9 points of bleeding per round,
move penalties between -12 and -18, or taking more
than 1/2, but less than3/4 of their Hits in damage. This
could include such specific damage as shattered bones,
damaged organs, limbs that are made useless for a limited
amount of time, and other similar types of damage.
Dire – This includes bleeding more than 10 hits per round,
move penalties greater than -18, or taking more than 3/4
of their Hits in damage. Specific could include destroyed
organs, severed limbs, destroyed limbs, and other similar
types of damage.
Mortal – This condition basically means that the character
is dying. This should only be used to describe critical
results that include “dead in # rounds” results.
Example: Jeff’s character, Rorg the Mighty, has just
finished a long battle with some goblins. The combined
damage that he took from several attacks made by
the goblins results in Rorg bleeding 4 hits per round
and he is at -14 from a generic wound and a broken
bone. Looking at each aspect of the total damage, Jeff
sees that the -14 puts Rorg into the Severely Wounded
category even though the other aspects of his wounds
are less. This means that when it comes to healing,
Rorg is treated as being Severely Wounded.

Healing

Getting injured takes only a moment. Healing, on the
other hand, can take weeks or even months of time unless
herbs or spells are used. The question is, exactly how long
does it take to heal?

Natural Healing

Out of the 4 types of damage dealt by weapons and spells,
we only need concern ourselves with 3, as stuns always go
away in short amount of time.

Healing Hits
If the character is resting, then for each hour of rest, he
will heal a number of Hits equal to his Stamina stat +1. If,
his Stamina stat is zero or below, treat it as if it were a zero
(i.e. he still heals 1 Hit per hour).
If the character is active, then the number of hits healed
each hour is halved. If the character is unconscious or
sleeping, then the number of hits healed during each hour
is doubled. If a character has been knocked unconscious
through taking too many hits, he will remain unconscious
until his hits are once again above zero.

Healing Bleeding
Bleeding wounds are very dangerous because they will
not stop unless halted by specific action, such as through
the Healing skill or the use of herbs or spells.
A simple bandage or compress will stop up to 1 point
of bleeding, or reduce a larger bleeding wound by 1 point
without requiring a Healing skill roll. A successful Healing
roll and the use of the bandages and compresses can stop
the bleeding of up to 2 points per round, or reduce a larger
bleeding wound by 2 points. A successful Challenging
Healing roll can stop 3 hits of bleeding, or reduce a larger
wound by 3 hits per round. Each additional level of difficulty
above that increases the amount of Bleeding stopped or
reduced by 1 more point. Bleeding above 5 Hits per Round
may require using a tourniquet or cauterizing or sewing the
wound shut. It is up to the GM to determine how detailed he
wants to get into this.
Once Bleeding has been stopped, it will take 8 hours
for this reduction in bleeding to become permanent. The
character will not be able to move at a pace faster than a slow
walk (half Move Rate) or exert himself in any way, such as
in combat, or the bleeding will resume. During this 8 hours,
the character will have a penalty of -2 per point of bleeding
that was stopped. Once the 8 hours is up, the penalty will be
halved (round down), and then gone after another 24 hours.

216

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Healing Specific Wounds/Penalties
All remaining damage is comprised of specific wounds,
often with associated penalties, or generic penalties without
any specific damage associated with them. How specific
the wounds are is determined by how they are described.
For example, a couple of bashing attacks that result in
damage attributed to fractures could have the end result be
a shattered bone if the penalty reached high enough.
In the section on General Degree of Injuries, we used
the various degrees of injury as a way of indicating the
character’s overall health while in combat. We will also use
that to determine how long natural healing, other than for
Hit Points, will take.
Players should make skill roll using their Body skill. They
should then look up this total on the Healing & Recovery
Times table, looking at the column that matches the overall
severity of the character’s wounds. The resulting number is
the number of days that it will take the character to heal
without any assistance.
A successful Healing skill roll can allow the character to add
the Success Levels gained to the Body skill roll as a modifier.
Only one such Healing roll can be used in this manner.

Magical Healing

The chapter on Magic (p. 133), contains a number of
healing spells. Healing from spells is not instantaneous, it
does take time to complete.
Use the Healing & Recovery Times table to determine
how long it takes for natural healing to occur, but read the
number of days as the number of Rounds required instead.
Spells that stop Bleeding or relieve Stuns are the exception,
in that they always take effect immediately.

Herbal Healing

The section on Herbalism (p. 220) gives a number of
specific herbs that may be used to heal various injuries
and wounds. Unless the herb gives a specific reference to
the amount of time it will take to heal something, magical
herbs should be considered to speed healing by changing
the natural recovery time, from the Healing & Recovery
Times table, from days to minutes. Don’t forget to include
the degree of the injury in figuring the recovery time.
In most instances, the initial effects of the herbs will be
felt on the round after the herb is taken/applied.
