Death

Curing Poisons and Diseases

Death normally occurs in one of several ways.
Immediate Death — Certain critical results can cause
characters to die immediately.
Death in # rounds — Certain critical results and/or other
effects (i.e. poisons, spells, etc) can cause damage that
results in “death in # rounds”. If the specific damage
that generated the result of death is not healed prior to
the end of the time frame given, the character will die.
Excessive Hits — If a character’s Hit Point go below zero
by an amount equal to their Kin’s Base Hits plus
double their Stamina stat they will die.
Example: Argorn is a Wood Elf, so has 15 Base Hits, and
he has a Stamina of 2. This means his death threshold on
Hits will be -19 (15 + (2 x 2 Stamina) = 19 below zero)
Therefore, if his Hit Points reach -20 or more, he will die.
Special — There are certain spells or occurrences that may
kill a character.

Soul Departure
Once a character dies, his brain will no longer receive
oxygen, and after 5 minutes, his soul will depart the body
for the afterlife.
Certain spells and herbs may be used to prevent the soul
from leaving the body (i.e. Life Keeping). If one of these
measures is used, and the body is then healed of its damage
before the soul departs, the character is considered to have
been saved. While under the effects of a Life Keeping measure,
the character is considered to be in a coma, unresponsive to
all external stimuli.
Once the soul has left the body, only extremely strong
magic or very potent herbs can bring the character back to
life (i.e. Life Giving).

Poison and Disease

The adventuring life is tough, and characters aren’t
endangered only by the blades of their enemies and evil
spells. Malady and sickness can best even the greatest of
heroes, and the vilest agents of the Darkmaster often use
poison to dispose of their foes.
Poisons and diseases are described individually, each having
its own Effects, Attack Level (against which a Toughness Save
Roll must be made), and form of Transmission.

A Hard (-6) Healing skill roll, and the use of a Healer’s
Kit permit poisoned or diseased characters to make a new
Save Roll to recover. Should this additional Save Roll fail,
the effects of the ailment will persist, but the patient will be
allowed to make a new Save Roll the next day. And so on,
until the character is either dead or healed.
A Partial Success in curing a poison or disease still allows
the patient to make a new Save Roll but inflicts a -2 penalty
on it. Antidotes, Spells and some healing herbs can also be
used to counteract its effects or heal the patient.

Sample Poisons
Deathly Adder Venom
The venom of a poisonous snake, commonly found in
many temperate regions.
Attack Level: 3
Transmission: Wound. Victims must make a Save Roll
when the snake bites them or the first time an enemy
with a sharp venom-coated weapon scores Critical
Damage against them.
Effects: Characters failing their Save Roll become Weary
and Dying in 1d10 minutes.
Deepwood Mandrake
A bitter yellowish-green juice, extracted from the roots
of a plant.
Attack Level: 8
Transmission: Ingestion. The victims must swallow the
Mandrake’s extract for the poison to have effect.
Effects: Those drinking the poison are plagued by intense
hallucinations for 3d10 minutes. During this period,
they suffer a -10 penalty to all their Skill and Attack
Rolls. Whenever they miss a foe or score a Partial
Success, Failure, or Critical Failure, the GM may
make them see, hear, and/or feel something that’s not
there, or make them perceive an object or creature as
something completely different.
Doomspores
Certain rare subterranean fungi emit clouds of poisonous
spores when disturbed. The Dwergars (evil dwarf-like fey) force
their Redcap slaves to harvest these spores, collecting them in
small sealed ceramic pots, which they employ in many of their
devious traps.
Attack Level: 4
Transmission: Inhalation. Anyone breathing the spores
must pass a Toughness Save Roll or suffer their effects.
Effects: Those failing their Save Roll become Stunned
for one Round, then they fall asleep, becoming
Incapacitated for 1d5 hours.
Giant Spider Venom
A potent paralytic venom, produced by some Giant

218

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Spiders to immobilize their prey.
Attack Level: Same as the level of the spider producing it.
Transmission: Wound. Characters who suffer Critical
Damage from the Stinger attack of a Giant Spider must
pass a Toughness Save Roll or be affected by the venom.
Effects: Characters failing the Save Roll become Held for
1d10 minutes. If they fail a Save Roll against another dose
of the same venom before its effects wear off, they become
paralyzed, and thus Incapacitated, for 2d10 minutes.

Sample Diseases
Barrow Rot
A vicious disease that mostly plagues looters and those
who frequenty rob tombs.
Attack Level: 4
Transmission: Direct contact. Characters bitten or
scratched by some undead creatures must pass a
Toughness Save Roll or suffer the effects of the disease.
Sometimes the disease can also be transmitted by
claws of evil creatures that often feast upon the dead,
or by being injured in undead-infested tombs or ruins.
Effects: Creatures suffering from this disease cannot
recover lost Hits, and will take 1d10 damage at the end
of every day, until their condition is healed. Moreover,
as long as they’re sick, all their Injuries take twice as
long to heal.
Bog Fever
Explorers traversing putrid swamps and fetid marshy
areas particularly fear this debilitating fever, which can spell
death even for the most prepared traveler.
Attack Level: 3
Transmission: Airborne. Simply travelling through an
infected area is enough to trigger a Toughness Save Roll.
Effects: Characters contracting the disease become Weary
and cannot remove this condition until they’re healed. At
the end of each day after the first, they must make another
Toughness Save Roll against the disease. If they succeed,
they recover from the Bog Fever. If they fail, they’ll suffer
a -4 Exhaustion penalty to all their Actions, as if they had
gone without eating or drinking. Should this penalty ever
reach the total of -20, the character will die.
Dark Plague
They say that this terrible plague was created centuries
ago by a Darkmaster on the home world of the D’Anui,

during his long war against their empire, centuries before
the Gods brought them to Anwyn. It’s believed to have been
eradicated, but sometimes outbreaks of the deadly disease
occasionally resurface in small, isolated settlements.
Attack Level: 7
Transmission: Contamination. Characters touching a
sick creature or something that has been recently used
or possessed by someone who has the Dark Plague
must pass a Toughness Save Roll or suffer its effects.
Effects: Sick characters become Weary and cannot recover
from this condition or from any of their Injuries until
they’re healed from this disease. At the end of each day,
they must pass a TSR against the disease or become
Incapacitated and Dying in 1d10 days.

Soul Damage

The darkest of magics, and the touch of demons, devils, and
certain undead can scar the characters’ own soul, draining the
life out of them. Heroes who are dealt Soul Damage will suffer
a permanent penalty to their Body skill equal to the amount
of Soul Damage taken. This will effectively lower their Total
Hit Points.
Example: Garnaith Bolg is struck by the life-draining
attack of an undead warrior, which deals 2 points of
Soul Damage to him. The hero will have to apply a
-2 penalty to his Body Skill, thus lowering his Total
Hit Points until the Soul Damage is healed.
The bodies of characters whose Total Hit Points reduced
to zero or less by Soul Damage becomes hollow lifeless
husks. They’re Incapacitated and start Dying in 6 Rounds.
Those who die to Soul Damage rise as undead 1d10
days later, unless proper precautions are taken. The type of
undead is often based on how they died.

Healing Damage to the Soul
Soul Damage cannot be healed by normal means. Only
magic or special herbs can reverse its effects.

219

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Herbalism
There are many different types of herbs. Some are the roots
of a plant, others are the leaves, or the stem, or even the bark
in some cases, and also possibly the fruit of the plant. In fact,
some plants may be the source of two or more different herbs,
with different parts of the plant being used for different things.
Herbalism is, for our purposes, the practice of identifying,
recognizing and using herbs for healing and for other
purposes, including the creation of magical items, such as
Herbal Remedies and Elixirs (see below).
In using these rules, the character will either use a Craft
specialty called Herbcraft, or use their Nature skill whenever
we ask for an Herbalism roll. There are a number of uses as
listed below:
• Knowing which herbs are required for specific uses.
Herbs can be used to increase normal healing or to
fight off infections and diseases. They are also the
main ingredients used in the creation of Herbal
Remedies, and the slightly more powerful Herbal
Elixirs. This includes which herbs or combination of
herbs can be used to produce specific effects.
• Knowing where to search for specific herbs in
the wild. Herbs can be found almost anywhere;
however, not all herbs grow in the same terrain or
environment. Some of the more powerful herbs will
grow only in certain locations, so the Herbalist must
often be willing to go where the herbs are, or to hire
somebody to go collect them for him.
• Identifying an herb is extremely important, as the
Herbalist needs to know what it is he is using. This
is even more important when the Herbalist isn’t the
one who collected the herb.
• Properly preserving herbs is also important,
especially if the herb is to be saved for later use. The
most common method of preservation is drying the
herb. A properly dried herb will remain usable for up
to 6 months if stored in a dry, dark location. If kept
in an air-tight container, a dried herb will remain
usable for up to 1 year.
• Knowing how to prepare an herb for use is one of
the most important aspects of Herbalism. There
are several different methods of preparing herbs
described later. The Herbalist knows that proper
preparations can render some poisonous herbs
beneficial and improper preparation can make
beneficial herbs useless, or worse, poisonous.
Most of the above tasks use your standard skill roll to
determine success. Searching for herbs in the wild though,
will depend upon a number of different factors, as explained
in the Searching for Herbs section.

Herbal Classifications

Herbs can be divided into 4 basic classifications, Common,
Uncommon, Rare, and Magical. Each has a base Search
Modifier (SM) that applies to any rolls made to search for
the herbs in the wild.
220

The basic descriptions of the 4 types of herbs are as follows:
Common (SM 0): Common herbs are the most plentiful
and the easiest to find. They can be used to alleviate
symptoms and cure maladies over the course of time.
When using this type of herb, daily doses will be required
for a minimum of 1-10 days in order to affect a complete
recovery, if one is possible. However, the patient should
shows signs of the treatment working within 1-10 hours
of the initial dosage. For injuries, taking the right herbs
can double the speed of natural healing. When searching
for common herbs, it is not unusual to find 1-10 doses
during a single search. Common herbs usually sell for
1-10 copper pieces per dose in an Apothecary’s shop.
Uncommon (SM -2): Uncommon herbs are a bit more
difficult to find than common herbs, and you often
find fewer doses (1-5) overall. A single dose of an
uncommon herb often sells for 1-10 bronze pieces
in an Apothecary’s shop. Uncommon herbs will start
working within 1-10 minutes of being used; however,
it will take 2-20 hours for the full effects of the herb to
resolve themselves. Uncommon herbs are required by
Alchemists for the creation of Herbal Remedies.
Example: While fighting some Goblins, Raglin
took a leg wound that was bleeding 1 hit every
round. Agnar applied first aid, to temporarily
stop the bleeding so that he could give Raglin
some herbs to heal the bleeding. Raglin chews the
piece of root that Agnar gives him, and within 10
minutes, the bleeding has completely stopped and
Agnar removes the first aid bandages. However,
Agnar cautions Raglin not to exert himself for
the next day (i.e. 2-20 hours is required time, but
Raglin overstates it to be sure) or else the wound
could re-open and start bleeding again.
Rare (SM -5): Rare herbs are nearly the hardest to find. They
often start working within 1-10 rounds of being used, and
their full effects will have occurred within 10 minutes. It
is unusual to find more than 1 or 2 doses of a rare herb at
a time and those doses will easily sell for 2-20 silver pieces
from an Apothecary or Herbalist’s shop. Rare herbs are
required by Alchemists for the creation of Herbal Elixirs.
Magical (SM -7): Magical Herbs are the hardest type of
herbs to find. Their effects are immediately and fully
felt the round after they are used. It is highly unusual
to find more than a single dose at a time, and that dose
often sells for 1 to 20 gold pieces at an Herbalist’s or
Alchemist’s shop. Magical herbs only grow in places
where there are or were large concentrations of magical
energy. This includes such places as the locations of
magical battles, places where there are natural reservoirs
of magic, and cross-over points (points where different
dimensions touch, such as near a magical portal, or a
rip in the fabric of reality). For the upcoming Anwyn
setting, this means Ilthach, the Esker Highlands, and
most especially in Tuist Rhion (the Star Crater).

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Searching For Herbs

Search Modifiers

Searching for herbs is actually a relatively simple process.
The player simply Herbalism roll on the FEAT table, using all
applicable modifiers.
A Partial Success results in finding the desired herb, but
only a single does that is ready to be harvested. It will be at
least another month before any other doses found will be
ready for harvesting.
A Successful search results in the finding of the number of
doses, with each Success Level adding +1 to the total number
of doses found.
A Critical Success means that double the normal number
of doses were found, and the 5 Success Levels adds another 5
doses to amount.
Each search covers 1 square mile of area and performing
a search takes anywhere from 1 to 10 hours, depending upon
the number of searchers. Each searcher beyond the first
reduces the time needed to search an area by 30 minutes,
down to the minimum of 1 hour.
Searching for herbs may only be done in the wild, as
cultivated areas will not have any wild herbs growing, but there
may be an Herbalist who maintains a garden of Common,
Uncommon, and the occasional Rare herb. In fact, it should be
expected that there will be no wild herbs found within 20 miles
of any village or town simply because the townsfolk and/or any
local Herbalists will routinely be searching such areas and thus
picked any available herbs within that range.

The Herb Search Modifiers table provides you with some
additional modifiers, beyond the base Search Modifiers, to the
search based on several different types of criteria. The table is
divided into 3 main sections and described in more detail in
the next section.

Herb Search Modifiers Table Key
Please keep in mind that Type of Herbs section of the table
is mainly for when searching for either whatever might be
available, of for herbs of a given type. When searching for
a specific Herb from the Sample Herbs section, the type of
herb is already taken into account.
Base Search Modifier — This is the base modifier based
on the type of herb described on the previous page:
Common, Uncommon, Rare, and Magical.

221

How Recently Searched — This section provides modifiers
for how recently the area that the characters desire
to search has been searched, either by the characters
themselves or by others. Each of the entries in this
section are self-explanatory. If an area has not been
searched within the last 6 months, there are no
modifiers from this section.
Searchers Involved — This section provides modifiers for
others who are assisting the character in his search.
Modifiers are provided for the number of helpers as
well as any special knack or training that they might
have. Also included in this section is a modifier for
the number of days spent searching a given area. The
more time spent searching one area, the more likely that
anything there will be found. These guidelines do not
require any rolls by those assisting. Those wishing to
Help (p. 116) as well, may do so.
Types of Herbs — This section lists the basic types of herbs
that a character might be searching for. Each has its
own modifiers for the classification it falls under,
but some types of herbs won’t be available under all
classifications, especially herbs that temporarily grant
magical abilities to the imbiber.
Antidotes — Unfortunately, the unscrupulous often resort
to poisons, and so there is always a market for antidotes
to those poisons. In many cases, the antidote is found in
the same locale as the poison it works against.
Disease & Ailment Cures — This is one of the primary
uses for herbs. This includes everything from reducing
a fever to easing a cough to treating a hangover,
and everything in between. Although it may seem
incongruous, cooking herbs are also covered by this
type. That is because many cooking herbs may also
have other beneficial uses over long periods of time.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Drugs (Narcotics) — This basically covers various herbs
and organic substances that are used to render the
imbiber unconscious or to put them to sleep. Many
such herbs also have various side effects, with only
rare and magical herbs having beneficial side effects.
In many cases, outside of an herbalist or physician,
possession these substances are usually illegal.
Drugs (Recreational) — These are herbs and other
substances that are used to produce altered states in the
recipients, usually feelings of euphoria. Occasionally,
these substances also produce unintended side effects,
such as increased strength or increased hunger while
under the influence. Possession of these substances are
often illegal in many towns and villages.
Hallucinogens/Dreams — There are many cultures that
use herbs to stimulate hallucinations (i.e. visions) and
dreams among their members as part of religious and
other ceremonies. In some cases, magical herbs can
not only produce these effects, but also have other
beneficial effects as well.
Healing Wounds — For many adventurers, herbs of
this type, which speed healing of wounds received
in battle or otherwise, are going to likely be the most
important ones that they can find. Especially prized
by warriors of all types are herbs that can alleviate or
prevent a person from being Stunned. This modifier is
used multiple times, once for each wound severity it
can heal up to (Light, Moderate, Severe, Dire, Mortal).
Life Restoration — Herbs that can restore life to a dead
body are among the rarest and most magical, and they
are especially prized. There are even some herbs within
this type that, if administered at the right time, can put the
recipient into a deep coma if they receive enough damage
to kill them, thus preserving their life and allowing them to
wake up once the death-dealing damage has been repaired.
Physical Enhancement — Herbs of this type include
any herb that can magically produce physical effects
upon the body of the recipient, such as an herb that
allows the imbiber to breathe underwater for a period
of time, or one that increases the strength, or the speed
of healing of the person who takes it.
Poisons — Honest, law abiding Herbalists do not traffic
in poisons. Only those who work the darker side of
the street will deal with them, and they will normally
only deal with known clientele, or those introduced by
known clientele, not with strangers. Victims of poisons
are always allowed a Saving Roll against their effects.
The more common a poison, the more doses required,
and the slower it will work.
Sense Enhancement — These herbs grant their recipient
the ability to see things normally hidden from them,
or to allow their senses to be expanded or extended in
some manner.

Preparing Herbs

Once an herb has been found, it must be properly prepared
before use. If the herb is not properly prepared, then it will have
no effect.
Here is a list of the most common methods of preparation:
Baked: The herb is baked into bread or other small cakes
and then consumed. This method may be used with
herbs that come from any portion of the plant.
Brewed: The herb is boiled into a serum or tea and the
resulting liquid must be drunk in order for the herb to
have any effect. This method of preparation is often used
on herbs that take the form of the leaves of the plant.
Chew: The herb is placed into the mouth of the recipient and
then chewed and swallowed. This method is normally used
with herbs that take the form of seeds, nuts, fruit or berries.
For larger herbs, such as fruit, the whole edible portion of
the fruit must be consumed for the herb to be effective.
Compress: The herb is finely chopped and then mixed
with just enough water so that is sticks together (not
quite a paste) that is then applied to a bandage or cloth
and pressed directly upon the skin of the recipient.
Any portion of a plant may be used for this.
Crushed: A fresh herb is crushed so that it releases its
natural oils and then rubbed on the skin or body of the
recipient. This method is most often used with herbs
that take the form of the leaves of the plant.
Dust: The herb is dried and crushed into a powder which
it then sprinkled on the skin of the recipient or mixed
into a liquid and drank. This method may be used with
herbs that come from any portion of the plant.
Juice: The herb is placed in the mouth of the recipient,
who then sucks the juice from the herb. This method
is most often used with some types of fruit, berries,
and stems, if the herb comes from a reed of some type.
Powder: The herb is ground into a fine powder and then,
depending upon the herb, the recipient must either
inhale the powder through his nose or mix it with food
or drink and ingest it. This method may be used with
herbs that come from any portion of the plant.
Salve: The herb is powdered and then mixed with melted
fats to form a paste as it cools This is then applied directly
to the skin of the recipient. This method may be used
with herbs that come from any portion of the plant.
Smoked: The herb is wrapped tightly in a thin parchment or
put into a pipe and then lit and the recipient inhales the
smoke from the herb. This method also includes burning
the herb much as one would burn incense. This is most
often used with herbs that come from the leaves and
stems of a plant.
Vapor: With this method, the herb is boiled in a pot of
water or alcohol, and the recipient leans over it and
inhales the vapors arising from it. This method of
preparation may be used with herbs from any part of
the plant, but most often the leaves.

222

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Sample Herbs

Below is a list of sample herbs that may be used in a
campaign. GMs are encouraged to add to these, to create
even more herbs, ones that are unique to the setting that
they are using. Unless the herb description specifically says
otherwise, the effects of a given herb will last for 10 minutes,
with healing herbs being the exception since they do not
require a duration.
The format is very simple and as follows:
Herb Name: (Source/Preparation; Climate/Locale; SM ##)
Description of effects.
The source refers to the portion of the plant that the herb comes
from, and the preparation refers to how the herb is prepared. The
Climate and Locale refer to where the herb is normally found.
The SM, otherwise known as the Search Modifier, includes the
base Search Modifier from the basic type of herb, and the other
modifiers from the Herb Search Modifiers table. For example,
a magical herb (base SM of -7, that is for healing wounds (-2),
and is also a relaxant (narcotic, -2), would have a total Search
Modifier of -11. And finally, we give a description of the herb’s
effects when taken as prepared.
Adwold: (Root/Brew; Temperate/Marsh; SM -11) When
drank, the tea created with this herb will all damage
up to what is covered by a Moderate Wound. [Magical]

Reaction Rolls

If you’re unsure about how a particular NPC or group of
NPCs will act upon meeting the heroes, or how they will
react to their actions, you may resolve the situation with a
Reaction Roll.
Make an open-ended roll on the Reaction Rolls table
below to determine the NPC’s Disposition towards the
heroes. This is normally a simple 2d10 roll, with no Skill
bonuses involved.
However, you may want to add or subtract a small
modifier if the situation demands it. For example, the
characters might incur on a -2 penalty to the Reaction Roll
if they aren’t wearing appropriate clothing at an audience
with the local lord. On the other hand, their roll might be
modified by +2 if they come bringing gifts and offerings.

Use the Combat column if the characters are fighting, or
if you must decide if the NPCs are ready to fight the heroes
or not, and the Interaction column for negotiations and
social encounters.
Note that Dispositions are simply guidelines to help you
choose how an NPC will react. An NPC’s attitude towards
the PCs will surely be influenced by their first impressions
but is bound to change over time according to their actions
and the events of your campaign.
There are some skills that refer to making rolls on the
Reaction Rolls table, or which may include such rolls in
certain situations. In such cases, the character makes the
relevant roll, and they receive a modifier based on the results
of that roll. Critical Failure provides a -5 to the Reaction
Roll, Failure provides a -2 modifier, Partial Success gives a +0
modifier, and Success gives a modifier equal to the number
of Success Levels rolled for the skill.

Commerce & Trade
In many games, the GM will just allow the players to
purchase items at the costs given, and this is quite alright as
it is their style of play. Other GMs and players may like to
haggle or use their trading skills. Both styles are valid.
Here are two separate methods that you could use for the
latter style, where the GM has characters haggle.

Conflicting Actions for Trading

With Conflicting Actions, you would have each side roll.
The one who rolled highest would be the winner, so the
end result would favor that person. Each point of difference
between the two rolls would be considered a 5% difference
in the listed price.
Example: Zhoran, an Ethori Scout has come upon
a nice looking dagger at a stall in the city market.
He decides to try and haggle with the owner of the
stall, Myridd, to see how good a price he can get.
Zhoran has 1 rank in Influence for a total bonus
of 3, and Myridd has 5 ranks of Influence for a
total bonus of 6. Zhoran’s player rolls a 17, with his
bonus, that gives him a total of 20. The GM rolls
a 11 for Myridd, for a total of 17. This means that
Zhoran wins the roll by 3 points, and is able to talk
Myridd down 15%. Since a dagger is 1 sp (which
equates to 10 bronze or 100 copper pieces). So 15%
of that is 15 cp, so the final cost of the dagger is 85
cp, or 8 bp, 5 cp after his haggling.

Commerce Table

If you want to go a more detailed route, you could use
the Commerce Table to determine final costs. With the
Commerce Table, we recommend that the GM make all of
the rolls, as some of the possible results are ones that you do
not want the players to know about in advance if they happen.
There are two main sections for the table, Purchase and
Sell. Purchase is for when the player’s characters are buying
things. The Sell section is for when the player’s characters
are selling things to the various types of merchants.
Each section has 3 columns, one for each type of merchant,
Shop, Vendor, and Illegal. Shops are those merchants who
operate out of a fixed building. They are well established and
not going anywhere.
Vendors are those merchants who travel from town
to town, or who operate out of market stalls. These are
temporary structures at best. Illegal means that the merchant
(who could be Shops or Vendors, though Shops are more
likely) deals with the underworld, with those who operate
outside the law.

Using the Table
To use the table, the GM makes an open-ended roll and then
adds in the player’s skill bonus and subtracts the merchant’s skill
bonus from the total and looks up the result on the Commerce
Table. The GM should also apply any other modifiers that are
appropriate to the situation. There are a number of modifiers
on the lower section of the table that could apply.
Reading the Results
Each of these columns has 6 possible results and they are
detailed here.
##% – This is the percentage of the listed sale price that the
character can purchase or resell their item for. A result of zero
(0) means that the merchant will not make a deal at all.
Not Available – This means that the item that the player is trying
to purchase is not available for sale. The GM is always allowed
to replace any result from the table with this result.
Reported – This only happens if dealing with one of the Illegal
markets. When this happens, the merchant declines to make
a transaction and then reports the character to the nearest
authority, usually City Watch or Guard.
Scammed – With this result, the merchant scams the player.
He might give him shaved or counterfeit coins that the next
merchant notices and calls him on (thinking the character
is trying to scam him), or he tries to sell you something
that you think is the item you are looking for.
Robbed – The merchant sells the item to the character, but
also arranges for it to be stolen soon after, in a non-violent
manner. This could be a pickpocket or a group of rowdy
children who grab the item and run off, or some other type
of method of separate the character from the item in a way
where nobody gets hurt. It could also be that the merchant
has nothing to do with it being stolen, but that the theft is
orchestrated by somebody who witnesses the purchase.
Mugged – The merchant makes his deal with the character
and then arranges for him to be violently relieved of his
recent acquisition (money or item). It is also possible
that the merchant has nothing to do with it, but that
somebody else witnessed the transaction and decided to
try for an easy profit. In either case, the character gets
attacked not too long after his transaction.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Rarity – This is a modifier based on how rare the item in

apply to items that are from Uncommon to Very Common
Rarity. It is unlikely that a Rare or Very Rare item will
suddenly flood the market; unlikely but not impossible.
This could drive prices up or down quite easily.

The Darkmaster

Epithet

No campaign preparation would be complete without
some thoughts on the great shadow that threatens the world
the heroes live in. The greatest enemy of the Free Races: the
Darkmaster himself.
The Darkmaster isn’t just a background feature, some
generic Big Bad whose presence the players can easily
ignore. It is often a key element of the game, and the GM
should carefully consider his nature, since it can shape both
the campaign setting and their tale.

Creating Your Darkmaster
In one campaign the heroes might battle the machinations
of the Witch Queen, while in another the Darkmaster could
be represented by the Blood Lord and his ravaging hordes.
In some settings you could have more than one
Darkmaster or even an entire pantheon of Dark Gods,
plotting to corrupt all creation with their ruinous powers.
Much in the same way, the influence and perception of
the Darkmaster in the game world depends on the tale the
group wants to tell and will vary with each campaign. In some
games the Darkmaster will be an overt threat no sane man
could deny, while in others it could be more subtle, acting
only in secret or hiding behind a facade of righteousness.
Creating the Darkmaster, giving him an epithet, and
defining his powers, minions, and agenda is an involved
process, requiring the cooperation of the whole group.
The identity of the Darkmaster can be decided right at the
start of the campaign, even before sitting down to generate
the PCs, or could take shape and be revealed as the game
progresses and the world is explored.
In both cases, the heroes will soon learn to recognize the
signs of the presence of the Darkmaster, his favorite minions,
the symbols of the forces of Darkness, and the horrible Taint
left by his touch on the land and the very soul of those who
accept his dark gifts.

The Weaver of Lies, the Horned King, the Gods of
Entropy, the Witch Queen. The Darkmaster is known by a
different name and wears a different face in each world he
besieges. Sometimes, with the passing of eons, the form he
wears changes, but usually in each world there is a single
embodiment, or avatar, of the Darkmaster at any given time.
Since no one knows the True Name of the Darkmaster,
this avatar is often given an epithet that describes his current
transient state at that particular point of time and space.
When you name your Darkmaster, give him an Epithet
that echoes his most prominent traits. Try to make it eerie
and suggestive, without revealing too much about the true
nature of his avatar.

Genesis
Where does the avatar of the Darkmaster come from? How
did he obtain his powers? The tale of the Darkmaster’s origins
will help you define his personality, motivations, and powers.
The Genesis of the Darkmaster may well be shrouded
in mystery, the tales about it little more than — often
contradictory — rumors and stories. But each of these
rumors will add a new layer of complexity and detail to your
game world’s history.
Start by jotting down some notes about it, and don’t
worry too much; you can always come back and flesh them
out as you complete the other steps.

Appearance and Symbol
What does the avatar look like? Does He wear an appealing
shape to entice his enemies and seduce them with poisoned
promises? Is he terrible to behold, his visage so dreadful it could
strike fear even in the heart of the mightiest of warriors? Or is
he in truth without form, a shapeless shadow of pure malice?
What symbol is painted on the banners of his armies and
on the shields of his warriors? Does he mark the flesh of his
most devoted servants, or do all his servants carry tokens
shaped in his likeness with them?

228

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Goals

Powers

The Darkmaster is always working on some nefarious
plan and will not rest until the whole creation is destroyed
or enslaved to His will.
He may be searching for a coveted artifact, bound to him by
Fate — the key to both his perpetual triumph and his ultimate
destruction. Or he might be intent on crushing the last few
rebels who dare oppose his domain of terror or amassing the
greatest army the world has ever seen to smash down the Light
once and for all. Think about the themes you’d like to explore
in your campaign or world setting, and choose a goal that
reinforces them. Make it grandiose and epic but remember to
give the heroes a chance to fight against it!

Surely the Darkmaster is a being of incommensurable might,
but how do his Dark Powers manifest? How do they influence
his subjects and what do they mean for your game setting?
Is he the most powerful Warlock in the world, weaving
eldritch enchantments stretching whole continents and
lasting for ages? A fierce Warlord, leading His legions of dark
minions into battle with unsurpassed skill? Or a Master
Manipulator, poisoning the Free Kingdoms from within
with his lies?
The Darkmaster could well be all of the above, and even
more. Deciding the nature, reach, and strength of the powers
of the Darkmaster will help you envision the fantastic world
you’re exploring and set the mood of your campaign.
You can pick the most appropriate Darkmaster Powers
from the examples below, choosing those that best fit your
campaign, or use them as a basis to write your own.
Note: You do not have to use any of these example
powers; you could default to a Darkmaster who has
no extra powers. Your Darkmaster could also simply
be a very powerful creature. One of the Darkmasters
for the Anwyn setting is an ancient Dracorex
(Dragon King), who is fighting a shadow war with
other Dracorex who are also trapped upon Anwyn.
Dracorex, being selfish creatures, often use proxies
in fighting their wars.

Servants
Who are servants of the Darkmaster, from his most powerful
heralds to his most pitiful minions? From the lieges and
chieftains of his elite troops to the lackeys, knaves, and slaves?
Look at the Bestiary and choose his Lieutenants from the
most powerful creatures described there. Demons, Giants,
Dragons, Undead Wraiths, and Dark Mages or Dark Knights
are all good choices as Lieutenants of his hosts. They’re
all creatures of great power, who can easily serve as main
villains for several scenarios or even whole campaigns.
The bulk of the Darkmaster’s forces will be made up
by low-level Minions. Creatures such as Undead Thralls,
Goblins, Kobolds, or even members of the Free Kins - Men,
Elves or Dwarves - who for some reason embraced his cause.
Choose two or three different creatures and stick with
them, to make the heroes’ opponents more distinctive and
to avoid falling into the “fantasy kitchen sink” trap.
The Darkmaster will also have Spies, messengers and
informers. Choose creatures prone to stealth, or able to
quickly cover great distances for this task. Murders of
black-feathered crows, sneaky Spriggans, and scuttling
Spiders make perfect Spies.

Dark Place
Where does the Darkmaster’s hideout lay, and what does
it look like?
The Dark Place where the Darkmaster resides is always
a dramatic location, shaped by his presence and reflecting
his twisted essence. It could be a huge fortress, impregnable
black ramparts raising up to the churning clouds, or a firetopped mountain, spitting ashes and flames all around
a barren, scorched land. It could be an ice-covered island
in the utmost North, bathed in perpetual twilight, or even
an entire underground realm, a labyrinthine complex of
tunnels, caves, and underground seas.
Generally, this Dark Place is located somewhere to the
farthest edge of the known world, or even beyond it. Simply
reaching such an impervious place, traveling through the
Dark and Blighted Lands that surround it, is a deed worth
being sung in epic poems.
Think about your Darkmaster, his past, and what he
represents, and give him a suitable abode.

Eldritch Horrors
The Darkmaster rules by fear, and His very existence threatens
the stability of the heroes’ minds. This ability is best suited for
grim, perilous fantasy tales with a dark or gothic twist.
The Servants of this Darkmaster also exude an aura of
Fear, requiring all who run into them the first time to make
a Will Save versus Fear.
Life Scourge
The Darkmaster is a herald of Death. Crops fail, rot and
diseases spread, and all life withers under his dread shadow.
Use this ability to inject a sense of despair in the campaign
or if you want to make careful resource management one of
the focuses of the game.
Hunting and foraging rolls only yield half the normal
amount of food. Additionally, injured characters have a chance
equal to the total penalties inflicted by Injuries of contracting
either the Barrow Rot or Bog Fever disease (GM’s choice).
Note: If a character’s injuries total -6, then 6 or
less on the roll of 2d10 means that they have
been exposed to one of the diseases and must
Save against it.
Dark Temptation
The Darkmaster whispers sweet lies into the heart of the
Free Kins, lulling them into complacency and tempting
them with promises of power.
This ability works well in campaigns where the heroes will
be often called to make difficult moral choices, and in tales
of righteousness, integrity, and tragic betrayals.

229

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Dark Magic

Dark Passions

Dark mages, evil warlocks, and deranged cultists often
wield forbidden magical powers. Dark Spells, containing
incantations so foul that the simple act of studying them
is enough to twist the mind and taint the soul of even the
strongest-willed magic practitioner. Such individuals pull
their Dark Magics from their Darkmaster, and gain a +4 to
all Spellcasting in his service. They may also know specific
forbidden spells that work better than normal spells in some
manner (i.e. one Darkmaster might make it easier for his
minions to permanently summon undead servants).

Taint
Taint represents the mark of the Darkmaster on a
character’s soul. Those who accept his dark gifts, make
themselves instruments of his will, or bend the knee to his
rule slowly lose their individuality, turning into twisted
reflections of their old selves, mere puppets under the
Darkmaster’s control.
Not every morally ambiguous or even plainly evil
character the heroes will encounter during their adventures
will be Tainted. Ruthless mercenaries, savage marauders,
power-hungry aristocrats, and sadistic tyrants are surely
despicable, but aren’t necessarily Tainted. Only those who
choose to serve the Darkmaster or accept to become pawns
in his schemes will suffer from Taint.
Much in the same way, heroes might be driven by less
than noble purposes, or succumb to temptation from time
to time, but this isn’t enough to Taint their soul.
Characters will gain Taint only in the following cases:
• When they learn a Dark Spell Lore;
• The first time they use a Tainted Magic Item;
• When their Affinity score with a Tainted Item of
Power increases enough to unlock a new power;
• If they make a pact with a demon, devil, or the
Darkmaster himself.
Taint should always be the result of a conscious decision.
The GM should always warn players beforehand if their
characters are going to suffer from Taint because of their
actions. Never force or trick characters into situations that
leave them no choice but becoming Tainted.
Taint slowly erodes a character’s free will, but always start
with a choice. The Darkmaster has no power over those who
don’t accept Him in their heart first.

Items of Power
Items of Power are extremely powerful and unique magical
artifacts with a will and intelligence of their own. Tainted
Items of Power are those that serve a Dark purpose.
Characters may have an Affinity (from 1-10) with such
items based on how well they follow the item’s purposes.
Some items may even have powers that are unlocked
when the Affinity reaches a certain point, Conversely,
these powers would be lost if that Affinity drops.

Taint attacks a character’s Passions, corrupting them and
turning them into mockeries of what the character once
held sacred.
When characters suffer Taint, they must change one
of their available Passions into a Dark Passion. First their
Motivation becomes an Obsession, then their Allegiance
turns into a Dark Oath, and lastly their Nature turns into a
Perversion and the character is removed from play.
To write an Obsession, take the hero’s Motivation and
bring it to an extreme, or write a new, possibly morally
questionable, goal the character is hell-bent on achieving.
Below you’ll find some good examples of Obsessions:
• The Sword of the Tuatha is mine by right: I will kill
anyone who dares to say otherwise.
• I will destroy every Orc and all those who ally with
them, no matter the cost.
• I would do anything and sacrifice everything to
reclaim the Crown of the Realm.
A Dark Oath represents the second step in the hero’s path
toward Darkness. The character isn’t completely under the
Darkmaster’s control yet, but is clearly bound to him in
some way. To write a Dark Oath, take the hero’s Allegiance,
and twist it to make it dependent on the Darkmaster, or
write a short phrase describing the nature of the pact they
made with him. Some examples of Dark Oath would be:
• With the Darkmaster’s help I can win back the favor
of the King.
• Only by doing the Darkmaster’s bidding I’ll be able
to save my family.
• Eoin is a fool; I’ll show him the beauty of the
Darkmaster’s teachings.
Perversion is the final stage of a hero’s downfall. There’s
no turning back now, the character has abandoned the Light
and became a pawn of the Darkmaster. A character who
suffers Taint for the third time becomes an NPC under the
control of the GM.
The group should take a moment to play out the tragic
scene of the character’s ultimate corruption, and decide
their fate. A fallen hero may well become a new, recurring
villain for the campaign, and a particularly unpleasant one,
given their ties with the other PCs! On the other hand, the
players may feel uneasy confronting their former comrade
and may prefer having the character dying or removed from
play in some other way.
The character sheet is then passed to the GM, who must
change their Nature into a vile mockery of the character’s
original Passion. Some examples of suitable Perversions are
given below:
• The Laws of Nature mean nothing to me; I follow the
path of Darkness.
• They’re all traitors; I will kill them all.
• I’m a Holy Knight; whoever opposes me is clearly
Evil and must be destroyed.

230

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Dark Passions work very similarly to standard Passions,
and heroes can follow them to gain Drive, as usual. However,
characters cannot change their Dark Passions unless they
redeem themselves (see the following paragraph for more
information), and cannot spend their Milestones to trigger
a Revelation if they have one or more Dark Passions.

Redemption
Characters suffering from Taint may attempt to redeem
themselves, before falling completely over to the Dark
side. A character completely foregoing what caused the
Taint (for example, destroying or abandoning the Tainted
Item, or openly disobeying the Darkmaster’s orders)
and accomplishing a valiant, heroic deed is considered
redeemed. The character can then spend a Milestone at the
first appropriate time to change one of their Dark Passions
back into a standard Passion. Be careful, however; the
chance for redemption comes only once.
Characters who succumb to the temptation of Darkness
again won’t be able to redeem themselves another time, and
will have to stick to their Dark Passions until the bitter end.

Defeating the Darkmaster
So, the Darkmaster has countless minions, an unassailable
fortress, is basically immortal and quite possibly the most
powerful being in the whole world. How could ever the
heroes hope to defeat Him?
In the Sword & Sorcery genre, the hero, after wading
through hordes of minor enemies, would face the Darkmaster
Himself in single combat. Using only his mighty thews against
the Darkmaster’s otherworldly powers, he would finally strike
him down with a single swing of his great sword of steel,
claiming fame, gold, and glory for himself.
One of the pillars of the Epic Fantasy genre, however, is that
the Darkmaster cannot be defeated by normal means. His fall
is an epochal event, attainable only after enormous sacrifices.
It may require the fulfillment of a mysterious and
seemingly impossible prophecy, or it could be connected
to the Darkmaster’s Coveted Artifact. In any case, the heroes
rarely win by confronting the Darkmaster directly. When they
do, it’s only because they’ve completed their quest and learnt
His only weakness, or because destiny guided their hands.
This is why the Darkmaster has no stats in the game. The
heroes cannot fight him or defeat him with their weapons
and spells, however mighty. Their only hope is doing exactly
what the protagonists of epic sagas do: undergo a perilous
quest and find a way to thwart his plans and free their world
from his tyrannical grasp.

231

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Bestiary

One of the standard tropes of a fantasy role-playing game
is that the characters will fight creatures and find treasure,
including magical items.
Fantasy Express is no exception. In this chapter, we will go
over the basics of determining a “random” encounter, provide
you with a selection of creatures that can be used as opponents
for the characters, and in the next chapter, we provide you
with some sample treasures that you can use as rewards.

Encounters

There are two possible types of encounters that characters
can have. They are as follows:

Planned Encounters

The first is a Planned Encounter. This is an encounter that
you, as GM have planned to occur at some point.
This may something like meeting a stranger at a crossroad
who provides the character with information that aids in his
adventure. Another example is the climactic battle with the
main bad guy of the adventure.

Random Encounters

The second type of encounter is the Random Encounter.
It is an encounter that is not planned. More often than not,
this sort of encounter will not have any impact on the main
goal of the adventure, but depending on where it happened,
it is always possible that it could.

Encounter Checks

The GM should roll to check for encounters periodically. If the
characters are traveling then the GM should make an Encounter
Check once for every 4 hours, or portion thereof, that the party
has traveled. This means that if the party is traveling for 5 hours,
that the GM should make 2 Encounter Checks.
If the party is camped, the GM should make an Encounter
Check for every 8 hours, or portion thereof, that the party
is camped. Thus, if the party camps for 12 hours, the GM
should make 2 Encounter checks.

To actually make an Encounter Check, the GM rolls 2d10
and adds in a number of modifiers based on the situation.
See the Encounter Check Modifiers section and table on the
next page for more information on the types of modifiers.
If the result of the Encounter Check is 20 or higher, then the
encounter is a Spotting Encounter. This means that one of the
two parties involved in the encounter has spotted or seen the
other. To determine which, look at the total dice result of your
encounter check. If the result was odd, then the subject of the
encounter has spotted the party first. If the result was even, then
the party spots the subject of the encounter first.
Once one side has been spotted, the spotter must decide
what it is going to do. This could be to leave the other side
alone, follow them, take a closer look, set a trap for them
or even attack them. It all depends upon the nature of the
encounter and its motivations and goals.
Example: The party is traveling in the wilderness.
The GM gets a total roll of 23 for the Encounter. Since
the result is odd, that means that the subject of the
Encounter has spotted the party. The GM decides that
the Encounter will be with a Dragon that lives in the
area. Since the Dragon is too powerful for the party,
the GM decides that the Dragon has been out hunting
and is now on its way home when it spots the party.
Being a little curious, the Dragon decides to take a
closer look. The Dragon then comes flying in behind
the party, staying up high enough to avoid shots from
scared mortals, and overflies the party to take a closer
look. As he approaches, the animals catch wind of
him, since he is not coming from downwind, and get
spooked, making them more difficult to control, so
the GM has the players make Riding rolls to control
their mounts. About this time, the party sees the very
large shadow crossing, and look up to see the Dragon
a few hundred feet away. Being slightly mischievous,
the Dragon chooses the moment that it is spotted to let
out with a roar, which scares the animals yet again,
causing yet another Riding roll to control them. The
Dragon then continues to fly off, chuckling to itself over
how much fun that was.

232

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

If the result of the Encounter Check is 30 or higher, then the
party will meet the encounter directly. This means that both
the party and the subject of the encounter have come upon
one another without too much warning to either side. Some
examples of this might be the party entering a clearing just as
a Goblin patrol enters from a different direction, or stumbling
upon a monster as it is eating something that it has caught.
In cases like this, the GM should definitely check for
Surprise (p. 129).

Encounter Check Modifiers
There are a number of different modifiers that can be applied
to an Encounter Check. The actual modifier applied will vary
depending upon the situation. Please note that not every
modifier will apply in every situation. For example, Terrain
modifiers are unlikely to apply in an urban environment.
Party Size: The number of characters in the party will provide
a modifier. If there are fewer than 4 members in the party,
there is a -2 modifier for each one less than four. If there
is more than four, then apply a +1 for each member over
four that there is. Mounts and pack animals count as 2
members each. Vehicles such as carts and wagons give a
+5 modifier per vehicle if they are less than 6’ in length,
and a +10 modifier if they are larger than 6’ in length.
For this, the draft animal(s) pulling the vehicle are not
counted when determining the modifier.
Weather: The weather can also have an impact on whether
or not the party has an encounter, the more inclement
the weather, the less likely that an encounter will
occur. If there is light rain or snow, apply a -2 modifier.
Moderate rain or snow gives a -5 modifier, and heavy
rain or snow gives a -10 modifier.
Terrain: The terrain can have a huge impact on the
Encounter Check. Open, flat ground with little or no
vegetation will give a +5 modifier to the Encounter
Check. Rough ground, on the other hand, gives a -5
modifier. In a light forest, the Encounter Check receives
an additional -3 modifier and heavy forest gives a -5
modifier. All terrain modifiers are cumulative.

tracking them at a distance), then the Encounter
Check will receive a +5 modifier for wilderness areas
and a +10 modifier for rural and urban areas.
Population Density: The Encounter Check should be
modified by +10 when near urban areas and +5 when
near rural areas. However, in such areas, the encounters
will be with residents, travelers and/or other locals, not
with monsters normally. Such encounters could include
pilgrims, patrols, messengers, scouts, bandits, traders,
etc. It depends on the actual location and several other
factors such as how close to a city or village the party is
among other things.

Travel Speed: Characters who are sneaking or moving
carefully, slower than or equal to half of the standard
movement rate for the terrain that they are in (see the
Overland Movement table on p. 211), will receive a -10
modifier to the Encounter Check, while those moving
faster than the average normal will receive a +5 modifier.
Hostile Area: If the party is in an area that controlled
by forces or creatures that are actively hostile to the
party, then their chances for having an encounter
are increased based upon the circumstances. If the
hostile forces have patrols out, then the Encounter
Check will receive a +2 modifier if the party is in a
wilderness area, a +5 modifier if the party is in a rural
area, or a +10 modifier if the party is in an urban area
controlled by the hostile forces. If the hostile forces
have already spotted the party once and are actively
pursuing them (i.e. a hue and cry pursuit, not simply

Creatures

Creatures are listed in alphabetical order, their name followed
by a few sentences describing their appearance, characteristics,
and in some cases, origins and typical behavior.
If multiple variants of the same creature are present, their
names will be written in bold and italics the first time they
appear in the description.

233

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Creature Stat Tables
Level: The Level of the creature.
Move Rate (MR): The Move Rate (expressed in feet per
round) of the creature. The first value represents the
primary, preferred means of movement of the creature.
The second, and sometimes the third, value indicates
others types of movement possessed by the creature.
Codes are: L = Land, F = Flight, S = Swim.
Defensive Modifier (DM): The Defensive Modifier of the
creature. It already factors the creature’s Dexterity, shield,
magical or special bonuses.
If the creature uses a shield, that will also be indicated here,
in parenthesis. (ts) means Target Shield, (rs) means Round
Shield, and (fs) means Full Shield.
If the creature has multiple types of movement, it is possible
that they may also have different Defensive Modifiers for each
movement type. If that is the case, it will be listed, and with the
same codes as for the types of movement.
Armor Rating (AR): When the creature is the sbuject of an
attack and they are hit, the amount of Hit Point damage
is reduced by the number for the specific Armor Rating
against that type of damage. B = Bash Damage, S = Slash
damage, P = Pierce Damage, E = Elemental damage, and
finally SL = Success Level Adjustment.
TSR: Toughness Save Roll bonus.
RSR: Reflexes Save Roll bonus.
WSR: Willpower Save Roll bonus.
HPs: The average number of Total Hit Points for the creature.
Attacks: Describes the type and bonus of the creature’s most
commonly used attacks. The number before the attack is the
skill bonus that the creature uses, and then the name or type
of attack, and that is followed by the attack’s Damage Rating
and type of the attack, listed in parenthesis. The number is
the amount of Hit Point damage that the attack deals, to be
multiplied by the number of Success Levels earned in the
attack. The letter or combination of letters after the number
tells you the type of damage:
•• b = Bash
•• s = Slash
•• p = Pierce
•• g = Grab/Grapple, successful attack means target
is also Held
•• ec = elemental cold damage
•• ee = elemental electrical damage
•• eh = elemental heat/fire damage
If more than one letter is given, the attack deals both types
of damage, and the target attacks uses his best AR type against
the attack. For example, many Bite attacks do both pierce and
slash damage. The target of the attack would use whichever
AR was better (S or P) against the attack, not both.
If an attack is preceded by an asterisk (*) symbol, then the
creature can perform this attack as a Free Action immediately
after the preceeding attack scores a hit that does Critical
Damage (i.e. An attack that does 1 or more Success Levels).

If the creature can do multiple attacks of a given type,
that will be include within the parenthesis as well. For
example, an attack followed by (x2) would mean that the
creature can make up to two different Attack Rolls with the
same Attack Action when using that attack.
Some creatures will not give specific types of attacks,
but instead give generalized types of attacks if no specific
attack or Combat Skill is given.
•• Melee: The creature has one or two melee combat
skills, and use this skill bonus for that.
•• Rock: This does not mean just rocks, but any thrown
weapon, most of which will be improvised. The
damage given is based on the creature’s strength.
Special: This is an indicator of whether the creature has any
special abilities, which would be more fully described
in the text for the creature.
If the special says Spells, then you should use the Knw
skill as the general bonus for casting spells. You should
also consider that the creature knows at least 1 Spell per
level that it has, but never more than 2 Spell per level.
Skills: This is given as a reference for the average Skill Bonus the
creature has when using any Skills from the corresponding
Skill Category: Rog = Roguery, Adv = Adventuring, Knw
= Knowledge. Please note that the GM is free to both
modify these values for a particularly skilled/unskilled
specimen, or apply a bonus or penalty to the number
listed to better reflect the creature’s specific Skills.

Creature Descriptions

This section provides any other information that you might
need about the creature.
As part of the description, along with height, length and
weight and such, we will also present the creature’s Size (Sz). This
is useful due to some skills or effects being based on the size of
the creature in comparison to that of the players. The following
list provides the basic Sizes that we use, and a rough guide to
what those Sizes are. Please be aware that we take into account
more than just height or length in determining Size.
•• Trivial: <6”; (+10 Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Tiny)
•• Miniscule: 6”-1.5’; (+6 Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ than
size Small)
•• Tiny: 1’-3’; (+3 Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Medium)
•• Small: 2.5’-4’; (+1 Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Large)
•• Medium: 3.5’-7’; (+2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Huge)
•• Large: 6’-12’; (-1 Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size Colossal)
•• Huge: 10’-18’; (-4 Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size
Gigantic)
•• Colossal: 15’-25’; (-8 Stealth; +2 AB/DM vs. foes ≥ size
Monstrous)
•• Gigantic: 20’-35’ (-12 Stealth;)
•• Monstrous: >30’ (-15 Stealth;)

Special Abilities
Many creatures have special abilities, representing unusual
skills, traits, or innate powers that can give them an edge (or
put them at a disadvantage) in certain situations. Each special
ability has a name and a short description of its effects.

Animals are creatures of the natural world that evolve and
develop on their own. Some creatures listed here may have some
minor elemental abilities while others are much larger tha you
might expect, but for our purposes, they are natural creatures.

Ants, Giant — Sz: Tiny, 2’-4’ length, 12”-18” tall, 30-

35 lbs, 3-30 per satellite colony, 10-40 in a Queen’s nest,
Encountered: 2-20
Giant Ants are omnivores, eating anything that they
can find. What they do not eat for themselves, they will

Failure by Banded Ant Poison Effects

6-10

Victim is unconscious as the poison ravages their system. They will

235

send back to their Queen’s nest. If you find a nest, you can
always expect to find others within a dozen miles or so.
Army Ants: The most common type of Giant Ant is the
brown worker or Army Ant. They have no special abilities
other than the ability to work together against larger foes.
Banded Ants: Banded Ants are called such because their
heads and their tails are a solid black while their central
sections are a dark brown. These are the only type of
Giant Ant that have a stinger on their tails, and they use it
to deliver a powerful poison.
Fire Ants: These ants a deep, dark red in color. They are not
poisonous like their cousins, the Banded Ants, but they are
in some ways even more dangerous. For one thing, Fire
Ants are able to spit a small ball of a viscous substance that
will burst into flame upon contact with the air. This attack
has a range of 3 meters (10 feet) normally.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Frost Ants: This type of ant is a bluish-white in color, and
like the Fire Ants, they do not posess a stinger. These
ants do produce and spit out a small jet of liquid that
will freeze what it touches. This jet of liquid has a range
of 3 meters (10 feet).

Beetle, Giant — Sz: Large, 4’-7’ body, 4”-8” pincers,

500-600 lbs, Encountered: 1-5
The bodies of Giant Beetles are covered in a hard
chitinous shell that often has a semi-metalic, opalescent
sheen in a multitude of colors. This sometimes leads to
them to be called Rainbow Beetles. Some varieties will
have but a single color, and this often gives them names
relating to those colors. Names such as Bronzeback,
Silverback, Copperback, Onyxback, Jadeback, or other
stranger names.
However, regardless of the name that they are called
by, they are all generally the same type of beetle, and
they are all poisonous through their bites. The poison
delivered by their bite is much more powerful than one
would think (Level 6). When bitten, the target must make
a TSR. The severity of the effects depend upon how much
they have failed the Save by.
Giant Beetles are omnivorous, meaning that they
will eat anything that they can tear their pinchers into,
even people. It is not unusual to see up to 5 of these
creatures working together to take down larger prey.
You can usually find Giant Beetles in rocky, wooded
terrains, from temperate to tropical. Their coloration
seems to depend upon their locale and diet, and has
been known to change as they age as well, becoming a
richer, deeper and more burnished hue.

Shock Ants: These ants are a yellowish-brown in color, and
they also do not have a stinger. When agitated, you can
see sparks of electricity sparking between their manibles.
When very agitated, these sparks can arc out to a
range of 2 meters (6 feet) to attack foes. Against foes
in metal armor, the range is actually 5 meters (15
feet). Multiple Shock Ants can combine their attacks,
increasing the range by 1 meter (3 feet) for each ant
beyond the first assisting in the attack.
Each additional ant involved in the attack also
increases the Damage Rating by 2 points as well.

Ape, Giant — Sz: Large, 10’-12’ tall, 1,000-1,200 lbs,

5-15 per nest, 2-4 young per nest, Encountered: 1-10
Giant Apes are territorial within their given range.
They normally favor tropical and subtropical forest
in the foothills surrounding mountains. They are
omnivores, preferring fruits, but not above eating meat.
Giant Apes live in extended family groups, the
largest male being the leader, with have the troop being
female, and the rest being children of various ages.
They only fight if they feel threatened, and will do
so by bashing with their fists, either singly or doubled.
They will also throw rocks and bite if their foe seems
tougher. As with their smaller cousins, they will also
use threat displays such as pounding on their chests
or on the ground and tearing nearby foilage to scare
intruders away whenever possible.

Failed By Giant Beetle Poison Results

Bear, Large — Sz: Large, 5’-9’ long, 400-600 lbs, 50% of

1-4 cubs if encountering a mated pair, Encountered: 1-5
Bears are always very problematic when they are
encountered. They are covered in a tough hide that is
covered in a thick coat of fur. Bears have short legs, but
are much quicker than many might think.
During cold months, bears tend to hibernate, but
they rarely sleep the entire winter long, so it is possible
to encounter them even then. When active, they will
often
supplement
their diet of meat
with a wide variety of
vegetation, especially
fruits and nuts.
Some examples of
Large Bears include
the Grizzly, Kodiak,
Black, larger Brown,
and Polar.

Mild Effect: Begins in 1d10 rounds. The victim is in great

6-10

all actions) with the main effects beginning in 1d10 hours. The
victim dies in massive pain as their internal organs turn to jelly.

Boar, Small — Sz: Medium, 3’-5’ length, 250-400 lbs,
2-10 piglets, Encountered: 2-20
Boars are the ancestors of domesticated pigs. Wild boars
differ from their tame relatives by having a large bristled
stripe of hair down their backs and by their two upward
curving tusks jutting out of their lower jaws.
While they do not look like it due to their heavy bodies,
boars are quite nimble and speedy, running on their thin
legs. Their two-toed hooves are also very sharp as well.
Boars will feed off almost anything, including carrion.
However, they will also use their long tusks to dig up their dinner.
Boars will attack if startled or if protecting themselves
or the piglets that may be accomanying them. Boars are
anywhere from 1-2 meters (3-6 feet) in length.
Boars can most often be found in temperate and more
northern forests, especially heavy forests where they can
roam freely and find safe locations for their families.

236

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Cat —
­ Lesser: Sz: Medium, 2’-3’ long, 75-200 lbs, 1-4 young;

Greater: Sz: Large, 4’-10’ long, 250-700 lbs, 1-4 young;
Encountered (either type): 1-2
The feline body type is both very powerful and
very flexible in nature and both types of Large Cat are
considered to be very efficient killing machines.
Both types of Large Cats are predators, eating meat
as their regular diet. They are also both great and
stalking and ambushing their prey, whether it be on
the plains or dropping from the branches above what
it hunts. They often kill using their powerful bites
for smaller prey, and using both their bite and claws
against larger prey.
Lesser Large Cats include those such as the Bobcat,
Cheetah, Caracal, Lynx, Mountain Lion, Ocelot, Serval
and Wild Cat. Greater Large Cats include the Cougar,
Jaguar, Leopard, Lion, Tiger, and Snow Leopard.

Dog — Small: Sz: Tiny, 8”-15” long, 10-40 lbs, 1-5 young,

Encountered (wild): 1-10; Large: Sz: Medium, 3’-5’
long, 60-150 lbs, 1-5 young, Encountered (wild): 2-20
There are a number of types of dogs. They were the
first animal demosticated by man. They are generally
recognized by their long muzzles and large triangular
ears, usually erect. Dogs are effective hunters, often using
their quick speed and endurance to wear down prey.
Wild variants include foxes, coyotes, dingos and jackals.
Some of the domesticated varieties include the following:
Hound: Bred for hunting small and medium sized game,
either to flush the game out or to retrieve it if it is
smaller game.
Ratter: This is a small terrier type of dog that is trained
to go into small tunnels after rats and other rodents.
Sheepdog: This is a relatively larger dog who is good are
helping herd sheep, goats and other livestock.
Wolfhound: This is a very large dog that has been bred to go
after wolves and other large animals that prey on livestock.

Donkey — Sz: Large, 2’6”-5’8” at the withers (shoulder), 180-

1,100 lbs, 1 young, Encountered: 1-20, Capacity: 250 lbs
While this animal is related to the horse, it is smaller
and is considered a working animal, which means that
it is used for performing jobs rather than for its meat.
Donkeys have a good weight hauling capability for
their size, but they are often considered obstinate and
this may make them less than ideal for certain tasks.

Coinyn (rabbet) — Sz: Miniscule, 10”-30” long, 8-16 lbs,

7-15 young, Encountered: 1-20
Coinyn are small mammals, adapted for rapid
movement. They have long hind legs, with four toes
on each foot, and shorter fore legs, with five toes each.
The soles of their feet are hairy, to improve grip while
running, and they have strong claws on all of their toes.
They also have distinctive, elongated and mobile ears,
and they have an excellent sense of hearing. Their eyes
are large, and their night vision is good, reflecting their
primarily nocturnal or twilight mode of living.
Coinyn are herbivores, eating grasses and other plants,
although they also eat leaves, fruit, and seeds of various
kinds. This makes them the bane of farmers everywere,
which also makes them often treated as vermin if
their populations get too large. Coinyn are also often
considered a food source for many, which also helps to
keep their populations under control.

Falcon — Sz: Tiny, 15”-28” long, 1-4 lbs, 30”-48” wingspan,
3-5 eggs, Encountered: 1-2
Falcons are known for their incredible speed and
ability to catch prey in the air. They are fierce birds
of prey and often hunt Coinyn and small rodents and
birds. They are highly prized as pets for the wealthy
and powerful.

Frog, Giant — Sz: Large, 5’-6’ long, 3’-4’ tall, 200-235 lbs,

Deer — Sz: Medium, 24”- 50” tall at the shoulder, 3’-6’ in

length, 150-530 lbs, 1-2 young, Encountered: 1-10
Typical of deer include long, powerful legs, a diminutive
tail and long ears. Deer exhibit a broad variation in physical
proportions. Only male deer have antlers, which are shed
on a yearly basis. The types of deer encompassed by this
description include White-Tailed, Mule Deer, Black-Tailed
and Red Deer. Deer are herbivores and tend to prefer wild
fields and forests as their homes.

1-10 young, Encountered: 2-10
Giant Frogs looks just like their normal sized cousins.
These amphibious creatures live almost exclusively in
dismal swamps and along lake shores where the ground
is super saturated and muddy. Giant Frogs have habits
similar to those of their smaller cousins. They feast on
giant insects and small creatures like rats and Coinyn and
the occassional small deer. However, they are no above
going after larger prey at times.
They attack using their 3 meter (10 feet) long tongues
to grapple and pull prey to them. They then bite them with
jaws that are as powerful as any lion or other large predator.
They will also attack any that they feel are poaching upon
their territory.

Garm (Riding Wolf) — Sz: Medium, 3’-5’ long, 120-150 lbs,
1-5 young, Encountered (wild): 2-20, Capacity: 180 lbs
This is a type of large heavy wolf that has been especially
trained to be a mount for Gnomes and Dwelfs. These
types of mounts are rare and hard to come by. Garm are
also taught to hunt for themselves at night, if given the
command to allow them to do so. This command allows
the Garm to range up to 2 miles from camp to hunt for
food. Garm are also intelligent mounts, able to detect and
warn their riders of danger that they can sense.

Goat — Sz: Small, 16”-23” at the shoulder, 50-150 lbs, 1-2

young, Encountered (wild): 2-20
Goats are a very versatile type of livestock as there
are many different breeds of goat. Some breeds have
a coat that is made into yarn for knitting clothing,
others give milk and provide meat in a manner similar
to cattle. They also are used for leather as well. Goats
can survive in almost any terrain, and can eat a wide
variety of things, including certain kinds of tree bark.

Mature Pony — Sz: Medium, 4’-5’ tall, 700-800 lbs, 1

young, Capacity: 180 lbs, Encountered (wild): 5-50
Ponies are essentially a small horse. It sometimes
has a thicker coat but its head, barrel and legs are fully
proportionate. Many Dvargr (Dwarves) prefer ponies
over horses because they are closer to the ground. Ponies
also tend to get used for smaller buggies.

Horse — Cart/Plow: Sz: Large, 6’-8’, 900-1,400 lbs, 1 young,

Capacity: 450 lbs; Light: Sz: Large, 6’-7’, 800-1,100 lbs,
1 young, Capacity: 200 lbs; Medium: Sz: Large, 7’-8’,
900-1,200 lbs, 1-2 young, Capacity: 300 lbs; Heavy: Sz:
Huge, 8’-9’, 1,000-1,200 lbs, 1-2 young, Capacity: 350
lbs; Warhorse: Sz: Huge, 7’-9’, 1,000-1,400 lbs, 1 young,
Capacity: 400 lbs; Encountered (wild): 5-50
Horses are large animals that are adapted to run.
They also have an excellent sense of balance and
a strong flight or fight response. Horse breeds are
usually loosely divided into three broad categories
based on temperament. Those referred to as hot bloods
tend to have high speeds and endurances, race horses
and those used by couriers. Those referred to as cold
bloods are those suited to slow or heavy work, such as
plowing fields or hauling wagons. And finally, there
are the ones referred to warm bloods. Those of this
last group are bred for specific purposes, such as war
horses or the mounts used by adventurers.

Mule — Sz: Large, 6’-7’ tall, 850-1,000 lbs, 1 young,
Capacity: 250 lbs, Encountered (wild): 2-20
A Mule is the offspring of a male donkey and a female
horse. Mules are more patient, hardy, and long-lived
than horses, and are described as slightly less obstinate
and much more intelligent than donkeys.

Oxen/Cows/Bulls — Sz: Large, 6’-12’ long, 4’-6’ tall,

Korex — Sz: Huge, 10’-12’ long, 800-1,200 lbs, 1-2 eggs,

700-1,200 lbs, 1-2 calves, Encountered (wild): 20-200
A group of cows are often referred to as cattle.
They are raised for their milk and meat. Most of the
common sorts of leather are made from cow hide.
Cows are also all female. Oxen are bulls that have been
castrated. Oxen tend to be used more as draft animals.

Capacity: 400 lbs, Encountered (wild): 5-30
It has a head that resembles that of a dragon, though
the two are not related. The Korex is an herbivore, but
can eat many different things in a manner similar to
a goat. Korex are used primarily by the Odavi as a
mount, since it looks fierce and also has the spikes on
its head and its claws to protect itself. Over the course
of the last 20 to 30 years, the Odavi have been trading
them into Cymbri in increasing numbers as they are
just as sturdy as horses, but less likely to be spooked
than horses.

Pig — Sz: Medium, 3’-5’ length, 250-400 lbs, 2-10 piglets, Sheep — Sz: Medium, 4’-6’ long, 100-350 lbs, 1-2 young,
Encountered: 2-20
Pigs or hogs as they are sometimes called are kept
as a source of meat called pork. Pigs also seem to be
related to wild boars, a much more dangerous cousin
that is also often hunted for meat as well.

Rat, Giant — Sz: Small, 3’-4’ long, 40-60 lbs, 2-10 young,

Encountered: 2-10
Giant Rats, on the other hand, tend to start off
about that length and can reach up to 2 meters (6 and
a half feet) in length if they have good diets. And that
does not include their tails, which tend to be about
half the length of their bodies. Giant Rats will eat
almost anything.
This will make them especially dangerous when
food supplies are short, since they are large enough
to take out a full grown human when one on one,
presuming that the human is unarmed or even just
lightly armed.

Encountered (wild): 1-10
This is a herbivorous animal with a thick wooly coat
that is often sheared off to make into yarn and then on into
clothing. They are sometimes used for food as well, but the
meat from a full grown sheep has a different flavor from
that of lambs.

Scorpion, Giant — Sz: Large, 4’-6’ long body, tail:

same length as body, but stretch 50% longer, 12”-18”
pincers, 150-200 lbs, 10-20 young, Encountered: 1-2
The Giant Scorpion is an extremely large predatory
arachnid. It is well known for hunting large prey, including
those of mannish size or larger. They use the stingers on
their tails both offensively and defensively.
Giant Scorpions have adapted to all but the coldest
climates, though they seem to prefer drier locations such
as deserts, or bad lands, they are not limited to such.
They are mean and sneaky, and will literally walk
up to prey and attack it visciously, and then back away
and wait for their poison to take effect. Their stinger
contains a 6th level poison, the effects of which are
described below.
Giant Scorpions are sometimes called Harvestmen,
since they always take their prey away with them after
killing them.
Their carapace contains flourescent compounds that
will literally glow under certain types of light. Some
Kins, such as Dwarves and Gnomes, have created other
compounds, that when poured on a chunk of Scorpion
carapace as big as a man’s fist, will cause it to glow as
brightly as a torch for up to 4 hours.

Failed By
