Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Created Undead (I) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1-30 Ghoul (I) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1-10
Special Abilities: Ghouls have the following abilities:
•• Fearsome Visage: All those who see the Ghoul must
make a WSR vs the Ghoul’s level or become Frightened.
•• Ghoul Rot: If subject to Critical Damage from an
attack, the character must make TSR agains Ghoul’s
level or suffer from Ghoul Rot, turning into Ghoul after
a week of severe illness, followed by death.
•• Sunlight Allergy: Ghouls take 2-20 Hits per Round
when in direct sunlight. 1-5 Hits per Round when in
indirect sunlight.
A Ghoul like an emancipated corpse with long,
sharp teeth and nails that look like claws. Ghouls
tend to be found near graveyards and burial grounds,
feasting on any corpses that they can find. They are
not above attacking the living to provide a corpse for
them to feed on.

These Undead are sometimes referred to as
Shamblers since they are so slow moving and clumsy.
Their uncoordinated state also means that anything
more than open terrain or stairs will be too complicated
and if when they fall, they will just continue to crawl
towards their targets. Their senses are also degraded so
that they cannot hear anything below a normal talking
volume, but vision, although cloudy, will be the same
that they had while alive.

Created Undead (II) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1-20
This Type of Undead are often called Walkers since
they are faster and more coordinated than the Type
I Undead. They can even negotiate ladders, and will
even open closed doors if they are unlocked.

Fire Phantom (III) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1
Special Abilities: Fire Phantoms have the following abilities:
•• Non-Corporeal: Only affected by magical weapons, or
weapons coated in Holy Water or Oil.
•• Soul Damage: Any attack that does damage will
require TSR against the Fire Phantom’s level or it will
do 1 Point of Soul Damage (p. 219).
•• Susceptibility: Immersion in water will destroy this
Undead.
Killed by fire, these Undead are encased in the flames
that killed them. They are attracted to any flames like a
moth to a candle. They will then attempt to engulf new
victime in a desperate plea for relief.

Mara (II) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1
Special Abilities: Mara have the following abilities:
•• Non-Corporeal: Only affected by magical weapons, or
weapons coated in Holy Water or Oil.
•• Life Drain: All within a 10’ radius must make a TSR
against the level of the Mara each Round or lose 1d10 Hits
•• Nightmares: Can bring nightmares (TSR vs Mara’s
level to resist) to those who hear its ethereal music,
preventing all restorative benefits of sleep.
When they were alive, the beings who become Mara
were gifted in music. In death, they play eerie ballads
on their ghostly instruments that bring nightmares to
all those sleeping within 100’ radius without waking
them if they fail their Save. If any resist, and awaken,
the Mara will flee to avoid discovery.

Ghost (II) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1
Special Abilities: Ghosts have the following abilities:
•• Non-Corporeal: Only affected by magical weapons, or
weapons coated in Holy Water or Oil.
•• Life Drain: All within a 10’ radius must make a TSR
against the level of the Ghost each Round or lose 1d10 Hits.
•• Susceptibility: Every Ghost has a physical focus such
as their remains or an item that they were attached
to. Destroying that focus and burning its remains will
destroy the Ghost.
Quite often, the only clue that a Ghost is an undead
creature is a slight haziness that blurs their image.
Many go about the
same actions that
they performed in
life, or they search for
something, they know
not, endlessly, often
unwittingly hurting
those around them.

Mummy (III) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1-2

275

Special Abilities: Mummies have the following abilities:
•• Susceptible: Takes double damage from fire-based
attacks. Receives a -5 to all fire and heat based Saves.
Mummies are the spirits of the unquiet dead
returned to their embalmed remains and secured
by many layers of specially prepared wrappings.
Mummies are often used to guard the tombs and
crypts where they were buried. They were often a
regular feature added to necropolises built to house
multiple dead.
Mummies fight by using their fist to bash their foes,
or to grab and crush them in their powerful arms.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Shade (II) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1

Vampyri (II) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1-3

Special Abilities: Shades have the following abilities:
•• Non-Corporeal: Only affected by magical weapons, or
weapons coated in Holy Water or Oil.
•• Trance Field: All within a 10’ radius must make a WSR
vs the Shade’s level or fall into a trance for 1d10 Rounds.
•• Blood Drinker: Shades will bite victims who are in a trance
and drink their blood at a rate of 2d10 Hits per Round.
Shades are, in essence, a living shadow. Their form
is a dark reflection of what it was when they were alive,
except for the gauzy shadow wings that they now have.
Their Undead form has also granted them shadow
fangs all the better to attack and consume the life
blood of the living.

Skeleton (II) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1-10
Special Abilities: Skeletons have the following abilities:
•• Soul Drain: After spending 6 Rounds (30 seconds) in the
presence of Skeleton, all those within a 10’ radius must
make a TSR each round or take 1 point of Soul Damage.
•• Susceptible: Takes double damage from fire-based
attacks. Damage from fire does not heal.
These animated skeletons have little to no flesh on
their bones. They are often given weapons, shields and
more rarely armor to serve as guardians. If they have
none of these, they will still attack using the claw-like
tips of their hands.
When wielding weapons, Skeleton Fighters will
more often than not use either a Short Sword (8s/7p)
or a Short Spear (7s/10p) along with a full shield.
Skeletons do not wear armor normally. Their AR
ratings represent how hard they are able to be hurt by
slashing and piercing weapons.

Specter (II) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1
Special Abilities: Specters have the following abilities:
•• Non-Corporeal: Only affected by magical weapons, or
weapons coated in Holy Water or Oil.
•• Fear Aura: All those within 100’ radius of a Specter
must make a WSR against its level of be Frightened.
•• Soul Damage: Any melee attack that does Critical
Damage will require TSR against the Specter’s level or it
will do 1 Point of Soul Damage (p. 219).
These transluscent spirits have a cold white light
where their eyes used to be. They also wrap their noncorporeal forms in tattered cloaks.
Their presence is heralded by the fear that preceeds
them and its fading signals their leaving. Specters were
once mortals whose lust for power and evil kept them
tied to the lands of the living.
Specters are also able to throw a small thunderbolt
to attack at range.

276

Special Abilities: Vampyri have the following abilities:
•• Blood Drinker: Vampyri will bite victims and drink
their blood at a rate of 2d10 Hits per Round.
•• Hypnotic Gaze: A Vampyri may attempt to magically
hypnotize a target. He must spend a full round staring
into the eyes of his target, who then gets a WSR against the
Vampyri’s level to resist. If hypnotized, the victim will obey
the commands of the Vampyri. Commands to cause harm to
oneself allow the victim another WSR, with a +5 modifier.
•• Susceptibility: May be killed by decapitation or by
driving a wooden stake through the Vampyri’s heart.
•• Sunlight Allergy: Vampyri take 2-20 Hits per round
when in direct sunlight. 1-5 Hits per round when in
indirect sunlight.
•• Supernatural Toughness: Non-magical weapons only do
half damage. Silvered or magical weapons do full damage.
The Vampyri, or the Vampire Spawn as they are
sometimes called, is among the weakest of the various
types of vampires. They are what normal mortals
become when they have been turned by a more powerful
vampire. And it will take the Vampyri decades to progress
to becoming one of the more powerful types.
Luckily, Vampyri cannot shape-shift or cast spells
like many more powerful types of vampires. Vampyri
tend to spend their time learning and then branching
out on their own and establishing their own feeding
grounds. Luckily, Vampyri cannot create new vampires
or the world might be overrun as Vampyri also tend to
have massive egos and that sometimes leads them to
take foolish risks.
Smarter Vampyri will often move from town to
town, feeding, but not killing their victims, so as to not
arouse suspicion.
In combat, Vampire Spawn can near instantly grow
long sharp claws that they use for attacking, eschewing
the need for such crutches as weapons.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Wight (IV) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1

Zombie (I) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 2-20

Special Abilities: Wights have the following abilities:
•• Non-Corporeal: Only affected by magical weapons, or
weapons coated in Holy Water or Oil.
•• Fear Aura: All those within 100’ radius of a Specter
must make a WSR against its level of be Frightened.
•• Cold Aura: All within a 10’ radius will take 1d10 Hits
of damage from the cold that a Wight radiates.
•• Soul Damage: Any attack that does Critical Damage
will require TSR against the Wight’s level or it will do 1
Point of Soul Damage (p. 219).
Wights are tied to graves, be they burial crypts or
barrows from long ago. They are unable to leave them, and
thus must protect these homes of the dead for all time.
Their vague, translucent forms flicker with a wicked
gleam, and their stern, emancipated visages promise a
death that their weapons are quick to fullfil.

Wraith (IV) — Sz: Medium, Encountered: 1
Special Abilities: Wraiths have the following abilities:
•• Non-Corporeal: Only affected by magical weapons, or
weapons coated in Holy Water or Oil.
•• Fear Aura: All those within 50’ radius of a Wraith must
make a WSR against its level of be Frightened.
•• Cold Aura: All within a 5’ radius will take 1d10 Hits of
damage from the cold that a Wraith radiates.
•• Soul Damage: Any attack that does Critical Damage
will require TSR against the Wraith’s level or it will do
1 Point of Soul Damage (p. 219).
These translucent, almost invisible beings are
distinguished by the red glow of their eyes. Wraiths
barely exist in the mortal world. Their weapons cross
this boundry as well, and if they achieve Critical
Damage, a tiny bit of that weapon is left within the
wound as well. These tiny fragments will turn those
affected into Wraiths upon their death unless they
are removed through magic that removes poisons or
curses. Nonmagically, the only cure is amputation.

277

Special Abilities: Zombies have the following abilities:
•• Brains: Zombies feed by eating the brains of those that
they kill. Doing so gives them an amount of life-force
(XP) equal to the Stamina of the person whose brain
they are eating.
•• Supernatural Toughness: Takes no damage from
bludgeoning weapons, takes full damage from edged
weapons.
•• Susceptibility: Zombies are susceptible to Holy Water
and Oils, fire and acid. Damage from these sources
cannot be regenerated.
•• Zombie Rot: when a person is bitten by a Zombie, he
must make a TSR against the Zombie’s level or he will
be afflicted with a disease that will eventually, over the
course of a week, turn the victim into another Zombie.
Naturally occurring Zombies are extremely rare
and have only one goal, to survive. They do that by
consuming the brains of anything that they kill. The
more brains that they eat, the more powerful that the
Zombie will become.
In appearance, Zombies look much like they did
in life, however, their bodies will be in varying states
of decay and decomposition, and their hair will be
stringy and the nails on their hands will be long,
yellow and claw-like.
Zombies do not use weapons when attacking,
they will bludgeon their foes with their fists or tear at
them with their claws, which are surprisingly strong
considering the condition of the rest of them.

Centaur — Sz: Large, 5’-6’ tall, 5’-6’ long, 300-500 lbs,

Goblin — Sz: Small, 3’6”-4’5” tall, 90-120 lbs,

Special Abilities: Centaurs have the following abilities:
•• Night Sight: As decribed on p. 205.
•• Animal Tongue: Centaurs are able to converse with
Horses and similar creatures.
Centaurs are curious beings, being almost Human
in appearance from the waist up, while from the waist
down, they have the full body of a small horse.
Centaurs prefer to live in areas where open fields
and rolling hills meet with thick forests. This allows
them both protection from outsiders while still giving
them the space to run. Centaurs usually stay away from
larger towns and cities, preferring their self-imposed
isolation to mixing with the other races, although
there are always exceptions.
Centaurs are extremely wary of outsiders who visit
their homelands, to the point of near paranoia until the
strangers have proven themselves to be friendly in some
manner. In fact, many Centaur communities would rather
that strangers never enter their villages. The majority of
Centaurs keep areas set aside on their borders specifically
for trading with outsiders, and get very antagonistic to any
who enter their lands without permission.
When in combat, Centaurs rarely wear more
than soft leather armor, preferring the freedom of
movement over any additional protection that heavier
armors can provide. However, Centaurs will almost
always employ a full shield when in melee. The shields
are often designed to be easily attached to the weapon
harness that they wear when they are employing their
bows. This harness also holds a special scabbard that
they can slide their bows into, and two full quivers of
arrows, with the space to add up to 2 more quivers,
though that would make is extremely crowded.

Special Abilities: Goblins have the following abilities:
•• Night Sight: As decribed on p. 205.
•• Animal Tongue: Can speak the language of one type of
animal, usually the language of their mounts.
•• Acute Hearing: Gain +5 to hearing related Perception rolls.
•• Geo-Awareness: Goblins always know which direction
they are facing or travelling.
Goblins are green-skinned humanoid creatures
with slightly oversized heads and eyes with spindly
limbs and long pointy ears. Their eyes are a bright
yellow. They dress in soft leathers and use simple
weapons like spears and small bows.
Goblins are a tribal people, ruled by the strongest;
usually a Hobgoblin or other being that has come in and
dominated them. They are cruel and vicious and like to
dominate those who are weaker than them, just as they
are often dominated by those who are stronger. Goblins
are not overly brave, and usually will not attack unless
they believe that they can win or if they are forced to.
Goblins usually live in underground warrens, and
their Geo-Awareness helps to keep them from getting
lost in their subterranean tunnels and caverns. When
they do leave the caverns, they usually ride specially bred
wolves or boars that are large enough to use as mounts.
Goblin tribes are fiercely competitive, often warring
between one another, unless there is a common foe
and a strong leader who can unite them.

Encountered: 1-10

Encountered: 1-10

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Hobgoblin — Sz: Medium, 4’6”-5’5” tall, 125-175 lbs, Lizardman — Sz: Medium, 6’-7’ tall, 200-300 lbs,
Encountered: 3-12

Encountered: 1-6

Special Abilities: Lizardmen have the following abilities:
•• Dark Sight: As decribed on p. 206.
•• Natural Weapons: Posess both claws and a tail whose
length is half the height of the Lizardman.
Lizardmen are rarely found in other than the warmer
and hotter climes that they are so well suited for. They
often prefer locations that others rarely travel to; such
as swamps, rocky deserts, and other similar locales;
desiring to avoid other peoples whenever possible.
Lizardmen often prefer to use simple weapons,
such as spears, allowing them to attack from a slightly
further distance than their tails or claws would
normally allow. With their built-in claws and tail,
many Lizardmen rarely learn how to use standard
melee weapons, though some may do just that to be
able to utilize weapons from captured foes.
In most cases, Lizardmen live in a tribal environment,
in settlements that are often hidden from outsiders in
some way. They dislike and distrust outsiders and will
rarely tolerate intruders in their territories.
While Lizardmen can run the gamut of potential
types of personalities and outlooks, just like any other
people, it often seems that they do tend to frequently
fall prey to clerics and shamans of the variety that
worships the darker gods more than any other.

Special Abilities: Hobgoblins have the following abilities:
•• Night Sight: As decribed on p. 205.
•• Animal Tongue: Can speak the language of one type of
animal, usually the language of their mounts.
•• Acute Hearing: Gain +5 to hearing related Perception rolls.
•• Geo-Awareness: Hobgoblins always know which direction
they are facing or travelling.
It is rumored that Hobgoblins were the result of
breeding between Orcs and Goblins, but scholars have
been unable to prove this. Other scholars think that they
are a completely separate Kin, or that they are a sub-type
of Goblins, kind of like the relationship between High
Elves and Wood Elves. As with the Goblin/Orc half-breed
theory, there is no proof either way.
What is known is that Hobgoblins are larger than
Goblins and that their skin is a mottled yellowish
orange in color. But other than that, they are amazingly
similar to Goblins.
It is not uncommon to find individual Hobgoblins
ruling over groups of Goblins. Scholars who compile
such information tell us that no adventurers have
reported finding any groups that are comprised solely
of Hobgoblins.

Kobold — Sz: Small, 3’5”-4’ tall, 50-70 lbs,
Encountered: 1-6

Special Abilities: Kobolds have the following abilities:
•• Night Sight: As decribed on p. 205.
•• Natural Weapons: Kobolds have claws on their hands.
Kobolds are a smaller Kin with a canine-shaped face
and they are covered in reddish-brown scales which
makes their skin tougher to penetrate than one might
normally think. They are extremely cunning and
dangerous. They have a great understanding of how to
build and use traps to their advantage.
Many see them as cowardly, but in truth, they
simply do not wish to throw their lives away without
reason. Kobolds are also very vengeful, and have been
known to track foes for weeks on end waiting for the
perfect moment to wreak havoc on the plans of their
foe, whether that be alerting another enemy of his foe
to that foe’s presence, or attacking him in a moment of
extreme vulnerability.

Lyrani — Sz: Medium, 5’-7’ tall, 150-250 lbs,

279

Encountered: 2-10

Special Abilities: Lyrani have the following abilities:
•• Dark Sight: As decribed on p. 206.
•• Natural Weapons: Lyrani have retractable claws on
their hands. And their toes have short, sharp talons.
Dwelling among the forests that edge large plains,
the Lyrani have a decided feline appearance, including
their ears. Their bodies are covered in short fur, in
many different shades,and many have long thing tail
that flicks from side to side behind them.
While the Lynari wear clothing, they do not wear boots
or shoes since the soles of their feet as tough and shaped
more like those of a large cat than most humanoids. If
they wear armor, they won’t wear anything heavier than
soft leather usually as they find that the natural toughness
of their hide is often enough.
The bloody custom of a duel to the death remains
an acceptable way to settle social differences among the
Lyrani. The fighting instincts of a predator lurk behind
the civilized manners that characterize most Lyrani. In
addition to their natural weaponry (a set of claws on
each hand), these felines are adept and normal melee
weapons and missile weapons.

Troglodyte — Sz: Medium, 4’6”-5’6” tall, 90-200 lbs, Zephyr — Sz: Medium, 4’-5’ tall, 10’-15’ wingspan, 75Encountered: 2-12
Special Abilities: Troglodytes have the following abilities:
•• Dark Sight: As decribed on p. 206.
•• Stench: When angry or afraid, Troglodytes release a
powerful odor, that requires all within a 30’ radius to
make an 8th level TSR or be nauseated (-4 to all actions)
for 1 Round for each point that the Save is failed by.
•• Natural Weapons: Troglodytes have claws on their hands.
•• Mild Camoflage: Troglodytes are able to change the
pigmentation of their scaly skin much like a chameleon,
gaining a +3 to Stealth when holding still, +6 if in
shadow or against natural rock.
Dwelling in deeper caves, Troglodytes fear sunlight, but
are not harmed by it, so it is possible for them to operate
outside of the caves where they make their homes.
These reptilian creatures have small stocky bodies
and spindly limbs. They have a number of small spikes
on their heads and line of them running down their
backs and their long, thin, whip-like tails.
Common tactics for Troglodytes is for them to hurl
spears or javelins at foes and then close for combat.
Should they appear to be losing, they will release their
stench, and then break off and attempt to flee and hide.

Ursoc — Sz: Medium, 6’-7’ tall, 250-35 lbs,
Encountered: 4-12

Special Abilities: Ursoc have the following abilities:
•• Night Sight: As decribed on p. 205.
•• Natural Weaponry: Ursoc have natural claws.
•• Acute Senses: Ursoc gain +3 to both scent and hearing
based Perception rolls.
Tales of Ursoc, often referred to as Bugbears, are
used by rural folk to scare their children. However,
these tales are based on some truth, for the Ursoc are a
savage people that live in some of the roughest terrain
imaginable. They cling to a strong tribal culture where
the strongest warrior is their leader.
Ursoc often employ rough broadswords or falchions
and sturdy Round Shields when in melee, preferring
short bows for ranged combat. They reserve their claws
for use as a secondary weapon, and for duels of honor.
Ursoc are extremely territorial, and even in this,
there are actually different degrees of territory. There
is the home lands, where the tribe lives, and then
there is the raiding lands, which acts as a buffer zone.
The combination of the two zones makes up about a
50-mile radius around the tribe’s village. The actual
distance may vary due to various terrain features. No
other tribe of Ursoc will make its village within this
zone unless they are willing to go to war with the tribe
already living within that zone.

130 lbs, Encountered: 1-10

Special Abilities: Zephyr have the following abilities:
•• Night Sight: As decribed on p. 205.
The Zephyri are a rare winged people. In appearance
they look like small, muscular humans, with wide
shoulders to support their wing structures.
But their image of strength is largely misleading, for
their bones are hollow, their lungs are huge, and their
muscles have a unique structure which makes them
very light.
All have golden brown skin and blonde or white
hair. Their wings are feathered, like that of a bird, with
many different colors of plumage possible. There are
rumors of sub-groups of Zephyri that have leathery
wings that are almost bat-like in appearance.
The Zephyri prefer to live at high altitudes,
especially among mountains with many cliffs that can
provide exciting crosswinds and updrafts.
Zephyri are able to fly at speeds of up to 50 miles per
hour (about 360 feet per Round) for short periods, for
5 minutes per rank that they have in their Body skill),
or at 25 miles per hour (about 180 feet per round) for
up to 30 minutes per rank in their Body skill.
This is exhausting though, so they also learn how
to glide for hours at a time by traveling the thermals
and updrafts. An adult Zephyr may carry up to half
his weight for short distances, but only at half their
normal speed.
Zephyris prefer polearms to other weapons, as they
can make strafing runs using them, and their wings
will not interfere like they do when attempting to use
missile weapons while aloft.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Treasure

When characters go adventuring, one of the primary
reasons for doing so is for finding treasures. The following
section will give you some guidelines for determining how
much treasure a foe might have based upon their level.
Animals and creatures will likely only have such treasure in
their lairs, if they brought prey back to their lairs to consume
them. Intelligent creatures and beings, such as Goblins and
Orcs, are much more likely to carry their treasure on them.
As GM, you should determine what treasure the creature
has before an encounter as intelligent creatures are quite
likely to be using any magic items that they might have that
are appropriate to them.
The following table gives the likelihood of a creature
having a given type of treasure based on its level, and if
so, how much treasure. However, we are not giving you
“random treasure tables” because it is felt that you, the GM,
should determine the actual items based upon your setting
and campaign and how rich you prefer the game to be.
Remember, this table is only meant as a guideline, and you,
the GM, should feel free to deviate from it as circumstances
require for your particular game.
It is also important to remember that this table is meant
for determining the wealth that an individual is carrying on
his person, or that can be found in the lair of a non-intelligent
creature. For intelligent creatures, such as Dragons, this table
is far from adequate and the GM should use his judgment in
determining what sorts of treasures might be found.

Treasure Table Key
Money (cp, bp, sp, gp, pp): These are the various types
of coins. They are listed on the table from lowest
denomination to the highest. Since copper pieces
are the lowest denomination of coin, it is presumed
that a character would only have a few of them on
his person, carrying the more common bronze piece
except for those few instances where copper is needed.
Gems: Valuable stones of any sort. Suggested total value of
all gems is one tenth of the Level in gold pieces of the
creature or character who has the stone(s) (i.e. 10th Level
would equate to 1 gp or 10 sp worth of gems). This value
should be divided among the number of gems found.
Jewelry: Various items created from precious stone and/
or metals. Suggested values for all pieces of jewelry
found are one fifth the Level of the creature or
character that has the item(s) in gold pieces. This
value should be divided among the number of pieces
of jewelry found.
Combat: This is armor, shields or weapons of a magical
nature. The “+” means that the item or items may
have higher than a +3 bonus to hit or damage, or that
it has bonuses to both, or that it might have other
additional abilities. The “++” means the item or items
definitely have additional capabilities in addition to
their bonuses.

1 Use Item: This is an herbal remedy, a potion, a scroll, or
some other item that is consumed by its usage.
Minor Item: This is an item that has an AP of 25 of less.
Major Item: This type of item has an AP of 26 to 40.
Artifact: Artifacts are items that have an AP of 41+ or higher.

Treasure Table Notes
There are two main types of entries on the Treasure Table.
The first is a basic dice notation (i.e. 2d10 or 2d10+5) which
means that you should roll the dice and that the result is how
much of that type of treasure the creature is likely to have.
The second notation (i.e. ≥15::1d10) has 2 parts, divided by
the double colon (::) symbol. The first part is the basic chance
of the creature having that type of treasure. A listing of “≥15”
means that you should roll 2d10 without any modifiers, and
if the total is 15 or greater, then the creature has that type of
treasure, and the section on the other side of the double colon
(i.e. the 1d10) is used to determine how much of that particular
type of treasure the creature has.
The Treasure Table included dice notations other than
d10, however the only dice that you will need in using the
Treasure Table are your d10s. The variant dice sizes can be
handled through the application of a little math as follows:
1d5: roll 1d10 and divide the result by 2, rounding up.
1d4: roll 1d5 and subtract 1 from the result. Any result of
0 should be treated as a result of 1.
1d3: roll 1d10 and divide the result by 3, rounding up.
Treat any result of “0” or “10” as a 3.
1d2: roll 1d10 and divide the result by 5, rounding up.

Attuning to Items

Fantasy Express incorporates the concept of the body
having 7 focal points of spiritual energy, or chakra as they
are sometimes called. When a character attunes to a magical
item, he is attuning it to one of these 7 chakra. This puts
a hard limit on the maximum number if items that the
character may attune to at 7.
To attune to an item, there are two possible methods. The
first requires the character carrying the item on his person for 7
days. This will allow the item to naturally attune to the character,
without him needing to make any skill rolls, presuming that he
does not already have 7 items attuned at the time.
The second method takes 1 minute of time spent
concentrating on the item, and requires succeeding at an
Arcana skill roll.
If the character opts to go for the roll, and fails it, he will
not be able to make another attempt to attune to this item,
either naturally or using his Arcana skill, until he increases
his number of ranks in the Arcana skill.
Attunement is only required for items that have spell or
spell-like abilities that can be activated. Single use items,
such as Scrolls, Potions, or even Charms or Talismans do
not require attuning to.
Items that provide a constant bonus or other effect, such
as weapon with a magical bonus or a pouch that preserves
any herb placed in it, also would not require attunement,
unless the item has other abilities that require activation,
and thus also require attunement.
If a character already is already attuned to 7 magial items,
and they pick up a new magical item, they will not be able to
attune to it, no matter how hard they try, unless they get rid
of one of the items they already had.
Many spell users will also use focus items when casting,
to help offset their Casting Modifiers. Unless the focus item
is also a magic item with other capabilities, it does not count
towards the limit of 7 attuned items.

282

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Herbal Elixirs

Sample Magic Items

The following are just a few sample magic items that the
GM can use when determining treasures for creatures and
other foes of the PCs.
For more information on how to create any of the
following sample items, please refer to the Alchemy 101 (p.
189) section.

Herbal Remedies

Herbal Remedies are fluid mixtures or salves that have
magical healing properties. They are generally made with
very little magic, using only what is required to enhance the
natural properties of the ingredients. Herbal Remedies can
usually be purchased for 1 sp per dose. If a given Herbal
Remedy costs more, it will be listed in the item’s description.
Aphrodisiac Antidote: Cures the drinker of love sickness.
Anti-parasitic: Rids the body of all parasites in about 5
minutes.

Herbal Elixirs fall between these Herbal Remedies and
Potions. They are made from herbal ingredients (uncommon
and rare herbs) and made in a manner similar to Herbal
Remedies and Potions, and they grant the imbiber a spelllike or magic-like ability. However, Herbal Elixirs do not last
as long as potions.
Herbal elixirs will cost 1 gp per dose unless the elixir’s
description says otherwise. The effects of a given elixir will
last for 10 + 1d10 minutes. A character may only be under
the effects of 1 Herbal Elixir or Potion at a time.
Charm: The drinker’s gaze acts as a Charm Person spell
against a single target within 20’ of the drinker. This
ability must be used within the duration of the elixir
or it is lost. The target is allowed a Will Save against
the level of the person who drank the Elixir to resist
the effect. If the target is charmed, the effect will last
for 30 minutes.

Cure Apathy: Relieves the drinker of any apathy that he is
inflicted with.
Cure Blindness: Restores vision to normal. This will even
heal eyes that have been damaged.
Cure Disease: Rids the body of any one disease. It does
not heal any damage done by the disease, but it does
prevent any further damage.
Cure Paralysis: Antidote for any sort of paralysis.
Heal Burns: This salve heals 2d10 Hits of damage from
burns or fire when applied. Healing takes place over
the course of 10 minutes.
Healing: Immediately heals 1d10 Hits of damage or stops
1 point of Bleeding or removes one -1 modifier from
Pain, when drank.
Insect Venom Antidote: Immediately heals all damage from
insect or spider venom, including the venom from
giant insects and spiders. It also stops the venom from
inflicting any further damage. This does not prevent
another dose of venom from affecting the target.
Poison Antidote: Acts as Insect Venom Antidote, but works
against any poison or venom. Cost: 5 gp
Remove Curse: Negates any curse or malediction that had
a level of 5 or less.
Remove Fear: Removes any magically or non-magically
caused fear. This lasts for 1 hour. If the cause of the
fear is still present, the fear will return.
Restore Speech: Restores the drinker’s normal vocal abilities.
Sedative: Induces a restful sleep within 1-4 minutes of
being drunk. If taken along with any healing remedy,
elixir, or potion, it doubles the effectiveness of the
healing. If the drinker is awoken before the sedative
wears off in 8 hours, he will be groggy and unsteady
(-4 to all Actions).
283

Detect Illusion: All illusions within a 20’ radius will be
outlined in a shimmering glow that the drinker will
be able to see.
Detect Invisibility: For the duration, the drinker will see
invisible beings, spirits, or creatures as if they were
only translucent.
Dexterity: The drinker gains a +2 bonus to his Dexterity.
Divination: This allows the drinker to divine the answer to
any single question of a simple nature. This can be a
“yes” or “no” question, or one that requires choosing one
of a few options (i.e. which path is the safest route to our
destination). The GM should be aware of the wording
of the question, as “best” should always be interpreted as
shortest or quickest or most likely option.
Elixir of Protection: These elixirs work by preventing the
creature or effect that its wards against from getting within
1’ radius of the protected individual. Some examples of
what can be protected against are as follows:
•• Demons
•• Devils
•• Disease
•• Evil – This is defined as those wishing to do harm to
others for the purpose of personal gain.
•• Fire
•• Lightning
•• Lycanthropes
•• Magical Influence
•• Spirits
•• Vampires
•• Wolves

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Elixirs of Resistance: These grant the drinker either a +2
or +4 modifier to any Save vs. the effect type that
is warded against. The more specific the ward, the
better it is for the drinker. Specific Resistances get +4
to Saves against, while more general get only a +2.
Here are a few examples:
•• Curses (+2)
•• Disease (+2)
•• Magic (+2)
•• Mummy Rot (+4)
•• Poison (+2)
•• Snake Venom (+4)
•• Wizardry (+4)
Flight: The drinker is able to fly with a Base Movement rate
of 20’ per Round.

Potions

Lockpicking: The character whose drinks this potion gains
a +2 to all lockpicking attempts, even if he has no skill
ranks in Gimmickry.

These are fluid mixtures that grant the drinker magical
or spell-like abilities. Potions last for 40 + 2d10 minutes
unless the description says otherwise. The exception to this
are Healing potions, their effects are permanent since they
are only restoring the body to its normal, healthy state, so
they don’t have an actual duration. A character may only be
under the effects of 1 Herbal Elixir or Potion at a time.
Potions normally cost 5 gp per dose unless the description
says otherwise. Sometimes, the alchemist who creates the
potion may be willing to trade it in exchange for ingredients
to make another, more esoteric potion.
For some potions, the drinker is able to use the effect of
the potion against others. Depending on the type of Potion,
the target may get a Save against the level of the drinker of
the Potion.
Aquatic Potion: Drinker is able to breathe underwater and
is able swim at double his normal movement rate.
Cost: 75 sp

Luck: This gives the player a +10 bonus to any single roll
(player’s choice) that is required for his character
within the duration of the elixir.

Charisma: Drinker’s Charisma stat is raised 10 points
for the duration. This may allow him to exceed his
normal Kindred maximums.

Reflexes: The drinker gains a +2 bonus to his Reflex Saves.

Cure Insanity: Drinker is immediately cured of one form
of insanity.

Stamina: The drinker gains a +2 bonus to his Stamina.

Speed: The drinker gains a +5’ to his Movement Rate and
+2 bonus to any Initiative rolls.
Strength: The drinker gains a +2 bonus to his Brawn.
Trap Finding: Any traps within 20’ will have an orange
glow to the drinker.
Truth: The drinker of this elixir will be unable to tell a lie,
refuse to answer, or answer any questions except with
the full and complete truth.

Cursed/Reversed Potions: These potions detect as and are
identified as if they were a beneficial potion of some
type. When drank, the potion has the opposite effect
as what it seemed to be. For example, a Cursed Potion
of Longevity would age the drinker 10 years. If the
Potion is actually cursed, as opposed to just reversed,
the effects last until the curse is removed.
Darkvision: Drinker gains Dark Sight out to 30’ for the
duration.
Detect Danger: This allows the drinker to know if anything
within a 100’ radius can and/or will hurt or is a danger
to him (within the next 5 rounds). The drinker will
know the general direction and distance of the danger,
but not its exact nature. For example, the drinker
approaches a trapped door. As he approaches, he will
sense a mild warning. If he decides to attempt to open
the door, his sense of impending danger will increase
dramatically. Against sentient beings, this only warns
the drinker if those beings specifically intend to harm
the drinker (just being armed will not se this off).
Detect Invisibility: For the duration, all invisible beings
or items are outlined in a faint, but easily discernible
blue glow.
Detect Magic: For the duration, all magical items or items
that have active spells on them are outlined in a faint,
but easily discernible blue glow.

284

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Emotional Influence: Drinker is able to invoke an
emotional response of sympathy, antipathy, apathy,
anger, happiness, etc. in up to 10 individuals within
a 20’ radius. Each person gets to make a Will Save
against this manipulation.
ESP: Drinker is able to read the thoughts of any one target
within 20’ radius. The target gets to make a Will Save
against this.
Free Action: Drinker is able to move as his normal speed
through mud, water, or any form of entanglement,
including magical forms.
Flying: The drinker is able to fly at a speed equal to double
their normal movement rate. One Mile per Hour is
equal to 7’ in a Round.
Gaseous Form: The drinker is able to transform his natural
form, including all equipment carried, from normal into
a gaseous form. The gaseous form is the same color(s) as
the character was before the change and it can move at
a rate of 5’ per Round. It takes one full round to make
the transformation from gaseous to solid. The drinker
may change forms only once every 5 minutes, and he will
return to solid form at the end of the duration.
Growth: Drinker grows to double his normal size. This
increases his weight by x8. The drinker gains a +3
modifier to their Brawn stat, a -2 modifier to their DM,
and their movement rate is doubled for the duration.
Haste: Drinker gains an extra Half Action for each of 3
rounds. The drinker may start those 3 rounds at any
time within the duration of the potion, but once
started, all 3 rounds must be taken all at once.
Heal Light Wounds: Drinker is immediately healed, over the
course of 1 round of one Light Wound’s worth of damage
(up to 3 Bleed, up to a -6 to actions, and 1/4 of their Hits).
This also includes any specific minor damage, such as 1st
degree burns or frostbite, as well as other minor damage.
Heal Moderate Wounds: Drinker is immediately healed, over
the course of 1 round of one Light Wound’s worth of
damage (up to 6 Bleed, up to a -12 to actions, and 1/2 of
their Hits). This also includes any specific minor damage,
such as 2nd degree burns or frostbite, as well as other
moderate damage. Cost: 75 sp
Heal Severe Wounds: Drinker is immediately healed, over the
course of 1 round of one Light Wound’s worth of damage
(up to 9 Bleed, up to a -18 to actions, and all of their Hits).
This also includes any specific minor damage, such as 3rd
degree burns or frostbite, as well as other severe damage.
Cost: 10 gp
Healing True: Drinker is immediately healed, over the
course of a single round, of all damage. Cost: 15 gp
Heroism: Character’s Brawn, Resolve, Dexterity and Stamina
are increased to their Kindred maximums (6 +/Kindred modifiers) for the duration.

285

Jumping: Character is able to jump up to 50’ horizontally
or 30’ vertically. He may only make one jump, but it
can be made at any time within the duration.
Longevity: Drinker’s age is permanently reduced by 10
years. This effectively increases his lifespan by the
same amount. Cost: 15 gp
Magic Resistance: Drinker gains a +4 modifier to all Saves
against magical effects and spells for the duration.
Nightvision: Drinker is granted Nightvision, as per the
Talent description for the duration.
Ogre Strength: Temporarily increases the drinker’s Brawn
by +6 for the duration. This may allow the drinker to
temporarily exceed his Kindred maximum for that stat.
Potion of Control: This powerful potion gives the drinker
the ability to “charm” or control up to 5 creatures or
beings of any single type. If they fail their Will Saves, the
controlled creatures will follow the drinker’s commands
and serve him until the duration expires and then they
will be very “hostile” towards their former “master”.
Note: One of the ingredients that this potion requires is
a portion of the same type of creature that it will control.
For example, a potion of Dragon Control requires
Dragon blood; a potion of Ogre Control might require
some hair or ground up bones from an Ogre, etc. This
makes alchemists always interested in bits of creatures.
Protection from Evil: Drinker is protected against attacks
from summoned or evoked creatures and beings
from the Abyss or the Nine Hells.
Regeneration: Drinker regenerates 1 hit per round for
the duration. Also, any lost limbs or organs will
be restored over the course of 10 to 30 minutes,
depending upon the severity.
Shrinking: Drinker shrinks to one half his normal height
and his weight is 1/8 normal. He receives a -3
modifier to his Brawn stat and +2 modifier to his
DM. Drinker’s normal movement rate is also halved
(rounded up) for the duration.
Speed: Temporarily increases the drinker’s reaction time
stat by 5 points (+5 to Initiative).
Spider Climb: Drinker is able to cling to walls and ceilings
for the duration. Movement rate is one half of their
normal movement rate.
Stealth: Drinker gains a bonus of 5 + 1d10 to their Stealth skill.
Stone to Flesh: This potion is poured over a person who
has been turned to stone. It will restore them to their
normal flesh.
Traceless Passing: Drinker is able to pass through any terrain
without leaving any sign or trace of their passage.
Water Breathing: Drinker is able to breathe water or air
for the duration.

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Magical Weapons & Armors

Some magical weapons and armors may also be made
partially of Orichalcum or other magical materials, which
may provide some of the item’s magical bonuses. The
following list of examples provides the total bonuses of the
items, and the costs include any costs for magical materials
(rounded up) added in.
Bracers of Defense: This is a set of Reinforced Leather
Bracers, DM +2, AR: B2/S2/P2/E2/SL0. (AP: 18
Cost: 270 gp)
Bracers of Defense: Metal bracers, DM +3, AR: B3/S3/P3/
E3/SL0 (AP: 27 Cost: 405 gp)
Dagger of Returning: Orichalcum dagger (AB+1,
6s/7p). It teleports back to the thrower’s hand at the
beginning of the round after it was thrown. (AP: 19
Cost: 287 gp)
Dancing Sword: This is a magical broadsword that will
float and fight of its own volition when drawn and
thrown into the air. A Dancing Sword will fight for
up to a maximum 2 rounds for every point of the
wielder’s Resolve each day, and the rounds need not
be consecutive. It has the same attack bonus as the
wielder, and it may only attack once per round. (AP:
19 Cost: 285 gp)
Dragonscale Armor: Full suit, including half helm, bracers,
and greaves, of reinforced leather armor made from
the hide and scales of a dragon. Even though it is
reinforced leather and encumbers as such (Move
Penalty -5, Dex Mod -1, AB Pen -1, Per Pen -1), it
provides protection much like full plate (AR: B16/
S20/P14/E10/SL2). The wearer of such a suit is also
completely immune to the breath weapon of Dragons
of the same type that the armor was made from. The
wearer must wear the full suit to gain any benefits.
However, any Dragon seeing a person wearing such
a suit of armor would likely be so enraged that he
would attack that person without mercy. (AP: 48
Cost: 720 gp)

286

Firebow: Longbow that causes any arrows fired from it
to burst into flame doing an additional +4 Hits of
damage and all of the damage is considered to be Fire
damage. (AP: 27 Cost: 405 gp)
Frostbow: Longbow that causes any arrows fired from
transform into ice doing an additional +4 damage
and all of the damage is considered to be Cold
damage. (AP 27 Cost: 405 gp)
Holy Sword: This Long Sword has +2 accuracy and deals
double damage to Demons, Devils, and Undead. The
double damage applies only when the Holy Sword
is wielded by Clerics or Paladins of “good” deities.
In the hands of all others, it is simply a sword with
a +2 modifier to the wielder’s attack bonus. (AP: 25
Cost: 375 gp)
Shield of Belnos: This 2’ diameter Round Shield of
polished steel was made to honor Belnos, the god
of the Sun. It is a normal shield with a +2 magical
bonus (total of +4 to DM). Its face is inscribed with a
stylized sun symbol. If the wielder of the shield holds
it forth towards a Demon, Devil, or Undead creature,
as if he were brandishing a Holy Symbol, the creature
must make a Save as if the shield actually were a Holy
Symbol. (AP: 25 Cost: 375 gp)

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Staves, Rods & Wands

Spell users are renowned for utilizing wands, rods, and
staves as magical items and as an aid in casting their spells.
Therefore, a listing of magical items would not be complete
without them. When using or activating one of these
devices, the wielder will use his Magecraft skill bonus if a
roll is required.
Arcane Bolt Wand: This thin wand of ornately carved
oak with a translucent crystal attached to its tip fires
an Arcane Bolt (Rng 50’, 6b, 1 charge), a bolt of pure
force that does bashing damage. It has 15 charges.
The charges automatically replenish with the rising
of the sun each day. (AP: 17 Cost: 255 gp)

Amulets, Rings, & Jewelry

Jewelry has always been a favorite medium for imbedding
magical abilities, specifically amulets and rings, but any type
of jewelry can easily be used.
Here is a short list of examples that also include the cost
breakdowns:
Amulet of Protection: This small amulet is formed of a single
strand of a golden alloy that is worked into an intricate
knot. This amulet provides a +2 modifier to all Saves
that the character has to roll. (AP 16 Cost: 240 gp)

Fire Staff: This quarterstaff is made from a reddish wood
that is covered with sigils that are seemingly burned
into it. It functions as a normal quarterstaff. It also
has 10 charges that recover 1 charge for each hour
that it is not used. With this staff, the wielder may use
the following 3 abilities. (AP: 35 Cost: 525 gp)
Torchlight: For a single charge will ignite the end of the staff,
providing light in a 20’ radius, just like a torch. This does
not consume the staff. This will last for 10 minutes. While
the torchlight is active, any attacks made with that end
of the staff will deal an additional 6 Hits of Fire damage
on top of the normal damage (these six Hits are applied
against AR separately from the normal damage).
Firebolt: For 1 charge, the wielder may shoot a firebolt (6eh,
Rng 50’) from the end of the staff. Each additional charge
put into the firebolt increases the damage by 2 points.
Firecaster: Whomever wields the staff also gains a constant
+2 bonus to any fire-based spells that they cast.
Rod of Smiting: This is a small metal rod with a steel ball
attached to one end. It strikes as a Mace (AB +3, 12b).
For the cost of 1 charge, the Rod can shoot a metal
shard (10p, Rng 65’) from the round ball on the end.
For 1 charge, the wielder is coated in a thin sheen of
metal, granting him DM +2 and AR (B2/S2/P2/E2/
SL0) . The Rod of Smiting has 30 charges and may be
recharged using the Arcana or Alkemics skills. (AP: 60
Cost: 900 gp)
Wand of Casting: This slender, plain wand of ash wood
grants a +3 bonus to all spellcasting. When found, a
spell user may, after possessing the wand for 24 hours,
cast any one known spell of level 3 or less, into the
Wand and the caster will then be able to use the wand
to cast that spell for free up to 3 times a day. This spell
only works for the caster who puts it into the wand. If
the wand is out of the possession of the caster for more
than 24 hours, the wand loses that spell, and it must be
cast into the wand again. (AP: 29 Cost: 435 gp)

287

Amulet of Trap Detection: This small amulet allows the
wearer to magically search for traps up to 3 times a
day. When activated, all traps within the wearer’s field
of vision, for the next ten minutes, will be surrounded
with a light blue glow that is visible only to him. (AP:
21 Cost: 315 gp)
Diadem of Sight: This is a slim silver headband with a
diamond mounted in the center of the wearer’s
forehead. The wearer is able to activate the magic of
the diadem up to 3 times per day. When activated, the
wearer is able to see a full 360 degrees around himself
in all directions at once. This also grants a +5 modifier
to all Perception rolls, and the character cannot be
surprised. This lasts for 10 minutes before wearing off.
If the ability is activated more than once in any given
hour, the wearer must make a Toughness Save versus his
own level or he will go blind from the strain placed on
his eyes. This blindness lasts one day for each point that
the Save is failed by. (AP: 43 Cost: 645 gp)
Headband of the Mystic: This thin band of silver protects
the wearer as if it were a plate helm. However, it has
no negative modifiers. (AP: 22 Cost: 330 gp)
Mask of the Many: This is a pale white mask that covers
the entire face. Upon activation, the mask will make
the wearer appear as somebody else entirely, as the
wearer desires. The illusionary facade that the Mask
produces may only be detected by spell, or by a
Heroic Perception roll. The mask will operate for up
to 24 hours, but once stopped, it cannot be used again
for an equal amount of time (i.e. if you use it for 6
hours, you must wait 6 hours before it can be used
again). (AP: 34 Cost: 510 gp)
Necklace of Protection from Spirits: This necklace
prevents spirits from approaching within 5’ of its
wearer. (AP 32 Cost: 480 gp)

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Ring of Spell Weaving: This is a heavy ring, silver in
color, etched with a knot-work design all around
the outer surface. This ring holds 50 charges that are
replenished at sunrise each day. The charges may be
used as Mana Points for the purpose of casting spells,
thus a third level spell would use 3 charges instead
and the caster would lose no Mana Points. (AP: 32
Cost: 480 gp)

Ring of Demon Summoning: This ornate silver ring
allows the wearer to summon a Demon once per day.
Rings of this type will vary in regards to the power
of the Demon that is summoned, but each ring only
summons one singular Demon of up to 5th level, and
always that Demon. The wearer does not have to use
a Summoning Circle as detailed on p. 140, but he
is still required to forge a pact with the summoned
demon as per normal. Once a pact has been sealed,
the Demon will serve the wearer faithfully for as long
as he has the ring. However, should the Demon ever
be slain upon the mortal plane, the ring will forever
lose its magic. (AP: 35 Cost: 525 gp)

Miscellaneous Magic Items
Ring of Devil Summoning: This ornate silver ring allows
the wearer to summon a Devil once per day. Rings of
this type will vary in regards to the power of the Devil
that is summoned, but each ring only summons one
singular Devil of up to 5th level, and always that
Devil. The wearer does not have to use a Summoning
Circle as detailed on p. 140, but he is still required
to forge a pact with the summoned demon as per
normal. Once a pact has been sealed, the Devil will
serve the wearer faithfully for as long as he has the
ring. However, should the Devil ever be slain upon
the mortal plane, the ring will forever lose its magic.
(AP: 35 Cost: 525 gp)
Ring of Flying: Allows the wearer to fly at a speed of 20’ as
a Base Move during a combat round, or up to speeds
of 100 miles per hour outside of combat. The flight
ability may be used for a total number of minutes
each day equal to five times the wearer’s Stamina plus
ten. These minutes of use need not be consecutive,
and each use will always use at least a full minute’s
worth of time. (AP: 25 Cost: 375 gp)

Almost anything can be made into a magical item. Here
is a selection of items that may appeal to both cloistered
magic users and adventurers alike.
Backpack of Holding: This normal looking backpack is
actually a portal to a small dimensional pocket. It
is capable of holding up to 2,000 lbs worth of gear,
with no volume restrictions, and never weighing
more than 1 lb for every 100 lbs placed within it. The
only restriction is that the items must fit within the
opening of backpack. The owner of the backpack
may pull out any item that he knows is in the pack
on the first try. If the owner attempts to put a living
creature in the pack, that creature will die within a
few minutes as the backpack does not contain any air
to breathe. Should the backpack ever be destroyed, all
items within it will be lost. (AP: 27 Cost: 405 gp)

288

Fantasy Express Copyright © 2023 by Tim Dugger and Firehawk Games. All rights reserved.

Bracers of the Spider: These are very powerful items.
This is a set of black leather bracers with silver
filigree that is reminiscent of a spider’s web. This
item has 20 charges and will recharge at a rate of 1
charge for every hour that the bracers are not used.
(AP: 42 Cost: 630 gp)
Charges may be spend for the following effects:
Spider-climb – Wearer is able to cling to walls and
ceilings for the duration. Movement rate is one
half of their normal movement rate. This lasts for
10 minutes.
Web Rope – Wearer can shoot forth a thick strand of
webbing that is up to 20’ in length for every charge
expended. The end of the strand is sticky and will
adhere to the surface that it is aimed at.
Web Grapple – Shoots forth a web that makes a
ranged grapple against a foe that is up to 50’ away.
Use the Ranged or Arcana skill for making this
attack. If successful, the foe is Held until they can
cut themselves free (takes 1 full round) or break
free using a Hard Athletics roll. Each additional
charge used in the Web Grapple increases the
difficulty by one step (i.e. 2 charges means that the
Web Grapple requires a Very Hard skill roll, etc).

Cloak of the Bat: This is dark leather cloak. The wearer may,
up to 3 times a day, transform the cloak into a set of
giant bat wings that allow him to fly at a rate of 20’ as a
Base Movement rate, or 100 miles per hour when not
in combat. The cloak will remain in wing form for up
to an hour each time. (AP: 35 Cost: 525 gp)
Cloak of Invisibility: When the wearer of this hooded
cloak draws the hood over his head, he is made
invisible to sight, sound, and scent. He will remain
invisible so long as he does not move faster than a
normal walk, attempt to attack somebody or attempt
to cast a spell. Attempting any of these actions will
immediately cause the hood to come off the wearer’s
head, rendering him visible (before the action is
completed). (AP: 28 Cost: 420 gp)

289

Crystal Ball: This is a 6-inch diameter, round chunk of clear
crystal set on a gold stand. If the wielder uses it as a
focus for any type of scrying spell, he may cast spells
on himself that expand his sensing capabilities beyond
normal or cast spells, which are not against DM, upon
the target of the scrying. The target still gets his Saves
against those spells and he also receives a +2 modifier
for all such Saves. (AP: 32 Cost: 480 gp)

Light Pouch: This stiff leather belt pouch is similar in
nature to a Backpack of Holding; however, it can only
hold up to 50 lbs while weighing 1 lb for every 10 lbs
within the pouch. Only items that can fit through the
3 inch by 5 inch opening may be placed within. If the
pouch is destroyed, all items within are lost. (AP: 27
Cost: 405 gp)

Lock Picks of Opening: This finely crafted set of lock picks
is enchanted with a +4 magical bonus (grants a +5
total bonus to Gimmickry rolls for opening locks).
(AP: 21 Cost: 315 gp)
Scrying Stone: This small, 1-inch diameter crystal allows
the wielder to be able to view any person or location
that he has actually seen or been to before. After each
use, the wielder must make a Will Save against his
own level or be blinded for 1-10 minutes. (AP: 19
Cost: 285 gp)

Combat Shuffle: You are able to move your foe and/or yourself 5’ in a specific direction for each SL spent on this. This also
1+
allows for changing Engagement Distance without a RSR, if desired.
1 Defensive Posture: Your attack leaves you in a better position. Gain +2 to your DM next round.
Disarm Foe: Foe has to make a TSR or RSR (whichever is better) against your level or his weapon goes flying 1’-10’ in a random
1
direction. This is not the same as the Martial Move, Disarm. This is a side effect of the attack.
Hold
Foe: Foe must make a RSR (or a TSR using Brawn as the stat, whichever is better) against your level or be Held.
1
1+ Initiative Boost: You gain +2 to your initiative in the next round for each SL spent on this.
Knock Prone: Foe must make a RSR against your level (bash, grapple, or martial arts attacks only) or be knocked Prone. This is
1
not the same as the Martial Move, Knock Down. This is a side effect of the attack.
1 Rapid Reload: You may immediately reload your bow or slingshot as an extra Free Action for the Round.
Attack Boost: You gain a +1 modifier to your Attack Bonus in the next round for each SL spent on this (i.e. spending 3 SL gives a
2+
+3 bonus). Requires spending a minimum of 2 SL.
2 Improved Hold: Foe is Held, no Save allowed this round, but they may attempt to escape starting on the following round.
Inspiring Attack: Your move so inspires your friends that they all gain +1 to initiative in the next round for each SL spent on
2+
this. Requires spending a minimum of 2 SL.
Lightning Strike: You may make a second attack against the same or a different foe (within range) with a -4 modifier. If you are
2
using a ranged weapon, you must have a loaded missile weapon in hand (this option may be used with Rapid Reload above).
2 Pierce Armor: You find a chink in your enemy’s armor. His Armor Rating is halved (rounded down) against this attack.
Advantageous Attack: Your attack leaves foe in an awkward and exposed position. This allows you to attack him from On Rear (+6 AB,
3
no shield bonus to DM for foe) in the next round. This also allows other position-based attacks, such as Backstab, to be used in combat.
Disarm Foe II: Foe has been Disarmed. His weapon goes flying 1’-10’ in a random direction, no Save allowed. This is not the
3
same as the Martial Move, Disarm. This is a side effect of the attack.
Double Shot: You may select an additional target within 30’ of your original target who is on the same line of attack. If the attack is
a Piercing attack, the first of the two targets gets a slashing attack, rather than piercing (i.e. the attack sliced the first target before
3
embedding in the second). Only a single roll is used, full result against first target, result -4 against the second.
3 Incapacitated: Foe makes a Save versus the number of ranks in your Combat Skill or they are knocked out.
3 Knocked Prone: Foe is knocked Prone. No Save allowed.
3 Multiple Strikes: Your attack roll may be used to strike an adjacent foe within reach of your melee wepaon, using the original roll at -2.
3 Pierce Armor II: Foe’s Armor Rating is one quarter normal (rounded down) against this attack.
Ricochet: Your ranged attack that does bashing damage strikes the first target normally, and then strikes a second target within 10’
3
of the first one. The attack on the second target uses the same roll as the first with a -4 modifier.
Deadly Strike: Foe must make a TSR against your Level. Success means that they are incapacitated. Failure means that foe dies in 10
4
rounds, minus the number of points that they Failed the Save by.
4 Knocked Out: Foe is totally incapacitated (knocked out). No Save Roll.
4 Pierce Armor True: You completely ignore foe’s Armor Rating for this attack.
5 Death Strike: Foe must make TSR against your Level or immediately die. If foe makes the Save, he is incapacitated for 24 hours.
6 Instant Death: Foe is killed instantly. No Saving Roll allowed.
* = This is the base SL cost. This cost may be increased based on the SL rating of armor being worn by the target of the attack.
+ = May spend multiple Success Levels on this option to gain the effect multiple times.

SLs Success Level Effects

Attack Advantage: Gain a +1 modifier to the caster’s attack
roll for this spell.
Harder Save: Increase the negative modifier applied to the
1+
Save Roll by 1.
Increased Targets: Spell affects 1 extra target more than
1+
normal.
Increased Range: The range of the spell is increased by 1
2+ increment. A range of Self can be increased to Touch, and
a range of Touch can be increased to 10’.
Increased Duration: The duration of the spell is increased
2+
by 1 increment. May not be used on spells with no duration.
Increased Radius: The radius of the spell is increased by 1
2+ increment. May not be used on spells that do not have an
effect with a radius.
Increased Distance: Some spells have an effect that
2+ includes a specific distance (i.e. moves point of sight 10’).
This increases that type of effect by 1 increment.
Increase Numerical Effect: When used on any spell whose
2+ non-damaging effect is measured by a number, that effect
is increased by one increment.
+ = Each Success Level beyond the intitial amount required adds
another instance of the Boon to the spell.
Increment = A number of the options refer to “increment”. An
increment is considered to be what is normal for the the
spell as it was cast (i.e. a range of 10’ means the increment
is 10’, but another spell with a range of 50’ would have an
increment of 50’; a Duration of 1 round per rank would
become 2 rounds per rank; etc.). Increment never applies to
the damage a spell attack might do.

Character learns an extra bit of relevant information that
he was not expecting.
Player gains a +2 bonus on the character’s next attempt at a
1*
task related to this one.
Result of skill use is increased by 10%, if possible. May be
1+ taken multiple times, but cannot increase result by more
than 50%.
Saves against the skill just used reecive a -2 modifier. This
1
does not apply against Conflicting Actions.
Task was performed more quietly than expected. Character
1* gains a +2 bonus to any rolls to which a quiet result of this
task will be of benefit.
The task was performed quicker than expected. Each SL
1+ spent reduces the amount of time required by 10%. May
not reduce required time by more than 50%.
Character gains or remembers information that can aid in
2 resolving the adventure (i.e. the Dragon’s cave has a back
entrance, but not where).
Character is so pumped from his success that the he gains a +4
2*
on his next die roll, regardless of its purpose.
Stunning Success: Onlookers are in awe of your skill, and
2
are literally stunned 1 round.
Character gains a +2 modifier to all future attempts to use
3* this skill, until the first time he earns a Critical Failure for
its use, then the modifier disappears.
Character gains or remembers information that can greatly
3 aid in resolving the adventure (i.e. you know where the
back entrance to the Dragon’s cave is).
Character is so pumped from his success that he gains a +2
3*
to all of his rolls for 24 hours.
Character and all allies receive a +3 modifier to their next
4
roll. It need not be related to the task that generated this.
Inspiring Success: Character and all allies within 50’ gain
5 a +4 bonus on their next roll. It need not be related to the
task that generated this.
* = only one of these bonuses may apply at any given time.
+ = May spend multiple Success Levels on this option to gain the
effect multiple times.

FX

ANTASY
E PRESS

SYSTEM BASICS

• 2d10 open-ended mechanic
• Universal Mechanic using the Fantasy Express
Action/Task (FEAT) table
• Five basic levels of success that allow you to
gauge how well you have succeeded at a task
• Success Level options that allow you, the
player, to determine what results you receive
beyond simple success or failure
• Critical Results in combat are chosen by the
player, based on how many Success Levels are
earned in your attack
• 250 Base Spells, spread across 8 Schools of
Magic, with almost 900 unique Scaling Options,
allowing for thousands of possibilities!
• 10 Kins to provide you with a range of role
playing possibilities
• 15 Cultures that are generic enough to
provide for wide variation between characters
who have the same basic region or location
• 32 Vocational Kits that allow for up to 528
potential combinations for you to use to design
your character — these Vocational Kits provide
both ranks in starting skills and Development
Points for building your character

FIREHAWK GAMES

• 42 core skills spread across 9 Skill Categories,
an additional 34 Special Skills that are used
to enhance those core skills
• 149 Background Options — 60 specific Gifts
with 2 entries for each (120 total options) and 35
Drawbacks to help make your character unique
• Passions & Drive to help your character be
successful in all their endeavors and once you
spend enough Drive enhance your character
in other ways.
• 165+ Creatures against which characters can
test themselves
• Rules for magical item creation
• Rules for finding and using magical herbs

ANWYN, THE SUNDERED ISLE
Anwyn is a small continent that sits in its
own little pocket dimension. It has ties and
connections to many different worlds, meaning
that you could find almost anything or anybody
on Anwyn. It has only been settled, this time, for
530 years, meaning that there is lots to explore
and discover.
